book.name: Genesis
book.info: Moses, the author of the five books of the Law ([link]Deut. 31:9[/link], [link]24[/link]; [link]Luke 24:27[/link], [link]44[/link]; [link]John 1:45[/link]; [link]5:46[/link]; [link]Acts 28:23[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 3:15[/link]).
Probably about 1490 B.C., when Exodus was written (see introductory material in Exodus).
In the wilderness east of Egypt.
From the beginning of creation ([link]1:1[/link]) until approximately 1635 B.C., the death of Joseph ([link]50:26[/link]).
book.subject: God Created, Satan Corrupted, Man Fell, and Jehovah Promised to Save

verse.text: [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]In the [note]2[/note]beginning [note]3[/note]God [note]4[/note][xref]b[/xref]created the [note]5[/note]heavens and the earth.
verse.note: The Bible, composed of two testaments, the Old Testament and the New Testament, is the complete written divine revelation of God to man. The major revelation in the entire Bible is the unique divine economy of the unique Triune God ([link]Eph. 1:10[/link]; [link]3:9[/link]; [link]1 Tim. 1:4b[/link]). The centrality and universality of this divine economy is the all-inclusive and unsearchably rich Christ as the embodiment and expression of the Triune God ([link]Col. 2:9[/link]; [link]1:15-19[/link]; [link]John 1:18[/link]). The goal of the divine economy is the church as the Body, the fullness, the expression, of Christ ([link]Eph. 1:22b-23[/link]; [link]3:8-11[/link]), which will consummate in the New Jerusalem as the union, mingling, and incorporation of the processed and consummated Triune God and His redeemed, regenerated, transformed, and glorified tripartite people. The accomplishing of the divine economy is revealed in the Bible progressively in many steps, beginning with God's creation in [link]Gen. 1-2[/link] and consummating with the New Jerusalem in [link]Rev. 21-22[/link]. In the Old Testament the contents of God's economy are revealed mainly in types, figures, and shadows, whereas in the New Testament all the types, figures, and shadows are fulfilled and realized. Thus, the Old Testament is a figurative portrait of God's eternal economy, and the New Testament is the practical fulfillment.[br][br][i]Genesis,[/i] adopted by the Septuagint as the title of this book, is a Latin word meaning [i]giving of birth, origin.[/i] As the first book in the Bible, Genesis gives birth to and is the origin of the divine truths in the holy Word. Thus, the seeds of the divine truths are sown in this book. These seeds grow and develop in the succeeding books, especially in the New Testament, and are finally harvested in the last book, the book of Revelation.[br][br]The book of Genesis is a miniature of the complete revelation of the entire Bible. It begins with a man created in God's image ([link]1:26[/link]) and ends with a man called Israel ([link]32:28[/link]; [link]48:2[/link]), a transformed person, a man not only outwardly in the image of God but a man in whom God has wrought Himself, making him His expression. The transformed Israel is a seed, a miniature, of the New Jerusalem.[br][br]Apparently, [link book="Gen."]chs. 1-2[/link] of Genesis are merely a record of creation; actually, nearly every item in the record of these two chapters is a revelation of Christ, who is life to God's people ([link]John 1:1[/link], [link]4[/link]; [link]11:25[/link]; [link]14:6[/link]) for the producing and building up of the church. Chapters 3-50 present biographies of eight great persons in two groups of four, representing two races of men: Adam, Abel, Enoch, and Noah, representing the created race, and Abraham, Isaac, Jacob, and Joseph, representing the called race. What is recorded is not primarily the works of these men but mainly their life, their living, and their way with God. In Genesis God uses both the record of creation and the biographies of eight persons to reveal the life that fulfills His purpose.

Referring to the beginning of time (cf. [link]John 1:1[/link]). Time began at the creation of the universe and continues until the final judgment at the great white throne ([link]Rev. 20:11-15[/link]). Time is for the accomplishing of God's eternal purpose, which God made in eternity past ([link]Eph. 3:11[/link]) for eternity future.

Heb. [i]Elohim,[/i] meaning [i]the Mighty One.[/i] The Hebrew name here is plural, but the verb [i]created[/i] is singular. Furthermore, in [link]v. 26[/link] the plural pronouns [i]Us[/i] and [i]Our[/i] are used in reference to God, whereas in [link]v. 27[/link] the pronouns [i]He[/i] and [i]His[/i] are used. These are seeds of the Trinity. God is one ([link]Isa. 45:5[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 8:4[/link]; [link]1 Tim. 2:5[/link]), but He is also three — the Father, the Son, and the Spirit ([link]Matt. 28:19[/link]). He is the Triune God. It was the Triune God who created. See note [link]14[sup]1[/sup], par. 3, in 2 Cor. 13[/link].[br][br]Genesis is divided into three sections, each beginning with a name. The first section ([link]1:1-2:25[/link]), beginning with the name [i]God,[/i] concerns God's creation; the second ([link]3:1-11:32[/link]), beginning with [i]the serpent,[/i] covers the serpent's corrupting of mankind; and the third ([link]12:1-50:26[/link]), beginning with the name [i]Jehovah,[/i] concerns Jehovah's calling of fallen man.

[i]Created[/i] here, denoting to bring something into existence out of nothing, differs from [i]made[/i] in [link]2:4[/link] and [i]formed[/i] in [link]2:7[/link], the latter two denoting to take something that already exists and use it to produce something else.[br][br]The motive of God's creation was to fulfill God's desire and to satisfy His good pleasure ([link]Eph. 1:5[/link], [link]9[/link]). The purpose of God's creation is to glorify the Son of God ([link]Col. 1:15-19[/link]) and to manifest God Himself ([link]Psa. 19:1-2[/link]; [link]Rom. 1:20[/link] and notes 1 and 2), especially in man ([link]1 Tim. 3:16[/link]) through His Son, Christ, who is the embodiment of God and the image, the expression, of God ([link]Col. 2:9[/link]; [link]1:15[/link]). The basis of God's creation is God's will and plan ([link]Eph. 1:10[/link] and note 1; [link]Rev. 4:11[/link] and note 2). The means of God's creation were the Son of God ([link]Col. 1:15-16[/link]; [link]Heb. 1:2b[/link]) and the Word of God ([link]Heb. 11:3[/link]; [link]John 1:1-3[/link]), both of whom are Christ ([link]John 1:1[/link], [link]18[/link]; [link]Rev. 19:13[/link]).

In the process of God's creation, the heavens and the angels therein were created first, and the earth, probably with some living creatures, was created second ([link]Job 38:4-7[/link] and note [link]7[sup]1[/sup][/link]).

verse.text: [note]1[/note]But the earth became [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]waste and emptiness, and [note]2[/note]darkness was on the surface of the [note]3[/note]deep,[separator][note]4[/note]and the [note]5[/note][xref]b[/xref]Spirit of God was brooding upon the surface of the waters.
verse.note: God created the earth in a good order ([link]Job 38:4-7[/link]; [link]Isa. 45:18[/link]). [i]But[/i] here and [i]became[/i] later in this verse indicate that something happened to cause God's creation to become "waste and emptiness." This cataclysmic event was God's judgment on the preadamic universe following Satan's rebellion. This judgment was executed on Satan, on the angels and the preadamic creatures living on the earth who joined Satan in his rebellion, and on the heavens and the earth themselves. See [link]Isa. 14:12-15[/link] and notes; [link]Ezek. 28:12-19[/link] and notes.

Whenever the words [i]waste[/i] and [i]emptiness[/i] are used together in the Old Testament, they denote a result of God's judgment (cf. [link]Jer. 4:23[/link]; [link]Isa. 24:1[/link]; [link]34:11[/link]). The darkness on the surface of the deep also is a sign of God's judgment (cf. [link]Exo. 10:21-22[/link]; [link]Rev. 16:10[/link]).

I.e., the deep water. In the Bible water symbolizes either life ([link]John 4:10[/link], [link]14[/link]; [link]7:38[/link]; [link]Rev. 22:1[/link]) or death ([link]7:17-24[/link]; [link]Exo. 14:21-30[/link]; [link]John 3:5[/link]; [link]Rom. 6:3[/link]). The water here signifies death. As a result of God's judgment on the preadamic universe, the entire earth was covered with deep water, signifying that the earth was filled with death and was under death. See notes [link]23[sup]1[/sup] in Mark 1[/link], [link]1[sup]6[/sup] in 1 Tim. 4[/link], and [link]1[sup]3[/sup] in Rev. 21[/link].

[link]Verse 1[/link] is a record of God's original creation. [link]Verse 2a[/link] refers to God's judgment on the preadamic universe. The entire section from 1:2b-2:3 refers not to God's original creation but to God's restoration of the damaged universe, plus His further creation, in six days.

Heb. [i]ruach,[/i] variously translated [i]spirit, wind, breath.[/i] This is the first mentioning of the Spirit in the Bible. The Spirit of God, as the Spirit of life ([link]Rom. 8:2[/link]), came to brood over the waters of death in order to generate life, especially man ([link]v. 26[/link]), for God's purpose. In spiritual experience, the Spirit's coming is the first requirement for generating life ([link]John 6:63a[/link]).

verse.text: And God [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]said, Let there be [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]light; and there was light.
verse.note: After the Spirit's brooding ([link]v. 2b[/link]), the word of God came to bring in the light (cf. [link]Psa. 119:105[/link], [link]130[/link]). In spiritual experience, the coming of the word is the second requirement for generating life ([link]John 5:24[/link]; [link]6:63b[/link]), and the coming of the light is the third requirement ([link]Matt. 4:13-16[/link]; [link]John 1:1-13[/link]).[br][br]The Spirit, the word, and the light were the instruments used by God to generate life for the fulfillment of His purpose. The Spirit, the word, and the light are all of life ([link]Rom. 8:2[/link]; [link]Phil. 2:16[/link]; [link]John 8:12b[/link]). Christ as the Spirit is the reality of God ([link]Rom. 8:9-10[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 3:17[/link]; [link]John 16:13-15[/link]); Christ as the Word is the speaking of God ([link]John 1:1[/link]; [link]Heb. 1:2[/link]); and Christ as the light is the shining of God ([link]John 8:12a[/link]; [link]9:5[/link]).

verse.text: And God saw that the light was [xref]a[/xref]good, and God [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]separated the light from the darkness.
verse.note: The separation of the light from the darkness for the purpose of discerning day from night ([link]v. 5[/link]; cf. [link]2 Cor. 6:14b[/link]) is the fourth requirement for generating life.

verse.text: And God called the light [xref]a[/xref]Day, and the darkness He called Night. And [xref]b[/xref]there was evening and there was morning, one day.
And God [xref]a[/xref]said, Let there be an [note]1[/note]expanse in the midst of the waters, and let it [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]separate the waters from the waters.
verse.note: The atmosphere, the air surrounding the earth.

The separating of the waters by producing an expanse between them, signifying, spiritually, the dividing of the heavenly things from the earthly things through the work of the cross ([link]Col. 3:1-3[/link]; [link]Heb. 4:12[/link]), was the fifth requirement for generating life.

verse.text: And God made the expanse and separated the waters which were under the expanse from the [xref]a[/xref]waters which were above the expanse, and it was so.
And God called the expanse Heaven. And [xref]a[/xref]there was evening and there was morning, a second day.[note]1[/note]
verse.note: At the end of the second day there is no record that God said that the expanse (the air) and the waters were good (cf. [link]vv. 4[/link], [link]10[/link], [link]12[/link], [link]18[/link], [link]21[/link], [link]25[/link]). This is because in the air there are fallen angels ([link]Eph. 2:2[/link]; [link]6:12[/link]), and the water is the dwelling place of the demons ([link]Matt. 12:43[/link] and note).

verse.text: And God [xref]a[/xref]said, Let the waters under the heavens be [xref]b[/xref]gathered together into one place, and let the [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]dry land appear; and it was so.
verse.note: The appearing of the dry land is the sixth requirement for generating life. This took place on the third day, corresponding to the day of resurrection ([link]1 Cor. 15:4[/link]). In the Bible the sea represents death and the land represents Christ (see note [link]7[sup]1[/sup] in Deut. 8[/link]) as the generating source of life. After the land appeared, every kind of life — the plant life, the animal life, and even the human life — was produced out of the land ([link]vv. 11-12[/link], [link]24-27[/link]; [link]2:7[/link]). This typifies that the divine life with all its riches comes out of Christ. On the third day Christ came out of death in resurrection to generate life ([link]John 12:24[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 1:3[/link]) for the constituting of the church.

verse.text: And God called the dry land [note]1[/note]Earth, and the gathering together of the waters He called [note]1[/note]Seas; and God saw that it was [xref]a[/xref]good.
verse.note: Dividing the land from the waters signifies separating life from death. From the second day ([link]vv. 6-7[/link]) God began to work to confine and limit the waters of death that covered the earth (cf. [link]Jer. 5:22[/link]). Eventually, when God's work is completed, in the new heaven and new earth there will be no more sea ([link]Rev. 21:1[/link] and note 3). Furthermore, in the New Jerusalem there will be no more night ([link]Rev. 21:25[/link] and note 2). This means that both death and darkness will be eliminated.

verse.text: And God [xref]a[/xref]said, Let the earth [xref]b[/xref]sprout [note]1[/note]grass, herbs yielding seed, [i]and[/i] fruit trees bearing fruit [xref]c[/xref]according to their kind with their seed in them upon the earth; and it was so.
verse.note: The plant life is the lowest form of life, a life without consciousness, corresponding to the earliest stage of the divine life in a newly-regenerated believer (cf. [link]1 Cor. 3:6[/link]). The countless varieties of the plant life typify the rich expression of the unsearchable riches of the life of Christ in their beauty for man's sight ([link]Gen. 2:9[/link]), in their fragrance ([link]S.S. 1:12-13[/link]), and in their nourishing man and animals ([link]Gen. 1:29-30[/link]). The trees ([link]Gen. 2:9[/link]; [link]Exo. 15:23-25[/link]; [link]S.S. 2:3[/link]; [link]5:15[/link]; [link]Isa. 11:1[/link]; [link]John 15:1[/link]; [link]Rev. 22:2[/link]), the flowers ([link]S.S. 1:14[/link]), and the grains as food for man ([link]John 6:9[/link], [link]13[/link]) and as offerings to God ([link]Lev. 2:1-3[/link], [link]14[/link]) are all types of Christ.

verse.text: And the earth brought forth grass, herbs yielding seed [xref]a[/xref]according to their kind, and trees bearing fruit with their seed in them [xref]a[/xref]according to their kind; and God saw that it was [xref]b[/xref]good.
And [xref]a[/xref]there was evening and there was morning, a third day.

And God [xref]a[/xref]said, Let there be [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]light-bearers in the expanse of heaven to separate the day from the night, and let them be for [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]signs and for seasons and for days and years;
verse.note: According to the revelation of the whole Bible, light is for life; light and life always go together ([link]Psa. 36:9[/link]; [link]Matt. 4:16[/link]; [link]John 1:4[/link]; [link]8:12[/link]; [link]1 John 1:1-7[/link]). The higher the light, the higher the life. The indefinite light of the first day ([link]v. 3[/link]) was sufficient for generating the lowest forms of life; the more solid and more definite light from the light-bearers — the sun, the moon, and the stars ([link]v. 16[/link]; [link]Psa. 136:7-9[/link]) — on the fourth day was necessary for producing the higher forms of life, including the human life. This signifies that for our spiritual rebirth, the light of the "first day" is sufficient; but for the growth in the divine life unto maturity, more and stronger light, the light of the "fourth day," is needed.
All the signs, seasons, days, and years are shadows of Christ ([link]Col. 2:16-17[/link]).

chapter.verse: And let them be light-bearers in the expanse of heaven to give light on the earth; and it was so.

verse.text: And God [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]made the two great light-bearers, the [note]2[/note]greater light-bearer to rule the day and the [note]3[/note]lesser light-bearer to rule the night, and the [note]4[/note][xref]b[/xref]stars.
verse.note: Although the sun, the moon, and the stars had been created earlier (cf. [link]Job 38:7[/link]), God stopped their functions when He judged the heavens and the earth following Satan's rebellion (see note [link]5[sup]1[/sup] in Job 9[/link]). On the fourth day their functions were recovered for the producing of the higher forms of life.

The sun ([link]Psa. 136:8[/link]), signifying Christ ([link]Mal. 4:2[/link]; [link]Luke 1:78-79[/link]; [link]Matt. 4:16[/link]; [link]Eph. 5:14[/link]). The overcoming saints were also likened to the sun by the Lord Jesus ([link]Matt. 13:43a[/link]).

The moon ([link]Psa. 136:9[/link]). In Joseph's dream his father was likened to the sun, his mother, to the moon, and his brothers, to the stars ([link]37:9[/link]). The moon can be considered a figure of the church, the wife of Christ (cf. [link]S.S. 6:10[/link]). The moon has no light of its own but shines in the night by reflecting the light of the sun. Likewise, the church shines in the dark night of the church age by reflecting the divine light of Christ (cf. [link]Phil. 2:15[/link]).

The stars first signify Christ ([link]Num. 24:17[/link]; [link]2 Pet. 1:19[/link]; [link]Rev. 22:16b[/link]). Although Christ is the real sun, He does not appear as the sun during the present age of night. Rather, He shines as the bright morning star ([link]Rev. 22:16[/link] and note 4). The stars also signify the overcoming saints ([link]Dan. 12:3[/link]; cf. [link]Rev. 1:20[/link]). The light from the stars is needed particularly when the moon wanes; likewise, the shining of the overcoming saints as the heavenly stars is needed particularly in the time of the church's degradation ([link]Rev. 2:7[/link], [link]11[/link], [link]17[/link], [link]26-28[/link]; [link]3:5[/link], [link]12[/link], [link]20-21[/link]).

verse.text: And God [xref]a[/xref]set them in the expanse of heaven to give light on the earth
And to [note]1[/note]rule over the day and over the night and to [note]1[/note]separate the light from the darkness, and God saw that it was [xref]a[/xref]good.
verse.note: The ruling of the fourth-day lights also strengthened the separating of the light from the darkness in [link]v. 4[/link]. Both are requirements for the growth in life.

verse.text: And [xref]a[/xref]there was evening and there was morning, a fourth day.
And God [xref]a[/xref]said, Let the waters swarm with swarms of [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]living animals, and let [note]2[/note]birds fly above the earth in the open expanse of heaven.
verse.note: This is the animal life with the lowest consciousness, corresponding to the first step in the believers' growth in life (cf. [link]1 John 2:13[/link]). The animal life in the sea typifies the riches of the life of Christ in the power that overcomes death (signified by the salt water) in His living. Just as fish can live in salt water without becoming salty, Christ and His believers, who have the divine life, can live in the satanic world without being "salted" by the world's corruption (cf. [link]John 14:30[/link]; [link]17:15-16[/link]). The animal life in the sea also shows the riches of Christ's life in feeding man with His riches ([link]John 6:9a[/link]; [link]21:9[/link]).

The bird life is higher than the fish life. Fish can live in the death waters, but birds can transcend the death waters. By growing further in the divine life, the believers are able to transcend all the frustrations of the earth (cf. [link]Isa. 40:31[/link]). The bird life typifies the riches of the life of Christ as seen in His being the eagle for carrying God's redeemed to His destination ([link]Exo. 19:4[/link]; [link]Deut. 32:11-12[/link]; [link]Rev. 12:14[/link]) and in His being the turtledoves or pigeons for offering to God for the sins of God's people ([link]Lev. 1:14[/link]; [link]5:7[/link]).

verse.text: And God created the [xref]a[/xref]great sea creatures and every living animal that moves, with which the waters swarmed, according to their kind, and every winged bird [xref]b[/xref]according to its kind; and God saw that it was [xref]c[/xref]good.
And God [xref]a[/xref]blessed them, saying, Be [xref]b[/xref]fruitful and multiply, and fill the waters in the seas, and let the birds multiply on the earth.

chapter.verse: And there was evening and there was morning, a fifth day.

verse.text: And God said, Let the earth bring forth [xref]a[/xref]living animals [xref]b[/xref]according to their kind, [note]1[/note]cattle and [note]2[/note]creeping things and [note]1[/note]animals of the earth [xref]b[/xref]according to their kind; and it was so.
verse.note: The cattle and the animals on the earth are a higher life with a higher consciousness than that of the fish and the birds, a life that can accomplish something on the earth. The animals and the cattle on the land typify the riches of the life of Christ as seen in Christ as the conquering lion ([link]Rev. 5:5[/link]) to fight for God's economy, as seen in Christ as the sheep and oxen for offering to God for the fulfillment of God's full redemption ([link]Lev. 1:2-3[/link], [link]10[/link]; [link]3:1[/link], [link]6[/link], [link]12[/link]; [link]4:3[/link]; [link]5:6[/link]; [link]John 1:29[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 1:19[/link]; [link]Rev. 5:6-9[/link]), and as seen in Christ as the ox to bear the responsibility and to labor faithfully for the accomplishing of God's will ([link]Matt. 20:28[/link]; [link]John 6:38[/link]). Through further growth in the divine life the believers in Christ are able to live on the earth a life that is useful for the fulfilling of God's will (cf. [link]1 Cor. 3:2[/link]; [link]Gal. 6:2[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 15:58[/link]).
See note [link]26[sup]6[/sup][/link].

verse.text: And God made the animals of the earth [xref]a[/xref]according to their kind and the cattle according to their kind and everything that creeps on the ground [xref]a[/xref]according to its kind, and God saw that it was [xref]b[/xref]good.

And God said, [note]1[/note]Let [xref]a[/xref]Us make [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]man [xref]c[/xref]in Our [note]3[/note][xref]d[/xref]image, according to Our [note]3[/note][xref]e[/xref]likeness; and let [note]4[/note]them have [note]5[/note][xref]f[/xref]dominion over the fish of the sea and over the birds of heaven and over the cattle and over all the earth and over every [note]6[/note]creeping thing that creeps upon the earth.
verse.note: [i]Let Us...[/i] reveals that a council was held among the three of the Godhead regarding the creation of man. The decision to create man had been made by the Triune God in eternity past, indicating that the creation of man was for the eternal purpose of the Triune God ([link]Eph. 3:9-11[/link]). God's intention in creating man was to carry out His divine economy for the dispensing of Himself into man ([link]1 Tim. 1:4[/link] and note 3, par. 1). This is fully unveiled in the following books of the Bible.

Or, mankind; Heb. [i]adam[/i]. So also in the next verse. The human life is the highest created life, the life that can express God in His image and likeness and can exercise dominion for God. Adam, the first man, typifies Christ ([link]Rom. 5:14[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 15:45[/link], [link]47[/link]; [link]Psa. 8:4-8[/link]; [link]Heb. 2:6-9[/link]) as the center of God's creation ([link]Col. 1:16-17[/link]), as the Head of all creation ([link]Col. 1:15[/link]) and of all men ([link]1 Cor. 11:3[/link]), as God's expression in God's image and likeness ([link]Heb. 1:3[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 4:4[/link]; [link]Col. 1:15[/link]), and as God's representative to rule over all things created by God ([link]Psa. 8:6-8[/link]; [link]Matt. 28:18[/link]).

God's image, referring to God's inner being, is the expression of the inward essence of God's attributes, the most prominent of which are love ([link]1 John 4:8[/link]), light ([link]1 John 1:5[/link]), holiness ([link]Rev. 4:8[/link]), and righteousness ([link]Jer. 23:6[/link]). God's likeness, referring to God's form ([link]Phil. 2:6[/link]), is the expression of the essence and nature of God's person. Thus, God's image and God's likeness should not be considered as two separate things. Man's inward virtues, created in man's spirit, are copies of God's attributes and are the means for man to express God's attributes. Man's outward form, created as man's body, is a copy of God's form. Thus, God created man to be a duplication of Himself that man may have the capacity to contain God and express Him. All the other living things were created "according to their kind" ([link]vv. 11-12[/link], [link]21[/link], [link]24-25[/link]), but man was created according to God's kind (cf. [link]Acts 17:28-29a[/link]). Since God and man are of the same kind, it is possible for man to be joined to God and to live together with Him in an organic union ([link]John 15:5[/link]; [link]Rom. 6:5[/link]; [link]11:17-24[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 6:17[/link]).[br][br]Christ the Son, as God's embodiment ([link]Col. 2:9[/link]), is the image of the invisible God, the expression of the essence of God's attributes ([link]Col. 1:15[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 4:4[/link]; [link]Heb. 1:3[/link]). Man was created according to Christ with the intention that Christ would enter into man and be expressed through man ([link]Col. 1:27[/link]; [link]Phil. 1:20-21a[/link]). Created man is a living vessel, a container, to contain Christ ([link]Rom. 9:21[/link], [link]23[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 4:7[/link]). Eventually, in His incarnation Christ put on human nature and became in the likeness of men ([link]Phil. 2:6-8[/link]) so that through His death and resurrection man may obtain God's eternal, divine life ([link]1 Pet. 1:3[/link]; [link]1 John 5:11-12[/link]) and by that life be transformed and conformed to the image of Christ inwardly ([link]2 Cor. 3:18[/link]; [link]Rom. 8:29[/link]) and transfigured into the likeness of Christ's glorious body outwardly ([link]Phil. 3:21[/link]) that he may be the same as Christ ([link]1 John 3:2b[/link]) and may express God with Him to the universe ([link]Eph. 3:21[/link]).[br][br]Created man was a duplication of God in God's image and likeness, but he did not have the reality of God or the life of God. Thus, he still needed to receive God as his life by eating of the tree of life so that he might have the reality of God to express Him ([link]2:9[/link] and note 2).

The pronouns [i]them[/i] here and in [link]vv. 27-28[/link] and [i]their[/i] in [link]5:2[/link] indicate that Adam was a corporate man, a collective man, including all mankind. God did not create many men; He created mankind collectively in one person, Adam. God created such a corporate man in His image and according to His likeness so that mankind might express God corporately.

God created a corporate man not only to express Himself with His image but also to represent Him by exercising His dominion over all things. God's intention in giving man dominion is (1) to subdue God's enemy, Satan, who rebelled against God; (2) to recover the earth, which was usurped by Satan; and (3) to exercise God's authority over the earth in order that the kingdom of God may come to the earth, the will of God may be done on the earth, and the glory of God may be manifested on the earth ([link]Matt. 6:10[/link], [link]13b[/link]).[br][br]God's intention that man would express God in His image and represent God with His dominion is fulfilled not in Adam as the first man ([link]1 Cor. 15:45a[/link]), the old man ([link]Rom. 6:6[/link]), but in Christ as the second man ([link]1 Cor. 15:47b[/link] and note 2), the new man ([link]Eph. 2:15[/link] and note 8), comprising Christ Himself as the Head and the church as His Body ([link]Eph. 1:22-23[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 12:12[/link] and note 2; [link]Col. 3:10-11[/link] and note 11[sup]9[/sup]). It is fully fulfilled in the overcoming believers, who live Christ for His corporate expression ([link]Phil. 1:19-26[/link]) and will have authority over the nations and reign as co-kings with Christ in the millennium ([link]Rev. 2:26-27[/link]; [link]20:4[/link], [link]6[/link]). It will ultimately be fulfilled in the New Jerusalem, which will express God's image, having His glory and bearing His appearance ([link]Rev. 4:3a[/link]; [link]21:11[/link], [link]18a[/link]), and also exercise God's divine authority to maintain God's dominion over the entire universe for eternity ([link]Rev. 21:24[/link]; [link]22:5[/link]).

Typifying Satan, the serpent ([link]3:1[/link], [link]14[/link]; [link]Rev. 12:9[/link]), and his angels ([link]Matt. 25:41[/link]; [link]Rev. 12:4a[/link], [link]7b[/link]), as well as the demons who follow Satan (cf. [link]Luke 10:19[/link]). See note [link]6[sup]2[/sup], par. 1, in Rev. 4[/link].

verse.text: And God created man [xref]a[/xref]in His own image; in the image of God He created him; [xref]b[/xref]male and female He [xref]c[/xref]created them.

And God [xref]a[/xref]blessed them; and God said to them, Be [xref]b[/xref]fruitful and multiply, and fill the earth and [note]1[/note]subdue it, and have dominion over the fish of the sea and over the birds of heaven and over every living thing that moves upon the earth.
verse.note: [i]Subdue[/i] here implies that a war is raging on earth between God and His enemy, Satan. Whoever gains the earth will have the victory. Man was created by God to subdue, to conquer, the earth and recover it for God.

verse.text: And God said, Behold, I have given you every herb that produces seed that is on the surface of all the earth and every tree [note]1[/note]which has fruit that produces seed; they shall be for you as [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]food.
verse.note: Lit., on which is the fruit of a tree seeding seed.
See note [link]3[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 9[/link].

chapter.verse: And to every animal of the earth and to every bird of heaven and to everything that creeps upon the earth, in which is a living soul, [i]I have given[/i] every green herb for food; and it was so.

verse.text: And God saw everything that He had made, and indeed, it was [note]1[/note]very [xref]a[/xref]good. And there was evening and there was morning, the sixth day.
verse.note: Previously God had said "good" ([link]vv. 4[/link], [link]10[/link], [link]12[/link], [link]21[/link], [link]25[/link]), but here He said "very good" because Adam had God's image and had been given God's dominion.

chapter.verse: Thus the heavens and the earth and all their host were finished.

verse.text: And on the [xref]a[/xref]seventh day God finished His work which He had done, and He [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]rested on the seventh day from all His work which He had done.
verse.note: God rested because He had finished His work and was satisfied. God's glory was manifested because man had His image, and His authority was about to be exercised for the subduing of His enemy, Satan. As long as man expresses God and deals with God's enemy, God is satisfied and can rest.[br][br]Later, the seventh day was commemorated as the Sabbath ([link]Exo. 20:8-11[/link]). God's seventh day was man's first day. God had prepared everything for man's enjoyment. After man was created, he did not join in God's work; he entered into God's rest. Man was created not to work but to be satisfied with God and rest with God (cf. [link]Matt. 11:28-30[/link]). The Sabbath was made for man, not man for the Sabbath ([link]Mark 2:27[/link]).[br][br]The rest here is a seed that develops through the Bible and is harvested in Revelation. The development of this seed includes the rest of the Sabbath day ([link]Exo. 20:8-11[/link]) and the rest of the good land ([link]Deut. 12:9[/link]; [link]Heb. 4:8[/link]) in the Old Testament, the rest of the Lord's Day in the New Testament ([link]Rev. 1:10[/link]; [link]Acts 20:7[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 16:2[/link]), and the rest of the millennial kingdom ([link]Heb. 4:1[/link], [link]3[/link], [link]9[/link], [link]11[/link]). The consummation of rest is the rest of the new heaven and new earth with the New Jerusalem, in which all the redeemed saints will express God's glory ([link]Rev. 21:11[/link], [link]23[/link]) and reign with God's authority ([link]Rev. 22:5b[/link]) for eternity. See note [link]9[sup]1[/sup] in Heb. 4[/link].

verse.text: And God blessed the seventh day and sanctified it because in it He rested from all His work which God had [note]1[/note]created and made.
verse.note: Lit., created to make.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]These are the generations of the heavens and of the earth when they were [note]2[/note]created. [note]3[/note]When [note]4[/note]Jehovah God [note]2[/note]made earth and heaven,
verse.note: God's desire and purpose to have a corporate man to express Him in His image and to represent Him with His authority is unveiled in [link]1:1-2:3[/link]. The remainder of [link]ch. 2[/link] is an added record to reveal the way, the procedure, God takes to accomplish His purpose. This way is life. In order for man to express God and represent God, he must have God as his life, signified by the tree of life in [link]v. 9[/link].

See note [link]1[sup]4[/sup], par. 1, in ch. 1[/link]. First, God [i]created[/i] the heavens and the earth ([link]1:1[/link]); then He [i]made[/i] the earth and the heavens. In God's creation, it was first the heavens and then the earth ([link]1:1[/link]), whereas in God's restoration and further creation, it was first the earth and then the heavens.
Lit., In the day.

Elohim ([link]1:1[/link]) is the name of God in His relationship to creation, whereas Jehovah is God's name in His relationship with man. [i]Jehovah[/i] means [i]I am who I am[/i] ([link]Exo. 3:14[/link]; cf. [link]John 8:24[/link], [link]28[/link], [link]58[/link]), indicating that Jehovah is the self-existing and ever-existing eternal One, the One who was in the past, who is in the present, and who will be in the future forever ([link]Rev. 1:4[/link]).

verse.text: And no [xref]a[/xref]plant of the field was yet in the earth, and no herb of the field had yet sprung up — for Jehovah God had not caused it to rain upon the earth, and there was no man to [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]work the ground,
verse.note: This signifies that there was no man to work with God by human labor in coordination with His divine labor (cf. [link]John 5:17[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 3:9[/link]). When man labors in coordination with God's labor, God has the basis to send the rain, signifying His Spirit of life ([link]Joel 2:23[/link], [link]28-29[/link]), to mingle with man, the dust of the earth ([link]v. 7[/link]), to produce life.

chapter.verse: But a mist went up from the earth and watered the whole surface of the ground —

verse.text: Jehovah God [note]1[/note]formed [note]2[/note]man from the [note]3[/note][xref]a[/xref]dust of the [note]4[/note]ground and breathed into his nostrils the [note]5[/note][xref]b[/xref]breath of life, and man became a living [note]6[/note][xref]c[/xref]soul.
verse.note: Or, shaped (as a potter would). See note [link]1[sup]4[/sup], par. 1, in ch. 1[/link].

Heb. [i]adam.[/i] The first step of God's procedure in fulfilling His purpose was to create man as a vessel to contain Himself as life ([link]Rom. 9:21[/link], [link]23[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 4:7[/link]; [link]2 Tim. 2:21[/link]).
Man's body, formed from the dust of the ground, is man's outward form and an organ for him to contact the material realm.
Heb. [i]adamah.[/i]

Heb. [i]neshamah,[/i] translated [i]spirit[/i] in [link]Prov. 20:27[/link], indicating that the breath of life breathed into man's body became the spirit of man, the human spirit (cf. [link]Job 32:8[/link]). Man's spirit is his inward organ for him to contact God, receive God, contain God, and assimilate God into his entire being as his life and his everything. It was specifically formed by God and is ranked in importance with the heavens and the earth in God's holy Word ([link]Zech. 12:1[/link]). The spirit of man is for man to worship God ([link]John 4:24[/link]), to be regenerated by God ([link]John 3:6b[/link]), and to be joined to God ([link]1 Cor. 6:17[/link]; [link]2 Tim. 4:22[/link]) that man may walk and live in an organic union with God ([link]Rom. 8:4b[/link]) to fulfill God's purpose.[br][br]The breath of life breathed into man's nostrils was not the eternal life of God nor the Spirit of God. See note [link]38[sup]2[/sup] in Luke 3[/link]. Man did not receive the Spirit of God until the Lord breathed the Holy Spirit into His disciples on the day of His resurrection ([link]John 20:22[/link]). Nevertheless, because the human spirit came out of God's breath of life, it is very close to the Spirit of God. Thus, there can be a transmission between God the Spirit and man's spirit, and the human spirit is able to contact God and be one with God ([link]Rom. 8:16[/link] and note 2; [link]1 Cor. 6:17[/link] and note 2).[br][br]Within man's spirit there are three functions: conscience, enabling man to know what God justifies and what He condemns ([link]Rom. 9:1[/link] and note 2); fellowship, that man may contact God, worship God, and commune with God ([link]John 4:24[/link]; [link]Eph. 6:18a[/link]; [link]Rom. 1:9[/link]); and intuition, giving man a direct sense of God and a direct knowledge from God ([link]Mark 2:8[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 2:11[/link]).

Man's soul, which is his person, his very self ([link]Exo. 1:5[/link]; [link]Acts 2:41[/link]), was not formed from a certain element but was produced by the combining of the human spirit and the human body. The soul, composed of man's mind, emotion, and will, has the psychological consciousness to contact the psychological realm.[br][br]God is triune — the Father, the Son, and the Spirit ([link]Matt. 28:19[/link]) — and man is tripartite — spirit and soul and body ([link]1 Thes. 5:23[/link]). The Triune God created such a tripartite man to be a living vessel that man may have the capacity to contain God and be joined to God organically ([link]John 15:4-5[/link]; [link]Rom. 11:17-24[/link]) to be His organism for His expression in humanity. See note [link]23[sup]5[/sup] in 1 Thes. 5[/link] and notes [link book="Heb." chapter="4"]12[sup]2[/sup][/link] and [link]12[sup]3[/sup] in Heb. 4[/link].

verse.text: And Jehovah God planted a [xref]a[/xref]garden in [note]1[/note]Eden, in the east; and there He put the man whom He had formed.
verse.note: A Hebrew word meaning [i]pleasure.[/i]

verse.text: And out of the ground Jehovah God caused to grow every tree that is [note]1[/note]pleasant to the sight and good for food, as well as the [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]tree of life in the middle of the garden and the [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]tree of the knowledge of good and evil.
verse.note: Indicating that God wanted to please man and make him happy. God wants man to be pleased with Him and satisfied with Him ([link]Psa. 100[/link]; [link]Phil. 4:4[/link]).

The second step of God's procedure in fulfilling His purpose was to place the created man in front of the tree of life, which signifies the Triune God embodied in Christ as life to man in the form of food. God's placing man in front of the tree of life indicates that God wanted man to receive Him as man's life by eating Him organically and assimilating Him metabolically, that God might become the very constituent of man's being. According to [link]John 1:1[/link], [link]4[/link], life is in the Word, who is God Himself. This life — the divine, eternal, uncreated life of God — is Christ ([link]John 11:25[/link]; [link]14:6[/link]; [link]Col. 3:4a[/link]), who is the embodiment of God ([link]Col. 2:9[/link]). The tree of life grows along the two sides of the river of water of life ([link]Rev. 22:1-2[/link]), indicating that it is a vine. Since Christ is a vine tree ([link]John 15:1[/link]) and is also life, He is the tree of life. He was processed through incarnation, crucifixion, and resurrection that man might have life and live by eating Him ([link]John 10:10b[/link]; [link]6:51[/link], [link]57[/link], [link]63[/link]).

The tree of the knowledge of good and evil signifies Satan as the source of death to man ([link]Heb. 2:14[/link]). It also signifies all things apart from God, for anything that is not God Himself, including good things and even scriptural things and religious things, can be utilized by Satan, the subtle one, to bring death to man. Even the Scriptures inspired by God and the law given by God can be utilized by Satan as the tree of knowledge to bring in death ([link]John 5:39-40[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 3:6b[/link]).[br][br]The tree of life causes man to be dependent on God ([link]John 15:5[/link]), whereas the tree of knowledge causes man to rebel against God and to be independent from Him (cf. [link]3:5[/link]). The two trees issue in two lines — the line of life and the line of death — that run through the entire Bible and end in the book of Revelation. Death begins with the tree of knowledge ([link]v. 17[/link]) and ends with the lake of fire ([link]Rev. 20:10[/link], [link]14[/link]). Life begins with the tree of life and ends in the New Jerusalem, the city of the water of life ([link]Rev. 22:1-2[/link]).

verse.text: And a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]river went [note]2[/note]forth from Eden to water the garden, and from there it divided and became [note]3[/note]four [note]4[/note]branches.
verse.note: The river here signifies the river of water of life, along which the tree of life grows ([link]Rev. 22:1-2[/link] and notes 12, 13, and 21). This river quenched man's thirst and watered the garden that life might grow. At the beginning and the end of the Bible there are the tree of life and the river flowing with living water.

The river going forth from Eden signifies the river of water of life flowing forth from God ([link]Rev. 22:1[/link]), indicating that God is the source of the living water for man to drink (cf. [link]John 4:10[/link]; [link]7:37[/link]).

The number four signifies man, the creature ([link]Ezek. 1:5[/link]). The one river becoming four branches signifies that the river flows out of the unique God (signified by the number one) as the source and center to reach man in every direction.
Lit., heads.

verse.text: The name of the first is Pishon; it is the one that goes around the whole land of [xref]a[/xref]Havilah, where there is gold.
And the [note]1[/note]gold of that land is good; [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]bdellium and [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]onyx stone are there.
verse.note: The flow of the river issued in three precious materials: gold, bdellium, and onyx. These materials typify the Triune God as the basic elements of the structure of God's eternal building. Gold typifies God the Father with His divine nature, which man may partake of through God's calling ([link]2 Pet. 1:3-4[/link]), as the base of God's eternal building; bdellium, a pearl-like material produced from the resin of a tree, typifies the produce of God the Son in His redeeming and life-releasing death ([link]John 19:34[/link]) and His life-dispensing resurrection ([link]John 12:24[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 1:3[/link]), as the entry into God's eternal building (cf. [link]Rev. 21:21[/link] and note 1, par. 1); and onyx, a precious stone, typifies the produce of God the Spirit with His transforming work ([link]2 Cor. 3:18[/link]) for the building up of God's eternal building. The New Jerusalem is constructed of these three categories of materials — gold, pearl, and precious stones ([link]Rev. 21:11[/link], [link]18-21[/link]). See note [link]21[sup]1[/sup], par. 2, in Rev. 21[/link].[br][br]The breastplate of the high priest, a symbol of Israel as God's Old Testament people, was constructed of gold and precious stones ([link]Exo. 28:6-21[/link]), and the church in the New Testament is built with gold, silver, and precious stones ([link]1 Cor. 3:12[/link] — there silver, signifying Christ's redemption, is listed instead of bdellium or pearl because of man's need of redemption after the fall). This indicates that the New Jerusalem includes the totality of God's chosen and redeemed people — Israel plus the church (see notes [link book="Rev." chapter="21"]12[sup]4[/sup][/link] and [link]14[sup]2[/sup] in Rev. 21[/link]).[br][br]The flowing of the divine life in man brings the divine nature into man ([link]2 Pet. 1:4[/link]), regenerates man ([link]1 Pet. 1:3[/link]), and transforms man into the glorious image of Christ ([link]2 Cor. 3:18[/link]). Thus, man, who was created of dust ([link]v. 7[/link]), becomes transformed precious materials for God's building, which will consummate in the New Jerusalem.

chapter.verse: And the name of the second river is Gihon; it is the one that goes around the whole land of Cush.

verse.text: And the name of the third river is [xref]a[/xref]Hiddekel; it is the one that goes east of Asshur. And the fourth river is the Euphrates.
And Jehovah God took the man and [note]1[/note]put him in the garden of Eden to [note]2[/note]work it and to [note]3[/note]keep it.
verse.note: Lit., caused him to rest.

Man's working the ground was that life, especially the tree of life ([link]v. 9[/link]), might grow for the fulfillment of the first aspect of God's purpose, i.e., to express God in His image. The ground typifies the human heart, into which Christ as the seed of the tree of life is sown ([link]Matt. 13:3-23[/link]). To work the ground signifies to loosen and break our hard heart, to open our heart to the heavens that the Spirit as the rain (see note [link book="Matt." chapter="13"]5[sup]1[/sup][/link]) may descend for the growth of Christ as the tree of life within us.

Or, guard. This is to protect the garden from God's enemy that the second aspect of God's purpose might be fulfilled, i.e., to deal with Satan by God's authority. We need to work the ground that God as the tree of life might enter into us. We also need to keep the ground, leaving no opening for Satan as the tree of knowledge.

verse.text: And Jehovah God commanded the man, saying, [xref]a[/xref]Of every tree of the garden you may eat freely,
But of the tree of the knowledge of good and evil, of it you shall [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]not eat; for in the day that you eat of it you shall surely [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]die.
verse.note: God's first commandment to man concerned man's eating, not man's conduct. Eating is critical to man, a matter of life or death. Man's outcome and destiny before God depends altogether on what he eats. If man eats the tree of life, he will receive God as life and fulfill God's purpose; if he eats the tree of knowledge, he will receive Satan as death and be usurped by him for his purpose.[br][br]God's forbidding commandment given as a warning to man indicates (1) God's greatness in creating man with a free will that man may choose God willingly and not under coercion; (2) God's love for man; and (3) God's desire that man would eat the tree of life to receive God into him as life.

Referring not to the death of man's body but to the deadening of man's spirit ([link]Eph. 2:1[/link]), which leads ultimately to the death of man's entire being — spirit, soul, and body ([link]Heb. 9:27[/link]; [link]Rev. 20:14[/link]). See note [link]1[sup]2[/sup] in Eph. 2[/link].

verse.text: And Jehovah God said, It is not [xref]a[/xref]good for the [note]1[/note]man to be alone; I will make him a [xref]b[/xref]helper as his [note]2[/note]counterpart.
verse.note: The third step of God's procedure in fulfilling His purpose was to work Himself into man to make man His complement. Adam here typifies God in Christ as the real, universal Husband, who is seeking a wife for Himself ([link]Rom. 5:14[/link]; cf. [link]Isa. 54:5[/link]; [link]John 3:29[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 11:2[/link]; [link]Eph. 5:31-32[/link]; [link]Rev. 19:7[/link]; [link]21:9[/link]). Adam's need for a wife typifies and portrays God's need, in His economy, to have a wife as His complement.
Or, his complement; lit., his parallel. So also in [link]v. 20[/link].

verse.text: Now Jehovah God had formed [xref]a[/xref]from the ground every animal of the field and every bird of heaven. And He brought [i]them[/i] to the man to see what he would call them; and whatever the man called any living animal, that was its name.
And the man gave names to all cattle and to the birds of heaven and to every animal of the field, but for Adam there was [note]1[/note]not found a helper as his counterpart.
verse.note: The wife must be the same as the husband in life, nature, and expression. Among the cattle, the birds, and the animals Adam did not find a complement for himself, one that could match him.

verse.text: And Jehovah God caused a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]deep sleep to fall upon the man, and he slept; and He took one of his [note]2[/note]ribs and closed up the flesh in its place.
verse.note: In order to produce a complement for Himself, God first became a man ([link]John 1:14[/link]), as typified by God's creation of Adam ([link]Rom. 5:14[/link]). Here Adam's deep sleep for the producing of Eve as his wife typifies Christ's death on the cross for the producing of the church as His counterpart ([link]Eph. 5:25-27[/link]). Through Christ's death the divine life within Him was released, and through His resurrection His released divine life was imparted into His believers for the constituting of the church (see note [link]34[sup]1[/sup] in John 19[/link]). Through such a process God in Christ has been wrought into man with His life and nature so that man can be the same as God in life and nature in order to match Him as His counterpart.

The rib taken from Adam's opened side typifies the unbreakable, indestructible eternal life of Christ ([link]Heb. 7:16[/link]), which flowed out of His pierced side ([link]John 19:34[/link]) to impart life to His believers for the producing and building up of the church as His complement. See notes [link]36[sup]2[/sup] in John 19[/link] and [link]16[sup]1[/sup] in Heb. 7[/link].

verse.text: And Jehovah God [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]built the rib, which He had taken from the man, into a [note]2[/note]woman and [note]3[/note]brought her to the man.
verse.note: It does not say that Eve was created but that she was built. The building of Eve with the rib taken from Adam's side typifies the building of the church with the resurrection life released from Christ through His death on the cross and imparted into His believers in His resurrection ([link]John 12:24[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 1:3[/link]). The church as the real Eve is the totality of Christ in all His believers. Only that which comes out of Christ with His resurrection life can be His complement and counterpart, the Body of Christ ([link]1 Cor. 12:12[/link]; [link]Eph. 5:28-30[/link]).

At the end of the Bible is a city, New Jerusalem, the ultimate and eternal woman, the corporate bride, the wife of the Lamb ([link]Rev. 21:9[/link]; [link]22:17[/link]), built with three precious materials ([link]Rev. 21:18-21[/link]), fulfilling for eternity the type shown in this chapter. Thus, in type all the precious materials mentioned in [link]vv. 11-12[/link] are for the building of the woman (see note [link]12[sup]1[/sup][/link]).

As Eve was taken out of Adam and brought back to Adam to be one flesh with him ([link]v. 24[/link]), so the church produced out of Christ will go back to Christ ([link]Eph. 5:27[/link]; [link]Rev. 19:7[/link]) to be one spirit with Him ([link]1 Cor. 6:17[/link]). See note [link]32[sup]1[/sup] in Eph. 5[/link].

verse.text: And the man said,[br/]This time this is [xref]a[/xref]bone of my bones / And flesh of my flesh; / This one shall be called [note]1[/note]Woman / Because [xref]b[/xref]out of [note]2[/note]Man this one was taken.
verse.note: Heb. [i]Ishshah,[/i] as also in [link]v. 22[/link]. Just as Eve was the increase of Adam, the church as the bride is the increase of Christ as the Bridegroom ([link]John 3:29-30[/link]).
Heb. [i]Ish.[/i] So also in [link]v. 24[/link]. Different from the word [i]adam,[/i] translated [i]man[/i] elsewhere in the chapter.

verse.text: Therefore a [xref]a[/xref]man shall leave his father and his mother and shall cleave to his wife, and [xref]b[/xref]they shall become one [note]1[/note]flesh.
verse.note: See note [link]22[sup]3[/sup][/link]. Adam and Eve becoming one flesh, one complete unit, is a figure of God and man being joined as one. The coming New Jerusalem will be the eternal union of God and man, a universal couple as a complete unit composed of divinity and humanity.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]And both the man and his wife were [xref]a[/xref]naked and were not ashamed before each other.
verse.note: Adam and Eve, being one, lived a married life together as husband and wife. This portrays that in the New Jerusalem the processed and consummated redeeming Triune God as the universal Husband will live a married life with the redeemed, regenerated, transformed, and glorified humanity as the wife, forever. See note [link]17[sup]1[/sup], par. 2, in Rev. 22[/link].[br][br]The revelation concerning the garden of Eden, as the beginning of the divine revelation in the Holy Scriptures, and the revelation concerning the New Jerusalem, as the ending of the divine revelation in the Holy Scriptures, reflect each other. Both contain four things: (1) the tree of life as the center of God's eternal economy ([link]v. 9[/link]; [link]Rev. 22:2[/link]), (2) the river flowing to reach the four directions of the earth ([link]v. 10[/link]; [link]Rev. 22:1[/link]), (3) three kinds of precious materials ([link]vv. 11-12[/link]; [link]Rev. 21:11-14[/link], [link]18-21[/link]), and (4) a couple ([link]vv. 18-25[/link]; [link]Rev. 21:9-10[/link]; [link]22:17[/link]). What is revealed in these two parts of the Scriptures is the central line of the divine revelation of the entire Holy Scriptures and should be a controlling principle of the interpreting and understanding of the Holy Scriptures.

verse.text: Now the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]serpent was more crafty than any [i]other[/i] animal of the field that Jehovah God had made. And he said to the [note]2[/note]woman, [note]3[/note]Did God really say, [xref]b[/xref]You shall not eat of any tree of the garden?
verse.note: Man's first fall was initiated by Satan through the deceiving by the serpent ([link]2 Cor. 11:3[/link]). The crafty serpent was the embodiment of Satan, the Devil, the enemy and adversary of God ([link]Matt. 13:39a[/link]; [link]Rev. 12:9[/link] and notes 3 and 4) and the tempter of man ([link]Matt. 4:3[/link]; [link]1 Thes. 3:5[/link]).[br][br]Immediately after the first two chapters of Genesis, Satan came in, and immediately before the last two chapters of Revelation, he will be cast out ([link]Rev. 20:10[/link]). Between the first two chapters and the last two chapters of the Bible, Satan, the serpent, is constantly working to corrupt and damage humanity and to thereby frustrate God from carrying out His eternal purpose. In every generation the goal of God's divine work is to build up the Body of Christ to express His Son, Christ, and also to eliminate the serpent.
The serpent contacted the woman, not the man, because the woman is the weaker vessel ([link]1 Pet. 3:7[/link]).

In tempting the woman, Satan first touched her mind by questioning God's word, causing her to doubt God's word. The serpent's question stirred up Eve's doubting mind and prevented her from using her spirit to contact God. Satan's evil thought entered into Eve and contaminated her mind even before she ate of the tree of knowledge.

verse.text: And the woman [note]1[/note]said to the serpent, Of the fruit of the trees of the garden we may eat;
verse.note: The outward cause of man's first fall was the serpent's temptation. The inward cause was the woman's assuming the headship ([link]vv. 2-3[/link], [link]6[/link]). The woman represents man's position in relation to God. God is man's Husband ([link]Isa. 54:5[/link]); man's position is that of the wife. As the man should be under the headship of God, so the woman should be under the headship of man ([link]1 Cor. 11:3[/link]). This is a safeguard against the subtlety of the enemy. Here Eve assumed the headship by speaking to the serpent directly, without the covering of her husband. Thus, she was ensnared by the serpent and was deceived ([link]1 Tim. 2:14[/link]). Eve's failure here typifies man's failure in putting God aside and assuming the headship over God to act independently of Him, thus opening the way for Satan, the subtle one, to deceive man. See note [link]4[sup]1[/sup] in Rom. 7[/link].

verse.text: But of the fruit of the tree which is in the middle of the garden, God has said, [xref]a[/xref]You shall not eat of it, nor shall you touch it, lest you die.
And the serpent said to the woman, [xref]a[/xref]You shall not surely die!
[note]1[/note]For God knows that in the day you eat of it your eyes will be opened, and you will become [xref]a[/xref]like [note]2[/note]God, knowing good and evil.
verse.note: This slanderous word from the evil one caused Eve to misunderstand God's love and to doubt God's heart in His forbidding man to eat of the tree of the knowledge of good and evil ([link]2:16-17[/link]). It poisoned Eve's emotion, causing her to dislike God.
Or, gods.

verse.text: And when the [xref]a[/xref]woman saw that the tree was good for food and that it was a [xref]b[/xref]delight to the eyes and [i]that[/i] the tree was to be desired to make [i]oneself[/i] wise, she [note]1[/note]took of its fruit and ate; and she also gave [i]some[/i] to her husband with her, and he [xref]c[/xref]ate.
verse.note: In the process of man's fall, man failed to use his spirit to contact God, thus bypassing God and putting God aside. Instead, he exercised his soul, reasoning with the serpent in the mind, desiring the tree of knowledge in the emotion, and deciding in the will to take the fruit and eat it.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]And the eyes of both of them were [xref]a[/xref]opened, and they [note]2[/note]knew that they were naked; and they sewed [note]3[/note]fig leaves together and made loincloths for themselves.
verse.note: The dreadful result of man's first fall was manifold. First, man transgressed God's commandment ([link]2:17[/link]; [link]Rom. 5:14[/link]) and thus fell under God's condemnation ([link]Rom. 5:16[/link]) and came under a curse ([link]vv. 17-19[/link]). He also became estranged from God ([link]v. 8[/link]) and alienated from the life of God ([link]Eph. 4:18[/link]) in the tree of life ([link]vv. 23-24[/link]). Not only so, in the fall Satan's evil thought, feeling, and will were injected into man's mind, emotion, and will, thus contaminating man's soul ([link]vv. 1[/link], [link]4-6[/link]). Through man's eating of the tree of knowledge, Satan entered man's body and became the very sin within man (cf. [link]Rom. 7:8[/link], [link]11[/link], [link]17[/link], [link]20[/link] and note [link]8[sup]1[/sup][/link]). Thus the human body, which was created pure and sinless, was transmuted into the flesh of sin ([link]Rom. 7:18a[/link] and note 2). As a consequence of the fall man's spirit was deadened (cf. [link]Eph. 2:1[/link], [link]5[/link] and note [link]1[sup]2[/sup][/link]), becoming insulated from God and losing its function toward God. Hence, each of man's three parts — his body, his soul, and his spirit — was damaged by the fall. Furthermore, fallen man was constituted a sinner ([link]Rom. 5:19[/link]) and became a victim of death ([link]Rom. 5:12b[/link], [link]14a[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 15:22a[/link]). Consequently, man was spoiled from fulfilling God's purpose, which is to express God in His image and represent God with His dominion ([link]1:26[/link]). Finally, because of man's fall all the creation is subjected to vanity and the slavery of corruption ([link]Rom. 8:20-21[/link]).

This is the beginning of the function of the human conscience. The conscience, being a function of man's spirit (see note [link]7[sup]5[/sup], par. 3, in ch. 2[/link]), came into being at the time man was created by God. However, it was not until after man partook of the tree of knowledge that the function of the conscience was manifested. After the fall Adam was ashamed of his nakedness (cf. [link]2:25[/link]) because the function of his conscience was activated. From that time the conscience in man began to bear the responsibility of refusing evil and accepting good. See note [link]1[sup]2[/sup] in Rom. 9[/link].

Fig leaves are of the vegetable life, which has no blood for redemption (cf. [link]Heb. 9:22[/link]). The coverings of fig leaves represent man's own works in attempting to cover his sinfulness. Such works are inadequate to cover man's nakedness that he might be justified, accepted, before God (cf. [link]Rom. 3:20a[/link]). See notes [link]21[sup]1[/sup][/link] and [link]21[sup]2[/sup][/link].

verse.text: And they heard the [note]1[/note]sound of Jehovah God walking about in the garden in the [note]2[/note]cool of the day, and the man and his wife [xref]a[/xref]hid themselves from the presence of Jehovah God among the trees of the garden.
verse.note: Or, voice.
Lit., breeze; Heb. [i]ruach.[/i]

verse.text: And [note]1[/note]Jehovah God called to the man and said to him, [note]2[/note]Where are you?
verse.note: Although the man created by God had been spoiled by His adversary, the unchanging and everlasting God would never change by annulling His eternal economy, which He made in eternity past for eternity future ([link]Eph. 3:9-11[/link]). Thus, He had to rescue the man whom He had created for His unchanging purpose, even at the cost of sacrificing His only begotten Son ([link]John 3:16[/link]). It is for this reason that even in eternity past Christ as the second of the Divine Trinity was preparing to come into time ([link]Micah 5:2[/link]) to die for fallen man according to the divine determination made in the council of the Divine Trinity in eternity past ([link]Acts 2:23[/link] and note 1; [link]1 Pet. 1:18-20[/link] and note [link]20[sup]1[/sup][/link]).

Immediately after the fall, Adam and Eve knew that the result of their transgression was to be death (cf. [link]Rom. 1:32a[/link]; [link]6:23a[/link]). Therefore, they hid themselves from the Lord's presence, awaiting the sentence of death ([link]v. 8[/link]). However, God came to seek them, not to declare the sentence of death but to preach the gospel to them and to save them from their fall (cf. [link]John 3:17[/link]; [link]Luke 19:10[/link]). The first word of the gospel preached by God was "Where are you?" This question was not the pronouncement of a judgment; it was the opening word of the glad tidings.

verse.text: And he said, I heard the sound of You in the garden, and I was afraid because I am [xref]a[/xref]naked; so I hid myself.
And He said, [note]1[/note]Who told you that you are naked? Have you eaten of the tree of which I commanded you not to eat?
verse.note: God questioned Adam and Eve not because He intended to condemn them but because He wanted to lead them to confess their transgressions (cf. [link]1 John 1:9[/link]).

chapter.verse: And the man said, The woman whom You gave [i]to be[/i] with me, she gave me [i]fruit[/i] from the tree, and I ate.

verse.text: And Jehovah God said to the woman, What is this that you have done? And the woman said, The [xref]a[/xref]serpent deceived me, and I ate.

And Jehovah God said to the serpent,[br/]Because you have done this, / You are [note]1[/note]cursed more than all the cattle / And more than all the animals of the field: / Upon your [note]2[/note]stomach you will go, / And [xref]a[/xref]dust you will eat / All the days of your life.
verse.note: God did not judge Adam and Eve, but He judged the serpent by cursing him.

This implies that God limited Satan's activity and move to the earth. As long as we set our mind on the things that are above the earth, the serpent, the Devil, Satan, cannot touch us ([link]Col. 3:1-3[/link]; [link]1 John 5:18[/link]; [link]Rom. 16:20[/link]).

verse.text: And I will put enmity / Between you and the [note]1[/note]woman / And between your [note]2[/note]seed and her [note]3[/note]seed; / He will [note]4[/note][xref]a[/xref]bruise you on the head, / But you will [note]4[/note]bruise him on the heel.
verse.note: The woman here signifies first Eve and then the virgin Mary, the mother of the Lord Jesus ([link]Gal. 4:4[/link]). She also signifies all the people of God who take the position of a woman before God, trusting in Him (see note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in Gen. 3[/link]), as represented by the universal woman in [link]Rev. 12:1[/link] (see note there). Thus, the enmity between the serpent and the woman is the enmity between Satan and all God's people (see note [link]4[sup]2[/sup] in Rev. 12[/link]). The serpent's hating and fighting against God's people began when Satan instigated Cain to murder Abel ([link]4:8[/link]; [link]1 John 3:12[/link]) and continues through all the generations until Satan is cast into the lake of fire for eternity ([link]Rev. 20:7-10[/link]).

The serpent's seed are the people who follow Satan. Because Satan, the old serpent ([link]Rev. 12:9[/link]; [link]20:2[/link]), has injected himself as sin into man's flesh (see note [link]18[sup]2[/sup] in Rom. 7[/link]), all men have become serpents in the eyes of God ([link]Matt. 23:33[/link]). As Satan's followers, they are his sons, his seed, not by adoption but by birth ([link]Matt. 3:7[/link]; [link]13:38[/link]; [link]John 8:44[/link]; [link]1 John 3:10[/link]). Thus, they have the serpentine nature and life. They are used by Satan to persecute and fight against the woman's seed.

The seed of the woman is the incarnated Jesus Christ, who as the very God was born of the virgin Mary to be a man, as prophesied in [link]Isa. 7:14[/link], fulfilled in [link]Matt. 1:23[/link], and confirmed in [link]Gal. 4:4[/link]. Thus, the promise here indicates that God Himself would come to be a human seed to bruise the head of the damaging serpent. Ultimately, the seed of the woman is enlarged to include the overcoming believers, the stronger part of God's people, signified by the man-child in [link]Rev. 12:5[/link] (see note 2 there). The man-child, the corporate seed of the woman, includes the Lord Jesus, the individual seed of the woman. [link]Psalm 2:8-9[/link], [link]Rev. 2:26-27[/link], and [link]Rev. 12:5[/link] indicate that the Lord Jesus as God's Anointed, the overcomers in the churches, and the man-child will rule the nations with an iron rod, thus proving that the Lord Jesus, the overcomers, and the man-child are one. The Lord as the leading Overcomer ([link]Rev. 3:21[/link]) is the Head, center, reality, life, and nature of the man-child, and the man-child as the following overcomers is the Lord's Body.

The bruising of the serpent's head by the seed of the woman is the destroying of Satan, the one who has the might of death, by the Lord Jesus through His death on the cross ([link]Heb. 2:14[/link] and note; [link]1 John 3:8[/link]). While the Lord was destroying the serpent on the cross, the serpent bruised His heel, i.e., wounded Him by nailing His feet to the cross ([link]Psa. 22:16[/link]).[br][br]Through the Lord's death on the cross, Satan, the old serpent, was judged, cast out ([link]John 12:31[/link]; [link]16:11[/link]). That judgment will ultimately be carried out by the overcomers as the man-child, the corporate seed of the woman ([link]Rev. 12:9[/link] and note 1).

verse.text: To the woman He said,[br/]I will greatly multiply / Your pain in your [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]childbearing; / In pain you will bring forth children. / And your desire will be to your husband, / And he will [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]rule over you.
verse.note: Childbearing with suffering and pain ([link]1 Tim. 2:14-15[/link]; [link]5:13-14[/link]) and the ruling of the husband ([link]1 Cor. 11:3[/link]; [link]1 Tim. 2:11-12[/link]) were ordained by God as a restriction and protection for the woman, who took the lead in man's fall.

verse.text: And to Adam He said, Because you listened to the voice of your wife and have eaten of the tree concerning which I commanded you, saying, You shall not eat of it;[br/][xref]a[/xref]Cursed is the ground because of you; / In [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]toil will you eat of it / All the days of your life.
verse.note: Or, pain. The ground's growing thorns and thistles ([link]v. 18[/link]), man's enduring pain, toil, and sweat all the days of his life ([link]vv. 17[/link], [link]19a[/link]), and his returning to the ground, i.e., dying ([link]v. 19b[/link]), were all ordained by God to restrict and protect fallen and sinful man.

verse.text: And [xref]a[/xref]thorns and thistles will it bring forth for you, / And you will eat the herb of the field;
By the sweat of your face / You will eat bread / Until you return to the ground, / Because from it you were taken; / For [xref]a[/xref]dust you are, / And [xref]b[/xref]to dust you shall return.
And the man called his wife's name [note]1[/note]Eve, because she was the mother of [xref]a[/xref]all living.
verse.note: Meaning [i]living.[/i] God's announcing of the glad tidings in [link]v. 15[/link] concerning the seed of the woman destroying the serpent was the first instance of the proclaiming of the gospel in the entire Bible. After hearing the glad tidings, Adam believed that he and Eve would live and not die (cf. [link]John 3:14-16[/link]); thus, he called his wife's name Eve, [i]living.[/i] Hence, God was the first preacher of the glad tidings of the gospel, and Adam was the first believer.

verse.text: And Jehovah God made coats of [note]1[/note]skin for Adam and for his wife and [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]clothed them.
verse.note: Probably the skins of lambs sacrificed as substitutes for the sinful Adam and Eve, with the shedding of blood for the forgiveness of sins ([link]Heb. 9:22[/link]). The killing of the lambs by God foreshadowed the substitutionary death of Christ as the Lamb of God, with the shedding of His precious blood for the accomplishing of redemption, based on which God justifies the believing sinners ([link]John 1:29[/link]; [link]Rev. 13:8b[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 1:18-20[/link]; [link]3:18a[/link]; [link]Eph. 1:7[/link]; [link]Rom. 3:24[/link]).[br][br]God's clothing Adam and his wife with the coats of skins means that God justified them through their faith ([link]Rom. 3:28[/link]). The coats are a type of Christ as God's righteousness to cover us that we might be justified by God ([link]Jer. 23:6[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 1:30[/link]). They were made by God and replaced the coverings of fig leaves sown by Adam ([link]v. 7[/link]). See note [link]22[sup]5[/sup] in Luke 15[/link].

Genuine substitution is based on union. After being clothed by God with a coat of lamb skins, Adam became one with the lamb. Thus, the sinner became one with the substitute. This is union. Union brings in the effectiveness of substitution. When we believe in the gospel, Christ is put upon us as our covering righteousness (cf. [link]Luke 15:22[/link]), and we are put into Christ ([link]1 Cor. 1:30[/link]), making us one with Christ. Since we are one with Christ, whatever He has accomplished on the cross becomes ours. To believe in Jesus Christ is to be one with Him, to enter into a union with Him (see note [link]16[sup]2[/sup] in John 3[/link]). In such a union, whatever Christ is, whatever He has, whatever He has done and will do, and whatever He has attained and obtained are ours. See notes [link]14[sup]3[/sup], par. 2, in ch. 6[/link]; [link]18[sup]1[/sup], par. 2, in ch. 8[/link]; [link]22[sup]2[/sup] in Exo. 12[/link]; and [link]2[sup]2[/sup] in 1 John 2[/link].[br][br]The main items of the gospel are seen in [link]vv. 15[/link] and [link]21[/link], which indicate that God, the Creator of man, became man's Savior after man's fall by becoming a human seed to die in order to destroy Satan, to redeem fallen man, and to become man's righteousness before God that he might be justified and be in God to be one with Him.

verse.text: And Jehovah God said, Behold, the man has become like one of [xref]a[/xref]Us, knowing good and evil; and now, [note]1[/note]lest he put forth his hand and take also from the [xref]b[/xref]tree of life and eat and live forever —
verse.note: Although Adam and Eve had the anticipated redemption, they did not yet have the actual redemption, which was accomplished by Christ on the cross. They were still sinful in nature. If they had eaten of the tree of life while in that condition, they would have lived forever with their sinful nature. God did not allow that. The tree of life, signifying God as life to man, must not be touched by sinful man. Thus, before the actual redemption was accomplished, God had to close the way to the tree of life. Once the actual redemption was completed to take away man's sin ([link]John 1:29[/link]) and terminate man's sinful nature ([link]John 3:14[/link] and note; [link]Rom. 8:3[/link] and note 3), access to the tree of life would again be possible ([link]Rev. 22:14[/link]).

verse.text: Then Jehovah God sent him forth from the garden of Eden, to work the [xref]a[/xref]ground from which he was taken.

So He drove the man out, and at the east of the garden of Eden He placed the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]cherubim and a [note]1[/note]flaming sword which turned in every direction to guard the way to the [xref]b[/xref]tree of life.
verse.note: God closed the way to the tree of life by means of three items: the cherubim, the flame, and the sword. Cherubim signify God's glory (cf. [link]Ezek. 9:3[/link]; [link]10:4[/link]; [link]Heb. 9:5[/link]), the flame signifies God's holiness ([link]Deut. 4:24[/link]; [link]9:3[/link]; [link]Heb. 12:29[/link]), and the sword for killing indicates God's righteousness (cf. [link]Lam. 3:42-43[/link]; [link]Rom. 2:5[/link]). These attributes of God placed requirements on sinful man. Since sinful man was unable to meet these requirements ([link]Rom. 3:10-18[/link], [link]23[/link]), he was not permitted to contact God as the tree of life, until Christ fulfilled the requirements of God's glory, holiness, and righteousness by His all-inclusive death on the cross to open a new and living way for us to enter the Holy of Holies and partake of the tree of life ([link]Heb. 10:19-20[/link] and note [link]20[sup]2[/sup][/link]; [link]Rev. 22:14[/link] and note 4).

verse.text: And the man knew Eve his wife, and she conceived and gave birth to [note]1[/note]Cain and said, I have [xref]a[/xref]acquired a man, [note]2[/note]Jehovah.
verse.note: Meaning [i]acquired.[/i]
Or, with [i]the help of[/i] Jehovah.

verse.text: And again she gave birth, to his brother [note]1[/note]Abel. And Abel was a [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]tender of sheep, but Cain was a [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]tiller of the ground.
verse.note: Meaning [i]breath[/i] or [i]vanity.[/i] As a result of man's first fall, everything in human life became vanity ([link]Eccl. 1:2-3[/link]).

Or, a shepherd, a feeder. Before the flood man was permitted to eat only fruits and vegetables ([link]1:29[/link]; [link]3:18[/link]), not meat (cf. [link]9:3[/link]). Thus, Abel's tending of sheep was not to produce food for his living but to provide offerings for God's satisfaction. Abel not only believed the gospel (see note [link]4[sup]1[/sup][/link]) but also practiced the gospel and lived for it.
Or, laborer. In his occupation Abel took care only of God's satisfaction, whereas Cain cared only for his own living.

verse.text: And in the course of time Cain brought an [note]1[/note]offering to Jehovah from the fruit of the ground.
verse.note: Cain did not follow the way of God's salvation through the anticipated redemption by the bleeding sacrifice ([link]3:21[/link]; [link]Heb. 9:22[/link]) but continued man's fall by presumptuously offering the fruit of his own labor to God. Cain's way of worshipping God was to invent a religion according to his human concept and opinion ([link]Jude 11[/link] and note 1), which were motivated by Satan, the subtle one ([link]v. 7[/link] and note; [link]1 John 3:12[/link]). Throughout the centuries and generations there have been countless followers of Cain, people in every place and time who have invented their own religion.

verse.text: And Abel also brought [i]an [note]1[/note]offering,[/i] from the [xref]a[/xref]firstlings of his flock, that is, from their fat portions. And Jehovah had regard for Abel and for his offering.
verse.note: According to [link]Heb. 11:4[/link], Abel's offering, a sacrifice, was offered to God by faith. Faith comes by hearing the word of the gospel ([link]Rom. 10:17[/link], [link]14[/link]). This indicates that Abel's parents, Adam and Eve, must have proclaimed to their children the glad tidings that God had announced to them ([link]3:15[/link], [link]21[/link]). Like his father and mother, Abel believed the gospel and presented his offering to God according to God's revelation in the word proclaimed by his parents. Thus, the first family on earth was a family of the gospel, a family of believers.[br][br]Abel was the first priest of God, representing all the believers in Christ ([link]1 Pet. 2:5[/link], [link]9[/link]). In type, Abel offered Christ to God. According to [link]Num. 18:17[/link], the firstling of a cow or sheep or goat, a type of Christ, had to be offered to God. This offering included the sprinkling of the blood upon the altar for redemption and the burning of the fat as a satisfying fragrance to God. Hence, Abel's offering, corresponding exactly with what was later revealed in the Mosaic law, proves that his way of worshipping God was according to God's divine revelation, not according to his own concept.

verse.text: But for [xref]a[/xref]Cain and for his offering He had [note]1[/note]no regard. And Cain became very angry, and his countenance fell.
verse.note: Cain rejected God's way of taking Christ as God's righteousness to cover him ([link]3:21[/link]; [link]Phil. 3:9[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 1:30[/link]). Like the religious Jews, he sought to establish his own righteousness, ignoring God's righteousness and not submitting to it ([link]Rom. 10:3[/link]). Thus, his offering was an insult to God, and God rejected it.

chapter.verse: And Jehovah said to Cain, Why are you angry, and why has your countenance fallen?

verse.text: If you do well, will not [i]your countenance[/i] be lifted up? And if you do not do well, [note]1[/note]sin is crouching at the door; and his desire is for you, but you must rule over him.
verse.note: Sin and Satan are one (Rom. 7:8 and note). If we reject God's way of salvation, Satan as sin is crouching at the door, waiting for the opportunity to seize and devour us (cf. [link]Luke 22:31[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 5:8[/link]).

verse.text: And Cain said to Abel his brother, [note]1[/note]Let us go into the field. And when they were in the field, Cain rose up against Abel his brother and [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]slew him.
verse.note: This clause is present in many ancient versions but lacking in the Hebrew text.

Cain murdered his brother because of his anger provoked by his religious jealousy ([link]vv. 4-5[/link]).
