Throughout the generations those who worship God according to the flesh have opposed, persecuted, and even murdered those who worship according to the Spirit ([link]Matt. 23:35[/link]; [link]John 16:2[/link]; [link]Rev. 17:6[/link]; cf. [link]Gal. 4:29[/link]). In his offering to God and his murdering his brother, Cain was on the line of the tree of the knowledge of good and evil. In contrast, Abel was on the line of the tree of life. See note [link]9[sup]3[/sup], par. 2, in ch. 2[/link].

verse.text: Then Jehovah said to Cain, Where is Abel your brother? And he said, [note]1[/note]I do not know. Am I my brother's keeper?
verse.note: This lie showed Cain's arrogance toward God. Cain's murdering of Abel and his lying to God were alluded to by the Lord Jesus in [link]John 8:44[/link], indicating that in the acts of murdering and lying, Cain was one with the Devil, Satan, who was his source ([link]1 John 3:12[/link]). Because Cain had rejected God's way and God's warning ([link]v. 7[/link]), he was gained by Satan, the murderer and the liar, and became a murderer and a liar with Satan.

verse.text: And He said, What have you done? The voice of your brother's [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]blood is crying out to Me from the ground.
verse.note: Both the blood of Abel and the blood of Jesus speak ([link]Heb. 12:24[/link] and note 3). Abel's blood spoke from the earth; Jesus' blood speaks from heaven.

verse.text: And now you are [xref]a[/xref]cursed from the ground, which has opened its mouth to receive your brother's [xref]b[/xref]blood from your hand.
When you till the ground, it will no longer yield its strength to you. You will be a fugitive and a [xref]a[/xref]wanderer on the earth.

chapter.verse: And Cain said to Jehovah, My punishment is greater than I can bear.

verse.text: Now You have driven me out this day from the face of the ground, and from Your [xref]a[/xref]face I will be hidden; and I will be a fugitive and a wanderer on the earth, and whoever finds me will [xref]b[/xref]kill me.

chapter.verse: And Jehovah said to him, Therefore whoever kills Cain, vengeance will be taken on him sevenfold. And Jehovah put a mark on Cain, so that anyone who found him would not strike him.

verse.text: And Cain went forth from the presence of Jehovah and dwelt in the land of [note]1[/note]Nod, east of Eden.
verse.note: Meaning [i]wandering.[/i]

verse.text: And Cain knew his wife, and she conceived and gave birth to [note]1[/note]Enoch; and he built a [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]city and called the name of the city after the name of his son Enoch.
verse.note: Meaning [i]initiated, dedicated, trained.[/i]

After leaving God's presence ([link]v. 16[/link]), Cain constructed a city for his protection and self-existence. Within this city he produced a culture without God. In the garden God was everything to man — his protection, maintenance, supply, and amusement. When man lost God, he lost everything. Man's loss of God forced man to invent human culture, the main elements of which were cities for existence, cattle-raising for making a living, music for amusement, and weapons for defense ([link]vv. 20-22[/link]). The godless culture invented in [link]Gen. 4[/link] will continue to develop until it climaxes in the great Babylon ([link]Rev. 17-18[/link]).

chapter.verse: And Irad was born to Enoch, and Irad begot Mehujael, and Mehujael begot Methushael, and Methushael begot Lamech.
And Lamech took two wives for himself: The name of the first was Adah, and the name of the second Zillah.
And Adah gave birth to Jabal; he was the father of those who dwell in tents and [i]raise[/i] cattle.
And his brother's name was Jubal; he was the father of all those who play the lyre and pipe.
And Zillah also gave birth to Tubal-cain, the forger of every cutting instrument of bronze and iron; and the sister of Tubal-cain was Naamah.
And Lamech said to his wives,[br/]Adah and Zillah, listen to my voice; / O wives of Lamech, hearken to my speech; / For I have slain a man for wounding me, / Even a young man for striking me.

verse.text: If Cain is avenged [xref]a[/xref]sevenfold, / Then Lamech seventy-sevenfold.

And Adam knew his wife again. And she gave birth to a son and called his name [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Seth, for, [i]she said,[/i] God has appointed me another seed instead of Abel, because Cain slew him.
verse.note: Meaning [i]appointed.[/i] After the martyrdom of Abel, God appointed Seth to replace Abel in taking God's way of salvation.

verse.text: And to Seth also a son was born, and he called his name [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Enosh. At that time [i]men[/i] began to [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]call upon the name of Jehovah.
verse.note: Meaning [i]frail, mortal man.[/i]

The Hebrew word means [i]to call out to, to cry unto,[/i] i.e., to cry out audibly. Because men realized that their life was vanity (see note [link]2[sup]1[/sup][/link]) and that they were frail and mortal (see note [link]26[sup]1[/sup][/link]), they spontaneously began to call upon the name of Jehovah, the eternal One (see note [link]4[sup]4[/sup] in ch. 2[/link]). Although they were vain and weak, by calling on the name of the Lord, they were made rich and strong, for they entered into the riches and strength of the One on whom they called ([link]Rom. 10:12-13[/link] and notes). See note [link]21[sup]1[/sup] in Acts 2[/link].

verse.text: This is the book of the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]generations of Adam. [note]2[/note]When God [xref]b[/xref]created Adam, He made him in the [note]3[/note]likeness of God.
verse.note: The genealogy recorded in this chapter includes the first ten generations of mankind, from Adam to Noah. According to [link]Luke 3:23-38[/link], human genealogy began with God and issued in Jesus Christ.[br][br]The history in the entire Old Testament is the Triune God's preparation for the carrying out of His eternal economy. This preparation was initiated in a man, Adam ([link]1:1-11:26[/link]), and eventually issued in three persons, Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob with Joseph ([link]11:27-50:26[/link]), who resulted in one people, Israel (Exo.-Mal.). The thirty-nine books of the Old Testament reveal the preparation for bringing forth Christ, the God-man, the complete God mingled with the perfect man ([link]Matt. 1[/link]), for the producing of the Body of Christ ([link]Eph. 1-4[/link]), the organism of the processed and consummated Triune God ([link]Eph. 4:4-6[/link]). The Body of Christ will consummate in the New Jerusalem ([link]Rev. 21:1-23[/link]) as the eternal enlargement of Christ (cf. [link]John 3:30[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 12:12[/link]), the eternal mingling of the Triune God with the tripartite man and the mutual dwelling of God and man ([link]Rev. 21:3[/link], [link]22[/link]) for the expression of the processed and consummated Triune God in His nature and glory ([link]Rev. 21:18b[/link], [link]21b[/link], [link]10-11[/link], [link]23[/link]) in the redeemed, regenerated, transformed, and glorified tripartite man for eternity.
Lit., In the day.
See note [link]26[sup]3[/sup], par. 1, in ch. 1[/link].

verse.text: Male and female He created them, and He [xref]a[/xref]blessed them and called [note]1[/note]their name Adam, on the day when they were created.
verse.note: See note [link]26[sup]4[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].

verse.text: And Adam [note]1[/note]lived one hundred thirty years and [note]1[/note]begot [i]a son[/i] in his likeness according to his image, and he called his name [xref]a[/xref]Seth.
verse.note: This genealogy does not record the deeds and activities of the people; it records only that they lived and begot. Man's living and begetting were for man's multiplication ([link]1:28a[/link]) to fulfill God's eternal purpose through mankind. Likewise, in the spiritual sense the believers today should live and beget ([link]1 Cor. 4:15[/link]) for God's multiplication ([link]John 1:12-13[/link]) to fulfill God's purpose through the church.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]And the days of Adam after he had begotten Seth were eight hundred years, and he begot [i]more[/i] sons and daughters.
And all the days that Adam lived were nine hundred thirty years, and he [note]1[/note]died.
verse.note: See note [link]12[sup]4[/sup] in Rom. 5[/link].

verse.text: And Seth lived one hundred five years and begot [xref]a[/xref]Enosh.

chapter.verse: And Seth lived after he had begotten Enosh eight hundred seven years, and he begot [i]more[/i] sons and daughters.
And all the days of Seth were nine hundred twelve years, and he died.
And Enosh lived ninety years and begot Kenan.
And Enosh lived after he had begotten Kenan eight hundred fifteen years, and he begot [i]more[/i] sons and daughters.
And all the days of Enosh were nine hundred five years, and he died.
And Kenan lived seventy years and begot Mahalalel.
And Kenan lived after he had begotten Mahalalel eight hundred forty years, and he begot [i]more[/i] sons and daughters.
And all the days of Kenan were nine hundred ten years, and he died.
And Mahalalel lived sixty-five years and begot Jared.
And Mahalalel lived after he had begotten Jared eight hundred thirty years, and he begot [i]more[/i] sons and daughters.
And all the days of Mahalalel were eight hundred ninety-five years, and he died.

verse.text: And Jared lived a hundred sixty-two years and begot [xref]a[/xref]Enoch.

chapter.verse: And Jared lived after he had begotten Enoch eight hundred years, and he begot [i]more[/i] sons and daughters.
And all the days of Jared were nine hundred sixty-two years, and he died.

verse.text: And Enoch lived sixty-five years and begot [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Methuselah.
verse.note: Meaning when he is dead, it will be sent. This name has a prophetic significance. By naming his son Methuselah, Enoch prophesied of the coming of the flood in the year that Methuselah died, which was Noah's six hundredth year ([link]7:6[/link]; [link]5:25-29a[/link]). Enoch had received the revelation from God that He would judge the entire ungodly generation of mankind (cf. [link]Jude 14-15[/link]). This motivated Enoch not to follow the current of the age but to walk with God ([link]vv. 22[/link], [link]24[/link]) and thus live a godly and holy life (cf. [link]2 Pet. 3:10-12[/link]).

verse.text: And Enoch [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]walked with God after he had begotten Methuselah three hundred years, and he begot [i]more[/i] sons and daughters.
verse.note: To walk with God is to take Him as our center and everything, to do things not according to our own concept and desire but according to His revelation and leading, and to do everything with Him. This implies the denying of our self and everything that is of our self ([link]Matt. 16:24-25[/link]) that we may be one with Him.

chapter.verse: And all the days of Enoch were three hundred sixty-five years.

verse.text: And Enoch walked with God, and he was not, for God [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]took him.
verse.note: Enoch was the first person to be raptured. By this he escaped death, the ultimate issue of man's fall ([link]Heb. 11:5[/link]). This first mentioning of the rapture establishes the principle of the rapture: our being raptured depends on our being mature in the divine life by our walking with God. Enoch walked with God day and night for three hundred years. According to [link]Heb. 11:5-6[/link], he did this by faith, believing that God is and that He is a rewarder of those who diligently seek Him. After three hundred years of seeking God and walking with Him, Enoch was taken by God, thus obtaining the reward of not seeing death.

chapter.verse: And Methuselah lived one hundred eighty-seven years and begot Lamech.
And Methuselah lived after he had begotten Lamech seven hundred eighty-two years, and he begot [i]more[/i] sons and daughters.
And all the days of Methuselah were nine hundred sixty-nine years, and he died.
And Lamech lived a hundred eighty-two years and begot a son.

verse.text: And he called his name [note]1[/note]Noah, saying, This one will [note]2[/note]give us rest from our work and from the toil of our hands, [i]which come[/i] because of the ground which Jehovah has [xref]a[/xref]cursed.
verse.note: Meaning [i]rest[/i] or [i]comfort.[/i]
Or, comfort us in our work.

chapter.verse: And Lamech lived after he had begotten Noah five hundred ninety-five years, and he begot [i]more[/i] sons and daughters.
And all the days of Lamech were seven hundred seventy-seven years, and he died.

verse.text: And Noah was five hundred years old. And Noah [xref]a[/xref]begot Shem, Ham, and Japheth.

chapter.verse: And when men began to multiply on the surface of the ground, and daughters were born to them,

verse.text: The [note]1[/note]sons of God saw that the daughters of men were fair; and they [note]2[/note]took wives for themselves from all whom they chose.
verse.note: The sons of God here are the fallen angels (cf. [link]Job 1:6[/link]; [link]2:1[/link]; [link]38:7[/link]) who joined Satan in his rebellion against God ([link]Rev. 12:4[/link]) and became the rulers and authorities in Satan's dark kingdom ([link]Matt. 12:26[/link]; [link]Eph. 6:12[/link]).

At the time of man's third fall, a number of the fallen angels in Satan's principality came down to the earth, took human bodies, and used these bodies to form illegal marriages with the daughters of men, thus polluting the human race by mixing it with the fallen spirits. According to [link]Jude 6-7[/link] (see notes [link book="Jude" chapter="1"]6[sup]1[/sup][/link] and [link]7[sup]1[/sup][/link] there) the example set up by the fallen angels in committing fornication with different flesh was followed by Sodom and Gomorrah ([link]19:4-9[/link]; [link]Rom. 1:27[/link]).

verse.text: And Jehovah said, My [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Spirit will not strive with man forever, for he indeed is [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]flesh; so his days will be [xref]c[/xref]one hundred twenty years.
verse.note: This is the second mentioning of the Spirit in this book (cf. [link]1:2[/link]). Before this time God's Spirit was graciously working and striving with man to counter man's rebellion and fall. Nevertheless, here a point was reached when the Spirit of God would strive with man no longer, signifying God's forsaking of man.

In man's first fall man did not exercise his spirit (see note [link]6[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 3[/link]); in the second fall he over-exercised his soul, inventing a new religion (see note [link]3[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 4[/link]). In the third fall man abused the fallen body and became flesh, full of lusts, fornication, and violence ([link]vv. 2[/link], [link]5[/link], [link]11[/link]). The fallen flesh is the strongest and most evil enemy of God ([link]Rom. 7:5-8:13[/link]) and is thoroughly and absolutely hated by God. At the time of the third fall the entire human race became flesh. Thus, God stepped in and told His servant Noah that He would destroy that whole generation ([link]vv. 7[/link], [link]13[/link]). This is a prefigure of the age immediately preceding the Lord's coming back ([link]Matt. 24:37-39[/link]).

verse.text: The [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Nephilim were on the earth in those days — and also afterward — when the sons of God came in to the daughters of men, and they bore children to them; these were the mighty men who were of old the men of renown.
verse.note: Or, giants. The word means [i]the fallen ones.[/i] The illegal marriage between fallen angels and the human race produced Nephilim, giants, "the mighty men who were of old the men of renown" (cf. [link]Num. 13:32-33[/link]). God sent the flood to exterminate Noah's generation because that generation had become impure. For the sake of the fulfillment of His purpose, God could not allow such a human race to exist.

verse.text: And Jehovah saw that the [xref]a[/xref]wickedness of man was great in the earth, and that every [note]1[/note]imagination of the thoughts of his [xref]b[/xref]heart was only evil continually.
verse.note: Or, purpose, desire.

verse.text: And Jehovah [xref]a[/xref]repented that He had made man on the earth, and it [xref]b[/xref]grieved Him in His heart.

And Jehovah said, I will [xref]a[/xref]blot out the man whom I have created from the surface of the ground, from man to beast to creeping things to the birds of heaven; for I repent that I have made them.
[note]1[/note]But Noah [xref]a[/xref]found [note]2[/note]favor in the sight of Jehovah.
verse.note: Satan had corrupted man to the uttermost, and God had determined to destroy the man whom He had created for His purpose. Thus, it appeared that God was defeated. But Noah points to the sovereign factor that provided God a way to continue to carry out His original purpose with man. Through Noah's life and work God gained the victory over His enemy and changed the age. Cf. notes [link]8[sup]1[/sup] in Dan. 1[/link] and [link]4[sup]1[/sup] in Eph. 2[/link].

Or, grace. Noah was able to walk with God ([link]v. 9[/link]) in that crooked, perverted, and adulterous generation because he found grace (cf. [link]Heb. 4:16[/link]). Grace is God coming to us to be our life supply, our strength, and our everything (see note [link]10[sup]1[/sup] in 1 Cor. 15[/link]). Such grace enabled Noah to overcome the flesh and to live a righteous life ([link]Ezek. 14:14[/link]; cf. [link]Rom. 5:17-21[/link] and notes).

verse.text: These are the generations of Noah. Noah was a [xref]a[/xref]righteous man, blameless in his generations; [i]and[/i] Noah [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]walked with God.
verse.note: Like his great-grandfather Enoch ([link]5:22-24[/link]), Noah walked with God by faith ([link]Heb. 11:7[/link]), which was God's divine element transfused and infused into him to be his believing ability ([link]Rom. 3:22[/link] and note). As a result, he became heir of God's righteousness (cf. [link]Rom. 4:3[/link], [link]9[/link]) and a herald of righteousness ([link]2 Pet. 2:5[/link]) as a protest against the evil generation. Noah's righteousness strengthened God's standing to execute His judgment upon that ungodly generation.

chapter.verse: And Noah begot three sons: Shem, Ham, and Japheth.
And the earth was corrupt before God, and the earth was filled with violence.
And God looked on the earth, and behold, it was corrupt; for all flesh had corrupted its way upon the earth.
And God said to Noah, The end of all flesh has come before Me, for the earth is filled with violence because of them; and now I am about to destroy them with the earth.

verse.text: Make yourself an [note]1[/note]ark of [note]2[/note]gopher wood; you shall make rooms in the ark and shall cover it within and without with [note]3[/note]pitch.
verse.note: The ark is a type of Christ ([link]1 Pet. 3:20-21[/link]), not only the individual Christ but also the corporate Christ, the church, which is the Body of Christ and the new man ([link]1 Cor. 12:12[/link]; [link]Eph. 2:15-16[/link]; [link]Col. 3:10-11[/link]). The building of the ark typifies the building of the corporate Christ, with the element of Christ's riches as the building material, by those who work together with God ([link]1 Cor. 3:9-12a[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 6:1[/link]; [link]Eph. 3:8-10[/link]; [link]4:12[/link]). By building the ark and entering into it, Noah was not only saved from God's judgment on the evil generation through the flood, but was also separated from that generation and ushered into a new age ([link]1 Pet. 3:20[/link] and note 3). Likewise, by building the church and entering into the church life, we will be saved from God's judgment on today's evil generation through the great tribulation ([link]Matt. 24:37-39[/link]; [link]Luke 17:26-27[/link]; [link]1 Thes. 5:3[/link]) and will be separated from that generation ([link]Luke 21:36[/link]; [link]Rev. 3:10[/link]) and ushered into a new age, the age of the millennium.
A kind of cypress, a resinous wood that can withstand the attack of water. It is a figure of the crucified Christ, who can withstand the waters of death ([link]Acts 2:24[/link]).

The root of the words pitch in this verse and expiation elsewhere in the Old Testament means primarily to cover. The pitch here is a type of the redeeming blood of Christ, which covers God's building within and without ([link]Lev. 4:5-7[/link]; [link]6:30[/link]; [link]16:14-19[/link]; [link]Heb. 9:21[/link]). The pitch within the ark was for the peace of Noah and his family (cf. [link]Heb. 9:14[/link]), whereas the pitch without was for God's satisfaction (cf. [link]Exo. 12:13[/link]). Noah and his family were saved from the judgment of the flood by the pitch on the ark, signifying that the believers in Christ are saved from God's judgment by the redeeming blood of Christ ([link]Rom. 5:9[/link]).[br][br]In order for the pitch on the ark to be effective, Noah and his family had to be in the ark, i.e., in union with the ark. Likewise, in order to apply the redemption through Christ's blood, we must be in Christ, i.e., in union with Him by believing into Him ([link]John 3:16[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 1:30[/link]; [link]Eph. 1:7[/link]). See notes [link]21[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 3[/link], [link]22[sup]2[/sup] in Exo. 12[/link], and [link]2[sup]2[/sup] in 1 John 2[/link].

verse.text: And [note]1[/note]this is how you shall make it: The length of the ark shall be [note]2[/note]three hundred [note]3[/note]cubits, its width [note]2[/note]fifty cubits, and its height [note]2[/note]thirty cubits.
verse.note: Noah built the ark not according to his own imagination but absolutely according to God's revelation. Cf. [link]Exo. 25:9[/link]; [link]1 Chron. 28:11-19[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 3:10-12[/link]; [link]Eph. 2:20a[/link] and note 2.

The numbers three and five, seen here as components of the ark's dimensions, are basic numbers of God's building (cf. [link]Exo. 27[/link]). The number three signifies the Triune God in His dispensing of Himself into man ([link]Matt. 28:19[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 13:14[/link]; [link]Eph. 3:16-19[/link]). The number five is composed of four, signifying man as one of God's creatures ([link]Rev. 4:6-7[/link] and note [link]6[sup]2[/sup][/link]), plus one, signifying the one unique God ([link]Deut. 6:4[/link]; [link]Isa. 45:5[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 8:4[/link]). The significance of the numbers three and five is the mingling of the Triune God with man. This is God's building.[br][br]The dimensions of the ark are composed of three and five multiplied by either ten or one hundred. The number ten signifies completeness ([link]Dan. 1:12[/link], [link]20[/link]) and the number one hundred signifies fullness ([link]Matt. 13:23[/link]). This signifies that God's building is the mingling of the Triune God with man in completeness and fullness.
A cubit is approximately eighteen inches.

verse.text: You shall make an [note]1[/note]opening for light for the ark, and you shall finish it up to a cubit from the top; and you shall put the [note]2[/note]entrance of the ark in its side; you shall make it with [note]3[/note]lower, second, and third [i]stories.[/i]
verse.note: From the same root as the Hebrew word for [i]noon.[/i] In the ark there was only one window, toward the heavens, signifying that in the church, God's building, there is only one revelation and one vision ([link]Acts 2:42a[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 4:17[/link]; [link]1 Tim. 1:3-4[/link]) through the one New Testament ministry ([link]2 Cor. 3:6-9[/link]; [link]4:1[/link]). The light comes from above ([link]Acts 26:13-19[/link]).
There is only one door, one entrance into the ark. This one door typifies Christ ([link]John 10:9[/link]).

The three stories of the ark signify the Triune God according to our experience of Him: the Spirit, signified by the lower story, reaches us first and brings us to the Son ([link]1 Pet. 1:2[/link]; [link]John 16:8[/link], [link]13-15[/link]), and the Son brings us higher in our experience, to the Father ([link]John 14:6[/link]; [link]Eph. 2:18[/link]; see note [link]8[sup]2[/sup] in 1 John 4[/link]).

verse.text: And now I am about to bring a [xref]a[/xref]flood of water upon the earth to destroy from under heaven all flesh in which is the breath of life; everything that is on the earth shall die.
But I will establish My [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]covenant with you, and you shall come into the ark, you and your sons and your wife and your sons' wives with you.
verse.note: See note [link]9[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 9[/link].

chapter.verse: And of every living thing, of all flesh, two of every kind you shall bring into the ark to preserve them alive with you; they shall be male and female.

Of the birds according to their kind and of the cattle according to their kind, of every creeping thing of the ground according to its kind, two of every kind will come to you in order to preserve them alive.
And for your part, take some of every kind of food that is edible, and gather it to yourself, and it will be for food for you and for them.

verse.text: And [xref]a[/xref]Noah did this; according to all that God [xref]b[/xref]commanded him, so he did.
Then Jehovah said to Noah, Come into the ark, you and all your household, for you [i]alone[/i] I have seen [i]to be[/i] [xref]a[/xref]righteous before Me in this generation.
Of every [xref]a[/xref]clean animal you shall take with you seven pairs, a male and its female; and of the animals that are not clean two, a male and its female;
Also of the birds of heaven, seven pairs, male and female; to [note]1[/note]preserve [i]their[/i] offspring alive on the surface of all the earth.
verse.note: The ark was not only for the salvation of man but also for the salvation of all living creatures. See [link]Col. 1:20[/link] and note 2; [link]Heb. 2:9[/link] and note 3; and [link]Mark 16:15[/link] and note 2.

verse.text: For in seven more days I will cause it to rain on the earth [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]forty days and forty nights, and every living being that I have made I will blot out from the surface of the ground.
verse.note: Forty is the number for trials, temptations, and sufferings ([link]Heb. 3:9[/link]; [link]Matt. 4:2[/link]; [link]1 Kings 19:8[/link]).

chapter.verse: And Noah did according to all that Jehovah commanded him.

verse.text: And Noah was [note]1[/note]six hundred years old when the [xref]a[/xref]flood of waters came upon the earth.
verse.note: See note [link]21[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 5[/link].

verse.text: And Noah and his sons and his wife and his sons' wives with him [xref]a[/xref]went into the ark because of the waters of the flood.

chapter.verse: Of clean animals and of animals that are not clean and of birds and of everything that creeps upon the ground,
Two by two they came into the ark to Noah, male and female, as God had commanded Noah.
And after the seven days the waters of the flood came upon the earth.

verse.text: In the six hundredth year of Noah's life, in the second month, on the seventeenth day of the month, on that very day all the [xref]a[/xref]springs of the great deep burst open, and the [xref]b[/xref]windows of heaven were opened.

chapter.verse: And the rain fell upon the earth forty days and forty nights.
On that very same day Noah and Shem and Ham and Japheth, the sons of Noah, and Noah's wife and the three wives of his sons with them entered the ark,

They and every animal according to its kind and all the cattle according to their kind and every creeping thing that creeps upon the earth according to its kind and every bird according to its kind — every bird, every winged creature.

verse.text: And they went into the ark to Noah, [xref]a[/xref]two by two of all flesh in which was the breath of life.
And those who went in, male and female of all flesh, went in as God had commanded him; and Jehovah [note]1[/note]shut [i]the door[/i] behind him.
verse.note: Noah's entering into the ark ([link]v. 13[/link]) is a type of our entering into Christ. God's shutting Noah in indicates that, although we are free to enter into Christ, once we are in, we have no way to get out. Once we believe into the Lord Jesus, we are "shut in" by God with no way to get out of Him ([link]John 10:28-29[/link] and note [link]28[sup]1[/sup][/link]).

verse.text: And the flood was on the earth [xref]a[/xref]forty days; and the [note]1[/note]waters increased and lifted up the ark, and it rose high above the earth.
verse.note: The water through which Noah passed was a figure of the water of baptism ([link]1 Pet. 3:20-21[/link] and note [link]21[sup]1[/sup][/link]). The pitch on the ark saved Noah from the judgment of the flood (see note [link]14[sup]3[/sup] in ch. 6[/link]), whereas the water of the flood not only judged the world but also separated Noah from the evil age (cf. [link]Gal. 1:4[/link]; [link]Acts 2:40-41[/link]). In the same manner, the water of the Red Sea judged the Egyptians and saved the children of Israel from the Egyptian age ([link]Exo. 14:26-30[/link]). The water of baptism symbolizes the death of Christ, which judged Satan and the world ([link]Rom. 6:3[/link]; [link]John 12:31[/link]) and which also saves the believers from the condemned world and the satanic power of darkness ([link]Gal. 6:14[/link]; [link]Heb. 2:14[/link]).

chapter.verse: And the waters prevailed and increased greatly upon the earth, and the ark went about on the surface of the waters.

verse.text: And when the waters had prevailed exceedingly upon the earth, all the high mountains that were under the entire heaven were [xref]a[/xref]covered.

chapter.verse: The waters prevailed fifteen cubits higher, once the mountains were covered.

verse.text: And all [xref]a[/xref]flesh that moved upon the earth expired: birds and cattle and animals and every swarming thing that swarms upon the earth and all mankind.
Everything in whose nostrils was the [xref]a[/xref]breath of the spirit of life, of all that was on the dry land, died.

Thus He blotted out every living being that was upon the surface of the ground, from man to beast to creeping things to the birds of heaven; and they were blotted out from the earth. And only [xref]a[/xref]Noah was left, and those who were with him in the ark.

chapter.verse: And the waters prevailed upon the earth one hundred fifty days.

verse.text: And God [xref]a[/xref]remembered Noah and all the animals and all the cattle that were with him in the ark; and God made a [xref]b[/xref]wind pass over the earth, and the waters subsided.
The [xref]a[/xref]springs of the deep and the windows of heaven were also stopped, and the rain from the heavens was restrained.
And the waters receded steadily from upon the earth. So at the end of [xref]a[/xref]one hundred fifty days the waters began to diminish.
And the ark came to [note]1[/note]rest in the seventh month, on the seventeenth day of the month, upon the mountains of Ararat.
verse.note: The ark's passing through the water of death and coming to rest on the mountains of Ararat is a type of Christ's passing through death and resurrecting out of death.

chapter.verse: And the waters diminished steadily until the tenth month. In the tenth month, on the first day of the month, the tops of the mountains were seen.
And at the end of forty days Noah opened the window of the ark which he had made.

verse.text: And he sent out the [note]1[/note]raven; and it went out, going to and fro until the waters had dried up from the earth.
verse.note: The raven is an unclean bird ([link]Lev. 11:15[/link]) because it feeds on carcasses, i.e., on death. The raven signifies the fleshly believers who love the world judged by God and return to it to feed on the things of death. The dove ([link]v. 8[/link]) is a clean bird because it feeds on seeds, i.e., on life. The dove signifies the spiritual believers who remain in the church life and care for life in the Spirit.

verse.text: And he sent out the [xref]a[/xref]dove from him to see if the waters had abated from the surface of the ground.

chapter.verse: But the dove found no resting place for the sole of her foot, so she returned to him to the ark, for the waters were on the surface of the whole earth. And he put out his hand and took her and brought her to himself into the ark.
And he waited yet another seven days, and again he sent out the dove from the ark.

verse.text: And the dove came to him toward evening time, and there in her beak was a freshly plucked [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]olive leaf. So Noah knew that the waters had abated from the earth.
verse.note: The olive is a type of the Spirit, and the fresh olive leaf signifies the new life in the Spirit. Thus, the olive leaf was a sign of life.

chapter.verse: And he waited yet another seven days and sent out the dove, and she did not return to him again.

And in the six hundred first year, in the first [i]month,[/i] the first day of the month, the water was dried up from the earth. And Noah removed the covering of the ark and saw that now the surface of the ground was dry.
And in the second month, on the twenty-seventh day of the month, the earth was dry.
And God spoke to Noah, saying,
Go forth from the ark, you and your wife and your sons and your sons' wives with you;

verse.text: Bring out with you every living thing that is with you of all flesh — birds and cattle and every creeping thing that creeps upon the earth — that they may swarm on the earth and be [xref]a[/xref]fruitful and multiply upon the earth.
So Noah [note]1[/note]went forth, as well as his sons and his wife and his sons' wives with him.
verse.note: Eight people emerged from the ark. Christ was resurrected on the first day of the week, i.e., the eighth day of the old week (see note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in John 20[/link]); thus, the number eight signifies resurrection. Since all the believers, the components of the church, were included in Christ's resurrection ([link]Eph. 2:6[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 1:3[/link]), they are the resurrected people. Hence, the living of Noah and his family after the flood signifies the living of the church in Christ's resurrection. This is a seed of the church life.[br][br]Eight persons were in the ark when it passed through the flood and when it came to rest on the mountain. Thus, whatever the ark experienced, they also experienced by being in the ark. This illustrates how the believers, by being in Christ ([link]1 Cor. 1:30[/link]; [link]Eph. 1:4[/link]), were crucified with Christ ([link]Rom. 6:6[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 5:14[/link]; [link]Gal. 2:20a[/link]) and also resurrected with Christ ([link]Eph. 2:6[/link]; [link]Col. 2:12[/link]; [link]3:1[/link]). Because we are in Christ, His experience has become ours.

chapter.verse: Every animal, every creeping thing, and every bird, everything that moves upon the earth, went forth from the ark according to their families.

verse.text: And Noah built an [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]altar to Jehovah and took of every [xref]b[/xref]clean beast and of every clean bird and [note]1[/note]offered [note]2[/note]burnt offerings on the altar.
verse.note: The altar is a type of the cross of Christ, and the offerings are types of the different aspects of Christ ([link]Lev. 1-7[/link] and notes). The building of an altar and the offering of offerings on it signify the offering of Christ to God through the cross. In the church life, the first thing we must do is not to work for God but to go to the cross to be terminated; then we need to experience Christ and offer to God the Christ whom we have experienced in different aspects for God's satisfaction. See note [link]38[sup]1[/sup] in Exo. 29[/link].
See note [link]3[sup]1[/sup] in Lev. 1[/link].

verse.text: And Jehovah smelled the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]satisfying fragrance; and Jehovah said in His heart, I will never again [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]curse the ground on account of man, for the imagination of man's [xref]c[/xref]heart is evil from his youth; [xref]d[/xref]nor will I ever again smite everything living as I have done.
verse.note: Or, soothing.

Man's fall brought in the curse ([link]3:17[/link]); the offering of Christ to God through the cross in the church life keeps the curse away and brings in the blessing ([link]v. 22[/link]; [link]Gal. 3:13-14[/link]). The ultimate curse is death, and the greatest blessing is life ([link]Psa. 133:3[/link]).

verse.text: Throughout all the days [i]that[/i] earth [i]remains,[/i] / [note]1[/note]Seed time and harvest, and cold and heat, / And summer and winter, and [xref]a[/xref]day and night / Shall not cease.
verse.note: Noah built an altar and offered burnt offerings (typifying Christ) to God to please Him ([link]vv. 20-21[/link]) so that the earth with its systems of nature could be preserved. The perpetual regularity of the different cycles in nature without end is God's guarantee that the order of the universe will be maintained for the preservation of the earth and the growth of all kinds of living things, that man may multiply endlessly and replenish the earth to fulfill God's eternal purpose ([link]1:26-28[/link]).

verse.text: And God [xref]a[/xref]blessed Noah and his sons and said to them, [note]1[/note]Be [xref]b[/xref]fruitful and multiply and fill the earth.
verse.note: This brought "resurrected" mankind back to God's original purpose, which was that man express God and represent Him (see notes [link chapter="1"]26[sup]3[/sup][/link] through [link]26[sup]5[/sup] in ch. 1[/link]). In the church life in Christ's resurrection we have been brought back to the beginning for the expression and representation of God.

verse.text: And the [xref]a[/xref]fear of you and the terror of you shall be upon every animal of the earth and upon every bird of heaven, on everything that creeps on the ground and on all the fish of the sea; into your hand they are delivered.
Every moving thing that lives shall be [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]food for you; just as [i]I gave you[/i] the green [xref]b[/xref]herb, so I have given you everything.
verse.note: Before the fall God ordained that man should eat only the plant life, the nourishing, generating life ([link]1:29[/link]). After the fall man needs to eat not only the plant life but also the animal life, which involves the shedding of blood and implies the need for redemption ([link]Heb. 9:22[/link]). See notes [link]51[sup]2[/sup] in John 6[/link] and [link]8[sup]1[/sup] in Exo. 12[/link].

verse.text: But flesh with its life, [i]that is,[/i] its [xref]a[/xref]blood, you shall not eat.
And indeed your lifeblood I will require; from every [xref]a[/xref]animal I will require it. And from [i]every[/i] man, from every man's brother, I will [xref]b[/xref]require the life of man.
[note]1[/note]Whoever sheds man's blood, / By man shall his blood be shed, / For in the [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]image of God / He made man.
verse.note: This was the beginning of human government. In the garden, before the fall, man was directly under the rule of God. After the fall, man was under the rule of his own conscience ([link]3:7-10[/link]). However, the rule of human conscience did not work well, and man fell further into wickedness ([link]6:5[/link], [link]11[/link]). Thus, after the flood, God authorized man to rule over other men, and human government began ([link]Rom. 13:1[/link] and notes 3 and 4).[br][br]At that time Noah was the deputy authority under God. This was a shadow of the kingdom of God, the reality of which is the church life in God's New Testament economy, and the manifestation of which will be the kingdom in the millennium (see notes [link]3[sup]4[/sup] in Matt. 5[/link] and [link]28[sup]1[/sup] in Heb. 12[/link]).
See note [link]26[sup]3[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].

verse.text: And you, be [xref]a[/xref]fruitful and multiply; / Abound on the earth and multiply in it.

chapter.verse: Then God spoke to Noah and to his sons with him, saying,

verse.text: And I Myself now establish My [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]covenant with you and with your seed after you
verse.note: In order to assure mankind that there would never again be a flood to destroy them and the earth, God made a covenant with Noah, with his seed, and with every living animal ([link]vv. 9-17[/link]). See notes [link]22[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 8[/link] and [link]6[sup]1[/sup] in Rev. 4[/link].

chapter.verse: And with every living animal that is with you: the birds, the cattle, and every animal of the earth with you, of all that came out of the ark, every animal of the earth.

verse.text: And I establish My covenant with you, that never again will all flesh be cut off by the [xref]a[/xref]waters of the flood, and never again will there be a flood to destroy the earth.
And God said, This is the [xref]a[/xref]sign of the covenant which I am making between Me and you and every living animal that is with you, for perpetual generations:
I set My [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]bow in the clouds, and it shall be for a sign of a covenant between Me and the earth.
verse.note: The rainbow signifies God's faithfulness in keeping His covenant. God Himself is faithfulness ([link]1 Cor. 1:9[/link]; [link]1 John 1:9[/link]). He is faithful to His word, and His word is His covenant. The rainbow is seen again at the end of the Bible ([link]Rev. 4:3[/link]), indicating that God's faithfulness will remain forever. See note [link]3[sup]3[/sup] in Rev. 4[/link], note [link]19[sup]1[/sup], par. 2, in Rev. 21[/link], and note [link]28[sup]1[/sup] in Ezek. 1[/link].

chapter.verse: And when I bring clouds over the earth, and the bow is seen in the clouds,

verse.text: I will [xref]a[/xref]remember My covenant which is between Me and you and every living animal of all flesh, and never again will the [xref]b[/xref]waters become a flood to destroy all flesh.
And the bow will be in the clouds, and I will look upon it to remember the [xref]a[/xref]everlasting covenant between God and every living animal of all flesh that is upon the earth.
And God said to Noah, This is the [xref]a[/xref]sign of the covenant which I have established between Me and all flesh that is upon the earth.

chapter.verse: Now the sons of Noah who came forth from the ark were Shem and Ham and Japheth. And Ham was the father of Canaan.

verse.text: These three were the sons of Noah, and [xref]a[/xref]from these the whole earth was spread over.

chapter.verse: And Noah began to be a farmer, and he planted a vineyard.

verse.text: And he drank of the wine and became drunk. And he [note]1[/note]uncovered himself inside his tent.
verse.note: This was Noah's failure, coming after the success in his work, which he experienced under God's blessing ([link]v. 1[/link]). Noah became drunk with the wine from his vineyards, and he was careless, becoming naked without realizing it. In spiritual experience, because of our fallen nature we must be covered whenever we come into God's presence ([link]3:7[/link], [link]21[/link]; [link]Exo. 20:25-26[/link]; [link]28:40-43[/link]). Spiritually, our covering is Christ ([link]Luke 15:22[/link]; [link]Gal. 3:27[/link]; [link]Psa. 45:13[/link]). To be naked spiritually is to lose Christ as our covering in the presence of God (cf. [link]Rom. 13:14[/link]).

verse.text: And Ham, the father of Canaan, saw the [xref]a[/xref]nakedness of his father and told his two brothers outside.

chapter.verse: And Shem and Japheth took a garment and laid [i]it[/i] upon both their shoulders, and they walked backward and covered the nakedness of their father. And their faces were [i]turned[/i] backward, so that they did not see their father's nakedness.
And Noah awoke from his wine and learned what his youngest son had done to him.

verse.text: And he said,[br/][note]1[/note]Cursed be Canaan: / A servant of servants / Shall he be to his brothers.
verse.note: As the father of his family and the leader of mankind, Noah was God's deputy authority on earth. Although Noah had failed, Ham's descendants were cursed because Ham exposed the failure of God's deputy authority ([link]v. 22[/link]) and thus touched God's government in a wrong way. Shem and Japheth were blessed because they respected God's government, covering the failure of the deputy authority and not looking at it ([link]v. 23[/link]). The failure of a leader in God's government is always a test to us. To expose a leader's failure causes us to be negatively involved with God's government and thus to lose God's blessing — see [link]Deut. 27:16[/link] (cf. [link]Eph. 6:2-3[/link]); [link]Num. 12:1-10[/link] and notes; [link]2 Sam. 15:10[/link]; [link]18:14-15[/link]. If we remain in a right position under God's government, a leader's failure will become our blessing.

verse.text: And he said,[br/]Blessed be Jehovah, / The God of [note]1[/note]Shem; / And let Canaan be his servant.
verse.note: Shem, Noah's first son, was the forefather of the Hebrews, the Jews (Abraham was a descendant of Shem — [link]11:10-26[/link]). In Noah's prophetic word concerning his three sons in [link]vv. 25-27[/link], Shem was blessed to have God as his God.

verse.text: May God enlarge Japheth, / And let him dwell in the [note]1[/note]tents of Shem, / And let Canaan be his servant.
verse.note: A tent is a place where people may dwell, rest, and have peace and enjoyment. Japheth's dwelling in the tents of Shem indicates that if Japheth and his descendants would be blessed and enjoy God as their rest, peace, enjoyment, and salvation, they must believe in the God of the Jews (cf. [link]John 4:22[/link]). When the Lord Jesus came as a seed of Abraham and a descendant of Shem, He became the tent, the tabernacle ([link]John 1:14[/link]), which will consummate in the New Jerusalem as the ultimate tent of Shem, the tabernacle of God with men for eternity, in which numerous Old Testament and New Testament saints from all the nations will dwell to participate in the eternal blessing of the eternal life ([link]Rev. 21:3[/link] and note).

chapter.verse: And Noah lived after the flood three hundred fifty years.
And all the days of Noah were nine hundred fifty years, and he died.
Now these are the generations of the sons of Noah, of Shem, Ham, and Japheth; and sons were born to them after the flood.

verse.text: The sons of [xref]a[/xref]Japheth: Gomer and Magog and Madai and Javan and Tubal and Meshech and Tiras.

chapter.verse: And the sons of Gomer: Ashkenaz and Riphath and Togarmah.

verse.text: And the sons of Javan: Elishah and Tarshish, Kittim and [note]1[/note]Rodanim.
verse.note: Some MSS read, Dodanim; cf. [link]1 Chron. 1:7[/link].

chapter.verse: From these the islands and coastal regions of the nations were separated into their lands, every one according to his tongue, according to their families, in their nations.

verse.text: And the sons of [xref]a[/xref]Ham: Cush and [note]1[/note]Mizraim and Put and Canaan.
verse.note: I.e., Egypt.

chapter.verse: And the sons of Cush: Seba and Havilah and Sabtah and Raamah and Sabtecha. And the sons of Raamah: Sheba and Dedan.

verse.text: And Cush begot [note]1[/note]Nimrod: He began to be a mighty one on the earth.
verse.note: Nimrod, the first type of Antichrist, was the first to oppose God. According to history, Nimrod brought in many idolatrous things ([link]Jer. 7:18[/link] and note). Human government formed in opposition to God began with Nimrod and will end with Antichrist ([link]Jer. 50:1[/link] and note; [link]Dan. 2:32-35[/link] and notes). The cities of Babel and Nineveh, built by Nimrod ([link]vv. 10-11[/link]), became the capitals of the nations of Babylon and Assyria, two strong figures of mankind in their opposing of God.

chapter.verse: He was a mighty hunter before Jehovah; therefore it is said, Like Nimrod, a mighty hunter before Jehovah.

verse.text: And the beginning of his kingdom was [xref]a[/xref]Babel and Erech and Akkad and Calneh, in the land of [xref]b[/xref]Shinar.

chapter.verse: From that land he went into Assyria and built Nineveh and Rehoboth-ir and Calah
And Resen between Nineveh and Calah, that is, the great city.
And Mizraim begot the Ludim and the Anamim and the Lehabim and the Naphtuhim
And the Pathrusim and the Casluhim, from which came the Philistines, and the Caphtorim.
And Canaan begot Sidon his firstborn and Heth
And the Jebusites and the Amorites and the Girgashites
And the Hivites and the Arkites and the Sinites
And the Arvadites and the Zemarites and the Hamathites, and afterward the families of the Canaanites were spread out.
And the territory of the Canaanites was from Sidon, as you go toward Gerar, as far as Gaza, [i]and[/i] as you go toward Sodom and Gomorrah and Admah and Zeboiim, as far as Lasha.
These are the sons of Ham, according to their families, according to their tongues, in their lands, in their nations.
And also to Shem, the father of all the children of Eber, the eldest brother of Japheth, children were born.

verse.text: The sons of [xref]a[/xref]Shem: Elam and Asshur and Arpachshad and Lud and Aram.

chapter.verse: And the sons of Aram: Uz and Hul and Gether and Mash.
And Arpachshad begot Shelah, and Shelah begot Eber.

verse.text: And to [xref]a[/xref]Eber were born two sons: The name of the one was [note]1[/note]Peleg, for in his days the earth was divided; and his brother's name was Joktan.
verse.note: Meaning [i]division.[/i] The seed of division among mankind is sown here. After the flood God gave man authority to rule others that there might be peace among men (see note [link]6[sup]1[/sup], par. 1, in ch. 9[/link]), but Satan caused man to abuse his God-given authority to form nations that man may have his own dominion, thus denying God's right and authority over man.[br][br]The forming of the nations in this chapter, which issued in Babel ([link]ch. 11[/link]), prefigures the forming of the divisions and denominations in Christianity, which will eventually consummate in Babylon the Great with her daughters ([link]Rev. 17[/link]).

chapter.verse: And Joktan begot Almodad and Sheleph and Hazarmaveth and Jerah
And Hadoram and Uzal and Diklah
And Obal and Abimael and Sheba
And Ophir and Havilah and Jobab; all these were the sons of Joktan.
And their dwelling was from Mesha, as you go toward Sephar, the hill country of the east.
These are the sons of Shem, according to their families, according to their tongues, in their lands, according to their nations.
These are the families of the sons of Noah, according to their generations, in their nations; and from these the nations were separated on the earth after the flood.
And the whole earth had one language and the same speech.

verse.text: And as they journeyed east, they found a plain in the land of [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Shinar; and they dwelt there.
verse.note: I.e., Babylon.

verse.text: And they said to one another, Come, let us [xref]a[/xref]make [note]1[/note]bricks and burn [i]them[/i] thoroughly. And they had brick for stone, and they had tar for mortar.
verse.note: God's building is of stones ([link]1 Kings 6:7[/link]; [link]Matt. 16:18[/link]; [link]John 1:42[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 3:12a[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 2:5[/link]; [link]Rev. 21:18-20[/link]), which are produced by God's divine work through creation and transformation, whereas the building of the city and tower of Babel was of bricks (cf. [link]Exo. 1:11[/link], [link]14a[/link]), which are the result of human labor through the burning of the God-created earth.[br][br]The earth is for growing life ([link]1:11[/link]). To make bricks is to kill, to burn, the element of the earth that grows life. In figure, the earth signifies humanity ([link]2:7[/link]; [link]3:19[/link]; [link]Matt. 13:3-8[/link] and notes; [link]1 Cor. 15:47a[/link]). Thus, the rebellion instigated by Satan kills the element within man that grows the divine life, by burning it out, and it misuses man to build up a man-made and godless life.

verse.text: And they said, Come, let us build ourselves a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]city and a [note]2[/note]tower whose top is in the [xref]b[/xref]heavens; and let us make a [note]2[/note]name for ourselves, lest we be [xref]c[/xref]scattered over the surface of the whole earth.
verse.note: The city built by man's labor signifies that man had forsaken God and replaced Him with a man-made and godless culture (see note [link]17[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 4[/link]).

The tower was built for the purpose of making a name for the people and for declaring their rebellion and opposition against God. Abraham's building an altar and calling on the name of Jehovah in [link]12:7-8[/link] are in contrast to what was done here.[br][br]According to historical records and archeological evidence, the city and tower of Babel were full of the names of idols. Thus, at Babel man followed Satan, exalted himself to oppose God, rejected God's name, denied God's right and authority over man, and fell into idolatry. This was man's fourth fall, a fall from human government under God's authority to a collective rebellion of the whole human race against God under Satan's instigation (see note [link]3[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 6[/link]).

chapter.verse: And Jehovah came down to see the city and the tower which the children of men had built.

And Jehovah said, Behold, they are one people, and they all have one language; and this is [i]only[/i] the beginning of what they will do; and now nothing which they purpose to do will be kept from them.

verse.text: Come, let [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Us go down and there [note]2[/note]confound their language, that they may not understand one another's speech.
verse.note: The pronoun [i]Us[/i] here indicates that at Babel the Triune God came down personally and judged that rebellion directly. See note [link]1[sup]3[/sup] in ch. 1[/link].

So that mankind might not be able to form an alliance against Him, God judged rebellious mankind with division and confusion: mankind was scattered, divided, in living, no longer able to live together in one place ([link]vv. 8-9[/link]), and confounded, confused, in language, no longer able to have the same speaking, i.e., the same understanding, opinion, and concept ([link]vv. 7[/link], [link]9[/link]). In contrast, in the proper church life there is oneness and harmony: all the believers have one mind with one opinion, and one mouth with one speaking ([link]1 Cor. 1:10[/link]; [link]Rom. 15:5-6[/link]; [link]Phil. 2:2[/link]; [link]4:2[/link]). Cf. [link]Acts 2:5-11[/link].[br][br]In the rebellion of mankind at Babel, man fell to the uttermost, causing God to eventually forsake the created race of Adam and to call one man, Abraham, out of that race that He might still have a way to fulfill His original purpose in creating man ([link]1:26-28[/link]).

verse.text: So Jehovah [xref]a[/xref]scattered them from there over the surface of all the earth, and they ceased building the city.

Therefore its name was called [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Babel, because there Jehovah confounded the language of all the earth, and from there Jehovah scattered them over the surface of all the earth.
verse.note: Meaning [i]confusion.[/i]

verse.text: These are the [xref]a[/xref]generations of Shem. Shem was one hundred years old when he begot Arpachshad, two years after the flood.

chapter.verse: And Shem lived after he had begotten Arpachshad five hundred years, and he begot [i]more[/i] sons and daughters.
And Arpachshad lived thirty-five years and begot Shelah.
And Arpachshad lived after he had begotten Shelah four hundred three years, and he begot [i]more[/i] sons and daughters.
And Shelah lived thirty years and begot Eber.
And Shelah lived after he had begotten Eber four hundred three years, and he begot [i]more[/i] sons and daughters.
And Eber lived thirty-four years and begot Peleg.
And Eber lived after he had begotten Peleg four hundred thirty years, and he begot [i]more[/i] sons and daughters.
And Peleg lived thirty years and begot Reu.
And Peleg lived after he had begotten Reu two hundred nine years, and he begot [i]more[/i] sons and daughters.
And Reu lived thirty-two years and begot Serug.
And Reu lived after he had begotten Serug two hundred seven years, and he begot [i]more[/i] sons and daughters.
And Serug lived thirty years and begot Nahor.
And Serug lived after he had begotten Nahor two hundred years, and he begot [i]more[/i] sons and daughters.
And Nahor lived twenty-nine years and begot Terah.
And Nahor lived after he had begotten Terah one hundred nineteen years, and he begot [i]more[/i] sons and daughters.

verse.text: And [xref]a[/xref]Terah lived seventy years and begot Abram, Nahor, and Haran.
Now these are the generations of Terah. Terah begot Abram, Nahor, and Haran. And Haran begot [xref]a[/xref]Lot.
And Haran died before his father Terah in the land of his birth, in [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Ur of the [note]2[/note]Chaldeans.
verse.note: Meaning [i]light.[/i] According to [link]Acts 7:2[/link], the God of glory appeared to Abraham first in Ur of the Chaldeans, while he was still in Mesopotamia, before he dwelt in Haran (cf. [link]v. 31[/link]). Before God's initial appearing to Abraham, he and his family served other gods ([link]Josh. 24:2[/link]). It was out of such a dark background of idol worship, the background of Babel ([link]vv. 3-4[/link]), that God called Abraham, the father of faith ([link]Rom. 4:16[/link]; [link]Gal. 3:7[/link]). God's coming to Abraham and appearing to him brought light to Abraham (cf. [link]Matt. 4:16[/link]; [link]Acts 9:1-3[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 4:6[/link]) and motivated him to come out of the country of satanic idolatry. See note [link]2[sup]2[/sup] in Acts 7[/link] and note [link]2[sup]2[/sup] in Heb. 12[/link].[br][br]God came in to call Abraham that He might have a new beginning with fallen man. God's calling of Abraham was a transfer of race, a transfer from the created Adamic race to the called Abrahamic race (see note [link]16[sup]1[/sup] in Rom. 4[/link]). The transfer of race in God's calling is actually the transfer of life, from the life of Adam to the life of Christ ([link]Gal. 2:20[/link]; [link]Phil. 1:21a[/link]), from the fallen life of the old creation to the stronger and better life of the new creation — the uncreated life of God. The process of this transfer of life is portrayed in the succeeding chapters of Genesis and is seen in the collective experiences of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.

Chaldea was a demonic place, a land of idolatry, in Mesopotamia, a region bounded by two great rivers, the Euphrates and the Tigris. Thus, in order to leave Chaldea, the land of idolatry, and travel to the good land, the land of Canaan, Abraham, the first Hebrew ([link]14:13[/link] and note), had to cross the Euphrates. See note [link]1[sup]2[/sup], par. 2, in Heb. 1[/link] and note [link]13[sup]2[/sup] in Heb. 11[/link].

verse.text: And Abram and Nahor took wives for themselves: The name of Abram's wife was [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Sarai, and the name of Nahor's wife was Milcah, the daughter of Haran, the father of Milcah and the father of Iscah.
verse.note: Meaning [i]my princess.[/i]

verse.text: And Sarai was [xref]a[/xref]barren; she had no child.

And [note]1[/note]Terah took Abram his son and [xref]a[/xref]Lot the son of Haran, his son's son, and Sarai his daughter-in-law, his son Abram's wife; and they went out together from [xref]b[/xref]Ur of the Chaldeans to go to the land of Canaan, but when they came to [note]2[/note]Haran they settled there.
verse.note: According to [link]Acts 7:2-3[/link], God appeared to Abraham in Ur of the Chaldeans and called him to "come out from your land and from your relatives, and come into the land which I will show you." This was God's first appearing and calling to him. However, Abraham did not accept God's calling immediately but remained in Ur for some time. After the death of Haran, Abraham's brother ([link]v. 28[/link]), God sovereignly caused his father, Terah, to bring the family from Ur to Haran. Thus, it was not Abraham but his father who took the initiative to leave Ur. See [link]Acts 7:4[/link] and note.

Abraham came out of Chaldea, but instead of going into Canaan as God had called him ([link]Acts 7:3[/link]), he settled in Haran. This shows Abraham's unwillingness to respond to God's calling absolutely.

chapter.verse: And the days of Terah were two hundred five years, and Terah died in Haran.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Now Jehovah [note]2[/note]said to Abram,[br/][xref]a[/xref]Go from your land / And from your relatives / And from your [note]3[/note]father's house / To the land that I will show you;
verse.note: After the death of Abraham's father ([link]11:32[/link]), God appeared to Abraham and called him the second time (see note [link]31[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 11[/link]). God's repeated appearing to Abraham was a strong attraction to him, motivating and strengthening him to accept God's calling. It is the same with the New Testament believers (see notes [link book="Matt." chapter="4"]20[sup]1[/sup][/link] and [link]22[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 4[/link], [link]9[sup]3[/sup] in Matt. 9[/link], [link]2[sup]2[/sup] in Heb. 12[/link], and [link]3[sup]8[/sup] in 2 Pet. 1[/link]).[br][br]The records of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob (with Joseph — see note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 37[/link]) overlap. Genesis does not portray them as three separate individuals but as constituents of one corporate person. The experiences of these three men portray different aspects of one complete person's experience of the Triune God. "The God of Abraham, the God of Isaac, and the God of Jacob" is Jehovah, the Triune God — the Father, the Son, and the Spirit ([link]Exo. 3:15[/link]; [link]Matt. 28:19[/link]). The experience of Abraham signifies the experience of God the Father in His calling man, justifying man, and equipping man to live by faith and to live in fellowship with Him ([link]12:1[/link]; [link]15:6[/link]; [link]chs. 17-18[/link]; [link]19:29[/link]; [link]21:1-13[/link]; [link]22:1-18[/link]). The experience of Isaac signifies the experience of God the Son in His redeeming man ([link]22:1-14[/link]) and His blessing man with the inheritance of all His riches, with a life of the enjoyment of His abundance, and with a life in peace ([link]25:5[/link]; [link]26:3-4[/link], [link]12-33[/link]). The experience of Jacob (with Joseph) signifies the experience of God the Father in His loving man and choosing man ([link]Mal. 1:2[/link]; [link]Rom. 9:10-13[/link]) and of God the Spirit in His working all things for the good of His lovers, in His transforming man, and in His making man mature in the divine life that man may be able to bless all the people, to rule over all the earth, and to satisfy all the people with God the Son as the life supply ([link]27:41[/link]; [link]28:1-35:10[/link]; [link]chs. 37[/link], [link book="Gen."]39-49[/link]; [link]Rom. 8:28-29[/link]).

When God appeared to Abraham, He also called him. God's speaking to Abraham was also a factor that motivated and strengthened him to accept God's calling (cf. [link]Rom. 1:6[/link]; [link]8:30[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 1:9[/link]). Cf. note [link]1[sup]1[/sup][/link], par. 1.

In His second appearing to Abraham, God called Abraham to come out not only from his country and his relatives but also from his father's house (cf. [link]Acts 7:3[/link]; see note [link book="Gen."]31[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 11[/link]). This means that God called only Abraham and his wife, Sarai. However, when Abraham left Haran, he took his nephew Lot with him ([link]vv. 4-5[/link]). This again shows Abraham's lack of absoluteness in accepting God's calling.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]And I will make of you a [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]great nation, / And I will bless you / And make your name great; / And you shall be a [xref]b[/xref]blessing.
verse.note: God's promise to Abraham in [link]vv. 2-3[/link] was the preaching of the gospel ([link]Gal. 3:8[/link] and note). God not only appeared to Abraham and called him, but He also gave him the promise of the gospel as an incentive to encourage Abraham to answer His calling.

In His preaching of the gospel to Abraham, God promised to make of him a great nation. This great nation is the kingdom of God, composed of the nation of Israel as God's kingdom in the Old Testament ([link]Matt. 21:43[/link]), the church as God's kingdom in the New Testament ([link]Matt. 16:18-19a[/link]; [link]Rom. 14:17[/link]), the millennial kingdom in the coming age ([link]Rev. 11:15[/link]; [link]20:4[/link], [link]6[/link]), and the new heaven and the new earth with the New Jerusalem in eternity ([link]Rev. 22:3[/link], [link]5[/link]).

verse.text: And I will bless those who [xref]a[/xref]bless you, / And him who [note]1[/note]curses you I will curse; / And in you [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]all the families of the earth will be [note]3[/note]blessed.
verse.note: From the time that Nebuchadnezzar destroyed the city of Jerusalem until now, every nation, people, race, or individual who has cursed the Jewish people has received a curse, and whoever has blessed the Jews has received a blessing.
In His calling God turned from Adam to Abraham, but in His promise He made another turn, from Abraham back to all the families of the Adamic race through Christ, the seed of Abraham.

The blessing here consists of the blessings of God's creation and redemption, including all that God wants to give man — God Himself and all that He has in this age and in the age to come. According to [link]Gal. 3:14[/link] (see notes there), the promised blessing is actually God Himself as the Spirit. Thus, in His preaching of the gospel to Abraham ([link]Gal. 3:8[/link]), God promised that He would give Himself to the called ones as a blessing. According to [link]22:18[/link], this blessing would come to all the nations through Abraham's seed, who is Christ ([link]Matt. 1:1[/link]; [link]Gal. 3:16[/link]). God's blessing to Abraham, which made him a blessing to others, implies the tents of Shem (see note [link]27[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 9[/link]).

verse.text: So Abram [xref]a[/xref]went as Jehovah had spoken to him, and Lot went with him. Now Abram was seventy-five years old when he went out of Haran.

And Abram took Sarai his wife and [xref]a[/xref]Lot his brother's son and all their possessions that they had gathered and the souls that they had acquired in Haran, and they [note]1[/note]went out to go to the [xref]b[/xref]land of Canaan. And they [note]2[/note]came to the land of [note]3[/note]Canaan.
verse.note: According to [link]Heb. 11:8[/link], Abraham went out by faith, not knowing where he was going. See note there.
See note [link]4[sup]1[/sup] in Acts 7[/link].

God's goal with Abraham was not merely to save him out of his environment and his background but to bring him into the land of Canaan for the fulfillment of God's purpose. Likewise, God's goal with the New Testament believers is not merely to save them from their fallen condition but to bring them into the reality of the good land, which is the all-inclusive Christ as the portion allotted by God to all the called ones ([link]Deut. 8:7-10[/link] and note [link]7[sup]1[/sup][/link]; [link]Col. 1:12[/link] and note 2). See note [link]3[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 15[/link].

verse.text: And Abram passed through the land to the place of [xref]a[/xref]Shechem, to the oak of Moreh. And at that time the Canaanites were in the land.

And Jehovah [note]1[/note]appeared to Abram and said, To your [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]seed I will give this [note]2[/note]land.[separator]And there he built an [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]altar to Jehovah who had appeared to him.
verse.note: This was the third time God appeared to Abraham. Here God's reappearing confirmed to Abraham that he had answered God's calling and had arrived at the place where God intended him to be. God's reappearing also strengthened Abraham to live by faith ([link]Heb. 11:8-10[/link]) as an anti-testimony to the godless living developed by mankind at Babel.

Both the seed and the land typify Christ, who is the centrality and universality of God's eternal economy. See note [link]3[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 15[/link].[br][br]Christ, the incarnated God, is the threefold seed: the seed of woman ([link]3:15[/link]; [link]Isa. 7:14[/link]; [link]Gal. 4:4[/link]), the seed of Abraham ([link]12:7[/link]; [link]Matt. 1:1[/link]; [link]Gal. 3:16[/link]), and the seed of David ([link]2 Sam. 7:12-14[/link]; [link]Matt. 1:1[/link]; [link]22:42-45[/link]; [link]Rom. 1:3[/link]; [link]Rev. 22:16[/link]). As the seed of woman, the seed of Mary ([link]Matt. 1:16[/link]), Christ accomplished redemption to destroy Satan, the serpent, and to save the believers in Christ from sin and death ([link]Heb. 2:14[/link]; [link]Matt. 1:20-21[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 15:53-57[/link]). As the seed of Abraham, Christ became the all-inclusive life-giving Spirit ([link]1 Cor. 15:45[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 3:17[/link]) that the believers in Christ, who are Abraham's seed ([link]Gal. 3:29[/link]), may inherit the consummated Spirit, the consummation of the processed Triune God, as their divine inheritance, their spiritual blessing for eternity ([link]Acts 26:18[/link]; [link]Eph. 1:14a[/link]; [link]Gal. 3:14[/link]). As the seed of David, Christ brings His believers into the kingdom and causes them to share in His kingship in His resurrection in the eternal kingdom of God ([link]2 Tim. 2:12[/link]; [link]Rev. 20:4[/link], [link]6[/link]; [link]22:5b[/link]). The revelation of Christ as the threefold seed is the contents of the full gospel.

This was the first altar that Abraham built. An altar is for worshipping God by offering all that we are and have to God for His purpose. Abraham's building of an altar was motivated by God's reappearing and can be considered an anti-testimony to the building of the tower of Babel.

verse.text: And he proceeded from there to the mountain on the east of [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Bethel and pitched his [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]tent, with Bethel on the west and [note]1[/note]Ai on the east; and there he built an [xref]c[/xref]altar to Jehovah and [note]3[/note][xref]d[/xref]called upon the name of Jehovah.
verse.note: [i]Bethel[/i] means [i]house of God[/i] and [i]Ai[/i] means [i]a heap of ruins.[/i] Bethel and Ai stand in contrast to each other, signifying that in the eyes of God's called ones only God's house is worthwhile; everything else is a heap of ruins.

Abraham first built an altar for the worship of God; then he pitched a tent for his living. Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob each lived in a tent ([link]12:8[/link]; [link]26:25[/link]; [link]35:21[/link]). Their dwelling in tents was a declaration that they were strangers and sojourners on the earth who were seeking a better country and eagerly waiting for "the city which has the foundations, whose Architect and Builder is God" ([link]Heb. 11:9-10[/link], [link]13-16[/link]). Both the better country and the city which has the foundations are the New Jerusalem (see notes [link book="Heb." chapter="11"]10[sup]1[/sup][/link] and [link]13[sup]2[/sup] in Heb. 11[/link]).
See note [link]26[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 4[/link].

verse.text: And Abram journeyed onward, journeying toward the [note]1[/note]Negev.
verse.note: I.e., the dry southern desert of Canaan.

verse.text: And there was a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]famine in the land; and Abram went down to Egypt to sojourn there, for the famine was severe in the land.
verse.note: The famine, prepared by God in His sovereignty, was a test to see whether or not Abraham would live by faith, trusting in God for his daily necessities (cf. [link]1 Pet. 1:6-7[/link]). Instead of trusting in God, Abraham went down to Egypt, which signifies the world under Satan's rule.

chapter.verse: And when he was about to enter into Egypt, he said to Sarai his wife, I know indeed that you are a beautiful woman to look at;
And when the Egyptians see you, they will say, This is his wife, and they will kill me; but they will keep you alive.

verse.text: Now say you are my [xref]a[/xref]sister, that it may be well with me on account of you and [note]1[/note]I may live because of you.
verse.note: Lit., my soul.

chapter.verse: And it came about that when Abram came to Egypt, the Egyptians saw that the woman was very beautiful.
And Pharaoh's officials saw her and praised her before Pharaoh, and the woman was taken into Pharaoh's house.
And he treated Abram well on account of her, and there were [i]given[/i] to him sheep and oxen and donkeys and male servants and female servants and female donkeys and camels.

verse.text: And Jehovah struck [xref]a[/xref]Pharaoh and his house with great plagues because of Sarai, Abram's wife.

chapter.verse: And Pharaoh called Abram and said, What is this you have done to me? Why did you not tell me that she was your wife?
Why did you say, She is my sister, so that I took her to be my wife? Now then here is your wife; take [i]her[/i] and go.

verse.text: And Pharaoh commanded [i]his[/i] men concerning him, and they sent him away [note]1[/note]with his wife and all that he had.
verse.note: While Abraham was in Egypt, he experienced God's keeping grace. Although Abraham had failed to trust in Him, God blessed Abraham, making him rich ([link]v. 16[/link]; [link]13:2[/link]), and preserved Sarai, his wife. By this experience in Egypt Abraham learned that the God who called Him also took care of him and that everything was in His sovereign hand.

verse.text: And Abram went up out of Egypt, he and his wife and all that he had, and [xref]a[/xref]Lot with him, into the Negev.

chapter.verse: And Abram was very rich in livestock, in silver and in gold.

verse.text: And he continued on his journey from the Negev as far as [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Bethel, to the place where his tent had been at the beginning, between Bethel and Ai,
verse.note: In His sovereign care for His called one, God not only blessed Abraham and spared his wife in Egypt, but He also brought Abraham back to the beginning, to the place of the tent and the altar, and recovered his calling on the name of the Lord ([link]v. 4[/link]).

verse.text: To the place of the [xref]a[/xref]altar, which he had made there formerly; and there Abram [xref]b[/xref]called on the name of Jehovah.
And [xref]a[/xref]Lot, who went with Abram, also had flocks and herds and tents.
And the land could not support them that they might dwell together, for their [xref]a[/xref]possessions were so great that they could not dwell together.
And there was [note]1[/note]strife between the herdsmen of Abram's livestock and the herdsmen of Lot's livestock. And at that time the Canaanites and the Perizzites dwelt in the land.
verse.note: This was another test arranged for Abraham under God's sovereignty. Through his experience in Egypt Abraham had learned the lesson of not striving for himself and of having no choice for himself but of trusting in God's care (see note [link]20[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 12[/link]). Thus, he allowed Lot to take his choice of the land ([link]v. 11[/link]).

chapter.verse: And Abram said to Lot, Let there please be no strife between me and you and between my herdsmen and your herdsmen, for we are brothers.
Is not the whole land before you? Please separate yourself from me. If [i]you go to[/i] the left, then I will go to the right. Or if [i]you go to[/i] the right, then I will go to the left.

verse.text: And Lot lifted up his eyes and saw the entire plain of the Jordan, that it was well watered everywhere — [i]this was[/i] before Jehovah had destroyed Sodom and Gomorrah — like the [xref]a[/xref]garden of Jehovah, like the land of Egypt, as you go to Zoar.

chapter.verse: So Lot chose for himself the entire plain of the Jordan, and Lot journeyed east; and they separated themselves from each other.

verse.text: Abram dwelt in the land of Canaan, and Lot dwelt in the cities of the plain and moved his tent [xref]a[/xref]as far as Sodom.
Now the men of [xref]a[/xref]Sodom were very wicked and sinful toward Jehovah.
And [note]1[/note]Jehovah said to Abram after Lot had separated from him, Now lift up your eyes, and look from the place where you are, northward and southward and eastward and westward;
verse.note: Because Abraham had prevailed in his trial with Lot, God appeared to him again and confirmed the promise in [link]12:7[/link] concerning the good land ([link]vv. 14-15[/link], [link]17[/link]) and the promise in [link]12:2[/link] concerning the increase of his seed ([link]v. 16[/link]). This ushered Abraham to the peak of his experience of God, for he moved his tent to dwell in Hebron, where he lived most of the remainder of his life in fellowship with God (see notes [link]18[sup]1[/sup][/link] and [link]18[sup]3[/sup][/link]).

verse.text: For all the land that you see I will give to you and to your [xref]a[/xref]seed forever.
And I will make your seed as the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]dust of the earth, so that if a man can number the dust of the earth, then your seed can also be numbered.
verse.note: See note [link]17[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 22[/link].

chapter.verse: Rise up; walk through the land according to its length and its breadth, for I will give it to you.

verse.text: And Abram moved his [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]tent and came and dwelt by the oaks of [note]2[/note]Mamre, which are in [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]Hebron, and there he built an [xref]c[/xref]altar to Jehovah.
verse.note: Abraham first pitched his tent between Bethel and Ai and built an altar there ([link]12:8[/link]). His tent there was a testimony of God to the world (see note [link]8[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 12[/link]). At Hebron Abraham's tent became a place where he had fellowship with God. By Abraham's pitching a tent at Hebron, God had a place on earth where He could communicate and fellowship with man (cf. [link]ch. 18[/link]). Abraham's tent with the altar built by him was a prefigure of the tabernacle with the altar built by the children of Israel after the exodus from Egypt ([link]Exo. 40[/link]). That tabernacle was God's testimony ([link]Exo. 38:21[/link]) and the place where God and His people could dwell and fellowship together. The ultimate consummation of the tabernacle will be the New Jerusalem, the testimony, the expression, of God in eternity and the eternal dwelling place of God and all His called ones ([link]Rev. 21:2-3[/link] and note [link]3[sup]1[/sup][/link]; [link]21:22[/link] and note 2).
Meaning [i]strength.[/i]
Meaning [i]fellowship, communion,[/i] or [i]friendship.[/i]

chapter.verse: And in the days of Amraphel the king of Shinar, Arioch the king of Ellasar, Chedorlaomer the king of Elam, and Tidal the king of Goiim,
[i]These kings[/i] made war with Bera the king of Sodom and with Birsha the king of Gomorrah, Shinab the king of Admah, and Shemeber the king of Zeboiim, and the king of Bela (that is, Zoar).

verse.text: All these joined together in the valley of Siddim (that is, the [note]1[/note]Salt Sea).
verse.note: I.e., the Dead Sea.

chapter.verse: Twelve years they had served Chedorlaomer, and in the thirteenth year they rebelled.

verse.text: And in the fourteenth year Chedorlaomer and the kings who were with him came and struck the [xref]a[/xref]Rephaim in Ashteroth-karnaim and the Zuzim in Ham and the Emim in Shaveh-kiriathaim

chapter.verse: And the Horites in Mount Seir as far as El-paran, which is by the wilderness.
And they turned back and came to En-mishpat (that is, Kadesh), and struck all the country of the Amalekites and also the Amorites who dwelt in Hazazon-tamar.

And the king of Sodom and the king of Gomorrah and the king of Admah and the king of Zeboiim and the king of Bela (that is, Zoar) went forth and set the battle in array against them in the valley of Siddim,
Against Chedorlaomer the king of Elam and Tidal the king of Goiim and Amraphel the king of Shinar and Arioch the king of Ellasar, four kings against the five.

verse.text: Now the valley of Siddim was full of tar pits, and the kings of Sodom and Gomorrah fled and fell there; but those who survived fled to the [xref]a[/xref]hill country.
