chapter.verse: And they took all the possessions of Sodom and Gomorrah and all their food and went away.

verse.text: And they took [xref]a[/xref]Lot, Abram's brother's son, and his possessions and departed, for he was dwelling in [xref]b[/xref]Sodom.

And one who had escaped came and told Abram the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Hebrew. Now he was dwelling by the oaks of Mamre the Amorite, the brother of Eshcol and the brother of Aner; and these were allies of Abram.
verse.note: The first mention of the term in the Bible. The word comes from the verb in Hebrew meaning [i]pass over, cross over.[/i] See note [link]1[sup]2[/sup], par. 2, in Heb. 1[/link].

verse.text: And when Abram heard that his [xref]a[/xref]brother had been taken captive, he led out his trained men, [xref]b[/xref]born in his house, three hundred eighteen [i]of them,[/i] and pursued as far as Dan.

chapter.verse: And he divided [i]his forces[/i] against them by night, he and his servants, and struck them and pursued them to Hobah, which is north of Damascus.
And he brought back all the possessions and also brought back Lot his brother and his possessions as well as the women and the people.
And after his return from the slaughter of Chedorlaomer and the kings who were with him, the king of Sodom went out to meet him at the valley of Shaveh (that is, the King's Valley).

verse.text: And [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Melchizedek the king of [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]Salem brought out bread and wine. Now he was [note]3[/note][xref]c[/xref]priest of [xref]d[/xref]God the Most High.
verse.note: Meaning [i]king of righteousness.[/i] Melchizedek is a type of Christ as the kingly High Priest ([link]Heb. 7:1-3[/link] and notes [link]1[sup]2[/sup][/link] and [link]3[sup]1[/sup][/link]). After Abraham gained the victory, Melchizedek appeared. Before his appearing, Melchizedek, a priest of God, must have been interceding for Abraham. It must have been through his intercession that Abraham was able to slaughter the four kings and gain the victory (cf. [link]Exo. 17:8-13[/link]). Today Christ, our High Priest, is interceding for us in a hidden way ([link]Rom. 8:34b[/link]; [link]Heb. 7:25b[/link]) that we may be His overcomers to defeat God's enemies, so that through our victory Christ can be manifested openly in His second coming.
Meaning [i]peace;[/i] an early designation for Jerusalem (cf. [link]Psa. 76:2[/link]).

Here the priesthood of Melchizedek is mentioned in the Scriptures before the priesthood of Aaron ([link]Exo. 28:1[/link]). The priesthood according to the order of Melchizedek is higher than the Aaronic priesthood ([link]Heb. 7[/link]). In His earthly ministry Christ was a High Priest according to the order of Aaron for the putting away of sin ([link]Heb. 9:14[/link], [link]26[/link]). Then, in His heavenly ministry Christ was designated a High Priest according to the order of Melchizedek ([link]Heb. 5:6[/link], [link]10[/link]), not to offer sacrifices for sin but to minister to us the very God who was processed through incarnation, human living, crucifixion, and resurrection, signified by the bread and the wine ([link]Matt. 26:26-28[/link]), as our life supply that we may be saved to the uttermost ([link]Heb. 7:25a[/link]). See notes [link]11[sup]1[/sup] in Zech. 6[/link], [link]6[sup]2[/sup] in Heb. 5[/link], and [link book="Heb." chapter="7"]1[sup]1[/sup][/link] and [link]11[sup]1[/sup] in Heb. 7[/link].

verse.text: And he [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]blessed him and said,[br/]Blessed be Abram of God the Most High, / [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]Possessor of heaven and earth;
verse.note: See note [link]23[sup]1[/sup] in Num. 6[/link].

Because Abraham, an overcomer, had gained the victory over God's enemies and was standing with God on the earth, God could be referred to not only as the God of heaven ([link]2 Chron. 36:23[/link]; [link]Neh. 1:5[/link]; [link]2:4[/link], [link]20[/link]) but also as the Possessor of heaven and earth ([link]vv. 19[/link], [link]22[/link]). See note [link]25[sup]3[/sup] in Matt. 11[/link].

verse.text: And blessed be God the Most High, / Who has delivered your enemies into your hand.[br/]And [note]1[/note]Abram gave him a [xref]a[/xref]tenth of all.
verse.note: Lit., he. See note [link]4[sup]1[/sup] in Heb. 7[/link].

chapter.verse: And the king of Sodom said to Abram, Give me the people, and take the possessions for yourself.

verse.text: But Abram said to the king of Sodom, I have [xref]a[/xref]lifted up my hand to Jehovah, God the Most High, [xref]b[/xref]Possessor of heaven and earth,
That I will [note]1[/note]not take a thread or a sandal thong or anything that is yours, lest you say, I have made Abram rich;
verse.note: Here Abraham overcame the temptation of earthly substance, displaying his purity in this matter. Cf. [link]2 Kings 5:15-27[/link]; [link]3 John 7[/link] and note 2.

chapter.verse: Except only that which the young men have eaten and the portion of the men who went with me — Aner, Eshcol, and Mamre; let them take their portion.

verse.text: [note]1[/note]After these things the word of Jehovah came to Abram in a vision, saying, Do not be afraid, Abram; I am your [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]shield [i]and[/i] your exceedingly great [note]2[/note]reward.
verse.note: Prior to this chapter Abraham had experienced God as the One who protected him and blessed him in material things ([link]12:16[/link]) to maintain his existence outwardly. Beginning with this chapter God came in to show Abraham that he needed God's grace inwardly for the fulfillment of God's purpose, which is to have a people to express God with His image, represent Him with His dominion, and possess the earth for His kingdom ([link]1:26-28[/link]).

After defeating the four kings ([link]14:13-17[/link]), Abraham might have feared their revenge. Thus, God came in to tell Abraham that He would be a shield to protect him. He would also be Abraham's reward for his rescue of Lot.

verse.text: And Abram said, O Lord Jehovah, what will You give me, for I go [xref]a[/xref]childless, and the heir of my house is Eliezer of Damascus?
And Abram said, Since You have given me no [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]seed, therefore, a [note]2[/note]servant in my house is my heir.
verse.note: For the fulfillment of God's purpose two things are required: the seed ([link]vv. 1-6[/link]) and the land ([link]vv. 7-21[/link]). The seed is first the individual Christ ([link]Gal. 3:16[/link] and note) and then the corporate Christ ([link]1 Cor. 12:12[/link]), composed of Christ as the Head and all His believers ([link]Gal. 3:29[/link] and note 1, par. 1) as the Body. The land is Christ as the all-inclusive, life-giving Spirit, in whom the believers live ([link]Deut. 8:7-10[/link] and note [link]7[sup]1[/sup][/link]); it is also the church as the enlargement, the expansion, of Christ. In order to fulfill God's purpose, we need to receive God's grace so that Christ can be wrought into us as the seed and lived out of us as the land to be our church life, that we may enjoy God's rest, defeat God's enemies, and establish God's kingdom with His habitation for His expression and representation.
Lit., a son of my house.

verse.text: But then the word of Jehovah came to him, saying, This man shall not be your heir, but he who will come out from your own [note]1[/note]body shall be your heir.
verse.note: Lit., inward parts. The seed needed for the fulfillment of God's purpose could not be anything Abraham already possessed (Eliezer — [link]v. 2[/link]) or could produce out of himself (Ishmael — [link]16:15[/link]). Only that which God worked into Abraham could bring forth from Abraham the required seed. Likewise, only what God works into us through His grace can bring forth Christ as the seed to fulfill God's purpose.

verse.text: And He brought him outside and said, Look now toward the heavens, and count the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]stars, if you are able to count them. And He said to him, [xref]b[/xref]So shall your seed be.
verse.note: See note [link]17[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 22[/link].

verse.text: And he [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]believed Jehovah, and He accounted it to him as righteousness.
verse.note: See note [link]3[sup]1[/sup] in Rom. 4[/link]. Here Abraham did not believe God to obtain outward blessings for his own existence; he believed that God was able to work something into him to bring forth a seed out of his own being for the fulfillment of God's purpose. This kind of faith is precious to God and is accounted by Him as righteousness. Abraham was justified by such a faith ([link]Rom. 4:1-5[/link] and note [link]1[sup]1[/sup][/link]).

verse.text: Then He said to him, I am Jehovah who brought you out of [xref]a[/xref]Ur of the Chaldeans to give you this land to inherit it.
And he said, O Lord Jehovah, [note]1[/note]how will I know that I will inherit it?
verse.note: Abraham believed God for His promise concerning the seed ([link]v. 6[/link]), but he lacked faith to believe God for the promise concerning the land. In order to strengthen Abraham's faith, God was compelled to confirm His promise to Abraham concerning the land by making a covenant with him ([link]vv. 9-21[/link]). The extraordinary way in which God enacted this covenant implies the way in which Abraham could fulfill God's eternal purpose.[br][br]The covenant God made with Abraham was a covenant of promise that would be fulfilled through God's power in His grace, not through Abraham's effort in his flesh. The new testament is a continuation of this covenant ([link]Gal. 3:17[/link] and note 1; [link]Gal. 4:22-26[/link] and note [link]24[sup]2[/sup][/link]).

verse.text: And He said to him, Bring Me a three-year-old [note]1[/note]heifer and a three-year-old female goat and a three-year-old ram and a turtledove and a young pigeon.
verse.note: God made His covenant with Abraham through the crucified and resurrected Christ. The three kinds of slain cattle here signify Christ in His humanity being crucified for us, and the two living birds signify Christ in His divinity being the living, resurrected One ([link]John 11:25[/link]; [link]Rev. 1:18[/link]). Christ was killed in His humanity, but He lives in His divinity ([link]John 14:19[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 3:18[/link] and note 3).[br][br]The heifer was for a peace offering ([link]Lev. 3:1[/link]), the female goat was for a sin offering ([link]Lev. 4:28[/link]; [link]5:6[/link]), and the ram was for a burnt offering ([link]Lev. 1:10[/link]). That they were all three years old signifies that Christ was offered to God and was crucified in resurrection ([link]John 2:19[/link]; [link]11:25[/link]; [link]Heb. 9:14[/link]).[br][br]In typology, the turtledove signifies a suffering life, and the young pigeon signifies a believing life, a life of faith. These are two characteristics of the Lord's life on the earth. Since two is the number of testimony ([link]Matt. 18:16[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 13:1[/link]), the two living birds bear testimony of Christ as the resurrected One living in us and for us ([link]John 14:19-20[/link]; [link]Gal. 2:20[/link]).[br][br]Five is the number of responsibility (see note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 25[/link]). Hence, the fact that there were three cattle and two birds, making a total of five items, signifies that Christ as the crucified and living One is now bearing all the responsibility for the fulfillment of God's eternal purpose.

verse.text: And he [note]1[/note]brought Him all these and [xref]a[/xref]cut them in two in the middle and laid the half of each opposite the other, but the [xref]b[/xref]birds he did not cut in two.
verse.note: God's asking Abraham to offer the cattle and the birds to Him implies that Abraham had to identify himself with and be one with all the things that he offered (see notes [link]21[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 3[/link] and [link]4[sup]1[/sup] in Lev. 1[/link]). This indicates that in order to fulfill God's eternal purpose, we must be crucified in Christ's crucifixion and resurrected in Christ's resurrection ([link]Rom. 6:5[/link], [link]8[/link]; [link]Gal. 2:20[/link]). Only in this way can we practice the church life in Christ as the promised land.

verse.text: And the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]birds of prey came down upon the carcasses, and Abram drove them away.
verse.note: The birds of prey coming to devour the sacrifices signify Satan and his angels coming to make Christ of none effect for the church life ([link]Gal. 5:2[/link], [link]4[/link]).

chapter.verse: And when the sun was going down, a deep sleep fell upon Abram; and, behold, a terror [i]and[/i] great darkness fell upon him.

verse.text: And He said to Abram, Know assuredly that your seed will be [xref]a[/xref]sojourners in a land that is not theirs, and they will serve them; and they will [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]afflict them [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]four hundred years.
verse.note: God's foretelling the sojourning, slavery, and affliction of Abraham's seed in Egypt was a confirmation that Abraham would surely have a son, an heir ([link]v. 4[/link]), and that God in His faithfulness would keep His promise, given in [link]12:7[/link] and [link]13:14-17[/link], to give to his seed the land from the Nile to the Euphrates ([link]v. 18[/link] and note).

verse.text: But I will also [xref]a[/xref]judge that nation, whom they will serve, and afterward they will come out with great [xref]b[/xref]possessions.
But as for you, you will go to your fathers in peace; you will be buried in a good [xref]a[/xref]old age.
And in the fourth generation they will come here again, for the iniquity of the [xref]a[/xref]Amorites is not yet complete.
And when the sun went down and it was dark, there came a smoking [note]1[/note]furnace and a [note]1[/note]torch of fire which passed between these pieces.
verse.note: A furnace is for refining, and a torch is for enlightening. To enact His covenant with Abraham, God passed through the sacrifices as a smoking furnace and a flaming torch in the dark night. This signifies that when God's called ones are suffering affliction, He will come in to refine and enlighten them that they may fulfill His purpose by the seed and by the land.

verse.text: On that day Jehovah made a [xref]a[/xref]covenant with Abram, saying,[br/]To your [xref]b[/xref]seed do I give this land, / From the [note]1[/note]river of Egypt to the great [xref]c[/xref]river, the river Euphrates:
verse.note: In His covenant with Abraham God set the boundaries of the good land, the land of Immanuel ([link]Isa. 8:8[/link]), the territory of Israel, from the Nile to the Euphrates (cf. [link]Exo. 23:31[/link]; [link]Deut. 11:24[/link]; [link]Josh. 1:3-4[/link]). This is the land that Christ, the unique seed of Abraham ([link]12:7a[/link]; [link]Gal. 3:16[/link]), will inherit for the establishing of His millennial kingdom. See notes [link]24[sup]1[/sup] in Deut. 11[/link] and [link]34[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 25[/link].

chapter.verse: [i]The land of[/i] the Kenites and the Kenizzites and the Kadmonites

verse.text: And the Hittites and the Perizzites and the [note]1[/note]Rephaim
verse.note: A race of giants ([link]Deut. 3:11[/link]).

chapter.verse: And the Amorites and the Canaanites and the Girgashites and the Jebusites.

verse.text: Now [note]1[/note]Sarai, Abram's wife, [xref]a[/xref]bore him no children; and she had an Egyptian female servant, whose name was [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]Hagar.
verse.note: Sarah and Hagar are an allegory symbolizing two covenants ([link]Gal. 4:22-28[/link] and notes [link]24[sup]2[/sup][/link] and [link]24[sup]5[/sup][/link]).

verse.text: And Sarai said to Abram, Because [xref]a[/xref]Jehovah has prevented me from bearing, please go in to my female servant; perhaps I will [note]1[/note]have children through her. And Abram listened to the voice of Sarai.
verse.note: Lit., be built up.

verse.text: So after Abram had dwelt [xref]a[/xref]ten years in the land of Canaan, Sarai, Abram's wife, took Hagar the Egyptian, her female servant, and gave her to Abram her husband to be a wife.

chapter.verse: And he went in to Hagar, and she conceived; and when she saw that she had conceived, her mistress was despised in her eyes.

And Sarai said to Abram, May the wrong [i]done[/i] to me be upon you. I gave my female servant into your bosom, and when she saw that she had conceived, I was despised in her eyes. May Jehovah judge between me and you.
And Abram said to Sarai, Your female servant is now in your hand; do to her what is good in your eyes. So Sarai dealt harshly with her, and she fled from before her.

verse.text: And the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Angel of Jehovah found her by a spring of water in the wilderness, by the spring on the way to Shur.
verse.note: The Angel of Jehovah is Jehovah Himself ([link]v. 13[/link]; [link]22:11-12[/link], [link]15-16[/link]; [link]31:11[/link], [link]13[/link]). See notes [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in Exo. 3[/link], [link book="Exo." chapter="23"]21[sup]2[/sup][/link] and [link]22[sup]1[/sup] in Exo. 23[/link], and [link]8[sup]2[/sup] in Zech. 2[/link].

chapter.verse: And He said, Hagar, Sarai's female servant, where did you come from and where are you going? And she said, I am fleeing from before my mistress Sarai.
And the Angel of Jehovah said to her, Return to your mistress, and submit yourself under her hands.

verse.text: And the Angel of Jehovah said to her, I will greatly [xref]a[/xref]multiply your seed, so that it will not be counted for multitude.
And the Angel of Jehovah said to her,[br/]You have now conceived / And will bear a son, / And you shall call his name [note]1[/note]Ishmael, / Because Jehovah has heard of your affliction.
verse.note: Meaning [i]God hears.[/i]

chapter.verse: And he will be a wild ass of a man; / His hand will be against everyone, / And everyone's hand, against him; / And he will settle down opposite all his brothers.

verse.text: And she called the name of Jehovah who spoke to her, [note]1[/note]You are a [note]2[/note]God who reveals Himself, for she said, [note]3[/note]Do I even remain here after He has revealed Himself to me?
verse.note: Or, You are El-roi.
Lit., God of seeing.
The meaning of the Hebrew is uncertain.

verse.text: Therefore the well was called [note]1[/note]Beer-lahai-roi; there it is, between Kadesh and Bered.
verse.note: Meaning [i]well of the living One who sees me, or well of the One who reveals Himself.[/i]

verse.text: And [xref]a[/xref]Hagar bore Abram a son, and Abram called the name of his son, whom Hagar bore, [note]1[/note]Ishmael.
verse.note: Abraham's producing of Ishmael through Hagar symbolizes man's attempt to fulfill God's purpose by the effort of the flesh in coordination with the law (see notes [link]16[sup]2[/sup] in Gal. 2[/link] and [link]23[sup]1[/sup] in Gal. 4[/link]).

chapter.verse: And Abram was eighty-six years old when Hagar bore Ishmael to Abram.

verse.text: And when Abram was [note]1[/note]ninety-nine years old, Jehovah appeared to Abram and said to him,[br/]I am the [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]All-sufficient God; / [note]3[/note]Walk before Me, and be [note]3[/note]perfect.
verse.note: Abraham's producing of Ishmael by the exercise of his natural strength was a serious offense against God and His economy. Because of this, after the birth of Ishmael, Abraham's fellowship with God was broken; God waited for thirteen years (cf. [link]16:16[/link]), until Abraham's natural strength was terminated, before He came to contact Abraham again ([link]Rom. 4:19[/link] and note). See note [link]4[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 15[/link].

Heb. [i]El Shaddai. El[/i] means [i]the Mighty One,[/i] and [i]Shaddai[/i] comes from the Hebrew word meaning [i]breast[/i] or [i]udder.[/i] This divine title reveals God as the Mighty One with an udder, that is, the all-sufficient Mighty One. He is the source of grace to supply His called ones with the riches of His divine being that they may bring forth Christ as the seed for the fulfillment of His purpose.

Here, to walk before God is to walk in His presence, constantly enjoying Him and His all-sufficient supply. To be perfect is to have God added to us as the element and factor of perfection. Practically, it means that we do not rely on the strength of the flesh but trust in God as the all-sufficient Mighty One for our life and our work.

verse.text: And I will make My [xref]a[/xref]covenant between Me and you, / And I will [xref]b[/xref]multiply you exceedingly.

chapter.verse: And Abram fell on his face, and God talked with him, saying,

verse.text: As for Me, this is My [xref]a[/xref]covenant with you, / And you shall become the [xref]b[/xref]father of a multitude of [note]1[/note]nations.
verse.note: The mentioning of nations and kings in [link]vv. 4-6[/link] and in [link]35:11[/link] implies that the result of our being multiplied must be the proper church life as the kingdom of God on earth ([link]Rom. 14:17[/link] and note 1). See note [link]2[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 12[/link].

verse.text: Your name shall no longer be called [note]1[/note]Abram, / But your name shall be [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]Abraham; / For I have made you the father of a multitude of nations.
verse.note: Meaning [i]exalted father.[/i]

Meaning [i]father of a multitude.[/i] In order to fulfill His eternal purpose, God needs not one exalted person but the father of a great multitude (cf. [link]1:28[/link]; [link]9:1[/link]). Hence, the changing of Abraham's name, signifying the changing of his person, was for the fulfillment of God's purpose. In spiritual experience, the real changing of a name is the change from "I" to Christ ([link]Gal. 2:20[/link]) and from "I" to the grace of God ([link]1 Cor. 15:10[/link]). Only Christ as God's grace, not "I," can bring forth the multitude needed to fulfill God's purpose (see note [link]4[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 15[/link]). Cf. [link]32:27-28[/link]; [link]John 1:42[/link].

verse.text: And I will make you exceedingly fruitful; and I will make [xref]a[/xref]nations of you, and [xref]b[/xref]kings will come forth from you.

And I will establish My [xref]a[/xref]covenant between Me and you and your seed after you throughout their generations for an everlasting covenant, to be [xref]b[/xref]God to you and to your seed after you.

And I will give to you and to your [xref]a[/xref]seed after you the land of your [xref]b[/xref]sojournings, all the land of Canaan, for an everlasting possession; and I will be [xref]c[/xref]their God.

chapter.verse: And God said to Abraham, And as for you, you shall keep My covenant, you and your seed after you throughout their generations.

verse.text: This is My covenant, which you shall keep, between Me and you and your seed after you: Every male among you shall be [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]circumcised.
verse.note: The spiritual meaning of circumcision is to put off the flesh, to put off the self and the old man, through the crucifixion of Christ ([link]Col. 2:11[/link], [link]13a[/link]; [link]Deut. 10:16[/link]; [link]Jer. 4:4a[/link]; [link]Acts 7:51[/link]; [link]Gal. 5:24[/link]; [link]Rom. 6:6[/link]; [link]Eph. 4:22[/link]; [link]Col. 3:9[/link]). In [link]ch. 16[/link] Abraham exercised his flesh to produce Ishmael. Here God asked him to cut off his flesh, to terminate his natural strength, so that God could come in and bring forth Isaac by His grace for the fulfillment of His purpose. The circumcision in the Old Testament is the equivalent of baptism in the New Testament ([link]Col. 2:11-12[/link] and notes). The real circumcision is not outward in the flesh but inward "of the heart, in spirit, not in letter" ([link]Rom. 2:28-29[/link]). See note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in Josh. 5[/link].

verse.text: And you shall be circumcised in the flesh of your foreskin, and it shall be a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]sign of a covenant between Me and you.
verse.note: Although God's promise concerning the inheriting of the good land by His elect ([link]12:1-2[/link], [link]7[/link]; [link]13:15-17[/link]) had been made a covenant ([link]15:4-5[/link], [link]18-21[/link]), there was still the need to confirm the covenant of God's promise with the covenant of circumcision. Circumcision was the procedure that God's elect had to pass through in order to inherit God's promise. It signifies that God's chosen ones in the New Testament must be terminated through the cross so that they may inherit all the riches in Christ promised by God (cf. [link]Gal. 2:20[/link]). See [link]Rom. 4:11[/link] and note 1.

verse.text: And he who is [note]1[/note]eight days old shall be circumcised among you, every male throughout your generations, he who is born in the house or bought with money from any [xref]a[/xref]foreigner who is not of your seed.
verse.note: In figure the eighth day, the first day of a new week, refers to Christ's resurrection ([link]Matt. 28:1[/link]; [link]John 20:1[/link]). Circumcision must be in resurrection, and it always ushers us into resurrection ([link]Col. 2:12[/link]; cf. [link]Rom. 6:3-5[/link]), making us a new person, a new creation ([link]2 Cor. 5:17[/link]; [link]Gal. 6:15[/link]), for the fulfillment of God's purpose.[br][br]Circumcision corresponds to the changing of human names ([link]v. 5[/link]). Both signify the terminating of our old being and our being brought into resurrection so that we may be no longer a natural person but a resurrected person.

verse.text: He who is born in your house and he who is bought with your money must be circumcised; thus My [xref]a[/xref]covenant shall be in your flesh for an [xref]b[/xref]everlasting covenant.
But as for the uncircumcised male who is not circumcised in the flesh of his foreskin, that person shall be [note]1[/note]cut off from his people; he has broken My covenant.
verse.note: If God's called ones do not live a crucified life by terminating their self and their natural being, in their subjective experience they will be cut off from Christ, from the church life, and from the supply of God's grace and will have nothing to do with God's covenant for the fulfillment of God's purpose ([link]John 15:6[/link]; [link]Gal. 5:4[/link]).

verse.text: And God said to Abraham, As for Sarai your wife, you shall not call her name [note]1[/note]Sarai, but her name shall be [note]2[/note]Sarah.
verse.note: Meaning [i]my princess.[/i]

Meaning princess. The word my before princess (see note [link]15[sup]1[/sup][/link]) indicates narrowness and particularity. Here, the changing of Sarah's name signifies generality and suggests the enlarging and broadening of her person to make her a mother of nations ([link]v. 16[/link]). As seen with both Abraham ([link]v. 5[/link]) and Sarah, such a change requires the termination of our old and natural man so that we may be transformed into a new person who can produce seed and care for others for the fulfillment of God's purpose.

verse.text: And I will bless her, and I will also give you a [xref]a[/xref]son [note]1[/note]by her. Indeed, I will bless her, and she will be [i]a mother of[/i] [xref]b[/xref]nations; kings of peoples will come forth from her.
verse.note: I.e., by God's grace in God's covenant of promise, symbolized here by Sarah, the free woman, Abraham's wife ([link]Gal. 4:22-26[/link]). The birth of Isaac by Sarah signifies the begetting of the believers in Christ by God's grace in the resurrection of Christ ([link]1 Pet. 1:3[/link]) to be the legal seed of Abraham ([link]Gal. 4:28[/link], [link]31[/link]; [link]3:29[/link]). God's covenant of circumcision in this chapter corresponds to the new covenant, in which Christ's death cuts off our old man in the flesh and Christ's resurrection germinates our new man, signified by Isaac, to make us the new creation ([link]2 Cor. 5:17[/link]).

verse.text: Then Abraham fell upon his face and [xref]a[/xref]laughed and said in his heart, Will a child be born to a man who is a [xref]b[/xref]hundred years old? And will Sarah, who is ninety years old, bear a child?

chapter.verse: And Abraham said to God, Oh that Ishmael might live before You!

verse.text: But God said, No, but Sarah your wife will bear you a [xref]a[/xref]son, and you shall call his name [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]Isaac; and I will [note]2[/note]establish My covenant with him for an everlasting covenant for his seed after him.
verse.note: Meaning [i]he laughs.[/i]

Ishmael, the seed produced by the flesh, was rejected by God ([link]21:10[/link]). Only Isaac, the seed brought forth by God's grace, was established for the fulfillment of God's purpose ([link]v. 21[/link]; [link]21:12[/link]; [link]Rom. 9:7-9[/link]).

verse.text: And as for Ishmael, I have heard you; indeed, I have blessed him and will make him fruitful and will [xref]a[/xref]multiply him exceedingly. [xref]b[/xref]Twelve princes will he beget, and I will make him a [xref]c[/xref]great nation.
But My covenant I will [xref]a[/xref]establish with Isaac, whom Sarah will bear to you at this [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]appointed time next year.
verse.note: See note [link]14[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 18[/link].

chapter.verse: And when He finished talking with him, God went up from Abraham.

verse.text: And Abraham took Ishmael his son and all who were born in his house and all who were bought with his money, every male among the men of Abraham's house, and [xref]a[/xref]circumcised the flesh of their foreskin on the very same day, as God had said to him.

chapter.verse: And Abraham was ninety-nine years old when he was circumcised in the flesh of his foreskin.
And Ishmael his son was thirteen years old when he was circumcised in the flesh of his foreskin.
On the very same day Abraham was circumcised as well as Ishmael his son.
And all the men of his house, those born in the house and those bought with money from a foreigner, were circumcised with him.

verse.text: And Jehovah appeared to him by the oaks of Mamre as he was sitting at the entrance of [i]his[/i] [xref]a[/xref]tent in the heat of the day.

And he lifted up his eyes and looked, and there were three [note]1[/note]men standing opposite him. And when he saw [i]them,[/i] he ran from the entrance of the tent to [xref]a[/xref]meet them. And he bowed down to the earth
verse.note: Or, mortal men. One of these three men was Jehovah God ([link]vv. 13-14[/link], [link]22[/link]) as Christ; the other two were angels ([link]v. 22[/link]; [link]19:1[/link]). After he was circumcised and his natural strength was terminated, Abraham lived in intimate fellowship with God and became God's friend ([link]James 2:23[/link]; [link]2 Chron. 20:7[/link]; [link]Isa. 41:8[/link]). Even before the incarnation ([link]John 1:14[/link]) Jehovah as Christ appeared to Abraham in human form, with a human body, and communed with him on a human level.

chapter.verse: And said, My Lord, if I have found favor in Your sight, please do not pass on from Your servant.

verse.text: Please let a little water be fetched, and do [xref]a[/xref]wash your feet, and rest yourselves under the tree.
And let me [xref]a[/xref]fetch a morsel of bread that you may sustain yourselves. After that you may pass on, since you have come to your servant. So they said, Do as you have said.
And Abraham hurried into the tent to Sarah and said, Quickly prepare [xref]a[/xref]three [note]1[/note]measures of fine flour, knead [i]it,[/i] and make [note]2[/note]cakes.
verse.note: Heb. [i]seahs.[/i] Three seahs are equivalent to one ephah, the normal portion for a meal (cf. [link]1 Sam. 1:24[/link]; [link]Judg. 6:19[/link]). The three measures of fine flour signify the resurrected Christ in His humanity. Cf. [link]Matt. 13:33[/link].

The cakes, the calf ([link]v. 7[/link]; cf. [link]Luke 15:23[/link]), and the curds and milk ([link]v. 8[/link]; cf. [link]1 Pet. 2:2[/link]) all signify the riches of the all-inclusive Christ as food for the satisfaction of both God and man. While Abraham was enjoying fellowship with God, in type he offered Christ to God as God's food.

verse.text: And Abraham ran to the herd and took a [xref]a[/xref]calf, tender and good, and gave [i]it[/i] to the servant, and he hurried to prepare it.

chapter.verse: And he took curds and milk and the calf which he had prepared, and set [i]them[/i] before them; and he stood by them under the tree while they ate.
And they said to him, Where is Sarah your wife? And he said, There, in the tent.

verse.text: And He said, I will certainly return to you according to the [xref]a[/xref]time of life, and then Sarah your wife shall have a [xref]b[/xref]son. And Sarah was listening at the entrance of the tent, which was behind Him.
Now Abraham and Sarah were [xref]a[/xref]old [i]and[/i] advanced in age; it had ceased to be with Sarah according to the manner of women.
And Sarah [xref]a[/xref]laughed within herself, saying, After I have become old, shall I have pleasure, my [xref]b[/xref]lord being old also?

chapter.verse: And Jehovah said to Abraham, Why did Sarah laugh, saying, Shall I indeed bear a child when I am old?

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Is anything too marvelous for Jehovah? At the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]appointed time I will return to you, according to the [xref]c[/xref]time of life, and Sarah shall have a son.
verse.note: The time of life ([link]v. 10[/link]), the appointed time for the birth of Isaac ([link]17:21[/link]), was the time of God's visitation ([link]21:1[/link]). The birth of Isaac was the coming of Jehovah, which was the coming of grace (cf. [link]John 1:17[/link]). Isaac was born by the strength of God's grace, not by the strength of man's natural life. This took place after Abraham had been circumcised and he and his wife, Sarah, had become completely deadened ([link]v. 11[/link]; [link]Rom. 4:18-19[/link]), signifying that the time of life, the time when Christ will be life to us, will come after our natural strength has been terminated.

chapter.verse: Then Sarah denied [i]it,[/i] saying, I did not laugh; for she was afraid. And He said, No, but you did laugh.
And the men rose up from there and looked down upon Sodom. And Abraham walked with them to send them away.

verse.text: And Jehovah said, [note]1[/note]Shall I [xref]a[/xref]hide from Abraham what I am about to do,
verse.note: God revealed to Abraham His intention to destroy Sodom, because He was seeking an intercessor. While God intended to destroy Sodom, His heart was concerned for Lot, who was dwelling in Sodom ([link]13:12[/link]; [link]14:12[/link]; [link]19:1[/link]). He wanted to save Lot in order to protect Christ's genealogy through Ruth, a Moabitess and a descendant of Lot ([link]19:37[/link]; [link]Ruth 1:4[/link]; [link]Matt. 1:5[/link]), but He could not do so without an intercessor. Thus, in His intimate fellowship with Abraham, in a mysterious way, without mentioning Lot's name, God revealed His heart's desire. The proper intercession is not initiated by man but by God's revelation. Thus, it expresses God's desire and paves the way for the accomplishing of His will.

verse.text: Since Abraham will indeed become a great and mighty nation, and [xref]a[/xref]all the nations of the earth will be blessed in him?

chapter.verse: For I know him, that he will command his children and his household after him to keep the way of Jehovah by doing righteousness and justice, that Jehovah may bring upon Abraham what He has spoken concerning him.

verse.text: And Jehovah said, The cry of [xref]a[/xref]Sodom and Gomorrah, how great it is; and their sin, how very heavy it is!

chapter.verse: I shall go down and see whether they have done altogether according to its outcry, which has come to Me; and if not, I will know.

verse.text: And the men turned from there and went toward Sodom, while Abraham [note]1[/note]remained [xref]a[/xref]standing before Jehovah.
verse.note: Abraham's purpose in standing before Jehovah was to intercede for Lot. The glorious intercession that Abraham made before God was not a prayer from man on earth to God in heaven; it was a human conversation between two friends, an intimate talk according to the unveiling of God's heart's desire.

verse.text: And Abraham came near and said, Will You indeed destroy the [note]1[/note]righteous with the wicked?
verse.note: Here Abraham referred to Lot by implication ([link]2 Pet. 2:7-9[/link]). Apparently, Abraham was interceding for Sodom; actually, he was interceding for Lot ([link]19:27-29[/link]).

chapter.verse: Suppose there are fifty righteous within the city; will You indeed destroy and not spare the place for the sake of the fifty righteous who are in it?

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Far be it from You to do such a thing, to put to death the righteous with the wicked, so that the righteous should be as the wicked. Far be it from You! Shall the [xref]a[/xref]Judge of all the earth not do justly?
verse.note: In Abraham's intercession for Lot, He did not beg God according to His love and grace; he challenged God according to His righteous way. God's righteousness binds Him much more than His love and grace do (see note [link]17[sup]1[/sup] in Rom. 1[/link]).

chapter.verse: And Jehovah said, If I find in Sodom fifty righteous within the city, then I will spare the whole place for their sake.
And Abraham answered and said, Now behold, I have taken [i]it[/i] upon myself to speak to the Lord, though I am but dust and ashes.
Suppose the fifty righteous are lacking five, will You destroy the whole city because of five? And He said, I will not destroy [i]it[/i] if I find forty-five there.
And he spoke to Him yet again and said, Suppose forty are found there? And He said, I will not do it, because of the forty.
And he said, Oh may the Lord not be angry if I speak. Suppose thirty are found there? And He said, I will not do [i]it[/i] if I find thirty there.
And he said, Now behold, I have taken [i]it[/i] upon myself to speak to the Lord. Suppose twenty are found there? And He said, I will not destroy [i]it,[/i] because of the twenty.
And he said, Oh let the Lord not be angry if I speak yet once more. Suppose ten are found there? And He said, I will not destroy [i]it,[/i] because of the ten.

verse.text: And Jehovah went away as soon as He had finished [note]1[/note]speaking with Abraham, and Abraham returned to his place.
verse.note: Abraham's intercession did not terminate with Abraham's speaking but with God's, showing that genuine intercession is God's speaking in our speaking.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]And the two angels came to Sodom in the evening, and [xref]b[/xref]Lot was sitting in the gate of Sodom. And when [note]1[/note]Lot saw [i]them,[/i] he rose up to meet them and bowed with his face to the ground.
verse.note: Lot was a righteous and godly man ([link]2 Pet. 2:6-9[/link]). Nevertheless, although he had come out of Ur of Chaldea and was dwelling as one of God's people with Abraham in the land of Canaan ([link]12:5[/link]), he became defeated because he separated himself from Abraham, with whom was God's witness and testimony, and drifted into the wicked city of Sodom ([link]13:11-13[/link]; [link]14:12[/link]), which was condemned by God and was to be destroyed under His judgment.[br][br]Ur of Chaldea was a place of idols, Egypt was a place of worldly riches and pleasures, and Sodom was a city of sin. These three places form a triangular boundary around the land of Canaan. God's called ones live within this triangle and must be careful lest they fall back to the city of idols, go down to the place of worldly pleasures, or drift into the city of sin.

verse.text: And he said, Now, my lords, please turn aside here to your servant's house, and spend the night, and [xref]a[/xref]wash your feet; then you can rise up early and go on your way. But they said, No; we will spend the night in the square.

chapter.verse: But he urged them strongly, and they turned aside to him and entered his house. And he made them a feast and baked unleavened bread, and they ate.

verse.text: [i]But[/i] before they lay down, the men of the city, the men of [xref]a[/xref]Sodom, surrounded the house, both young and old, all the people from every quarter;
And they called to Lot and said to him, Where are the men who came to you tonight? Bring them out to us that we may [note]1[/note]know them.
verse.note: The wicked Sodomites were homosexuals ([link]Rom. 1:24-27[/link]).

chapter.verse: And Lot went out to them at the entrance and shut the door behind him.
And he said, Please, my brothers, do not act [i]so[/i] wickedly.

verse.text: I have here two [note]1[/note]daughters who have not known a man. Please, let me bring them out to you, and do to them as is fitting in your eyes; only do not do anything to these men, inasmuch as they have come under the shelter of my roof.
verse.note: Lot's willingness to sacrifice his two virgin daughters to satisfy the Sodomites' lust shows that Lot, having dwelt a considerable time in the sinful city of Sodom, had lost his sense of morality and shame ([link]vv. 33[/link], [link]35[/link]).

verse.text: But they said, Stand aside. Then they said, This one came [i]here[/i] to [xref]a[/xref]sojourn, and already he is acting like a judge. Now we will treat you worse than [i]we would have[/i] them. And they pressed hard against the man, against Lot, and came near in order to break down the door.

chapter.verse: But the men stretched out their hand and brought Lot into the house to them and shut the door.

verse.text: And they struck the men who were at the entrance of the house with [note]1[/note]blindness, both small and great, so that they wearied themselves [i]trying[/i] to find the entrance.
verse.note: This shows that sinfulness blinds people. See notes [link]27[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 9[/link], [link]40[sup]1[/sup] in John 12[/link], and [link]1[sup]2[/sup] in John 9[/link].

chapter.verse: And the men said to Lot, Whom else do you have here? A son-in-law or your sons and your daughters or anyone you have in the city — bring [i]them[/i] out of the place.
For we are about to destroy this place, because their outcry has become so great before Jehovah that Jehovah has sent us to destroy it.

verse.text: And Lot went out and spoke to his sons-in-law, who were to marry his daughters, and said, Rise up; [xref]a[/xref]go forth from this place, for Jehovah will destroy the city. But it seemed to his sons-in-law as though he were joking.
And when the morning dawned, the angels urged [xref]a[/xref]Lot, saying, Rise up; take your wife and your two daughters who are here, lest you be destroyed in the iniquity of the city.

But he [note]1[/note]lingered; so the men seized his hand and the hand of his wife and the hand of his two daughters, Jehovah being merciful to him, and they brought him out and set him outside the city.
verse.note: Lot had no willingness to escape from the evil and condemned city, but the Lord was merciful, pulling him out of Sodom like wood plucked out of a fire (cf. [link]Zech. 3:2[/link]; [link]Jude 23[/link]).

verse.text: And when they had brought them outside, He said, Escape for your life. Do not look [xref]a[/xref]behind you, neither stay anywhere in the plain. Escape to the hills, lest you be destroyed.

chapter.verse: And Lot said to them, May it not be so, Lord;

Even though Your servant has found favor in Your sight, and You have magnified Your lovingkindness, which You have showed to me in preserving my life; I cannot escape to the mountain, lest the disaster overtake me and I die.

verse.text: Here, this city is nearby to flee to, and it is a little one. Please let me escape there — is it not a little one? — and [note]1[/note]I shall live.
verse.note: Lit., my soul.

chapter.verse: And He said to him, I now grant you this request also, that I will not overthrow the city concerning which you have spoken.

verse.text: Hurry, escape there; for I cannot do anything until you arrive there. Therefore the name of the city was called [note]1[/note]Zoar.
verse.note: Meaning [i]little.[/i]

chapter.verse: The sun had risen over the earth when Lot came to Zoar.

verse.text: Then Jehovah rained upon [xref]a[/xref]Sodom and upon Gomorrah [xref]b[/xref]brimstone and fire from Jehovah out of heaven.
verse.xref: Jer. 50:40; Lam. 4:6; Amos 4:11; Zeph. 2:9; 2 Pet. 2:6; Jude 7; Matt. 10:15; Rom. 9:29

chapter.verse: And He overthrew those cities and all the plain and all the inhabitants of the cities and what grew on the ground.

verse.text: But his [xref]a[/xref]wife looked back from behind him, and she became a [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]pillar of salt.
verse.note: See note [link]32[sup]1[/sup] in Luke 17[/link].

verse.text: And Abraham rose up early in the morning [i]and went[/i] to the place where he had [xref]a[/xref]stood before Jehovah.
And he looked down upon Sodom and Gomorrah and upon all the land of the plain. And as he looked, there it was: the smoke of the land was going up like the [xref]a[/xref]smoke of a furnace.
And when God destroyed the cities of the plain, God [xref]a[/xref]remembered Abraham and sent Lot out from the midst of the overthrow, when He overthrew the cities among which Lot dwelt.

chapter.verse: Then Lot went up out of Zoar and dwelt in the mountains, and his two daughters with him, for he was afraid to dwell in Zoar. And he and his two daughters dwelt in a cave.
And the firstborn said to the younger, Our father is old, and there is not a man on the earth to come in to us after the manner of all the earth.

verse.text: Come, let us make our father drink wine; and let us lie with him, that we may preserve alive [note]1[/note]seed from our father.
verse.note: Having been drugged with the wicked current of the evil world, Lot's daughters had lost their sense of morality. Desiring to have seed regardless of the means, they bore sons out of their father by incest, thus breaking the governing principle ordained by God. In principle, to use any kind of sinful or worldly methods to secure increase for our success in the Christian work is to break God's governing principle and thus to commit spiritual incest (cf. [link]Matt. 7:21-23[/link]). The seed produced by incest became a great damage to the people of God through fornication ([link]Num. 25:1-5[/link]; [link]Rev. 2:14[/link] and notes 2 and 3).

chapter.verse: And they made their father drink wine that night. And the firstborn went in and lay with her father, and he did not know when she lay down or when she arose.

And the next day the firstborn said to the younger, I have now lain with my father last night. Let us make him drink wine tonight also; and you go in, and lie with him, that we may preserve alive seed from our father.
And they made their father drink wine that night also. And the younger one arose and lay with him, and he did not know when she lay down or when she arose.
Thus both the daughters of Lot became pregnant by their father.

verse.text: And the firstborn bore a son and called his name [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Moab; he is the father of the [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]Moabites to this day.
verse.note: Meaning [i]from father.[/i]

God rejected the Moabites and the Ammonites ([link]v. 38[/link]) with a holy and divine hatred, commanding His people not to "seek peace with them nor prosperity with them all your days forever" and forbidding an Ammonite or a Moabite to enter the congregation of Jehovah, "even to the tenth generation...forever" ([link]Deut. 23:3-6[/link]; cf. [link]Matt. 1:5[/link] and note 3).[br][br]Ishmael, brought forth by fleshly effort, was rejected by God ([link]21:10-12[/link]). Moab and Ben-ammi, brought forth by incest, were a shame in history. Only Isaac, brought forth by God's grace, was used to fulfill God's purpose.

verse.text: And the younger, she also bore a son and called his name [note]1[/note]Ben-ammi; he is the father of the children of [xref]a[/xref]Ammon to this day.
verse.note: Meaning [i]son of my people.[/i]

verse.text: And Abraham journeyed from [note]1[/note]there toward the region of the Negev and dwelt between Kadesh and Shur; then he sojourned in Gerar.
verse.note: I.e., Hebron ([link]18:1[/link]; cf. [link]13:18[/link]).

verse.text: And Abraham said of Sarah his wife, [note]1[/note]She is my [xref]a[/xref]sister. And Abimelech the king of Gerar sent and took Sarah.
verse.note: When Abraham journeyed from Hebron ([link]v. 1[/link]), he left God's presence and the proper standing on which he could have fellowship with God ([link]13:18[/link] and notes). Although he had been circumcised both physically and spiritually ([link]17:10[/link], [link]23-24[/link] and note [link]10[sup]1[/sup][/link]), when he left the proper standing of fellowship with God, Abraham was again in the flesh and repeated his previous failure ([link]12:13[/link]). This shows that no matter how high our spiritual attainment may be, as long as we are still in the old creation, if we do not remain in fellowship with God, we are capable of being in the flesh and of behaving like the worldly people. We should never have any confidence in our flesh; the flesh is absolutely untrustworthy ([link]Rom. 7:18[/link]; [link]Phil. 3:3[/link]). We must put our trust in the Lord's presence.

verse.text: But God came to Abimelech in a [xref]a[/xref]dream by night and said to him, You are now about to die because of the woman whom you have taken, for she is a man's wife.

chapter.verse: But Abimelech had not come near her, so he said, Lord, will You slay even a righteous nation?
Did he himself not say to me, She is my sister? And even she herself said, He is my brother. In the integrity of my heart and the innocence of my hands I have done this.
And God said to him in the dream, Yes, I know that in the integrity of your heart you have done this, and I also prevented you from sinning against Me; therefore I did not let you touch her.

verse.text: Now therefore return the man's wife, for he is a prophet; and he will [xref]a[/xref]pray for you, and you will live. But if you do not return [i]her,[/i] know that you shall surely die, you and all who are yours.

chapter.verse: And Abimelech rose early in the morning and called all his servants and spoke all these things in their hearing. And the men were very afraid.

Then Abimelech called Abraham and said to him, What have you done to us? And how have I sinned against you, that you have brought on me and on my kingdom a great sin? You have done to me things that ought not to be done.

verse.text: And Abimelech said to Abraham, [note]1[/note]What were you thinking, that you have done this thing?
verse.note: Lit., What did you see...

verse.text: And Abraham said, Because I [note]1[/note]thought, Surely there is no fear of God in this place, and they will [xref]a[/xref]slay me because of my wife.
verse.note: Lit., said.

chapter.verse: But she is also truly my sister, the daughter of my father, but not the daughter of my mother; and she became my wife.

verse.text: And [note]1[/note]when [xref]a[/xref]God caused me to wander from my father's house, I said to her, This is your kindness which you must do to me: At every place where we go, say of me, He is my brother.
verse.note: Abraham's lying to Abimelech was planned by him from the time he began to follow the way of God. Thus, his failure in this chapter exposed his hidden weakness in the matter of following the Lord and trusting in Him absolutely.

verse.text: Then Abimelech took sheep and oxen and male servants and female servants, and gave [i]them[/i] to Abraham; and he [note]1[/note]returned Sarah his wife to him.
verse.note: In figure, Abraham signifies faith and Sarah signifies grace ([link]Gal. 3:7[/link]; [link]4:23[/link]). When Abraham failed, Sarah suffered and Abraham lost the testimony of grace. This shows that whenever faith fails on our side, grace suffers on God's side, and whenever the enjoyment of grace is lost, the testimony of grace also is lost.[br][br]Although Abraham's faith failed, God still preserved him by His sovereign care. God wisely and sovereignly restored Sarah, taking care of His grace and His testimony.

chapter.verse: And Abimelech said, My land is now before you; dwell wherever it pleases you.

verse.text: And to Sarah he said, I have now given your brother a thousand [i]pieces of[/i] silver. It is now your [note]1[/note]vindication in the eyes of all who are with you. And in every respect you have been cleared.
verse.note: Lit., covering.

verse.text: And Abraham [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]prayed to God; and God healed Abimelech and his wife and his female servants, so that they bore children.
verse.note: Abraham had to intercede for Abimelech's need in spite of his own failure and the fact that Sarah was still barren. This shows that our interceding for others does not depend on our condition; it depends on who we are. God did not count Abraham's failure but considered him His prophet ([link]v. 7[/link]). Regardless of our condition, in God's eyes we, God's called ones, are His prophets ([link]1 Cor. 14:31[/link]), His new creation ([link]2 Cor. 5:17[/link]), the members of the Body of Christ ([link]Eph. 5:30[/link]).

verse.text: For Jehovah had completely shut up all the wombs of the house of Abimelech because of Sarah, Abraham's [xref]a[/xref]wife.
[note]1[/note]And Jehovah [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]visited Sarah as He had said, and Jehovah did to Sarah as He had [xref]b[/xref]promised.
verse.note: For [link]vv. 1-13[/link] in this chapter, see notes in [link]Gal. 4:22-31[/link].
See note [link]14[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 18[/link].

verse.text: And [xref]a[/xref]Sarah conceived and [note]1[/note]bore Abraham a [xref]b[/xref]son in his old age, at the [xref]c[/xref]appointed time of which God had spoken to him.
verse.note: God's goal in His economy is to bring forth Christ as the seed for the fulfillment of His eternal purpose ([link]3:15[/link]; [link]12:7[/link]; [link]22:18[/link]; [link]Gal. 3:16[/link]; [link]2 Sam. 7:12-14a[/link]). The birth of Isaac signifies the bringing forth of Christ as the promised seed through God's work of grace at God's appointed time. The prerequisite to this is the termination of our natural life and strength through spiritual circumcision ([link]17:10-16[/link]).

verse.text: And Abraham called the name of his son who was born to him, whom Sarah bore to him, [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Isaac.
verse.note: Meaning [i]he laughs.[/i]

verse.text: And Abraham [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]circumcised Isaac his son when he was [note]2[/note]eight days old, as God had commanded him.
verse.note: See note [link]10[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 17[/link].
See note [link]12[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 17[/link].

verse.text: And Abraham was a [xref]a[/xref]hundred years old when Isaac his son was born to him.
And Sarah said, God has made me [xref]a[/xref]laugh; everyone who hears will laugh with me.

chapter.verse: And she said, Who would have said to Abraham that Sarah would nurse children? Yet I have borne him a son in his old age.

verse.text: And the child [note]1[/note]grew and was weaned. And Abraham made a great feast on the day that Isaac was weaned.
verse.note: The growth of Isaac signifies the growth of Christ in the New Testament believers after He is born in them. The growth of Christ in us is needed that Christ may be formed in us ([link]Gal. 4:19[/link] and note 4).

verse.text: And Sarah saw the [xref]a[/xref]son of Hagar the Egyptian, whom she had borne to Abraham, [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]mocking.
verse.note: See notes [link]29[sup]2[/sup] in Gal. 4[/link] and [link]17[sup]3[/sup] in Gal. 3[/link].

verse.text: So she said to Abraham, [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Cast out this maidservant and her son, for the son of this maidservant shall [xref]b[/xref]not inherit with my son Isaac.
verse.note: The casting out of Hagar and Ishmael signifies the casting out of the law and the result of the effort of the flesh, which have no place in God's economy (see notes [link book="Gal." chapter="4"]24[sup]5[/sup][/link] and [link]30[sup]1[/sup] in Gal. 4[/link]).

chapter.verse: And the matter displeased Abraham greatly on account of his son.

verse.text: And God said to Abraham, Do not be displeased on account of the boy and on account of your maidservant. Whatever Sarah says to you, listen to her voice, for in [xref]a[/xref]Isaac shall your [xref]b[/xref]seed be called.
And of the son of the maidservant I will also make a [xref]a[/xref]nation, because he is your seed.

chapter.verse: And Abraham rose up early in the morning and took bread and a waterskin [i]full[/i] of water and gave [i]them[/i] to Hagar, putting [i]them[/i] on her shoulder, and [i]gave her[/i] the child and sent her away. And she departed and wandered in the wilderness of Beer-sheba.
When the water in the waterskin was finished, she cast the child under one of the bushes.

And she went and sat herself down opposite [i]him,[/i] a fair distance away, about a bowshot away, for she said, Do not let me look upon the death of the child. And as she sat opposite [i]him,[/i] she lifted up her voice and wept.

verse.text: And God heard the voice of the boy. And the [xref]a[/xref]Angel of God called to Hagar out of heaven and said to her, What troubles you, Hagar? Do not be afraid, for God has heard the voice of the boy where he is.

chapter.verse: Rise up; lift up the boy, and hold him with your hand, for I will make him a great nation.

verse.text: And God opened her eyes, and she saw a [note]1[/note]well of water. And she went and filled the waterskin with water and gave the boy a drink.
verse.note: A well signifies the source of one's living. Ishmael's well was in the wilderness close to Egypt ([link]vv. 14[/link], [link]20-21[/link]). Ishmael's source of living made him an archer ([link]v. 20[/link]; cf. [link]10:8-9[/link]), a hunter, a killer of life, and eventually joined him to Egypt, signifying the world ([link]v. 21[/link]).

chapter.verse: And God was with the boy, and he grew. And he dwelt in the wilderness and became an archer.
And he dwelt in the wilderness of Paran. And his mother took a wife for him from the land of Egypt.
And at that time Abimelech and Phicol the captain of his army spoke to Abraham, saying, God is with you in all that you do.

verse.text: Now therefore [xref]a[/xref]swear to me here by God that you will not deal falsely with me or with my offspring or with my posterity. According to the kindness that I have shown to you, you shall do to me and to the land in which you have sojourned.

chapter.verse: And Abraham said, I swear [i]it.[/i]

verse.text: And Abraham confronted Abimelech concerning the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]well of water which Abimelech's servants had taken by force.
verse.note: The well for Isaac is a type of Christ as the life-giving Spirit ([link]1 Cor. 15:45[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 3:6[/link], [link]17[/link]), who is the source of the living water as the divine supply for God's people ([link]John 4:14[/link]; [link]7:37-39[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 12:13[/link]; [link]Rev. 22:17[/link]). Isaac's source of living made him a burnt offering for God's satisfaction and led him up to Mount Moriah ([link]22:2[/link]), which eventually became Mount Zion, where God's temple was built in Jerusalem ([link]2 Chron. 3:1[/link]). Ultimately, the proper source of living makes us Isaacs and leads us to the New Jerusalem ([link]Gal. 4:26-28[/link]).

chapter.verse: And Abimelech said, I do not know who has done this thing; and you did not tell me [i]about it,[/i] nor have I even heard [i]of it[/i] until today.
And Abraham took sheep and oxen and gave them to Abimelech. And the two of them made a covenant.

verse.text: And Abraham set [note]1[/note]seven ewe lambs of the flock by themselves.
verse.note: Abraham redeemed the well at the cost of seven ewe lambs. In typology the seven ewe lambs signify the full redemption of Christ, indicating that the divine living water has been redeemed, bought back, by Christ's full redemption ([link]John 19:34[/link]).

chapter.verse: And Abimelech said to Abraham, What is the meaning of these seven ewe lambs which you have set by themselves?
And he said, These seven ewe lambs you shall take from my hand, that it may be a witness for me that I dug this well.

verse.text: Therefore he called that place [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Beer-sheba, because there the two of them swore an oath.
verse.note: Meaning [i]well of an oath.[/i]

verse.text: So they made a [note]1[/note]covenant at Beer-sheba; and Abimelech rose up with Phicol the captain of his host, and they returned into the land of the [note]2[/note]Philistines.
verse.note: The covenant here, involving the redeeming of the well at Beer-sheba, is a seed of the new covenant ([link]Jer. 31:31-34[/link]; [link]Heb. 8:8-12[/link]), enacted through Christ's redeeming blood ([link]Matt. 26:28[/link]; [link]Luke 22:20[/link]). Isaac drank of redeemed water, the water of the covenant. Likewise, the living water drunk by the New Testament believers is redeemed and covenanted water.

In typology, the Philistines signify a people who accept God but handle the things of God according to human cleverness, not according to God's economy ([link]1 Sam. 6:1-9[/link] and note [link]4[sup]1[/sup][/link]).

verse.text: And [note]1[/note]Abraham planted a [note]2[/note]tamarisk tree in Beer-sheba, and there he [xref]a[/xref]called on the name of Jehovah, the [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]Eternal God.
verse.note: Lit., he.

A tamarisk, having slender branches and very fine leaves, portrays the flow of the riches of life, the issue of the experience of the tree of life ([link]2:9-10[/link]; cf. [link]John 7:37-38[/link]). Thus, the tamarisk tree signifies the tree of life experienced and expressed.

Heb. [i]El Olam. El,[/i] meaning [i]the Mighty One,[/i] is one of the names of God. [i]Olam,[/i] meaning [i]eternal[/i] or [i]eternity,[/i] comes from a Hebrew root meaning [i]to conceal, to hide.[/i] The divine title [i]El Olam[/i] implies eternal life (cf. [link]John 1:1[/link], [link]4[/link]). Hence, by calling on the name of Jehovah, the Eternal Mighty One, Abraham experienced God as the ever-living, secret, mysterious One, who is the eternal life.

chapter.verse: And Abraham sojourned in the land of the Philistines many days.

verse.text: Now after these things God [xref]a[/xref]tested Abraham and said to him, Abraham. And he said, Here I am.

And He said, Take now your son, your [note]1[/note]only son, whom you love, Isaac, and go to the land of [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]Moriah, and [note]3[/note]offer him there as a [note]4[/note]burnt offering on one of the mountains of which I will tell you.
verse.note: Abraham's offering of his beloved and only son, Isaac, on the altar is a vivid picture of God the Father's offering of His beloved and only Son, Jesus Christ, on the cross. In this picture Isaac typifies Christ in a detailed way. Isaac, as Abraham's only son ([link]vv. 2[/link], [link]12[/link], [link]16[/link]), typifies Christ as God's only begotten Son ([link]John 3:16[/link]). Isaac was Abraham's beloved son ([link]v. 2[/link]), and Christ was the Father's beloved Son, in whom He delighted ([link]Matt. 3:17[/link]). Isaac took his father's will ([link]v. 6[/link]), and Christ also chose the will of His Father ([link]Matt. 26:39[/link]). Isaac was obedient unto death ([link]vv. 9-10[/link]); likewise, Christ was obedient unto death ([link]Phil. 2:8[/link]). Isaac carried the wood for the burnt offering and walked to the top of Mount Moriah ([link]v. 6[/link]); in the same way, Christ bore His cross and walked to Golgotha ([link]John 19:17[/link]). Isaac was offered to God as a burnt offering on Mount Moriah; Christ also was offered to God on the same mountain (see note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in Mark 10[/link]) to fulfill the type of the burnt offering. Isaac was "killed" on the altar and was returned to Abraham on the third day, that is, in resurrection ([link]vv. 4[/link], [link]10-13[/link]; [link]Heb. 11:19[/link]); similarly, Christ was crucified on the cross and was resurrected on the third day ([link]1 Cor. 15:4[/link]). Isaac was multiplied in resurrection ([link]v. 17[/link]), and Christ also was multiplied in His resurrection ([link]John 12:24[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 1:3[/link]). Isaac was the seed of Abraham for the blessing of all the nations ([link]v. 18[/link]); likewise, Christ is the unique seed of Abraham in whom the blessing of Abraham has come to the nations ([link]Gal. 3:8[/link], [link]14[/link], [link]16[/link]).

Meaning [i]the vision of Jah.[/i] Mount Moriah, the place of God's choice, eventually became Mount Zion, the site for the temple (cf. [link]2 Chron. 3:1[/link]) and the center of the good land. Abraham was the first to worship God with the burnt offering on Mount Zion. Later, Abraham's descendants, the children of Israel, were commanded by God to go three times a year to this place to worship God and there to offer to Him their burnt offerings ([link]Deut. 16:16[/link]; [link]Psa. 132:13[/link]). Today, the New Testament believers, Abraham's spiritual descendants, are on Mount Zion ([link]Heb. 12:22-23[/link]). Eventually, we all will join Abraham to worship God on the eternal Mount Zion, the New Jerusalem ([link]Rev. 21:22[/link]).

Isaac, a type of Christ as the promised seed ([link]Gal. 3:16[/link]), was given to Abraham by God. Here God asked Abraham to give back to God what God had given him. This surely was a test to Abraham ([link]v. 1[/link]; [link]Heb. 11:17[/link]). This shows a basic principle in God's economy: all that God has given us, even what He has wrought in us and through us, must eventually be offered back to Him, that we may live a life of faith, not holding on to anything, even to the things given by God, but relying only on Him. After Isaac was offered, he was returned to Abraham in resurrection and became a blessing ([link]vv. 12-13[/link], [link]16[/link], [link]18[/link]; [link]Heb. 11:19[/link]). Likewise, after we have offered to God what we have received of Him, He will return it to us in resurrection and it will become a blessing for the fulfillment of His purpose. See [link]Rom. 4:17[/link] and notes.
See note [link]3[sup]1[/sup] in Lev. 1[/link].

verse.text: And Abraham [note]1[/note]rose early in the morning and saddled his donkey and took two of his young men with him and Isaac his son. And he split the wood for the burnt offering and rose up and went to the place of which God had told him.
verse.note: Abraham obeyed God immediately because he believed in the resurrecting God ([link]v. 5[/link]; [link]Heb. 11:17-19[/link]; [link]James 2:21-22[/link]; [link]Rom. 4:17[/link] and note 1).

chapter.verse: On the third day Abraham lifted up his eyes and saw the place from afar.
And Abraham said to his young men, Stay here with the donkey; and I and the boy will go over there, and we will worship, and [i]then[/i] we will return to you.
And Abraham took the wood for the burnt offering and laid [i]it[/i] upon Isaac his son. And he took in his hand the fire and the knife. And the two of them walked together.
And Isaac spoke to Abraham his father and said, My father! And he said, Here I am, my son. And he said, The fire and the wood are here, but where is the lamb for a burnt offering?

verse.text: And Abraham said, God Himself will [xref]a[/xref]provide the [xref]b[/xref]lamb for a burnt offering, my son. So the two of them walked on together.
And they came to the place of which God had told him. And Abraham built the altar there and laid the wood in order and bound [xref]a[/xref]Isaac his son and laid him on the altar on top of the wood.

chapter.verse: And Abraham stretched out his hand and took the knife to slaughter his son.

verse.text: And the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Angel of Jehovah called to him from the heavens and said, Abraham, Abraham. And he said, Here I am.
verse.note: See note [link]7[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 16[/link].

chapter.verse: And He said, Do not stretch out your hand upon the boy, nor do anything to him; for now I know that you fear God, since you have not withheld your son, your only son, from Me.

verse.text: And Abraham lifted up his eyes and looked, and there behind [i]him[/i] was a [note]1[/note]ram, caught in the [note]2[/note]thicket by its horns. And Abraham went and took the ram and offered it up for a burnt offering in place of his son.
verse.note: The ram here, killed in place of Abraham's son, is a type of Christ as the Lamb of God ([link]John 1:29[/link]) provided by God to replace God's chosen people, those who would inherit God's promised inheritance, as the burnt offering ([link]v. 2[/link]) for God's satisfaction.

Horns signify fighting power, and the thicket signifies humanity. Christ as the Lamb of God was willing to have His "horns" caught by His human nature that He might be offered to God as our Substitute ([link]1 Pet. 3:18[/link]). Cf. [link]Matt. 26:50-54[/link].

verse.text: And Abraham called the name of that place [note]1[/note]Jehovah-jireh, as it is said [i]to[/i] this day, On the [xref]a[/xref]mount of Jehovah [note]2[/note]it will be [xref]b[/xref]provided.
verse.note: Meaning [i]Jehovah will provide,[/i] or [i]Jehovah will see [to it].[/i]
Or, He will be seen.
verse.xref: 2 Chron. 3:1; Isa. 2:3; 30:29; Joel 3:17; Micah 4:2; Zech. 8:3; cf. Num. 10:33

verse.text: And the [xref]a[/xref]Angel of Jehovah called to Abraham a second time from the heavens
And said, By Myself I have [xref]a[/xref]sworn, declares Jehovah: Because you have done this thing and have not withheld your son, your only son,

[xref]a[/xref]I will surely bless you and will greatly multiply your seed like the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]stars of the heavens and like the [note]1[/note][xref]c[/xref]sand which is on the seashore; and your seed shall possess the [xref]d[/xref]gate of his enemies.
verse.note: The stars of the heavens signify Abraham's heavenly descendants, the descendants who are of faith ([link]Gal. 3:7[/link], [link]29[/link]), whereas the sand on the seashore and the dust of the earth ([link]13:16[/link]) signify Abraham's earthly descendants, the descendants in the flesh. The sand on the seashore is the dust beside the sea. This sand is separated from the sea and also washed by the waves of the sea. The sea signifies the Gentile nations ([link]Isa. 57:20[/link]; [link]Rev. 17:15[/link]). The Gentile nations used by God to chastise Israel throughout the centuries ([link]Joel 1:4[/link] and note) were like the waves from the Mediterranean, coming up again and again with their invading armies to wash Israel as the dust to produce a remnant who are like the sand on the seashore ([link]Zech. 12-14[/link]; [link]Rom. 9:27-29[/link]). The New Jerusalem is composed of these two categories of Abraham's descendants ([link]Rev. 21:12[/link], [link]14[/link]). Hence, the New Jerusalem will be the ultimate consummation of Abraham's seed. By being offered to God by Abraham, Isaac was multiplied to become the New Jerusalem. This was God's blessing to Abraham.
verse.xref: Gen. 32:12; Jer. 33:22; 2 Sam. 17:11; 1 Kings 4:20; Isa. 10:22; Hosea 1:10; Rom. 9:27; Heb. 11:12; cf. Gen. 13:16[br/]See note 17[sup]1[/sup].

verse.text: And in your [note]1[/note]seed [xref]a[/xref]all the nations of the earth shall be blessed, because you have [xref]b[/xref]obeyed My voice.
verse.note: According to [link]Gal. 3:14[/link], the promise given to Abraham was that God Himself would come to be the seed of Abraham, and this seed would be a blessing to all the nations by becoming the all-inclusive Spirit for mankind to receive ([link]1 Cor. 15:45[/link]). God's blessing of Abraham eventually issued in Christ as the unique seed in whom all the nations of the earth are blessed ([link]Acts 3:25-26[/link]; [link]Gal. 3:16[/link]). All the believers in Christ, as members of the corporate Christ ([link]1 Cor. 12:12[/link]), are included in this seed as the heirs of God's promised blessing ([link]Gal. 3:7[/link], [link]29[/link] and note [link]29[sup]1[/sup][/link]).[br][br]In this chapter Christ is revealed in three ways: as the Angel of Jehovah ([link]vv. 11-12[/link], [link]15-18[/link]), as the ram ([link]v. 13[/link]), and as the seed of Abraham ([link]v. 18[/link]). The Angel of Jehovah, who is Christ, provided the ram, a type of Christ, which eventually issued in the seed, who is also Christ.

chapter.verse: So Abraham returned to his young men, and they rose up and went together to Beer-sheba. And Abraham dwelt in Beer-sheba.
And after these things it was told Abraham, saying, Milcah has now also borne children to your brother Nahor:
Uz his firstborn and Buz his brother and Kemuel the father of Aram
And Chesed and Hazo and Pildash and Jidlaph and Bethuel;

verse.text: And Bethuel begot [note]1[/note]Rebekah. These eight Milcah bore to Nahor, Abraham's brother.
verse.note: Meaning [i]ensnarer.[/i]

chapter.verse: And his concubine, whose name was Reumah, also bore Tebah and Gaham and Tahash and Maacah.
And the life of Sarah was one hundred twenty-seven years. [i]These were[/i] the years of the life of Sarah.

verse.text: And Sarah died in Kiriath-arba (that is, [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Hebron) in the land of Canaan. And Abraham proceeded to mourn for Sarah and to weep for her.
verse.note: See note [link]18[sup]3[/sup] in ch. 13[/link].

verse.text: Then Abraham rose up from before his dead [i]wife[/i] and spoke to the [note]1[/note]children of Heth, saying,
verse.note: I.e., the Hittites.

verse.text: I am a stranger and a [xref]a[/xref]sojourner among you. Give me the possession of a burial place among you that I may bury my dead [i]wife[/i] out of my sight.

chapter.verse: And the children of Heth answered Abraham, saying to him,

verse.text: Hear us, my lord. You are a prince of God in our midst. In the [note]1[/note]choicest of our burial places bury your dead [i]wife.[/i] None of us will withhold from you his burial place for burying your dead [i]wife.[/i]
verse.note: Abraham buried Sarah in the choicest burial place. He cared much more for the place in which he and his descendants would be buried than for his tent as his earthly dwelling (cf. [link]Matt. 8:20[/link]; [link]27:57-60[/link]). He was more concerned for the future than for the present. This is because he considered himself a stranger and a sojourner on the earth, looking for a permanent city and a better country ([link]Heb. 11:9-10[/link], [link]16[/link]).

chapter.verse: And Abraham rose up and bowed down to the people of the land, to the children of Heth.
And he spoke with them, saying, If it is your desire that I should bury my dead [i]wife[/i] out of my sight, hear me, and entreat Ephron the son of Zohar for me,

verse.text: That he would give me the cave of [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Machpelah, which is his [i]and[/i] which is at the end of his [note]2[/note]field. For the full price let him give it to me in your midst for the possession of a burial place.
verse.note: Meaning [i]double, doubling.[/i] Abraham and Sarah, Isaac and Rebekah, and Jacob and Leah, three couples, were all buried in the cave of Machpelah ([link]v. 19[/link]; [link]25:9[/link]; [link]49:29-32[/link]; [link]50:13[/link]). The names Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob are the components of the divine title of God, who is the God of resurrection ([link]Exo. 3:15[/link]; [link]Matt. 22:32[/link] and note).

Although Abraham, Sarah, and Isaac were living at Beer-sheba ([link]21:33[/link]), Sarah died and was buried in Hebron, the place of fellowship with God. Hebron is between Beer-sheba on the south and Jerusalem on the north. Thus, Hebron was not only a place of fellowship but also a way that led to Jerusalem. In spiritual significance, the cave of Machpelah in Hebron ([link]v. 19[/link]), in which Sarah was buried, is the gateway to the New Jerusalem.[br][br]The cave of Machpelah was at the end of a field, in which were many trees ([link]v. 17[/link]). A field is a place where life grows; thus, it implies resurrection. Abraham did not bury Sarah in a place of death but in a place of life, a place full of resurrection ([link]1 Cor. 15:36[/link] and note). This indicates that Abraham believed in the God of resurrection ([link]Rom. 4:17[/link]) and was filled with the expectation that his wife would be resurrected and would be in the city which has the foundations, the New Jerusalem. According to Abraham's realization, Sarah's death was not a termination but an entering into the gate of resurrection, the gateway into the expected city and the better country ([link]Heb. 11:10[/link], [link]16[/link]).

chapter.verse: Now Ephron was sitting in the midst of the children of Heth. And Ephron the Hittite answered Abraham in the hearing of the children of Heth, [i]in the hearing[/i] of all who went in at the gate of his city, saying,
No, my lord, hear me. I give you the field and the cave that is in it; to you I give it. In the presence of the children of my people I give it to you; bury your dead [i]wife.[/i]
And Abraham bowed down before the people of the land.

And he spoke to Ephron in the hearing of the people of the land, saying, But if you will, please hear me; I will give the price of the field. Take [i]it[/i] from me, that I may bury my dead [i]wife[/i] there.
And Ephron answered Abraham, saying to him,
My lord, listen to me. A piece of land worth four hundred shekels of silver, what is that between me and you? Therefore bury your dead [i]wife.[/i]
And Abraham listened to Ephron, and Abraham weighed out to Ephron the silver which he had named in the hearing of the children of Heth, four hundred shekels of silver, current with the merchant.

verse.text: So the field of Ephron, which was in [xref]a[/xref]Machpelah [i]and[/i] which was before Mamre, the field and the cave which was in it and all the trees that were in the field, which were in all its territory, were assured

chapter.verse: To Abraham for a possession in the presence of the children of Heth, in the presence of all who went in at the gate of his city.
And after this, Abraham buried Sarah his wife in the cave of the field of Machpelah before Mamre (that is, Hebron) in the land of Canaan.
And the field and the cave that is in it were assured to Abraham for the possession of a burial place from the children of Heth.

verse.text: And Abraham was old [i]and[/i] advanced in age. And Jehovah had [xref]a[/xref]blessed Abraham in all things.
[note]1[/note]And Abraham said to his [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]servant, the oldest of his house, who ruled over all that he had, Put your hand under my thigh;
verse.note: This chapter primarily reveals the practical living of God's people in oneness with God for the accomplishing of His eternal purpose. The marriage of Isaac was not merely for his human living; it was altogether for the producing of a people, the seed of Abraham, for the fulfillment of God's purpose ([link]22:17[/link]). Thus, in the gaining of a wife for Isaac, everything was done according to God's economy to bring forth Christ for the producing of the kingdom of God.[br][br]This chapter also presents a rich type of the marriage of Christ, typified by Isaac, and the church, typified by Rebekah.

In this account of the marriage of Isaac, Abraham typifies God the Father, the servant typifies God the Spirit, Isaac typifies God the Son, and Rebekah typifies the chosen people of God, who will marry the Son and become His counterpart. The entire New Testament is a record of the Triune God working together to gain a part of the human race to be the bride, the counterpart, of the Son ([link]John 3:29[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 11:2[/link]; [link]Eph. 5:25-32[/link]; [link]Rev. 19:7-9[/link]; [link]21:2[/link], [link]9-10[/link]). In eternity past God the Father had an eternal purpose and made an eternal plan to gain the church as a bride for His Son out of the human race ([link]Eph. 3:8-11[/link]).
