Then, in time, God the Father commissioned God the Spirit to carry out His plan by going to contact the chosen bride and bring her to God the Son to be His counterpart, His wife.

verse.text: And I will make you swear by Jehovah, the [xref]a[/xref]God of heaven and the God of earth, that you will [note]1[/note]not take a wife for my son from the [xref]b[/xref]daughters of the Canaanites, among whom I am dwelling.
verse.note: There is no record that God told Abraham not to take a wife for his son from among the Canaanite women (cf. [link]Deut. 7:1-4[/link]). Because Abraham lived in oneness with God ([link]v. 40a[/link]), he knew God's will and mind and acted in accordance with God's inner feeling (cf. [link]1 Cor. 7:25[/link] and note; [link]2 Cor. 2:10[/link] and note 3; [link]Phil. 1:8[/link] and note).

verse.text: But you shall go to my country and to my [note]1[/note]relatives, and take a [xref]a[/xref]wife for my son Isaac.
verse.note: In typology, the fact that Isaac's bride was taken from Abraham's relatives indicates that the counterpart of Christ must come from Christ's race, not from the angels or from any other creatures ([link]2:18-23[/link] and notes). Since Christ was incarnated to be a man ([link]Heb. 2:14a[/link]), humanity has become His race.

chapter.verse: And the servant said to him, Perhaps the woman will not be willing to follow me to this land. Must I then take your son back to the land from where you came?

verse.text: And Abraham said to him, [note]1[/note]Be certain not to take my son back there.
verse.note: Abraham's word to his servant in [link]vv. 6-8[/link] and [link]40[/link] indicates that he lived by faith in the sovereign Lord for the carrying out of His economy in the land of God's promise.

verse.text: Jehovah, the [xref]a[/xref]God of heaven, who [xref]b[/xref]took me from my father's house and from the land of my birth, and who spoke to me, and who swore to me, saying, To your [xref]c[/xref]seed I will give this land, He will send His angel before you; and you shall take a wife for my son from there.

chapter.verse: And if the woman is not willing to follow you, you shall be free from this oath of mine; only you shall not take my son back there.
So the servant put his hand under the thigh of Abraham his master and swore to him concerning this matter.

verse.text: And the servant took ten camels from the camels of his master and departed, having all kinds of his master's good things in his hand. And he rose up and went to [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Aram-naharaim, to the city of Nahor.
verse.note: Meaning [i]Aram of the two rivers;[/i] i.e., Mesopotamia.

chapter.verse: And he made the camels kneel down outside the city by the well of water at the time of evening, at the time when women go out to draw [i]water.[/i]

verse.text: And he said, O Jehovah, the God of my master [xref]a[/xref]Abraham, [note]1[/note]please grant me success today, and show lovingkindness to my master Abraham.
verse.note: The servant's prayer here indicates that he followed in Abraham's footsteps, trusting in the Lord for the carrying out of his responsibility ([link]vv. 21[/link], [link]42[/link]).

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]I am standing here by the spring of water as the daughters of the men of the city are coming out to draw water.

chapter.verse: And may it be that the girl to whom I say, Please let down your pitcher that I may drink, and who says, Drink, and I will also give your camels a drink, may she be the one whom You have appointed for Your servant, for Isaac; and in this I will know that You have shown kindness to my master.
But before he had finished speaking, there was Rebekah, who was born to Bethuel the son of Milcah, the wife of Nahor, Abraham's brother, coming out with her pitcher upon her shoulder.

verse.text: And the girl was very beautiful in appearance, a [note]1[/note]virgin, and no man had known her. And she went down to the spring and filled her pitcher and came up.
verse.note: Rebekah was chaste, kind, and diligent. She was also absolute in her decision to take Isaac as her husband ([link]vv. 57-58[/link], [link]61[/link]) and was submissive to Isaac ([link]vv. 64-65[/link]). As such, she is an excellent type of the church as the bride, the wife, of Christ.

chapter.verse: And the servant ran to meet her and said, Please let me sip a little water from your pitcher.
And she said, Drink, my lord. And she hurried and lowered her pitcher on her hand and gave him a drink.
And when she had finished giving him a drink, she said, I will draw [i]water[/i] for your camels also, until they have finished drinking.
And she hurried and emptied her pitcher into the trough and ran again to the well to draw [i]water,[/i] and she drew [i]it[/i] for all his camels.
And the man gazed fixedly upon her in silence to know whether Jehovah had made his journey prosperous or not.

verse.text: And when the camels had finished drinking, the man took a golden [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]nose-ring weighing [note]2[/note]half a shekel and two [note]1[/note]bracelets for her hands weighing [note]2[/note]ten gold shekels,
verse.note: These gifts, sent from Isaac and given by the servant of Abraham, the father, signify the riches of Christ given by the Spirit of God to the bride for the accomplishing of God's purpose. These gifts relate to the function of the believers. Gold signifies the divine nature, and a ring signifies the initial gift of the Spirit ([link]Acts 2:38[/link]), which is the Spirit Himself as a seal and a pledge, a foretaste of God as our eternal portion ([link]Eph. 1:13-14[/link]; cf. [link]Luke 15:22[/link]). The function of the nose is to smell. The putting of the nose-ring upon Rebekah's nose ([link]v. 47[/link]) signifies, spiritually, that her "smelling" function had been caught by the divine nature (cf. [link]2 Cor. 2:14-16[/link]; [link]Heb. 6:4-6[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 2:2-3[/link]; [link]2 Pet. 1:4[/link]). Hands are for working (see note [link]8[sup]3[/sup] in 1 Tim. 2[/link]). The putting of the bracelets on Rebekah's hands signifies the receiving of the divine function for the service in the Body of Christ ([link]Rom. 12:4[/link]).

The half shekel signifies the first taste, the foretaste, of the Spirit, which guarantees that the full taste is coming ([link]Rom. 8:23[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 1:22[/link]; [link]Eph. 1:13-14[/link]). The ten shekels, ten signifying fullness, or completeness (e.g., the Ten Commandments, which express God's demand in full), indicate that the divine function we have received of the Spirit is complete, not partial ([link]1 Cor. 12:4-11[/link]).

chapter.verse: And said, Whose daughter are you? Please tell me, is there room in your father's house for us to lodge in?
And she said to him, I am the daughter of Bethuel the son of Milcah, whom she bore to Nahor.
She also said to him, We have plenty of straw and fodder and also a place to lodge.

verse.text: And the man bowed and [xref]a[/xref]worshipped Jehovah.

And he said, Blessed be Jehovah, the God of my master [xref]a[/xref]Abraham, who has not forsaken His lovingkindness and His faithfulness toward my master. As for me, Jehovah has led me in the way to the house of my master's brothers.

chapter.verse: And the girl ran and told her mother's house about these things.

verse.text: And Rebekah had a brother whose name was [xref]a[/xref]Laban, and Laban ran out to the man, to the spring.

chapter.verse: As soon as he had seen the nose-ring and the bracelets upon his sister's hands, and had heard the words of Rebekah his sister, saying, This is what the man spoke to me, he went to the man. And there he was, standing by the camels at the spring.

verse.text: And he said, Come in, O [xref]a[/xref]blessed of Jehovah! Why do you stand outside when I have prepared the house and a place for the camels?

And the man came into the house, and [note]1[/note]Laban unloaded the camels. And he gave straw and fodder to the camels and water to [xref]a[/xref]wash his feet and the feet of the men who were with him.
verse.note: Lit., he.

chapter.verse: And [i]food[/i] was set before him to eat. But he said, I will not eat until I have stated my business. And he said, Speak on.
And he said, I am Abraham's servant.

verse.text: And Jehovah has [xref]a[/xref]blessed my master greatly, and he has become great. And He has given him flocks and herds, and silver and gold, and male servants and female servants, and camels and donkeys.
And Sarah my master's wife bore a [xref]a[/xref]son to my master after she had become old. And he has given [xref]b[/xref]all that he has to him.
And my master made me [xref]a[/xref]swear, saying, You shall not take a wife for my son from the daughters of the Canaanites, in whose land I dwell.

chapter.verse: But you shall go to my father's house and to my family, and take a wife for my son.
And I said to my master, Perhaps the woman will not follow me.

verse.text: And he said to me, Jehovah, before whom I walk, will send His [xref]a[/xref]angel with you and make your journey prosperous. And you shall take a wife for my son from my family, even from my father's house.

chapter.verse: Then you will be free from my oath, when you come to my family and if they do not give [i]her[/i] to you; you will be free from my oath.

verse.text: And I came today to the spring and said, O Jehovah, the God of my master [xref]a[/xref]Abraham, if now You will only make my journey on which I go prosperous!

[xref]a[/xref]I am standing here by the spring of water, and may it be that the maiden who comes out to draw [i]water,[/i] to whom I will say, Please give me a little water from your pitcher to drink,
And she will say to me, [xref]a[/xref]Drink, and I will also draw [i]water[/i] for your camels, may she be the woman whom Jehovah has appointed for my master's son.

chapter.verse: Before I had finished speaking in my heart, there came Rebekah, and her pitcher was on her shoulder. And she went down to the spring and drew [i]water.[/i] And I said to her, Please let me drink.
And she hurried and let down her pitcher from her [i]shoulder[/i] and said, Drink, and I will also give your camels a drink. So I drank, and she also gave the camels a drink.

verse.text: And I asked her and said, Whose daughter are you? And she said, The daughter of Bethuel, Nahor's son, whom Milcah bore to him. And I put the [xref]a[/xref]nose-ring upon her nose and the bracelets upon her hands.

And I bowed and [xref]a[/xref]worshipped Jehovah and blessed Jehovah, the God of my master Abraham, who had led me in the right way to take the daughter of my master's [xref]b[/xref]brother for his son.

chapter.verse: And now if you will deal kindly and truly with my master, tell me [i]so;[/i] but if not, tell me [i]so,[/i] that I may turn to the right hand or to the left.
Then Laban and Bethuel answered and said, The matter comes from Jehovah; we cannot speak to you bad or good.
Here is Rebekah before you: Take [i]her,[/i] and go; and let her be the wife of your master's son, as Jehovah has spoken.
And when Abraham's servant heard their words, he bowed down to the earth to Jehovah.

verse.text: And the servant brought forth [note]1[/note]silver jewelry and gold jewelry and clothing and gave them to Rebekah. He also gave precious things to her brother and to her mother.
verse.note: The gold nose-ring and bracelets ([link]v. 22[/link]), the silver and gold jewelry, and the clothing given to Rebekah, along with the precious things given to her brother and her mother, symbolize the unsearchable riches of Christ ([link]Eph. 3:8[/link]). The servant testified to Rebekah concerning Isaac's riches, which he inherited from his father ([link]vv. 35-36[/link]), and gave some of these riches to Rebekah as a foretaste. This caused Rebekah to be attracted to Isaac and made her willing to leave her father's house to be his wife ([link]v. 58[/link]) even though she had never seen him. In the same manner the Spirit comes to Christ's believers and testifies to them of the riches of Christ, which He has received from the Father ([link]John 16:13-15[/link]), causing them to be attracted to Christ and to love Him, to forsake the world, and to leave their natural relations in the flesh to be joined to Christ ([link]Matt. 19:29[/link]), even though they have never seen Him ([link]1 Pet. 1:8[/link]). Before Rebekah met Isaac in the good land, she had participated in and enjoyed Isaac's inheritance through the servant's gifts. Likewise, before we meet Christ, we enjoy the gifts of the Spirit as a foretaste of the full taste of His riches ([link]Heb. 6:4[/link]; [link]Rom. 8:23[/link]).

chapter.verse: And they ate and drank, he and the men who were with him, and spent the night. And they rose up in the morning, and he said, Send me away to my master.
And her brother and her mother said, Let the girl stay with us [i]a few days,[/i] ten [i]or so;[/i] after that she may go.
And he said to them, Do not delay me, since Jehovah has made my journey prosperous. Send me away that I may go to my master.

verse.text: And they said, Let us call the girl and ask [note]1[/note]her.
verse.note: Lit., from her mouth.

chapter.verse: And they called Rebekah and said to her, Will you go with this man? And she said, I will go.

verse.text: So they sent away Rebekah their sister and her [xref]a[/xref]nurse and Abraham's servant and his men.

And they blessed Rebekah and said to her,[br/]May you, our sister, become / [xref]a[/xref]Thousands of ten thousands, / And may your seed possess / The [xref]b[/xref]gate of those who hate [note]1[/note]them.
verse.note: Or, him.

chapter.verse: And Rebekah arose with her maids, and they rode on the camels and followed the man. And the servant took Rebekah and went away.

verse.text: Now Isaac had come from going to [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Beer-lahai-roi, for he was dwelling in the region of the Negev.
verse.note: Meaning [i]well of the living One who sees me,[/i] or [i]well of the One who reveals Himself.[/i]

chapter.verse: And Isaac went out to meditate in the field toward evening. And he lifted up his eyes and looked, and behold, camels were coming.
And Rebekah lifted up her eyes; and when she saw Isaac, she sprang off the camel.

verse.text: And she said to the servant, Who is this man who is walking in the field to meet us? And the servant said, It is my master. And she took her [xref]a[/xref]veil and covered herself.

chapter.verse: And the servant told Isaac all the things that he had done.

verse.text: And Isaac [note]1[/note]brought her into the tent of Sarah his mother. And he took Rebekah, and she became his wife, and he loved her. And Isaac was comforted after [i]the death of[/i] his mother.
verse.note: Isaac, Abraham's son, did nothing but receive his bride. This signifies that everything is planned by the Father and accomplished by the Spirit. The Son only receives the bride.[br][br]Isaac received Rebekah in the evening ([link]v. 63[/link]), signifying that the marriage of Christ will be at the evening, the close, of this age. Isaac brought Rebekah into the tent of Sarah, his mother, and loved Rebekah, signifying that Christ will receive His bride in grace (typified by Sarah) as well as in love. After marrying Rebekah, Isaac was comforted, satisfied; likewise, Christ will be satisfied on the day of His marriage.

verse.text: And Abraham took [note]1[/note]another wife, whose name was [xref]a[/xref]Keturah.
verse.note: Although Abraham was called by God, was justified and lived by faith in God, and lived in fellowship with God, he did not attain to maturity in his spiritual life. This is shown by the fact that, after Sarah died, Abraham remarried and brought forth six sons by the energy of his flesh. Furthermore, at the end of his days Abraham did not bless anyone, in contrast to Isaac and Jacob ([link]27:27-29[/link]; [link]48:13-20[/link]; [link]49:1-28[/link]; cf. [link]Heb. 7:7[/link]).[br][br]As far as the experience of life is concerned, Abraham cannot stand as a complete person. He needed Isaac and Jacob (with Joseph) to complete him. See note [link]1[sup]1[/sup], par. 2, in ch. 12[/link].

verse.text: And she bore him Zimran and Jokshan and Medan and [xref]a[/xref]Midian and Ishbak and Shuah.

chapter.verse: And Jokshan begot Sheba and Dedan. And the sons of Dedan were the Asshurim and the Letushim and the Leummim.
And the sons of Midian: Ephah and Epher and Hanoch and Abida and Eldaah. All these were the sons of Keturah.

verse.text: And Abraham gave [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]all that he had to [note]2[/note]Isaac.
verse.note: God considered Isaac as Abraham's only son, the unique seed to inherit the promises given by God to Abraham for the fulfillment of His purpose ([link]22:2[/link], [link]12[/link], [link]16[/link], [link]18[/link]; [link]17:19[/link]; [link]26:3-4[/link]). As such, he typifies Christ as the only begotten Son of the Father ([link]John 1:14[/link]; [link]3:16[/link]), who was given by the Father all that the Father has ([link]John 3:35[/link]; [link]16:15a[/link]). It was by grace, not by Isaac's effort, that Isaac became the heir of his father's riches.

In Genesis the records of Abraham ([link]12:1-25:18[/link]) and Isaac ([link]21:1-8[/link]; [link]22:1-24[/link]; [link]24:1-67[/link]) overlap. Abraham's life reveals that if we would enjoy God's grace and have the full enjoyment of God's riches, we must suffer loss and have our natural life circumcised, cut off. Isaac's life reveals that our suffering to terminate our natural life is for the enjoyment of God's grace. Throughout his entire life Isaac did nothing but enjoy God's rich blessing ([link]v. 11[/link]; [link]26:24b[/link]), which points to the grace of the New Testament (see note [link]11[sup]1[/sup][/link]). Isaac was born in grace ([link]21:1-3[/link]; [link]Gal. 4:23[/link]), grew up in grace ([link]21:8[/link]), and was made an heir of grace ([link]v. 5[/link]). In the New Testament, all the called believers are heirs of grace, destined to enjoy God's absolute and unconditional grace ([link]Eph. 1:3[/link], [link]6-8[/link]; [link]2:7[/link]).

chapter.verse: But to the sons of the concubines that Abraham had, Abraham gave gifts. And he sent them away from Isaac his son, while he was still living, eastward to the east country.
And these are the days of the years of Abraham's life which he lived, one hundred seventy-five years.
And Abraham expired and died in a good old age, an old man and full [i]of days,[/i] and he was gathered to his people.

verse.text: And Isaac and Ishmael his sons buried him in the cave of [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Machpelah, in the field of Ephron the son of Zohar the Hittite, which faces Mamre,
verse.note: See notes on [link]23:9[/link].

verse.text: The field which Abraham purchased of the children of Heth; there [xref]a[/xref]Abraham was buried with Sarah his wife.
And after the death of Abraham, God [note]1[/note]blessed Isaac his son. And Isaac dwelt by [xref]a[/xref]Beer-lahai-roi.
verse.note: The blessing in the Old Testament corresponds to the grace in the New Testament (see note [link]3[sup]6[/sup] in Eph. 1[/link]). God's free gift to us is His blessing. When God's free gift in Christ is wrought into us to be the life element within us, it becomes grace. See note [link]2[sup]2[/sup] in Rom. 5[/link].

verse.text: Now these are the generations of [xref]a[/xref]Ishmael, Abraham's son, whom Hagar the Egyptian, Sarah's female servant, bore to Abraham.
And these are the names of the [xref]a[/xref]sons of Ishmael, by their names according to their generations: the firstborn of Ishmael, Nebaioth; then Kedar and Adbeel and Mibsam

chapter.verse: And Mishma and Dumah and Massa;
Hadad and Tema, Jetur, Naphish, and Kedemah.
These are the sons of Ishmael, and these are their names by their villages and by their encampments, twelve princes according to their peoples.
And these are the years of the life of Ishmael, one hundred thirty-seven years. And he expired and died and was gathered to his people.
And they dwelt from Havilah to Shur, which faces Egypt, as you go toward Assyria. He settled down opposite all his brothers.

verse.text: And these are the generations of Isaac, Abraham's son. Abraham begot [xref]a[/xref]Isaac.

chapter.verse: And Isaac was forty years old when he took Rebekah, the daughter of Bethuel the Aramaean of Paddan-aram, the sister of Laban the Aramaean, to be his wife.

verse.text: And Isaac [note]1[/note]entreated Jehovah for his wife because she was barren. And Jehovah was entreated of him, and Rebekah his wife [xref]a[/xref]conceived.
verse.note: Isaac's need to have a son corresponded with God's need to have a seed out of Isaac for the fulfillment of His eternal purpose. Because of this, God answered Isaac's entreaty. Eventually, Isaac's son Jacob not only met Isaac's need but also fulfilled God's purpose, for out of Jacob came Christ ([link]Matt. 1:1-2[/link]), who brings in the church, the kingdom, and the New Jerusalem.

chapter.verse: And the children struggled with each other within her. And she said, If it is so, why am I [i]like this?[/i] And she went to inquire of Jehovah.

verse.text: And Jehovah said to her,[br/][note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Two nations are in your womb, / And two peoples shall be separated from your bowels. / And the one people shall be [xref]b[/xref]stronger than the other people. / And the older shall [xref]c[/xref]serve the [note]2[/note]younger.
verse.note: I.e., Israel ([link]32:28[/link]) and Edom ([link]v. 30[/link]; [link]36:1[/link], [link]43[/link]; [link]Jer. 49:7-8[/link]; [link]Obad. 8[/link]).

This was God's choosing, His selecting, of Jacob before he was born, corresponding with God's choosing before the foundation of the world ([link]Rom. 9:11a[/link]; [link]Eph. 1:4[/link]). God's choosing of Jacob was according to His foreknowledge ([link]1 Pet. 1:2[/link]; [link]Rom. 8:29[/link]), not of Jacob's works but of God who calls and who shows mercy ([link]Rom. 9:11b[/link], [link]16[/link]). God's choosing is with His predestinating and is followed by His calling ([link]Eph. 1:4-5[/link]; [link]Rom. 8:30[/link]).

chapter.verse: And when her days to be delivered were fulfilled, behold, there were twins in her womb.

verse.text: And the first came forth red, all over like a hairy garment; and they called his name [note]1[/note]Esau.
verse.note: Meaning [i]hairy, rough.[/i]

verse.text: And after that his brother came forth, and his hand was [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]holding on to Esau's heel, so his name was called [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]Jacob. And Isaac was sixty years old when she bore them.
verse.note: Even while he was still in his mother's womb Jacob was striving to be the firstborn. His desire to be the first corresponded with God's intention that he be the one who would receive the birthright. However, like his grandfather Abraham, Jacob exercised his natural ability and his natural strength to fulfill God's intention and satisfy his desire. Although God had chosen him to be the first, God sovereignly caused Jacob to be born the second so that he might learn that his natural man was altogether unworthy and had to be cut off. Since Jacob's natural man was not qualified, he needed to be transformed.[br][br]The record of Jacob's life occupies more than half of the book of Genesis. This long record shows us that the purpose of God in His selecting, predestinating, and calling is to transform sinners into royal sons of God who bear God's image to express Him and exercise God's dominion to represent Him (cf. [link]1:26[/link]). God destined Jacob to live a struggling life all his days. Furthermore, God sovereignly arranged every circumstance, situation, and person in Jacob's life and caused them all to work together for Jacob's good, so that He could transform Jacob, a supplanter and a heel holder, into Israel, a prince of God. In particular, God used Jacob's family, including his father, his mother, his brother, his uncle, and his wives and children, to deal with Jacob for his transformation. God's dealing with Jacob is a full picture of the Holy Spirit's discipline and His transforming work in the New Testament believers ([link]Rom. 8:28-29[/link]; [link]12:2[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 3:18[/link]).
Meaning [i]supplanter, heel holder.[/i]

verse.text: And when the boys grew up, Esau became a skillful hunter, a man of the field; but Jacob was a quiet man, dwelling in [xref]a[/xref]tents.
Now Isaac loved Esau because [note]1[/note]he had a taste for game, but Rebekah loved Jacob.
verse.note: Lit., game was in his mouth. Isaac's preferential love for his firstborn son was altogether in the natural life and according to the natural taste and preference, as was Rebekah's love for Jacob and Jacob's love for Joseph ([link]37:3-4[/link]). Although Isaac lived in a natural way, he nevertheless enjoyed God's grace. However, his living in the natural life caused him to suffer, as was the case with Rebekah and Jacob.

chapter.verse: And Jacob cooked a stew. And Esau came in from the field, and he was faint.

verse.text: And Esau said to Jacob, Let me swallow down some of the red [i]stew,[/i] that red [i]stew there,[/i] for I am faint. Therefore his name was called [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Edom.
verse.note: Meaning [i]red.[/i]

verse.text: And Jacob said, [note]1[/note]First sell me your birthright.
verse.note: Lit., today. So also in [link]v. 33[/link].

chapter.verse: And Esau said, I am now about to die. Of what use then is this birthright to me?

verse.text: And Jacob said, First swear to me. And he swore to him and sold his [xref]a[/xref]birthright to Jacob.
And Jacob gave Esau bread and lentil stew, and he ate and drank and rose up and went away. Thus Esau [note]1[/note]despised his birthright.
verse.note: Concerning Esau's despising of the birthright, see [link]Heb. 12:16-17[/link] and notes.

verse.text: And there was a famine in the land, besides the former [xref]a[/xref]famine that had occurred in the days of Abraham. So Isaac went to Abimelech the king of the Philistines at Gerar.

chapter.verse: And Jehovah appeared to him and said, Do not go down to Egypt; dwell in the land of which I will tell you.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Sojourn in this land, and I will be [xref]b[/xref]with you and will [note]1[/note]bless you; for to you and to your [xref]c[/xref]seed I will give all these lands, and I will [xref]d[/xref]establish the [xref]e[/xref]oath which I swore to Abraham your father.
verse.note: Isaac inherited not only all that his father had but also the promise God had given to his father concerning the good land and the unique seed, who is Christ, in whom all the nations of the earth were to be blessed ([link]Gal. 3:14[/link], [link]16[/link]). This promise was actually for the fulfillment of God's purpose that God might have a kingdom on the earth in which to express Himself through a corporate people. See notes [link]2[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 12[/link] and [link]3[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 15[/link].

verse.text: And I will multiply your seed as the [xref]a[/xref]stars of heaven and will give to your seed all these lands; and in your seed [xref]b[/xref]all the nations of the earth will be blessed,
Because Abraham [xref]a[/xref]obeyed My voice and kept My charge, My commandments, My statutes, and My laws.

chapter.verse: So Isaac dwelt in Gerar.

verse.text: And the men of the place asked about his wife. And he said, [note]1[/note]She is my [xref]a[/xref]sister, for he was afraid to say, My wife, [i]thinking,[/i] The men of this place might slay me on account of Rebekah, because she is beautiful in appearance.
verse.note: This exposed Isaac's natural weakness, which was the same as his father Abraham's (cf. [link]20:1-2[/link], [link]11-13[/link]).

chapter.verse: And when he had been there a long time, Abimelech the king of the Philistines looked out through his window and saw, and there was Isaac playfully [i]caressing[/i] Rebekah his wife.
And Abimelech called Isaac and said, So she is indeed your wife. How then did you say, She is my sister? And Isaac said to him, Because I thought I might die on account of her.
And Abimelech said, What is this you have done to us? One of the people might easily have lain with your wife, and you would have brought guilt upon us.
And Abimelech charged all the people, saying, He who touches this man or his wife shall surely be put to death.

verse.text: And Isaac sowed in that land and gained in the same year a [xref]a[/xref]hundredfold. And Jehovah [xref]b[/xref]blessed him,
And the man became [note]1[/note]rich and continued to grow [note]1[/note]richer until he became very [note]1[/note]rich.
verse.note: Or, great...greater...great.

verse.text: And he had possessions of flocks and possessions of herds and a great [note]1[/note]household, so that the Philistines envied him.
verse.note: Or, body of servants.

verse.text: Now all the wells which his father's servants had [xref]a[/xref]dug in the days of Abraham his father the Philistines had stopped up and filled with earth.

chapter.verse: And Abimelech said to Isaac, Go away from us, for you are much mightier than we.
So Isaac went away from there and camped in the valley of Gerar and dwelt there.

verse.text: And Isaac dug again the wells of water which had been dug in the days of Abraham his father and [i]which[/i] the Philistines had stopped up after the death of Abraham; and he called them by the same [xref]a[/xref]names which his father had given them.
And Isaac's servants dug in the valley and found there a well of [note]1[/note]springing water.
verse.note: Lit., living. See note [link]16[sup]1[/sup] in Num. 21[/link].

verse.text: And the shepherds of Gerar strove with Isaac's shepherds, saying, The water is ours. So he called the name of the well [note]1[/note]Esek, because they contended with him.
verse.note: Meaning [i]contention.[/i]

verse.text: And they dug another well; and they strove over that also, so he called the name of it [note]1[/note]Sitnah.
verse.note: Meaning [i]enmity.[/i]

verse.text: And he moved away from there and dug another well, but they did not strive over it, so he called the name of it [note]1[/note]Rehoboth; and he said, Now Jehovah has made room for us, and we will be fruitful in the land.
verse.note: Meaning [i]broad places, broad ways.[/i]

chapter.verse: And he went up from there to Beer-sheba.

verse.text: And Jehovah [note]1[/note]appeared to him the same night and said, I am the [xref]a[/xref]God of Abraham your father. Do not be afraid, for I am [xref]b[/xref]with you, and I will bless you and multiply your seed for My servant Abraham's sake.
verse.note: Although Isaac enjoyed God's unconditional grace, finding enjoyment and satisfaction (signified by a well) in every place that he went ([link]25:11[/link]; [link]26:15-22[/link]), Beer-sheba was the unique place in which he experienced God's appearing, received His promise, built an altar, called on the name of the Lord, and pitched a tent as a testimony. God's called ones are destined to enjoy God's grace regardless of their standing, but this enjoyment does not justify their standing. If we desire to have God's appearing, inherit His promises, and live a life for the fulfillment of His eternal purpose, we must come to the unique place that God has chosen and remain there. This unique place is signified by Beer-sheba, with the well for life supply and the tamarisk tree as the expression of the rich flow of life ([link]21:25[/link], [link]33[/link]). Cf. notes [link book="Deut." chapter="12"]5[sup]1[/sup][/link] and [link]17[sup]1[/sup] in Deut. 12[/link].

verse.text: And he built an [xref]a[/xref]altar there and [xref]b[/xref]called upon the name of Jehovah and pitched his [xref]c[/xref]tent there. And there Isaac's servants dug a well.
And Abimelech came to him from Gerar with Ahuzzath his [note]1[/note]adviser and Phicol the captain of his army.
verse.note: Or, friend.

chapter.verse: And Isaac said to them, Why have you come to me, since you hate me and have sent me away from you?
And they said, We see plainly that Jehovah is with you; so we say, Let there now be an oath between us, [i]even[/i] between us and you, and let us make a covenant with you,

verse.text: That you will not do us any harm, just as we have not touched you, and just as we have done to you nothing but good and have sent you away in peace. You are now the [xref]a[/xref]blessed of Jehovah.

chapter.verse: And he made them a feast, and they ate and drank.

verse.text: And they rose up early in the morning and [xref]a[/xref]swore to one another. And Isaac sent them away, and they departed from him in peace.

chapter.verse: And the same day Isaac's servants came and told him about the well which they had dug and said to him, We have found water.

verse.text: And he called it [note]1[/note]Shibah. Therefore the name of the city is [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]Beer-sheba to this day.
verse.note: Meaning [i]oath.[/i]
Meaning [i]well of oath.[/i]

verse.text: Now when Esau was forty years old, he took as wife Judith the [xref]a[/xref]daughter of Beeri the Hittite and Basemath the daughter of Elon the Hittite.
And they caused [xref]a[/xref]bitterness of spirit to Isaac and to Rebekah.
Now when Isaac was old, and his eyes had become so [xref]a[/xref]dim that he could not see, he called Esau his older son and said to him, My son. And he said to him, Here I am.

chapter.verse: And he said, Behold now, I am old, [i]and[/i] I do not know the day of my death.

verse.text: Now then, please take your weapons, your quiver and your bow, and go out to the field, and [xref]a[/xref]hunt game for me,
And prepare for me a tasty meal, such as I love, and bring it to me to eat, so that [note]1[/note]I may [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]bless you before I die.
verse.note: Lit., my soul.
See note [link]23[sup]1[/sup] in Num. 6[/link].

chapter.verse: Now Rebekah had been listening when Isaac spoke to Esau his son. So when Esau went to the field to hunt for game to bring it [i]home,[/i]
Rebekah spoke to Jacob her son, saying, I just heard your father speaking to Esau your brother, saying,
Bring me game, and prepare for me a tasty meal so that I may eat [i]it[/i] and bless you before Jehovah before my death.

verse.text: Now therefore, my son, [xref]a[/xref]obey my voice according to that which I command you.

chapter.verse: Go now to the flock, and take two choice kids for me from there, and I will prepare them as a tasty meal for your father, such as he loves.

verse.text: Then you shall bring [i]it[/i] to your father to eat, so that he may [xref]a[/xref]bless you before his death.
And Jacob said to Rebekah his mother, Behold, Esau my brother is a [xref]a[/xref]hairy man, and I am a smooth man.
Perhaps my father will feel me, and I will be as a [note]1[/note]deceiver in his sight, and I will bring upon myself a [xref]a[/xref]curse and not a blessing.
verse.note: Or, mocker.

verse.text: And his mother said to him, Your curse be [xref]a[/xref]on me, my son; only obey my voice, and go, get [i]them[/i] for me.

chapter.verse: And he went and got [i]them[/i] and brought [i]them[/i] to his mother; and his mother prepared a tasty meal, such as his father loved.

verse.text: And Rebekah took the best [xref]a[/xref]clothes of Esau her older son, which were with her in the house, and put them on Jacob her younger son.

chapter.verse: And she put the skins of the kids on his hands and on the smooth part of his neck.
And she put the tasty meal and the bread that she had prepared into the hand of Jacob her son.
And he came to his father and said, My father. And he said, Here I am. Who are you, my son?

verse.text: And Jacob said to his father, I am Esau your firstborn; I have done as you told me. Now rise up; sit up and eat some of my game, so that [note]1[/note]you may bless me.
verse.note: Lit., your soul.

chapter.verse: And Isaac said to his son, How is it that you have found [i]it[/i] so quickly, my son? And he said, Because Jehovah your God put [i]it[/i] in my way.
And Isaac said to Jacob, Please come near that I may feel you, my son, [i]to know[/i] whether you are really my son Esau or not.
And Jacob came near to Isaac his father. And he felt him and said, The voice is Jacob's voice, but the hands are Esau's hands.
And he did not recognize him, because his hands were hairy like his brother Esau's hands; so he blessed him.
And he said, Are you really my son Esau? And he said, I am.

verse.text: And he said, Bring [i]it[/i] near to me, and I will eat of my son's game, that [note]1[/note]I may [xref]a[/xref]bless you. So he brought [i]it[/i] near to him, and he ate; and he brought him wine, and he drank.
verse.note: Lit., my soul.

chapter.verse: Then his father Isaac said to him, Please come near and kiss me, my son.

verse.text: So he came near and kissed him;[separator]and when [note]1[/note]Isaac smelled the smell of his garments, he [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]blessed him and said,[br/]See, the smell of my son — / Like the smell of a field / Which Jehovah has blessed.
verse.note: Lit., he.

In [link]v. 4[/link] Isaac wanted to bless Esau, but he mixed God's blessing with his natural taste. Here, Isaac blessed Jacob, but he blessed blindly, both physically ([link]v. 1[/link]) and spiritually, because he had been blinded by his natural taste. This indicates that Isaac did not have much maturity in life. However, Isaac did bless his sons by faith, and God honored his blessing and it became a prophecy ([link]Heb. 11:20[/link]).[br][br]Esau's despising of the birthright ([link]25:34[/link]), Rebekah's ingeniousness in her preferential love, and Isaac's blindness in blessing worked together for Jacob's good, that God might sovereignly fulfill the purpose of His selection (cf. [link]Rom. 8:28-30[/link]).

verse.text: And may God give you / Of the [xref]a[/xref]dew of heaven and of the fatness of the earth, / And an abundance of [xref]b[/xref]grain and new wine.

Let peoples serve you, / And nations bow down to you. / Be lord over your brothers, / And let your mother's [xref]a[/xref]sons bow down to you. / Cursed be those who curse you, / And [xref]b[/xref]blessed be those who bless you.

chapter.verse: And as soon as Isaac had finished blessing Jacob, when Jacob had just gone out from the presence of Isaac his father, Esau his brother came in from his hunting.

verse.text: And he also had prepared a tasty meal and brought it to his father. And he said to his father, Let my father rise up, and eat some of his son's game, that [note]1[/note]you may bless me.
verse.note: Lit., your soul.

chapter.verse: And Isaac his father said to him, Who are you? And he said, I am your son, your firstborn, Esau.
And Isaac trembled very greatly and said, Who was it then who hunted game and brought [i]it[/i] to me, so that I ate of it all before you came and blessed him? And blessed will he be.

verse.text: When Esau heard the words of his father, he cried with a very great and [xref]a[/xref]bitter cry and said to his father, Bless me, [i]even[/i] me also, O my father.

chapter.verse: And he said, Your brother came deceitfully and has taken away your blessing.

verse.text: And [note]1[/note]Esau said, Is he not rightly named [xref]a[/xref]Jacob, for he has supplanted me these two times? He took away my [xref]b[/xref]birthright, and behold now he has taken away my blessing. Then he said, Have you not reserved a blessing for me?
verse.note: Lit., he.

verse.text: And Isaac answered and said to Esau, I have already made him your [xref]a[/xref]lord, and all his brothers I have given to him for servants; and with [xref]b[/xref]grain and new wine I have sustained him. And what then shall I do for you, my son?

chapter.verse: And Esau said to his father, Do you have only one blessing, my father? Bless me, [i]even[/i] me also, O my father. And Esau lifted up his voice and wept.

verse.text: And Isaac his father answered and [xref]a[/xref]said to him,[br/]Behold, [note]1[/note]of the [xref]b[/xref]fatness of the earth shall your dwelling be, / And [note]1[/note]of the [xref]c[/xref]dew of heaven from above.
verse.note: Or, away from the fatness...away from the dew.

verse.text: Yet by your sword shall you live, / And you shall [xref]a[/xref]serve your brother. / And when you [note]1[/note]become restless, / You shall [xref]b[/xref]break his yoke from off your neck.
verse.note: Or, have roved about. The meaning of the Hebrew is uncertain.

verse.text: And Esau hated Jacob because of the blessing with which his father had blessed him; and Esau said in his heart, The days of mourning for my father are near; then I will slay my [xref]a[/xref]brother Jacob.

chapter.verse: And the words of Esau her older son were told to Rebekah, so she sent and called Jacob her younger son and said to him, Now your brother Esau is consoling himself concerning you [i]by planning[/i] to kill you.
Therefore, my son, obey my voice now, and rise up; flee to Laban my brother at Haran,
And stay with him a few days, until your brother's fury turns away,

Until your brother's anger turns away from you, and he forgets what you have done to him; then I will send [i]word[/i] and bring you back from there. Why should I be bereaved of both of you in one day?

verse.text: And Rebekah said to Isaac, I am [xref]a[/xref]weary of my life because of the [note]1[/note]daughters of Heth. If Jacob takes a wife of the daughters of Heth like these, from the [xref]b[/xref]daughters of the land, what good will my life be to me?
verse.note: I.e., the Hittite women.

verse.text: And Isaac called Jacob and [xref]a[/xref]blessed him; and he charged him and said to him, You shall not take a wife from the [xref]b[/xref]daughters of Canaan.

chapter.verse: Rise up, go to Paddan-aram, to the house of Bethuel your mother's father; and take from there a wife from the daughters of Laban your mother's brother.

verse.text: And may the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]All-sufficient God bless you and make you [xref]b[/xref]fruitful and multiply you, that you may become a company of peoples.
verse.note: Heb. [i]El Shaddai.[/i] See note [link]1[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 17[/link].

verse.text: And may He give you the [xref]a[/xref]blessing of Abraham, to you and to your seed with you, that you may possess [i]this[/i] land of your [xref]b[/xref]sojournings, which God gave to Abraham.

chapter.verse: And Isaac sent Jacob away, and he went to Paddan-aram, to Laban the son of Bethuel the Aramaean, the brother of Rebekah, Jacob's and Esau's mother.

Now Esau saw that Isaac had blessed Jacob and had sent him away to Paddan-aram to take a wife from there, [i]and that[/i] when he blessed him, he charged him, saying, You shall not take a wife from the daughters of Canaan,
And that Jacob had obeyed his father and his mother and had gone to Paddan-aram.

verse.text: So Esau saw that the [xref]a[/xref]daughters of Canaan displeased Isaac his father.

chapter.verse: Then Esau went to Ishmael and took Mahalath the daughter of Ishmael, Abraham's son, and the sister of Nebaioth to be his wife, in addition to the wives that he had.

verse.text: And Jacob went out from Beer-sheba and went toward [xref]a[/xref]Haran.

And he came to a certain place and spent the night there, because the sun had set. And he took [i]one[/i] of the stones of the place and [note]1[/note]put [i]it[/i] under his head, and he lay down in that place.
verse.note: Or, placed it as his pillow. So also in [link]v. 18[/link].

verse.text: And he [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]dreamed that there was a [note]2[/note]ladder set up on the earth, and its top reached to heaven; and there the [note]3[/note][xref]b[/xref]angels of God were ascending and descending on it.
verse.note: Jacob's dream is a most crucial point in this book, and [link]vv. 10-22[/link] unveil the most crucial matter in the revelation of God. God desires to have a house on earth, and His intention is to transform His called ones into stones, material for His building. In the account of Jacob's dream, the stone ([link]vv. 11[/link], [link]18[/link], [link]22[/link]), the pillar ([link]v. 18[/link]), the house of God ([link]vv. 17[/link], [link]19[/link], [link]22[/link]), and the oil ([link]v. 18[/link]) are outstanding items. The stone symbolizes Christ as the foundation stone, the top stone, and the cornerstone for God's building ([link]Isa. 28:16[/link]; [link]Zech. 4:7[/link]; [link]Acts 4:10-12[/link]). It also symbolizes the transformed man, who has been constituted with Christ as the transforming element to be the material for the building of God's house ([link]2:12[/link]; [link]Matt. 16:18[/link]; [link]John 1:42[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 3:12[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 2:5[/link]; [link]Rev. 21:11[/link], [link]18-20[/link]), which is the church today ([link]1 Tim. 3:15[/link]) and which will consummate in the New Jerusalem as the eternal dwelling place of God and His redeemed elect ([link]Rev. 21:3[/link], [link]22[/link]). In [link]v. 11[/link] a stone was used by Jacob for a pillow, signifying that the very divine element of Christ constituted into our being through our subjective experience of Him becomes a pillow for our rest (cf. [link]Matt. 11:28[/link]). After awaking from his dream, Jacob set up the pillow-stone as a pillar, signifying that the Christ who has been wrought into us and on whom we rest becomes the material and the support for God's building, God's house (cf. [link]1 Kings 7:21[/link]; [link]Gal. 2:9[/link]; [link]Rev. 3:12[/link]). Eventually, Jacob poured oil, a symbol of the Spirit as the consummation of the Triune God reaching man ([link]Exo. 30:23-30[/link]; [link]Luke 4:18[/link]), on the pillar, symbolizing that the transformed man is one with the Triune God and expresses Him. That stone became Bethel, the house of God ([link]vv. 19[/link], [link]22[/link]). God's house is the mutual dwelling place of God and His redeemed ([link]John 14:2[/link], [link]23[/link]) — man as God's dwelling place ([link]Isa. 66:1-2[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 3:16[/link]; [link]Eph. 2:22[/link]; [link]Heb. 3:6[/link]; [link]Rev. 21:3[/link]) and God as man's dwelling place ([link]Psa. 90:1[/link]; [link]John 15:5[/link]; [link]Rev. 21:22[/link]). Hence, the house of God is constituted of God and man mingled together as one. In God's house God expresses Himself in humanity, and both God and man find mutual and eternal satisfaction and rest.

This ladder is the center, the focus, of Jacob's dream. This dream is a revelation of Christ, for Christ is the reality of the ladder that Jacob saw ([link]John 1:51[/link] and notes). Christ as the Son of Man, in His humanity, is the ladder that brings heaven (God) to earth (man) and joins earth and heaven as one (cf. [link]John 14:6[/link]). Our regenerated spirit, which is God's dwelling place today ([link]Eph. 2:22[/link]), is the base on earth where Christ as the heavenly ladder has been set up ([link]2 Tim. 4:22[/link]). Hence, whenever we turn to our spirit, we experience Christ as the ladder bringing God to us and us to God (see note [link]19[sup]1[/sup] in Heb. 10[/link]). Where this ladder is, there are an open heaven, the transformed man, the anointing upon this man, and the building up of the house of God with this man. The issue of Christ as the heavenly ladder is Bethel, the church, the Body of Christ, and the consummation of this ladder is the New Jerusalem.
The angels are ministering spirits sent forth to serve the heirs of God's salvation ([link]Heb. 1:14[/link] and note 1, par. 3).

verse.text: And there was Jehovah, standing above it; and He said, I am Jehovah, the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]God of Abraham your father and the [note]1[/note]God of Isaac. The [note]2[/note]land on which you lie, I will give to you and to your [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]seed.
verse.note: God's referring to Himself as the God of Abraham and the God of Isaac implies that He would also become the God of Jacob. The God of Abraham is the God of justification, the God of Isaac is the God of grace, and the God of Jacob is the God of transformation through divine discipline. Eventually, the God of Jacob became the God of Israel ([link]33:20[/link]; [link]Exo. 5:1[/link]), the God of the transformed Jacob.

God promised Jacob that He would give him the seed, the land, and the blessing ([link]vv. 13-14[/link]), as He had promised Abraham ([link]12:3[/link], [link]7[/link]; [link]13:14-16[/link]; [link]15:18[/link]; [link]22:17-18[/link]) and Isaac ([link]26:3-4[/link]). The land is for the kingdom of God, and the seed is for the expression of God and for the spreading of God's image. Both the land and the seed are Christ (see note [link]3[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 15[/link]), who also becomes the blessing ([link]v. 14[/link]) with which we bless others ([link]Rom. 15:29[/link]).

verse.text: And your seed will be as the [xref]a[/xref]dust of the earth, and you will spread abroad to the west and to the east and to the north and to the south, and in you and in your seed will [xref]b[/xref]all the families of the earth be blessed.

And, behold, I am [xref]a[/xref]with you and will keep you wherever you go and will cause you to return to this land, for I will not [xref]b[/xref]leave you until I have done what I have promised you.

chapter.verse: And Jacob awoke from his sleep and said, Surely Jehovah is in this place, and I did not know [i]it.[/i]

verse.text: And he was afraid and said, How awesome is this place! This is none other than the [xref]a[/xref]house of God, and this is the [note]1[/note]gate of heaven.
verse.note: This was a place on earth, but it was joined to heaven; hence, Jacob called it the gate of heaven. While we are in the church, the house of God, on earth, we can enter the gate of heaven, and through Christ as the heavenly ladder we can see and experience the things of heaven. See [link]Heb. 4:16[/link] and note 1.

verse.text: And Jacob rose up early in the morning and took the [xref]a[/xref]stone that he had put under his head, and he set it up as a pillar and poured [xref]b[/xref]oil on top of it.
And he called the name of that place [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Bethel, but the name of the city was [xref]b[/xref]Luz previously.
verse.note: Meaning [i]house of God.[/i] See note [link]1[sup]1[/sup], par. 2, in ch. 35[/link].

verse.text: And Jacob [xref]a[/xref]vowed a vow, saying, If God will be with me and will keep me in this way that I go and will give me bread to eat and garments to put on,
So that I return to my father's house in peace, then Jehovah will be [xref]a[/xref]my God,
And this [xref]a[/xref]stone, which I have set up as a pillar, will be God's house; and of all that You give me I will surely give one [xref]b[/xref]tenth to You.
Then Jacob [note]1[/note]went on his journey and came to the land of the children of the east.
verse.note: Lit., lifted up his feet.

chapter.verse: And he looked, and there in the field was a well, and there three flocks of sheep were lying beside it; for from that well they watered the flocks. And the stone on the mouth of the well was large.
And when all the flocks would gather there, they would roll the stone from the mouth of the well and water the sheep; then they would put the stone back on the mouth of the well in its place.
And Jacob said to them, My brothers, where are you from? And they said, We are from Haran.
And he said to them, Do you know Laban the son of Nahor? And they said, We do know [i]him.[/i]
And he said to them, Is it well with him? And they said, It is well, and here is his daughter Rachel, coming with the sheep.
And he said, Look, it is still full day; [i]and[/i] it is not time for the livestock to be gathered together. Water the sheep, and go feed [i]them.[/i]
And they said, We cannot until all the flocks are gathered together and they roll the stone from the mouth of the well; then we water the sheep.
While he was still speaking with them, Rachel came with the sheep which belonged to her father, for she was a shepherdess.

Now when Jacob saw Rachel the daughter of Laban his mother's brother and the sheep of Laban his mother's brother, Jacob drew near and rolled the stone from the mouth of the well, and watered the flock of Laban his mother's brother.
Then Jacob kissed Rachel and lifted up his voice and wept.

verse.text: And Jacob told Rachel that he was her father's [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]relative and that he was Rebekah's son. And she ran and [xref]b[/xref]told her father.
verse.note: Lit., brother. So also in [link]v. 15[/link].

verse.text: And when Laban heard the news of Jacob his sister's son, he ran to meet him. And he embraced him and kissed him and brought him to his house. Then [note]1[/note]Jacob related to Laban all these things.
verse.note: Lit., he.

chapter.verse: And Laban said to him, Surely you are my bone and my flesh. And he stayed with him a month.
And Laban said to Jacob, Because you are my relative, should you therefore serve me for nothing? Tell me, what shall your wages be?
Now Laban had two daughters; the name of the older was Leah, and the name of the younger was Rachel.

verse.text: And Leah's eyes were [note]1[/note]dull, but Rachel was beautiful in form and beautiful in appearance.
verse.note: Or, tender, weak.

verse.text: And Jacob loved Rachel. And he said, I will [xref]a[/xref]serve you seven years for Rachel your younger daughter.

chapter.verse: And Laban said, It is better that I give her to you than that I should give her to another man; stay with me.
And Jacob served seven years for Rachel, but they seemed to him only a few days because of the love he had for her.
Then Jacob said to Laban, Give [i]me[/i] my wife that I may go in to her, for my time is completed.
And Laban gathered together all the men of the place and made a feast.
But in the evening he took Leah his daughter and brought her to him, and he went in to her.

verse.text: And Laban gave [xref]a[/xref]Zilpah his female servant to his daughter Leah to be her female servant.
And in the morning there she was, [note]1[/note]Leah! And he said to Laban, What is this you have done to me? Did I not serve with you for Rachel? Why then have you deceived me?
verse.note: Jacob was a crafty supplanter, but Laban was more subtle than Jacob. This was sovereignly arranged by God. Everything Laban did to cheat and to "squeeze" Jacob ([link]31:7[/link], [link]40-42[/link]), plus the competition, envy, and wrestling between Jacob's wives in their bearing children ([link]29:31-30:24[/link]), were sovereignly used by God to deal with Jacob's natural disposition so that God could transform him. Jacob's history shows that God sovereignly arranges each aspect of the environment of His chosen ones so that He may carry out His work of transformation in them ([link]Rom. 8:28-30[/link]).

chapter.verse: And Laban said, It is not done in this way in our place, to give the younger before the firstborn.
Complete the week of this one, and we will give you the other also for the service which you will serve with me for another seven years.
And Jacob did so and completed her week, and he gave him Rachel his daughter as a wife.

verse.text: And Laban gave to Rachel his daughter [xref]a[/xref]Bilhah his female servant to be her female servant.
And he went in also to Rachel, and he also loved Rachel, more than Leah. And he [xref]a[/xref]served with [note]1[/note]Laban for another seven years.
verse.note: Lit., him.

verse.text: Now when Jehovah saw that Leah was [xref]a[/xref]hated, He opened her womb; but Rachel was [xref]b[/xref]barren.
And Leah conceived and bore a son, and she called his name [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Reuben, for she said, Because Jehovah has looked upon my affliction, surely now my husband will love me.
verse.note: Meaning [i]see, a son.[/i]

verse.text: And she conceived again and bore a son and said, Because Jehovah has heard that I am hated, He has therefore given me this [i]son[/i] also; so she called his name [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Simeon.
verse.note: Meaning [i]hearing.[/i]

verse.text: And she conceived again and bore a son and said, Now this time my husband will be joined to me, because I have borne him three sons. Therefore his name was called [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Levi.
verse.note: Meaning [i]joined.[/i]

verse.text: And she conceived again and bore a son and said, This time I will praise Jehovah. Therefore she called his name [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Judah. Then she ceased bearing.
verse.note: Meaning [i]praise.[/i]

verse.text: And when Rachel saw that she bore Jacob no [xref]a[/xref]children, Rachel envied her sister and said to Jacob, Give me children, or else I die.
And Jacob's anger burned against Rachel, and he said, Am I in the place of God, who has [xref]a[/xref]withheld from you the fruit of the womb?
And she said, Here is my servant [xref]a[/xref]Bilhah; go in to her, that she may bear upon my knees and that I also may [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]have children through her.
verse.note: Lit., be built up.

chapter.verse: And she gave him Bilhah her female servant as a wife, and Jacob went in to her.
And Bilhah conceived and bore Jacob a son.

verse.text: And Rachel said, God has judged me, and has also heard my voice and given me a son; therefore she called his name [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Dan.
verse.note: Meaning [i]judging.[/i]

chapter.verse: And Bilhah Rachel's female servant conceived again and bore Jacob a second son.

verse.text: And Rachel said, [note]1[/note]In wrestling with God, I have wrestled with my sister and have prevailed; so she called his name [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]Naphtali.
verse.note: Or, with mighty wrestlings.
Meaning [i]my wrestling.[/i]

verse.text: Now when Leah saw that she ceased bearing, she took [xref]a[/xref]Zilpah her female servant and gave her to Jacob as a wife.

chapter.verse: And Zilpah Leah's female servant bore Jacob a son.

verse.text: And Leah said, How fortunate! So she called his name [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Gad.
verse.note: Meaning, perhaps, [i](good) fortune.[/i]

chapter.verse: And Zilpah Leah's female servant bore Jacob a second son.

verse.text: And Leah said, [note]1[/note]Happy am I! For the daughters will call me [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]blessed; so she called his name [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]Asher.
verse.note: In Hebrew the words [i]happy[/i] and [i]blessed[/i] are from the same root.
Meaning [i]happy,[/i] or [i]blessed.[/i]

verse.text: And Reuben went out in the days of wheat harvest and found [xref]a[/xref]mandrakes in the field and brought them to his mother Leah. Then Rachel said to Leah, Please give me some of your son's mandrakes.

chapter.verse: And she said to her, Is it a small matter that you have taken away my husband? And would you take away my son's mandrakes also? So Rachel said, Then he may lie with you tonight in return for your son's mandrakes.
And Jacob came from the field in the evening, and Leah went out to meet him and said, You must come in to me, for I have surely hired you with my son's mandrakes. So he lay with her that night.
And God gave heed to Leah, and she conceived and bore Jacob a fifth son.

verse.text: And Leah said, God has given me my hire, because I gave my female servant to my husband; so she called his name [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Issachar.
verse.note: Meaning [i]hire.[/i]

chapter.verse: And Leah conceived again and bore a sixth son to Jacob.

verse.text: And Leah said, God has endowed me with a good dowry; now my husband will [note]1[/note]dwell with me, because I have borne him six sons; so she called his name [note]2[/note][xref]a[/xref]Zebulun.
verse.note: Or, honor me.
Meaning [i]honoring, exaltation,[/i] or [i]exalted dwelling.[/i]

chapter.verse: And afterward she bore a daughter and called her name Dinah.

verse.text: Then God [xref]a[/xref]remembered Rachel, and God gave heed to her and [xref]b[/xref]opened her womb.
And she conceived and bore a son and said, God has taken away my [xref]a[/xref]reproach.
And she called his name [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Joseph, saying, May Jehovah add to me [xref]b[/xref]another son.
verse.note: Meaning [i]adding.[/i]

chapter.verse: And when Rachel had borne Joseph, Jacob said to Laban, Send me away, that I may go to my own place and to my own country.

verse.text: Give [i]me[/i] my wives and my children for whom I have [xref]a[/xref]served you, that I may go; for you indeed know my service by which I have served you.

chapter.verse: And Laban said to him, If you please, I have divined that Jehovah has blessed me on account of you.
And he said, Name me your wages, and I will give it.

verse.text: And [note]1[/note]Jacob said to him, You indeed know how I have served you, and how your livestock have fared with me.
verse.note: Lit., he.

chapter.verse: For you had little before I came, and it has spread into a multitude, and Jehovah has blessed you wherever I turned. But now when shall I provide for my own house also?
And he said, What shall I give you? And Jacob said, You shall not give me anything. Just do this [i]one[/i] thing for me: Let me again feed your flock and keep [i]it.[/i]

Let me pass through all your flock today, removing from there every speckled and spotted animal, that is, every black animal among the sheep, and the spotted and speckled among the goats; and such will be my wages.

So my righteousness will testify for me later, when you come concerning my wages, [i]by what is[/i] before you. Every one that is not speckled and spotted among the goats and black among the sheep, [i]if found[/i] with me, will be counted stolen.
And Laban said, Fine; let it be according to your word.

verse.text: But on that day [note]1[/note]Laban removed the male goats that were streaked and spotted, and all the female goats that were speckled and spotted, every one that had white in it, and all the black ones among the sheep, and gave them into the care of his sons.
verse.note: Lit., he.

chapter.verse: And he set [i]a distance of a[/i] three days' journey between himself and Jacob, and Jacob fed the rest of Laban's flocks.
And Jacob took rods of fresh poplar and almond and plane trees and peeled white stripes in them, exposing the white which was in the rods.
And he set the rods which he had peeled in front of the flocks in the troughs, [i]that is,[/i] in the watering places where the flocks came to drink; and they bred when they came to drink.
And the flocks bred before the rods; and the flocks brought forth [i]young[/i] that were streaked, speckled, and spotted.
And Jacob separated the lambs and set the faces of the flock toward the streaked and all the black in the flock of Laban, and he put his own herds apart and did not put them with Laban's flock.
And whenever the stronger of the flock were breeding, Jacob placed the rods before the eyes of the flock in the troughs so that they might breed among the rods;
But when the flock was feebler, he did not put [i]them[/i] in; so the feebler were Laban's, and the stronger Jacob's.

verse.text: And the man became spread out exceedingly, and had large [xref]a[/xref]flocks, and female servants and male servants, and camels and donkeys.
Now [note]1[/note]Jacob heard the words of Laban's sons, saying, Jacob has taken away all that belonged to our father; and from what belonged to our father he has made all this [note]2[/note]wealth.
verse.note: Lit., he.
Or, glory.

chapter.verse: And Jacob saw Laban's countenance, and now it was not [i]favorable[/i] toward him as previously.

verse.text: And Jehovah said to Jacob, [xref]a[/xref]Return to the land of your fathers and to your relatives, and I will be [xref]b[/xref]with you.

chapter.verse: So Jacob sent and called Rachel and Leah to his flock in the field,
And he said to them, I see that your father's countenance is not [i]favorable[/i] toward me as previously, but the God of my father has been with me.

verse.text: And you yourselves know that with all my strength I have [xref]a[/xref]served your father.
And your father has cheated me and changed my wages [xref]a[/xref]ten times, but God did not allow him to harm me.

If he spoke in this way, The speckled shall be your [xref]a[/xref]wages, then all the flock bore speckled; and if he spoke in this way, The streaked shall be your wages, then all the flock bore streaked.
Thus God has [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]taken away your father's livestock and given [i]them[/i] to me.
verse.note: Lit., rescued, or, salvaged. So also in [link]v. 16[/link].

chapter.verse: And at the time the flock was breeding, I lifted up my eyes and saw in a dream; and there were the male goats, leaping upon the flock — streaked, speckled, and spotted.

verse.text: And the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Angel of God said to me in the dream, Jacob; and I said, Here I am.
verse.note: See note [link]7[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 16[/link].

verse.text: And He said, Lift up your eyes now, and see that all the male goats which leap upon the flock are streaked, speckled, and spotted; for [note]1[/note]I have [xref]a[/xref]seen all that Laban is doing to you.
verse.note: Jehovah's word to Jacob here indicates that he became wealthy not through his own cleverness but through God's sovereign hand ([link]v. 16[/link]).

verse.text: I am the [note]1[/note]God of [xref]a[/xref]Bethel, where you [xref]b[/xref]anointed a pillar, where you vowed a vow to Me. Rise up now; go out from this land, and [xref]c[/xref]return to the land of your birth.
verse.note: Heb. [i]El-Bethel.[/i]

chapter.verse: And Rachel and Leah answered and said to him, Do we still have any portion or inheritance in our father's house?
Are we not regarded by him as foreigners? For he has sold us and has even entirely used up the money [i]given[/i] for us.
Surely all the wealth which God has taken away from our father is ours and our children's. So do now whatever God has said to you.
Then Jacob rose up and set his sons and his wives upon the camels;

And he drove away all his livestock and all his property which he had acquired, the livestock in his possession which he had acquired in Paddan-aram, in order to go to Isaac his father in the land of Canaan.

verse.text: Now Laban had gone to shear his sheep, and Rachel stole the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]teraphim that were her father's.
verse.note: These were idols worshipped in Laban's home. So also in [link]vv. 34[/link], [link]35[/link].

chapter.verse: And Jacob deceived Laban the Aramaean by not telling him that he was fleeing.

verse.text: So he fled with all that he had, and he rose up and crossed over the [note]1[/note]River and set his face toward the hill country of Gilead.
verse.note: I.e., the Euphrates.

chapter.verse: And it was told Laban on the third day that Jacob had fled.
And he took his brothers with him and pursued after him [i]the distance of a[/i] seven days' journey; and he overtook him in the hill country of Gilead.

verse.text: And [note]1[/note]God came to Laban the Aramaean in a [xref]a[/xref]dream of the night and said to him, Be careful that you do not speak to Jacob either good or bad.
verse.note: The crucial person in this chapter is neither Jacob nor Laban, but the invisible, transforming God, who was sovereignly preparing the environment for Jacob's transformation (cf. [link]Rom. 8:28-29[/link]). Jacob was under the secret care of Christ as the Angel of God ([link]v. 11[/link]) because Christ would eventually be born of Jacob's descendant Mary ([link]Matt. 1:2[/link], [link]16[/link]).

verse.text: And Laban caught up with Jacob. Now Jacob had [xref]a[/xref]pitched his tent in the hill country, and Laban with his brothers [i]also[/i] pitched [i]tents[/i] in the hill country of Gilead.
And Laban said to Jacob, What are you doing [xref]a[/xref]deceiving me and carrying away my daughters like captives of the sword?

chapter.verse: Why did you flee secretly and steal away from me and not tell me, when I might have sent you away with joy and with songs, with tambourine and with lyre?
And you did not allow me to kiss my sons and my daughters. Now you have acted foolishly.

verse.text: It is in my power to do you harm, but the [xref]a[/xref]God of your father spoke to me last night, saying, Be careful that you do not speak to Jacob either good or bad.

chapter.verse: And now, though you had to go because you longed greatly for your father's house, why did you steal my gods?

verse.text: And Jacob answered and said to Laban, Because I was afraid, for I [note]1[/note]thought that you might take your daughters from me by force.
verse.note: Lit., said.

verse.text: [i]The [xref]a[/xref]one[/i] with whom you find your gods shall not live. In the presence of our brothers indicate what [i]there is[/i] with me [i]that[/i] is yours, and take [i]it[/i]. Now Jacob did not know that Rachel had stolen them.

chapter.verse: And Laban went into Jacob's tent and into Leah's tent and into the two female servants' tent, but he did not find [i]them.[/i] Then he went from Leah's tent and entered Rachel's tent.
Now Rachel had taken the teraphim and put them in the camel's saddle, and she sat upon them. And Laban rummaged through all the tent but did not find [i]them.[/i]
And she said to her father, Let not my lord be angry that I cannot rise up before you, for the manner of women is upon me. So he searched but did not find the teraphim.
And Jacob became angry and contended with Laban; and Jacob answered and said to Laban, What is my transgression? What is my sin, that you have so hotly pursued me?

Although you have rummaged through all my possessions, what have you found of all your household goods? Set [i]it[/i] here before my brothers and your brothers, that they may decide between the two of us.
These twenty years have I been with you; your ewes and your female goats have not miscarried, and I have not eaten the rams of your flocks.

verse.text: That which was torn [i]by beasts[/i] I did not bring to you; I [xref]a[/xref]bore the loss of it myself. Of my hand you required it, whether stolen by day or stolen by night.

chapter.verse: [i]Thus[/i] I was: By day the dry heat consumed me, and the frost by night, and my sleep fled from my eyes.

verse.text: These twenty years have I been in your house; I [xref]a[/xref]served you fourteen years for your two daughters and six years for your flock, and you have changed my wages [xref]b[/xref]ten times.

If the [xref]a[/xref]God of my father, the God of Abraham, and the Dread of Isaac, had not been with me, surely now you would have sent me away empty. God has seen my affliction and the labor of my hands and rebuked [i]you[/i] last night.

chapter.verse: And Laban answered and said to Jacob, The daughters are my daughters, and the children are my children, and the flocks are my flocks, and all that you see is mine. But what can I do this day to these my daughters or to their children whom they have borne?

verse.text: So come now; let us [xref]a[/xref]make a covenant, I and you; and let it be a witness between me and you.
So Jacob took a [xref]a[/xref]stone and set it up [i]as[/i] a pillar.

chapter.verse: And Jacob said to his brothers, Gather stones. So they took stones and made a heap, and they ate there by the heap.

verse.text: And [xref]a[/xref]Laban called it [note]1[/note]Jegar-sahadutha, but Jacob called it [note]2[/note]Galeed.
verse.note: In Aramaic, meaning [i]the heap of witness.[/i]
In Hebrew, meaning [i]the heap of witness.[/i]

verse.text: And Laban said, This heap is a [xref]a[/xref]witness between me and you today. Therefore its name was called Galeed
And [note]1[/note]Mizpah, because he said, Jehovah watch between me and you when we are absent from one another.
verse.note: Meaning [i]watchpost.[/i]

verse.text: If you afflict my daughters, and if you take wives besides my daughters — [i]even though[/i] no man is with us — see, God is [xref]a[/xref]witness between me and you.
verse.xref: Judg. 11:10; 1 Sam. 12:5; Jer. 42:5; cf. Job 16:19; Micah 1:2

verse.text: And Laban said to Jacob, Here is this [xref]a[/xref]heap, and here is the pillar which I have set between me and you.
This heap is a witness, and the pillar is a [note]1[/note]witness, that I will not pass beyond this heap to you and that you will not pass beyond this heap and this pillar to me, for harm.
verse.note: The pillar set up here by Jacob was a witness, a testimony. The thought of a pillar as a testimony is seen also in the two pillars (two is the number for a witness, a testimony — [link]Matt. 18:16[/link]; [link]Luke 10:1[/link]) set up by Solomon in front of the temple ([link]1 Kings 7:21[/link]), and in the church, the house of God, as the pillar that upholds the truth by testifying, manifesting, the truth ([link]1 Tim. 3:15-16[/link]). The three pillars set up by Jacob in [link]chs. 31[/link] and [link book="Gen."]35[/link] were three landmarks of Jacob's life. (The pillar set up in [link]28:18[/link] was in response to a dream and was not part of Jacob's spiritual experience; hence, it is not considered a landmark in his life. See note [link]14[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 35[/link].) The first pillar, set up at Galeed ([link]vv. 45[/link], [link]47[/link]), was a testimony of God's sovereign care for him in the first stage of his experience. The second pillar, set up at Bethel ([link]35:14[/link]), was a testimony of God's building, God's house, in the second stage. The third pillar, set up on Rachel's grave on the way to Bethlehem ([link]35:20[/link]), was a testimony of the death of Jacob's natural choice for the bringing forth of Christ, typified by Benjamin, in the third stage of his experience (see notes [link book="Gen." chapter="35"]18[sup]1[/sup][/link] and [link]18[sup]3[/sup] in ch. 35[/link]).

verse.text: The God of Abraham and the God of Nahor, the [xref]a[/xref]God of their father, judge between us. And Jacob swore by the Dread of his father Isaac.

chapter.verse: And Jacob offered a sacrifice on the mountain and called his brothers to eat a meal, and they ate a meal and spent the night in the mountain.
And early in the morning Laban rose up and kissed his sons and his daughters and blessed them, and Laban departed and returned to his place.
And Jacob went on his way, and the angels of God met him.

verse.text: And Jacob said when he saw them, This is God's [xref]a[/xref]camp. So he called the name of that place [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]Mahanaim.
verse.note: Meaning [i]two camps.[/i] See note [link]13[sup]2[/sup] in S.S. 6[/link].

verse.text: And Jacob sent messengers before him to Esau his brother, into the land of [xref]a[/xref]Seir, the field of Edom.

chapter.verse: And he commanded them, saying, Thus you shall say to my lord Esau: Thus says your servant Jacob, I have sojourned with Laban and stayed until now;

verse.text: And I have oxen and donkeys [i]and[/i] flocks, and male servants and female servants; and I have sent to tell my lord [i]this[/i], that I may [xref]a[/xref]find favor in your sight.
And the messengers returned to Jacob, saying, We came to your brother Esau, and he also is coming to meet you; and [xref]a[/xref]four hundred men are with him.
Then Jacob was greatly afraid and distressed; and he divided the people who were with him and the flocks and the herds and the camels into [xref]a[/xref]two camps;

chapter.verse: And he said, If Esau comes to the one camp and attacks it, then the camp which is left will escape.

verse.text: Then Jacob said, O [xref]a[/xref]God of my father Abraham and God of my father Isaac, O Jehovah, who said to me, [xref]b[/xref]Return to your country and to your relatives, and I will do you good,

I am not worthy of all the lovingkindnesses and all the faithfulness which You have shown to Your servant; for with my staff [i]only[/i] I crossed over this Jordan, and now I have become [xref]a[/xref]two camps.

chapter.verse: Deliver me, please, from the hand of my brother, from the hand of Esau, for I fear him, lest he come and attack me [i]and[/i] the mother with the children.

verse.text: But You have said, I will surely do you good and make your seed like the [xref]a[/xref]sand of the sea, which cannot be numbered for multitude.
And he spent that night there. Then from what he had with him he took a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]present for Esau his brother:
verse.note: Although Jacob had prayed in [link]vv. 9-12[/link], he did not trust in his prayer but continued to exercise his human wisdom by sending gifts to Esau to appease him.

chapter.verse: Two hundred female goats and twenty male goats, two hundred ewes and twenty rams,
Thirty nursing camels and their young, forty cows and ten bulls, twenty female donkeys and ten male donkeys.
And he delivered [i]them[/i] into the hand of his servants, every drove by itself, and said to his servants, Cross over before me, and put a space between each drove.
And he commanded the foremost, saying, When Esau my brother meets you and asks you, saying, To whom do you belong? And where are you going? And whose [i]animals[/i] are these before you?
Then you will say, Your servant Jacob's; it is a present sent to my lord Esau; and now he also is behind us.
And he commanded also the second and the third, and all who followed the droves, saying, In this way you shall speak to Esau when you find him,
And you shall also say, Your servant Jacob is right behind us. For he said, I will appease him with the present that goes before me, and afterward I will see his face; perhaps he will accept me.
So the present crossed over before him, and he himself spent that night in the camp.
And he rose up that night and took his two wives and his two female servants and his eleven children and crossed over the ford of the Jabbok.
And he took them and sent them over the stream and sent over what he had.

verse.text: And Jacob was left alone, and a [note]1[/note]man [xref]a[/xref]wrestled with him until the break of dawn.
verse.note: According to [link]Hosea 12:4[/link], this man was the Angel of Jehovah, Christ (see note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in Exo. 3[/link]). The Lord as a man wrestled with Jacob so that He might touch Jacob's natural strength, signified by the socket of Jacob's hip at the thigh muscle ([link]vv. 25[/link], [link]32[/link]). The Lord's wrestling with Jacob lasted a considerable time, fully exposing how natural Jacob was.

verse.text: And when [note]1[/note]the man saw that He did not prevail against him, He [note]2[/note]touched the socket of his hip; and the socket of Jacob's hip was dislocated as he wrestled with Him.
verse.note: Lit., He.

The touching of the socket of Jacob's hip at the thigh muscle ([link]v. 32[/link]), the strongest muscle in the body, signifies the touching of Jacob's natural life, his natural strength. This was the beginning of Jacob's transformation. As [link]ch. 33[/link] shows (see notes [link book="Gen." chapter="33"]4[sup]1[/sup][/link] and [link book="Gen." chapter="33"]17[sup]1[/sup][/link] there), after this experience Jacob was still natural. Nevertheless, although there was no change in Jacob's outward living, his natural life, his inward natural strength, had been dealt with by the Lord. This is signified by the fact that Jacob walked with a limp ([link]v. 31[/link]). The way of religion is to change man's outward behavior; the way of God in His economy is to touch man's inward life in order to change his inward being.

verse.text: And the [note]1[/note]man said, Let Me go, for the dawn is breaking. But [note]2[/note]Jacob said, I will [xref]a[/xref]not let You go unless You bless me.
verse.note: Lit., He.
Lit., he.

verse.text: And He said to him, [note]1[/note]What is your name? And he said, Jacob.
verse.note: Here the Lord asked Jacob his name to cause Jacob to realize who he was — Jacob, the supplanter (see note [link]26[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 25[/link]).
