verse.text: And He said, Your name will no longer be called Jacob, but [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Israel; for you have [xref]b[/xref]struggled with God and with men, and have prevailed.
verse.note: Meaning [i]one who struggles with God.[/i] The changing of Jacob's name to Israel indicates that God would eventually transform Jacob. See note [link]5[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 17[/link].

verse.text: And Jacob asked [i]Him[/i] and said, Please [xref]a[/xref]tell [i]me[/i] Your name. But He said, Why is it that you ask My name? And He blessed him there[note]1[/note].
verse.note: It does not say that the man came to Jacob before wrestling with him ([link]v. 24[/link]), nor does it say that the man left Jacob after wrestling with him. This means that the Lord who wrestled with Jacob was with him all the time and never left him. Cf. [link]John 20:26[/link] and note 3.

verse.text: And Jacob called the name of the place [note]1[/note]Peniel, for, [i]he said,[/i] I have [xref]a[/xref]seen God face to face, and yet my life has been preserved.
verse.note: Meaning [i]the face of God.[/i]

verse.text: And the [note]1[/note]sun rose upon him as he crossed over Penuel, and he limped because of his hip.
verse.note: In the dark night Jacob was strong, and every part of him was whole. After being touched by the Lord, Jacob was lame, but he was in the shining of the heavenly light.

chapter.verse: Therefore the children of Israel do not eat the thigh muscle, which is upon the socket of the hip, to this day, because He touched the socket of Jacob's hip at the thigh muscle.

verse.text: And Jacob lifted up his eyes and looked, and there was Esau coming, and [xref]a[/xref]four hundred men with him. So he divided the children among Leah and among Rachel and among the two female servants.

chapter.verse: And he put the female servants and their children in front, and Leah and her children next, and Rachel and Joseph last.
And he himself passed on before them and bowed down to the ground seven times until he came near to his brother.

verse.text: And Esau ran to meet him and embraced him and fell on his neck and [note]1[/note]kissed him, and they wept.
verse.note: All Jacob's fears were products of his own worrying, and all he had done in exercising his natural skill and ability to save himself was in vain. God had protected Jacob from Laban by appearing to Laban in a dream ([link]31:24[/link]), and He had aroused Esau's brotherly love toward Jacob. These were God's marvelous acts to care for His chosen one. Thus, Jacob, who had God's promises and was on the way to reach God's goal, did not need to fear what was behind him or what was ahead of him. Instead of trusting in his own striving, he should have rested in God and in His all-sufficient care (cf. [link]Phil. 4:6-7[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 5:7[/link]).

verse.text: And he lifted up his eyes and saw the women and the children and said, Who are these with you? And he said, The children whom God has [xref]a[/xref]graciously given your servant.

chapter.verse: Then the female servants came near, they and their children, and they bowed down.
And Leah also came near with her children, and they bowed down; and afterward Joseph came near with Rachel, and they bowed down.

verse.text: And [note]1[/note]Esau said, What do you mean by all this [xref]a[/xref]camp which I met? And he said, To find [xref]b[/xref]favor in the sight of my lord.
verse.note: Lit., he.

chapter.verse: And Esau said, I have enough, my brother; let what you have be yours.
And Jacob said, No, please, if now I have found favor in your sight, then take my present from my hand; for I see your face as one sees the face of God, and you have received me favorably.

verse.text: Please take my [xref]a[/xref]blessing which has been brought to you, because God has dealt graciously with me, and because I have all [i]that I need.[/i] So he urged him, and he took it.
Then [note]1[/note]Esau said, Let us take our journey and go, and I will go before you.
verse.note: Lit., he.

chapter.verse: And he said to him, My lord knows that the children are frail and that the nursing flocks and herds are a concern to me; and if they overdrive them for one day, all the flock will die.

Let my lord please pass on before his servant, and I will lead on slowly according to the pace of the cattle which are before me and according to the pace of the children, until I come to my lord at Seir.

verse.text: So Esau said, Let me please leave with you some of the people who are with me. And he said, What need is there? Let me [xref]a[/xref]find favor in the sight of my lord.

chapter.verse: So Esau returned that day on his way to Seir.

verse.text: And Jacob journeyed to Succoth and [note]1[/note]built a house for himself and made booths for his livestock; therefore the name of the place is called [note]2[/note]Succoth.
verse.note: Jacob's building a house for himself and booths for his cattle indicate that he was still natural and for himself. He neglected the dream that he had had at Bethel and the vow that he had made to God, promising that he would build a house for Him ([link]28:20-22[/link]).
Meaning [i]booths.[/i]

verse.text: And Jacob came [note]1[/note]safely to the city of [note]2[/note]Shechem, which is in the land of Canaan, when he came from Paddan-aram; and he camped before the city.
verse.note: Or, in peace.
See note [link]1[sup]1[/sup], par. 1, in ch. 35[/link].

verse.text: And he [xref]a[/xref]bought the piece of land, where he had pitched his [xref]b[/xref]tent, from the hand of the children of Hamor, Shechem's father, for a hundred pieces of money.
And there he erected an [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]altar and called it [note]2[/note]El-Elohe-Israel.
verse.note: In Shechem in the land of Canaan, Jacob pitched his tent ([link]v. 19[/link]) and erected an altar, as his grandfather Abraham had done ([link]12:6-7[/link]). Here Jacob began to live a life as God's called one for the fulfillment of God's purpose.
Meaning [i]El, the God of Israel.[/i]

verse.text: And [xref]a[/xref]Dinah the daughter of Leah, whom she had borne to Jacob, went out to see the daughters of the land.

chapter.verse: And when Shechem the son of Hamor the Hivite, the prince of the land, saw her, he took her and lay with her and humbled her.

verse.text: And his soul clung to Dinah the daughter of Jacob, and he loved the girl and spoke [note]1[/note]affectionately to the girl.
verse.note: Lit., to the heart of.

verse.text: And Shechem spoke to his father Hamor, saying, Get me this young girl as a [xref]a[/xref]wife.

chapter.verse: Now when Jacob heard that he had defiled Dinah his daughter, his sons were with his livestock in the field; so Jacob kept silent until they came in.
And Hamor the father of Shechem went out to Jacob to speak with him.

And the sons of Jacob came in from the field when they heard of it. And the men were grieved and became very angry, because he had committed folly in Israel by lying with Jacob's daughter, for such a thing ought not to be done.
And Hamor spoke with them, saying, The soul of my son Shechem longs for your daughter; please give her to him as a wife.
And make marriages with us: Give your daughters to us, and take our daughters for yourselves.

verse.text: And you shall dwell with us, and the land will be before you; dwell and [note]1[/note]trade in it, and acquire holdings in it.
verse.note: Or, move about. So also in [link]v. 21[/link].

chapter.verse: And Shechem said to her father and to her brothers, Let me find favor in your sight, and whatever you say to me I will give.
Impose upon me a very large bridal price and gift, and I will give whatever you say to me; but give me the girl as a wife.
Then the sons of Jacob answered Shechem and Hamor his father deceitfully; and because he had defiled Dinah their sister, they spoke
And said to them, We are not able to do this thing, to give our sister to one who is uncircumcised, for that would be a reproach to us.
Only on this [i]condition[/i] will we consent to you: If you become like us, and every male among you is circumcised,
Then we will give our daughters to you and will take your daughters for ourselves; and we will dwell with you and become one people.
But if you will not listen to us and be circumcised, then we will take our daughter and go.
And their words seemed good to Hamor and Shechem, Hamor's son.
And the young man did not delay to do the thing, because he delighted in Jacob's daughter. Now he was honored above all the house of his father.
And Hamor and Shechem his son came to the gate of their city and spoke with the men of their city, saying,

These men are with us peacefully; therefore let them dwell in the land and trade in it, for here the land is large enough for them. Let us take their daughters for ourselves as wives, and let us give them our daughters.
Only on this [i]condition[/i] will the men consent to us to dwell with us, to become one people: that every male among us be circumcised as they are circumcised.
Will not their livestock and their property and all their animals be ours? Only let us consent to them, and they will dwell with us.
And all who went out of the gate of his city listened to Hamor and to Shechem his son; and every male was circumcised, all who went out of the gate of his city.

verse.text: Then on the third day, when they were [i]still[/i] in pain, two of Jacob's sons, [xref]a[/xref]Simeon and Levi, Dinah's brothers, each took his sword and came upon the city [note]1[/note]unawares, and slew every male.
verse.note: Lit., secure.

chapter.verse: And they slew Hamor and Shechem his son with the edge of the sword, and they took Dinah out of Shechem's house and went away.
The sons of Jacob came upon the slain and plundered the city, because they had defiled their sister.
They took their flocks and their herds and their donkeys and whatever was in the city and whatever was in the field;
And they took captive and plundered all their wealth and all their little ones and their wives, and even all that was in the houses.

verse.text: And Jacob said to Simeon and Levi, You have [note]1[/note]brought trouble upon me by making me odious among the inhabitants of the land, among the Canaanites and the Perizzites; and I am [xref]a[/xref]few in number, and they will gather themselves together against me and strike me; and I will be destroyed, I and my house.
verse.note: See note [link]1[sup]1[/sup], par. 1, in ch. 35[/link].

chapter.verse: And they said, Should he treat our sister like a harlot?

verse.text: And God said to Jacob, Rise up, go up to [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Bethel, and dwell there; and make an [xref]b[/xref]altar there to the God who appeared to you when you [xref]c[/xref]fled from your brother Esau.
verse.note: At Bethel Jacob had made a vow to God, promising that if God would preserve him and care for him, the stone which he set up for a pillar would be the house of God ([link]28:20-22[/link]). Here, God reminded Jacob to fulfill his part of that vow (cf. [link]31:13[/link]). On his return from Paddan-aram, Jacob came to Shechem in the land of Canaan, and he settled there ([link]33:18-20[/link]). However, this was short of God's goal. God's purpose according to His heart's desire is to have Bethel, His house on earth. Thus, it was necessary for Jacob to go on from Shechem to Bethel. All the unfortunate events in [link]ch. 34[/link] were sovereignly used by God to make it impossible for Jacob to remain in Shechem and to prepare Jacob to receive God's charge to go up to Bethel. Jacob's passing through Shechem and going up to Bethel signifies our passing through the individual Christian life and going up to the corporate church life for the building up of God's eternal dwelling place, which is the church today and the New Jerusalem in eternity.[br][br]Bethel is a great seed in the Bible, a seed of the house of God. When Israel, the transformed Jacob, was multiplied into the house of Israel, in God's eyes the house of Israel was the house of God (see note [link]6[sup]1[/sup] in Heb. 3[/link]). Eventually, the tabernacle and later the temple were built as symbols of the house of Israel as God's dwelling place on the earth in the Old Testament time. In the beginning of the New Testament the Lord Jesus came through incarnation to be the reality of the tabernacle and the temple ([link]John 1:14[/link]; [link]2:18-21[/link]). Then, in [link]Matt. 16:18[/link] the Lord prophesied that He would build the church as the habitation, the temple, of God ([link]Eph. 2:22[/link]; [link]1 Cor. 3:16-17[/link]) on Himself as the rock and with His believers as stones ([link]1 Cor. 3:11[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 2:5[/link]). This is Bethel, the house of God ([link]1 Tim. 3:15[/link]). Ultimately, this Bethel will be enlarged to consummate in the New Jerusalem, the eternal tabernacle of God, in which God Himself and the Lamb will be the temple ([link]Rev. 21:3[/link], [link]22[/link]). See note [link]12[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 28[/link].

verse.text: Then Jacob said to his household and to all who were with him, [note]1[/note]Put away the foreign gods that are among you, and purify yourselves, and [note]1[/note]change your garments.
verse.note: An idol is anything that replaces the genuine and true God (cf. [link]1 John 5:20-21[/link]). For Bethel, God's house, the idols must be removed ([link]2 Cor. 6:16[/link]). Furthermore, everything impure, filthy, or defiled must be cleansed away ([link]2 Cor. 7:1[/link]). For the realizing of Bethel, the old man with his old manner of life, signified by the old garments ([link]Isa. 64:6[/link]), must also be put off, and the new man with his new manner of life, the church life, must be put on ([link]Eph. 4:22-24[/link]).

verse.text: And let us rise up and go up to Bethel, that I may make an altar there to the God who [xref]a[/xref]answered me in the day of my distress and has been [xref]b[/xref]with me wherever I have gone.
So they gave Jacob all the foreign gods which were in their hand and the [note]1[/note]rings which were in their ears, and Jacob hid them under the oak that was near Shechem.
verse.note: Earrings are for self-beautification. Jacob buried these with the foreign gods, the idols, indicating that in the consciousness of Jacob and his household, the earrings were as abominable as the idols (cf. [link]Exo. 32:2-4[/link] and note [link]2[sup]1[/sup][/link]).

verse.text: And as they journeyed, the [xref]a[/xref]terror of God was upon the cities that were around them, so they did not pursue the sons of Jacob.
And Jacob came to Luz (that is, [xref]a[/xref]Bethel), which is in the land of Canaan, he and all the people who were with him.
And he built an [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]altar there and called the place [note]2[/note]El-bethel, because there God had revealed Himself to him when he fled from his [xref]b[/xref]brother.
verse.note: An altar is for consecration. Jacob's consecration in erecting an altar at Shechem ([link]33:20[/link]) was for himself as an individual; his consecration in building an altar at Bethel was for the house of God, to fulfill God's eternal purpose and satisfy His heart's desire.
Meaning [i]God of Bethel.[/i] At Bethel God is no longer merely the God of individuals but the God of a corporate body, the house of God.

verse.text: And [xref]a[/xref]Deborah, Rebekah's nurse, died, and she was buried below Bethel under the oak; so its name was called [note]1[/note]Allon-bacuth.
verse.note: Meaning [i]oak of weeping.[/i]

chapter.verse: And God appeared to Jacob again when he came from Paddan-aram and blessed him.

verse.text: And God said to him,[br/]Your name is Jacob; / Your name shall [xref]a[/xref]no longer be called Jacob, / But [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]Israel shall be your name.[br/]Thus He called his name Israel.
verse.note: At Peniel God changed Jacob's name to Israel ([link]32:28[/link]), but there Jacob did not have much experience of this new name. It was at Bethel that Jacob was actually renewed and became a new person, a transformed person (cf. [link]Rom. 12:2[/link]). This kind of change can be experienced only at Bethel, i.e., in the proper church life. The church is altogether a new man ([link]Eph. 2:15[/link]), and the church life is the new life of the transformed Israel ([link]Gal. 6:16[/link]), which life is God in Christ.

verse.text: And God said to him,[br/]I am the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]All-sufficient God: / Be [xref]b[/xref]fruitful and multiply; / A [note]2[/note][xref]c[/xref]nation and a company of nations shall come from you, / And kings shall come forth from your loins.
verse.note: Heb. El Shaddai. This chapter and [link]ch. 17[/link] correspond to each other in the revelation of the divine title the All-sufficient God ([link]v. 11[/link]; [link]17:1[/link]), in the changing of human names, signifying the transforming of human beings ([link]v. 10[/link]; [link]17:5[/link]), and in the promise of multiplication for the bringing forth of nations and kings ([link]v. 11[/link]; [link]17:4[/link], [link]6[/link]). These three matters indicate that God's all-sufficiency and His transforming of His people are for them to be fruitful and multiply to produce transformed persons as materials for the building of God's house, Bethel. See notes [link book="Gen." chapter="17"]5[sup]2[/sup][/link] and [link]15[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 17[/link].
See note [link]4[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 17[/link].

verse.text: And the land which I gave to Abraham and to Isaac, / I will give to you; / And I will give the land to your [xref]a[/xref]seed after you.

chapter.verse: Then God went up from him in the place where He had spoken with him.

verse.text: And Jacob set up a [note]1[/note]pillar in the place where He had spoken with him, a [xref]a[/xref]pillar of stone; and he poured out a [note]2[/note]drink offering on it and poured oil on it.
verse.note: This was a repetition of what Jacob had done in [link]28:18[/link]. There Bethel, the house of God, was only a dream; it was not yet Jacob's experience. Here Jacob set up a second pillar at Bethel to consecrate himself to God for the fulfillment of the dream and of his vow to God in [link]28:10-22[/link]. This pillar was the second landmark in Jacob's experience (see note [link]52[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 31[/link]).

See note [link]17[sup]1[/sup] in Phil. 2[/link]. This is the first mentioning of the drink offering in the Bible ([link]Num. 15:1-5[/link]; [link]28:7-10[/link]; [link]Phil. 2:17[/link]; [link]2 Tim. 4:6[/link]). Its being mentioned here in connection with the pillar at Bethel indicates that the drink offering is for God's building. The fact that Jacob poured a drink offering upon the pillar before pouring oil upon it signifies that the pouring out of the drink offering brings in the outpouring of the Spirit ([link]Acts 2:33[/link]) for the sanctifying of God's house ([link]Exo. 40:9[/link]).

verse.text: And Jacob called the name of the place where God had spoken with him [xref]a[/xref]Bethel.

chapter.verse: And they journeyed from Bethel. And while there was still some distance to come to Ephrath, Rachel began to give birth; and she had hard labor.

verse.text: And while she was in hardest labor, the midwife said to her, Do not be afraid, for now you have [i]another[/i] [xref]a[/xref]son.
And as her soul was departing (for she [note]1[/note]died), she called his name [note]2[/note]Ben-oni; but his father called him [note]3[/note][xref]a[/xref]Benjamin.
verse.note: Rachel was Jacob's natural choice according to his heart's desire ([link]29:18-20[/link]). The death of Rachel was the loss of Jacob's natural choice. This was a deep and personal dealing for Jacob. Jacob lost Rachel, but in the process he gained Benjamin, who was a type of Christ. "Rachel" had to die so that "Benjamin" could be born. In the same manner, God will eventually take away our natural choice so that we may bring forth Christ for His expression. God's goal is not to make His chosen ones suffer loss; it is to bring forth Christ through them.
Meaning [i]son of my affliction.[/i]

Meaning [i]son of the right hand.[/i] Benjamin is a type of Christ, who was first Ben-oni, the Son of affliction, from His birth through His human life on earth ([link]Isa. 53:3[/link]), but eventually became Benjamin, the Son at the right hand of God, from His resurrection and in His ascension ([link]Matt. 26:64[/link]). See note [link]27[sup]1[/sup] in Psa. 68[/link].[br][br]Benjamin and Joseph, the two sons born to Jacob by Rachel, are both types of Christ. Although Joseph was born first, in typology he is the continuation of Benjamin, for the record of Joseph's life ([link]chs. 37-50[/link]) follows the record of Benjamin's birth. Joseph, like Benjamin, typifies the suffering and exalted Christ. During the first part of his life Joseph suffered as the son of affliction, and during the second part he was exalted to the throne at the right hand of Pharaoh ([link]41:40-44[/link]).

verse.text: So Rachel [xref]a[/xref]died and was buried on the way to Ephrath (that is, [xref]b[/xref]Bethlehem).
And Jacob set up a [note]1[/note]pillar on her grave; that is the [xref]a[/xref]pillar of Rachel's grave, [i]which is there[/i] to this day.
verse.note: See note [link]52[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 31[/link].

verse.text: And [note]1[/note]Israel journeyed and pitched his [xref]a[/xref]tent beyond the tower of Eder.
verse.note: Prior to this time Jacob's name had been changed to Israel ([link]32:27-28[/link]; [link]35:10[/link]), but this is the first time he is actually referred to as Israel. This indicates that after his experience at Bethel and the death of Rachel, Jacob had become a transformed person.

verse.text: And while Israel dwelt in that land, Reuben went and [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]lay with Bilhah his father's concubine, and Israel heard [i]of it.[/i] Now the sons of Jacob were [xref]b[/xref]twelve:
verse.note: Reuben, born of Leah, was the firstborn and should have inherited the birthright. However, because of his defilement in his lust, he lost the birthright, and it was given to Joseph, Rachel's son ([link]1 Chron. 5:1[/link]; [link]Gen. 49:3-4[/link]; [link]48:22[/link]). Joseph gained the birthright because of his purity ([link]39:7-12[/link]). Cf. [link]Heb. 12:16[/link] and note.

chapter.verse: The sons of Leah: Reuben, Jacob's firstborn, and Simeon and Levi and Judah and Issachar and Zebulun.
The sons of Rachel: Joseph and Benjamin.
And the sons of Bilhah, Rachel's female servant: Dan and Naphtali.
And the sons of Zilpah, Leah's female servant: Gad and Asher. These are the sons of Jacob, who were born to him in Paddan-aram.

verse.text: And Jacob came to Isaac his father at Mamre, at Kiriath-arba (that is, [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Hebron), where Abraham and Isaac had [xref]b[/xref]sojourned.
verse.note: After experiencing the deeper and more personal dealings, Jacob entered into full fellowship with God at Hebron (Hebron means fellowship, communion). Abraham had come to Shechem ([link]12:6[/link]), had passed through Bethel ([link]12:8[/link]), and had dwelt in Hebron ([link]13:18[/link]; [link]18:1[/link]), and Isaac spent nearly his whole life in Hebron. Jacob followed Abraham's footsteps to come to Shechem ([link]33:18[/link]), to pass through Bethel ([link]35:6[/link]), and to dwell in Hebron. In Hebron Jacob enjoyed full rest, joy, satisfaction, intimacy, and fellowship with the Lord. It was in Hebron that he began to mature in life.

chapter.verse: And the days of Isaac were a hundred and eighty years.

verse.text: And Isaac expired and died and was gathered to his people, an old man and full of days; and Esau and Jacob his sons [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]buried him.
verse.note: Isaac died in faith, as indicated by the fact that he was buried in the cave of Machpelah ([link]49:30-32[/link]; cf. [link]23:9[/link] and notes).

verse.text: Now these are the generations of Esau (that is, [xref]a[/xref]Edom).
Esau took his wives from the [xref]a[/xref]daughters of Canaan: Adah the daughter of Elon the Hittite; and Oholibamah the daughter of Anah, the daughter of Zibeon the Hivite;

chapter.verse: And Basemath Ishmael's daughter, the sister of Nebaioth.
And Adah bore Eliphaz to Esau, and Basemath bore Reuel,
And Oholibamah bore Jeush and Jalam and Korah. These are the sons of Esau, who were born to him in the land of Canaan.

And Esau took his wives and his sons and his daughters and all his household and his livestock and all his cattle and all his possessions which he had acquired in the land of Canaan, and he went into a land away from his brother Jacob.

verse.text: For their [xref]a[/xref]property was too great for them to dwell together, and the land where they sojourned could not sustain them because of their livestock.

chapter.verse: And Esau dwelt in Mount Seir; Esau is Edom.
And these are the generations of Esau the father of the Edomites in Mount Seir:
These are the names of Esau's sons: Eliphaz the son of Esau's wife Adah, Reuel the son of Esau's wife Basemath.
And the sons of Eliphaz were Teman, Omar, Zepho, and Gatam and Kenaz.

verse.text: And Timna was a concubine to Eliphaz, Esau's son, and she bore [xref]a[/xref]Amalek to Eliphaz. These are the sons of Esau's wife Adah.

chapter.verse: And these are the sons of Reuel: Nahath and Zerah, Shammah and Mizzah. These were the sons of Esau's wife Basemath.
And these were the sons of Oholibamah the daughter of Anah, the daughter of Zibeon, Esau's wife: And she bore to Esau Jeush and Jalam and Korah.

verse.text: These are the [note]1[/note]clans of the sons of Esau. The sons of Eliphaz the firstborn of Esau: Clan Teman, Clan Omar, Clan Zepho, Clan Kenaz,
verse.note: Or, chiefs. So also throughout this chapter.

chapter.verse: Clan Korah, Clan Gatam, Clan Amalek; these are the clans of Eliphaz in the land of Edom. These are the sons of Adah.
And these are the sons of Reuel, Esau's son: Clan Nahath, Clan Zerah, Clan Shammah, Clan Mizzah; these are the clans of Reuel in the land of Edom. These are the sons of Basemath, Esau's wife.
And these are the sons of Oholibamah, Esau's wife: Clan Jeush, Clan Jalam, Clan Korah. These are the clans of Oholibamah the daughter of Anah, Esau's wife.
These are the sons of Esau (that is, Edom), and these are their clans.
These are the sons of Seir the Horite, the inhabitants of the land: Lotan and Shobal and Zibeon and Anah
And Dishon and Ezer and Dishan; these are the clans of the Horites, the children of Seir in the land of Edom.
And the sons of Lotan were Hori and Heman; and Lotan's sister was Timna.
And these are the sons of Shobal: Alvan and Manahath and Ebal, Shepho and Onam.

verse.text: And these are the sons of Zibeon: Aiah and Anah. This is the Anah who found the [note]1[/note]hot springs in the wilderness as he fed the donkeys of Zibeon his father.
verse.note: The meaning of the Hebrew is uncertain.

chapter.verse: And these are the children of Anah: Dishon and Oholibamah the daughter of Anah.
And these are the sons of Dishon: Hemdan and Eshban and Ithran and Cheran.
These are the sons of Ezer: Bilhan and Zaavan and Akan.
These are the sons of Dishan: Uz and Aran.
These are the clans of the Horites: Clan Lotan, Clan Shobal, Clan Zibeon, Clan Anah,
Clan Dishon, Clan Ezer, Clan Dishan. These are the clans of the Horites, according to their clans in the land of Seir.

verse.text: And these are the kings who [xref]a[/xref]reigned in the land of Edom before a king of the children of Israel reigned:

chapter.verse: Now Bela the son of Beor reigned in Edom, and the name of his city was Dinhabah.
And Bela died, and Jobab the son of Zerah of Bozrah reigned in his place.

verse.text: And Jobab died, and Husham of the land of the Temanites reigned in his place.

chapter.verse: And Husham died; and Hadad the son of Bedad, who struck Midian in the field of Moab, reigned in his place; and the name of his city was Avith.
And Hadad died, and Samlah of Masrekah reigned in his place.

verse.text: And Samlah died, and Shaul of Rehoboth by the [note]1[/note]River reigned in his place.
verse.note: I.e., the Euphrates.

chapter.verse: And Shaul died, and Baal-hanan the son of Achbor reigned in his place.
And Baal-hanan the son of Achbor died, and Hadar reigned in his place. And the name of his city was Pau; and his wife's name was Mehetabel the daughter of Matred, the daughter of Mezahab.
And these are the names of the clans of Esau, according to their families, according to their places, by their names: Clan Timna, Clan Alvah, Clan Jetheth,
Clan Oholibamah, Clan Elah, Clan Pinon,
Clan Kenaz, Clan Teman, Clan Mibzar,

verse.text: Clan Magdiel, Clan Iram. These are the clans of Edom according to their habitations in the land of their possession. This is Esau the father of the [xref]a[/xref]Edomites.
And [note]1[/note]Jacob dwelt in the land where his father had [xref]a[/xref]sojourned, in the land of Canaan.
verse.note: At this point Jacob was a transformed person, but he was not yet mature. To be transformed is to be metabolically changed in our natural life ([link]Rom. 12:2[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 3:18[/link]); to be mature is to be filled with the divine life that changes us. We may be changed in our natural life (transformed) yet not be filled with the divine life (mature). The last stage of transformation is maturity. Jacob's transformation began at the time God touched him ([link]32:25[/link]), and it continued until the end of [link]ch. 36[/link], when the process of transformation was relatively complete (see note [link]3[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 37[/link]). [link]Genesis 37:1-43:14[/link] is a record of the process of Jacob's maturity.[br][br]Genesis shows a complete picture of how human beings can be remade and transformed to express God in His image and represent God with His dominion. This book ends as it begins — with God's image and dominion. The last fourteen chapters indicate that after Jacob had become Israel, he bore the image of God and, through Joseph, exercised the dominion of God. For God's expression and dominion there is the need of maturity. Only a mature life can bear God's image and exercise His dominion.

verse.text: These are the generations of Jacob.[separator][note]1[/note]Joseph, when he was seventeen years old, was [note]2[/note]shepherding the flock with his brothers while he was [i]still[/i] a youth, with the sons of Bilhah and with the sons of Zilpah, his father's wives. And Joseph brought an evil report of them to their father.
verse.note: In the last fourteen chapters of Genesis the biographies of Jacob and Joseph are blended, indicating that according to spiritual experience, Jacob and Joseph are one person (cf. note [link]1[sup]1[/sup], par. 2, in ch. 12[/link] and note [link]1[sup]1[/sup], par. 2, in ch. 25[/link]). Joseph is a type of Christ as the One who is altogether perfect, having no defects ([link]Luke 23:4[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 5:21[/link]; [link]Heb. 4:15[/link]; [link]1 Pet. 2:22[/link]). As such, Joseph represents the reigning aspect of the mature Israel, the constitution of Christ in Jacob's mature nature. As a mature saint constituted of Christ, the perfect One, Jacob reigned through Joseph ([link]41:39-44[/link]).

Joseph, like Abel, was a shepherd. This signifies the aspect of the constitution of Christ in the mature life that is the shepherding life to care for others ([link]John 10:11[/link]; [link]21:15-17[/link]).

verse.text: Now Israel loved Joseph [note]1[/note]more than all his sons because he was the son of his [xref]a[/xref]old age, and he had made him a [xref]b[/xref]coat of many colors.
verse.note: Jacob's preferential love for Joseph indicates that he was not fully transformed but was still living somewhat in the natural life. Jacob's partiality toward Joseph caused him further sufferings, which deeply touched his personal feelings. These final dealings brought him to full maturity for the expression and dominion of God.

chapter.verse: And when his brothers saw that their father loved him more than all his brothers, they hated him and could not speak peaceably to him.

verse.text: Then Joseph had a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]dream; and when he told [i]it[/i] to his brothers, they hated him even more.
verse.note: Joseph's two dreams ([link]vv. 7-9[/link]), both from God, unveiled to him God's divine view concerning the nature, position, function, and goal of God's people on earth. According to their fallen nature, God's people are evil and unclean, but in God's eternal view, His people are sheaves of wheat full of life and heavenly bodies full of light (cf. [link]Num. 23:21[/link]; [link]1 Kings 19:18[/link]; [link]Rev. 12:1[/link] and note). The reigning aspect of the mature life never condemns God's people (cf. [link]v. 2c[/link]). Rather, it shepherds and appreciates them. Joseph's dreams controlled and directed his behavior (cf. [link]Acts 26:19[/link]). See notes [link]12[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 39[/link] and [link]9[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 42[/link].

chapter.verse: And he said to them, Listen to this dream which I have had:

verse.text: There we were, binding sheaves in the field, when suddenly my sheaf rose up and remained standing; and then your sheaves gathered around and [xref]a[/xref]bowed down to my sheaf.

chapter.verse: And his brothers said to him, Will you indeed reign over us and actually be a ruler among us? So they hated him even more for his dreams and for his words.

verse.text: And he had still another dream and told it to his brothers and said, Now I have had another dream: There were the [xref]a[/xref]sun and the moon and eleven stars, [xref]b[/xref]bowing down to me.

chapter.verse: And he told [i]it[/i] to his father and to his brothers; and his father rebuked him and said to him, What is this dream that you have had? Shall I and your mother and your brothers indeed come to bow down to the ground to you?

verse.text: And his brothers were [xref]a[/xref]jealous of him, but his father [xref]b[/xref]kept the saying [i]in his heart.[/i]

chapter.verse: Then his brothers went to shepherd their father's flock in Shechem.

verse.text: And Israel said to Joseph, Your brothers are now shepherding [i]the flock[/i] in Shechem. Come, and I will [note]1[/note]send you to them. And he said to him, Here I am.
verse.note: Joseph's life was a copy of the life of Christ: in his being a shepherd ([link]v. 2[/link]; [link]John 10:11-16[/link]); in his being his father's beloved ([link]vv. 3-4[/link]; [link]Matt. 3:17[/link]; [link]17:5[/link]); in his being sent by his father to minister to his brothers according to his father's will ([link]vv. 12-17[/link]; [link]John 6:38[/link]); in his being hated, persecuted, and betrayed (sold) by his brothers ([link]vv. 5[/link], [link]18-36[/link]; [link]John 15:25[/link]; [link]Matt. 26:4[/link], [link]14-16[/link]); in his being cast into the prison of death with two criminals, one of whom was restored and the other executed ([link]39:20[/link]; [link]40:1-23[/link]; [link]Acts 2:23[/link]; [link]Luke 23:32[/link], [link]39-43[/link]); in his being released (resurrected) from the prison of death ([link]41:14[/link]; [link]Acts 2:24[/link]); in his being enthroned with authority ([link]41:40-44[/link]; [link]Matt. 28:18[/link]; [link]Acts 2:36[/link]; [link]Rev. 3:21[/link]); in his receiving glory and gifts ([link]41:42[/link]; [link]Heb. 2:9[/link]; [link]Psa. 68:18[/link]; [link]Acts 2:33[/link]); in his becoming the savior of the world, the sustainer of life (the revealer of secrets) ([link]41:45[/link] and note 1; [link]Acts 5:31[/link]; [link]John 6:50-51[/link]); in his taking a wife from the Gentiles ([link]41:45[/link]; [link]John 3:29[/link]; [link]Eph. 5:23-27[/link]; [link]Rev. 19:7[/link]; cf. note [link]1[sup]4[/sup] in Matt. 1[/link]); in his supplying people with food ([link]41:56-57[/link]; [link]John 6:35[/link]); in his acknowledging his ignorant brothers and being recognized by them ([link]45:1-4[/link], [link]14-15[/link]; [link]Rom. 11:26[/link]; [link]Zech. 12:10[/link]; [link]Rev. 1:7[/link]); and in his reigning in the kingdom over the whole earth ([link]41:40-50:26[/link]; [link]Rev. 11:15[/link]; [link]Dan. 7:13-14[/link]).

chapter.verse: And he said to him, Go now, see if it is well with your brothers and well with the flock, and bring word back to me. So he sent him from the valley of Hebron, and he came to Shechem.
And a man found him; and there he was, wandering in the field, and the man asked him, saying, What are you seeking?
And he said, I am seeking my brothers. Please tell me where they are shepherding [i]the flock.[/i]
And the man said, They have moved on from here; for I heard them say, Let us go to Dothan. And Joseph went after his brothers and found them in Dothan.

verse.text: And when they saw him from a distance and before he came near to them, they [note]1[/note]conspired against him to put him to death.
verse.note: While Joseph's brothers were drowning in the water of human anger, Joseph, representing the reigning aspect of a mature life, lived as a sheaf of life (see note [link]5[sup]1[/sup][/link]) and emerged from the death water of human anger.

chapter.verse: And they said one to another, Here comes this master of dreams.

verse.text: Now then, come and let us [xref]a[/xref]slay him and throw him into one of the pits; and we will say, A wild beast has devoured him; then we will see what will become of his dreams.
But when Reuben heard [i]it,[/i] he tried to deliver him out of their hand and said, [xref]a[/xref]Let us not take his life.

And Reuben said to them, Shed no blood; throw him into this [xref]a[/xref]pit that is in the wilderness, but do not lay a hand on him — that he might deliver him out of their hand to restore him to his father.
And when Joseph came to his brothers, they stripped Joseph of his coat, the [xref]a[/xref]coat of many colors that was on him;

chapter.verse: And they took him and threw him into the pit. Now the pit was empty; there was no water in it.

verse.text: Then they sat down to eat food; and they lifted up their eyes and looked, and there was a [xref]a[/xref]caravan of Ishmaelites, coming from Gilead, with their camels bearing aromatic gum and balm and myrrh, going to carry [i]it[/i] down to Egypt.
Then Judah said to his brothers, What gain is there if we [xref]a[/xref]slay our brother and conceal his blood?

chapter.verse: Come, and let us sell him to the Ishmaelites, and let our hand not be on him; for he is our brother, our flesh. And his brothers listened [i]to him.[/i]

verse.text: So when some [note]1[/note]Midianite traders passed by, they pulled Joseph up, lifting [i]him[/i] out of the pit, and they [xref]a[/xref]sold Joseph to the [note]1[/note]Ishmaelites for twenty [i]pieces[/i] of silver. And [i]these[/i] brought Joseph into Egypt.
verse.note: Ishmael was the son of Abraham by Hagar ([link]16:15[/link]), and Midian was the son of Abraham by his last wife, Keturah ([link]25:1-2[/link]). Both the Ishmaelites and the Midianites represent the flesh, the natural strength. In addition, hatred ([link]v. 8[/link]) is related to the flesh, and the flesh is connected to the world, represented by Egypt ([link]Heb. 11:25-26[/link]). In His sovereignty God used everything, including the flesh, the hatred of Joseph's brothers, and Egypt, to fulfill His purpose concerning Joseph ([link]45:5-8a[/link]; [link]50:20[/link]).

chapter.verse: And when Reuben returned to the pit and saw that Joseph was not in the pit, he tore his clothes.
And he returned to his brothers and said, The boy is not there; so as for me, what shall I do?

verse.text: Then they took Joseph's [xref]a[/xref]coat and slaughtered a male goat and dipped the coat in the blood.

chapter.verse: And they sent the coat of many colors and had it brought to their father and said, We found this; please examine [i]it, and see[/i] whether it is your son's coat or not.

verse.text: And he recognized it and said, It is my son's coat. A [xref]a[/xref]wild beast has devoured him; Joseph is without doubt [xref]b[/xref]torn to pieces.

chapter.verse: And Jacob tore his garments and put sackcloth upon his loins and mourned for his son many days.

verse.text: And all his sons and all his daughters rose up to comfort him; but he refused to be comforted and said, Surely I will go down to [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Sheol to my son, mourning. Thus his father wept for him.
verse.note: See note [link]23[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 11[/link].

verse.text: Meanwhile the Midianites had [note]1[/note]sold him in Egypt to Potiphar, an official of Pharaoh, the [xref]a[/xref]captain of the guard.
verse.note: The time from the selling of Joseph to the sending of Jacob's sons to Egypt ([link]42:1-5[/link]) was at least twenty years. In the record of Jacob those twenty years were a time of silence. Through the loss of Joseph, Jacob became a person who was absolutely open to God. It must have been that during those years God dispensed Himself into Jacob more and more, until Jacob was filled with the divine life unto maturity. See note [link]2[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 42[/link].

chapter.verse: Now at that time Judah went down from his brothers and pitched [i]his tent[/i] near a certain Adullamite, whose name was Hirah.

verse.text: And Judah saw there the daughter of a certain Canaanite whose name was [xref]a[/xref]Shua. And he took her and went in to her.
And she conceived and bore a son, and he called his name [xref]a[/xref]Er.

chapter.verse: And she conceived again and bore a son, and she called his name Onan.

verse.text: And yet again she bore a son and called his name Shelah, and [note]1[/note]she was in Chezib when she bore him.
verse.note: Following the Septuagint; the Hebrew text reads, he was.

verse.text: And Judah took a wife for Er his firstborn, and her name was [note]1[/note]Tamar.
verse.note: For [link]vv. 6-30[/link], see [link]Matt. 1:3a[/link] and notes.

verse.text: And Er, Judah's firstborn, was [xref]a[/xref]wicked in the sight of Jehovah. And Jehovah put him to death.
And Judah said to Onan, Go in to your brother's [xref]a[/xref]wife, and perform the duty of a brother-in-law to her, and raise up seed to your brother.

chapter.verse: But since Onan knew that the seed would not be his, whenever he went in to his brother's wife, he spilled it on the ground, so that he would not give seed to his brother.
But what he did was evil in the sight of Jehovah, so He put him to death also.

verse.text: Then Judah said to Tamar his daughter-in-law, Remain a widow in your father's house until Shelah my son grows up. For he [note]1[/note]thought, He also may die, like his brothers. So Tamar went and dwelt in her father's house.
verse.note: Lit., said.

chapter.verse: And in process of time Shua's daughter, the wife of Judah, died; and Judah was comforted and went up to his sheepshearers at Timnah, he and his friend Hirah the Adullamite.
And it was told to Tamar, saying, Your father-in-law is now going up to Timnah to shear his sheep.

verse.text: And she removed from herself her widow's garments and covered [i]herself[/i] with a veil and wrapped herself and sat in the gate of Enaim, which is on the way to Timnah; for she saw that [xref]a[/xref]Shelah had grown up, and she had not been given to him as [i]his[/i] wife.
And when [note]1[/note]Judah saw her, he thought she was a harlot, for she had covered her face.
verse.note: Judah behaved in a blind way, indulging in his lust in darkness. In contrast, Joseph, living as a star of light (see note [link]5[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 37[/link]), overcame his lust ([link]39:7-12[/link]).

chapter.verse: And he turned aside to her by the way and said, Come now, let me come in to you; for he did not know that she was his daughter-in-law. And she said, What will you give me, that you may come in to me?
And he said, I will send [i]you[/i] a kid from the flock. And she said, Only if you give me a pledge until you send [i]it.[/i]

verse.text: And he said, What pledge shall I give you? And she said, Your [xref]a[/xref]seal and your cord and your staff that is in your hand. And he gave [i]them[/i] to her and went in to her, and she conceived by him.

chapter.verse: And she arose and went away, and removed her veil from herself and put on her widow's garments.
And Judah sent the kid by the hand of his friend the Adullamite, to receive the pledge from the woman's hand; but he did not find her.
Then he asked the men of her place, saying, Where is the prostitute who was by the road at Enaim? And they said, There has been no prostitute here.
And he returned to Judah and said, I did not find her; and also the men of the place said, There has been no prostitute here.
And Judah said, Let her keep [i]the things[/i] for herself, lest we become a laughing stock; you see, I sent [i]her[/i] this kid, but you did not find her.

And about three months later it was told Judah, saying, Tamar your daughter-in-law has played the harlot; moreover, now she is pregnant by harlotry. And Judah said, Bring her out, and let her be burned.

verse.text: As she was being brought out, she sent [i]word[/i] to her father-in-law, saying, I am pregnant by the man to whom these belong. And she said, Please note whose these are, the [xref]a[/xref]seal and the cords and the staff.
And Judah took note [i]of them[/i] and said, She is more righteous than I, because I did not give her to my son [xref]a[/xref]Shelah. And he did not know her again anymore.

chapter.verse: And at the time of her delivery, there were twins in her womb.
And while she was giving birth, one put out a hand; and the midwife took and tied a scarlet thread on his hand, saying, This one came out first.

verse.text: But when he drew back his hand, his brother suddenly came out; and she said, What a breach you have made for yourself! Therefore his name was called [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Perez.
verse.note: Meaning [i]a breach.[/i]

verse.text: And afterward his brother came out, who had the scarlet thread on his hand; and his name was called [note]1[/note]Zerah.
verse.note: Meaning [i]a dawning,[/i] or [i]a shining.[/i]

verse.text: Now Joseph was brought down to Egypt; and Potiphar, an official of Pharaoh, the [xref]a[/xref]captain of the guard, an Egyptian, bought him from the [xref]b[/xref]Ishmaelites who had brought him down there.
And Jehovah was [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]with Joseph, and he became a prosperous man; and he was in the house of his master, the Egyptian.
verse.note: As a representative of the reigning aspect of a mature life, Joseph enjoyed the presence of the Lord, and with it the Lord's authority, prosperity, and blessing ([link]vv. 2-5[/link]).

verse.text: And his master saw that Jehovah was with him and that Jehovah caused all that he did to [xref]a[/xref]prosper in his hand.
And Joseph [xref]a[/xref]found favor in his sight, and he ministered to him; and he made him overseer of his house and put all that he had in his [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]charge.
verse.note: Lit., hand. So also throughout the chapter.

verse.text: And from the time he made him overseer in his house and [i]put him[/i] over all that he had, Jehovah blessed the Egyptian's house on account of Joseph; and the [xref]a[/xref]blessing of Jehovah was upon all that he had, in the house and in the field.

chapter.verse: And he left all that he had in Joseph's charge; and with him [i]there,[/i] he was not concerned about anything except the food that he ate. And Joseph was handsome in form and handsome in appearance.
Now after these things his master's wife cast her eyes upon Joseph and said, Lie with me.

verse.text: But he refused and said to his master's wife, Behold, with me [i]here,[/i] my master is not concerned about anything in the house, and he has put everything he has in my [xref]a[/xref]charge.
There is no one greater in this house than I, and he has withheld nothing from me except you, because you are his wife. How then can I do this great evil, and [xref]a[/xref]sin against God?

chapter.verse: And although she spoke to Joseph day after day, he would not listen to her to lie beside her [i]or[/i] be with her.
And one such day he went into the house to do his work, and none of the men of the house were there in the house.

verse.text: And she grabbed him by his garment, saying, Lie with me! But he left his garment in her hand, and [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]fled and went outside.
verse.note: Joseph lived a life that corresponded to the vision he saw in his two dreams (see note [link]5[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 37[/link]; cf. [link]Acts 26:19[/link]). Joseph's brothers vented their anger ([link]37:18-31[/link]) and indulged in their lust ([link]38:15-18[/link]), but Joseph subdued his anger and conquered his lust, behaving as a sheaf full of life and conducting himself like a heavenly star shining in the darkness (see notes [link]18[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 37[/link] and [link]15[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 38[/link]). Joseph's life under the heavenly vision was the life of the kingdom of the heavens described in [link]Matt. 5-7[/link]. By living such a life, he was fully prepared to reign as a king.

chapter.verse: And when she saw that he had left his garment in her hand and had fled outside,
She called to the men of her house and spoke to them, saying, See, he has brought in a Hebrew man to us to mock us. He came in to me to lie with me, and I called out with a loud voice;
And when he heard that I lifted up my voice and called out, he left his garment beside me, and fled and went outside.
And she placed his garment beside her until his master came home.
And she spoke to him with these words, saying, The Hebrew servant, whom you have brought to us, came in to me to mock me.
And when I lifted up my voice and called out, he left his garment beside me and fled outside.
And when his master heard the words of his wife that she had spoken to him, saying, This is the way your servant treated me; his anger burned.

verse.text: And Joseph's master took him and put him into the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]prison, the place where the king's prisoners were confined. But while he was there in the prison,
verse.note: Joseph was rejected by his brothers, sold by them, and cast into prison. Likewise, Christ was first rejected by His brothers, then sold by one of His people, and eventually cast into the prison of death.

verse.text: Jehovah was [xref]a[/xref]with Joseph; and He extended kindness to him and gave him favor in the sight of the chief jailer.
And the chief jailer put in Joseph's [xref]a[/xref]charge all the prisoners who were in the prison; and whatever was done there, he was the one to do [i]it.[/i]
The chief jailer did not supervise anything that was in his charge, because Jehovah was [xref]a[/xref]with him; and whatever he did, Jehovah caused [i]it[/i] to [xref]b[/xref]prosper.

chapter.verse: And after these things, the cupbearer and the baker of the king of Egypt offended their lord, the king of Egypt.
And Pharaoh was angry with his two officials, the chief of the cupbearers and the chief of the bakers.

verse.text: And he put them in custody at the house of the [xref]a[/xref]captain of the guard, in the prison, the place where Joseph was [xref]b[/xref]confined.

chapter.verse: And the captain of the guard put Joseph in charge of them, and he ministered to them; and they were in custody for some time.
And the cupbearer and the baker of the king of Egypt, who were confined in the prison, both of them had a dream, each man with his own dream in one night, and each dream with its own interpretation.
And Joseph came to them in the morning and looked at them, and they were troubled.
And he asked Pharaoh's officials, who were with him in custody in his master's house, saying, Why are your faces so sad today?

verse.text: And they said to him, We have had a [xref]a[/xref]dream, and there is no one to interpret it. And Joseph said to them, [note]1[/note]Do not interpretations belong to [xref]b[/xref]God? Please tell [i]it[/i] to me.
verse.note: Although his own dreams ([link]37:5-11[/link]) were not yet fulfilled, Joseph had the faith and the boldness to interpret the dreams of his two companions. The fact that he acknowledged God as the source of interpretations indicates that he still believed in the interpretation God had given him of his own dreams. Eventually, Joseph was released from prison indirectly through his speaking by faith in interpreting the cupbearer's dream ([link]41:9-13[/link]), and he was ushered to the throne directly through his speaking boldly in interpreting Pharaoh's dreams ([link]41:14-46[/link]). Both release and authority came to him through his speaking.

chapter.verse: And the chief of the cupbearers told his dream to Joseph and said to him, In my dream there was a vine before me,
And on the vine were three branches. And as soon as it budded, its blossoms came out, [i]and[/i] its clusters ripened into grapes.
And Pharaoh's cup was in my hand, and I took the grapes and squeezed them into Pharaoh's cup, and I put the cup in Pharaoh's hand.

verse.text: And Joseph said to him, This is its [xref]a[/xref]interpretation: The three branches are three days.

Within three more days Pharaoh will [xref]a[/xref]lift up your head and restore you to your office, and you will put Pharaoh's cup into his hand according to your former custom when you were his cupbearer.

chapter.verse: But remember my being with you when it is well with you, and please do me a kindness and make mention of me to Pharaoh and [i]so[/i] have me brought out of this house.

verse.text: For I was actually [xref]a[/xref]kidnapped out of the land of the Hebrews, and here also I have not done anything that they should put me into the [xref]b[/xref]dungeon.

chapter.verse: Now when the chief of the bakers saw that the interpretation was good, he said to Joseph, I also [i]saw this[/i] in my dream: There were three baskets of white bread on my head.
And in the uppermost basket there were all sorts of baked food for Pharaoh, and the birds were eating them out of the basket on my head.

verse.text: And Joseph answered and said, This is its [xref]a[/xref]interpretation: The three baskets are [xref]b[/xref]three days.
Within three more days Pharaoh will lift up your head from you and will [xref]a[/xref]hang you on a tree, and the birds will eat your flesh from you.

And on the third day, which was Pharaoh's birthday, he made a feast for all his servants; and he [xref]a[/xref]lifted up the head of the chief of the cupbearers and the head of the chief of the bakers among his servants.
And he [xref]a[/xref]restored the chief of the cupbearers to his cupbearing, and he put the cup into Pharaoh's hand;
But the chief of the bakers he [xref]a[/xref]hanged, just as Joseph had interpreted to them.
Yet the chief of the cupbearers did not [xref]a[/xref]remember Joseph, but forgot him.
And at the end of [note]1[/note]two full years Pharaoh had a dream, and [xref]a[/xref]there he was, standing by the [note]2[/note]River.
verse.note: Like the Old Testament priests and the Lord Jesus, Joseph had to wait until he was thirty years old before he was fully put into his ministry ([link]v. 46[/link]; [link]Num. 4:3[/link]; [link]Luke 3:23[/link]). While Joseph was in confinement, he was being tried, tested, and trained for his enthronement.
I.e., the Nile. So throughout the chapter.

chapter.verse: And there came up out of the River seven cows, fine-looking and fat-fleshed; and they grazed in the reed grass.
Then there came up after them seven other cows out of the River, ugly-looking and thin-fleshed; and they stood beside the [i]other[/i] cows on the bank of the River.
And the ugly-looking and thin-fleshed cows ate up the seven fine-looking and fat cows. Then Pharaoh awoke.
And he slept and dreamed a second time. And there were seven ears of grain, coming up on one stalk, fat and good.
Then there were seven ears, thin and scorched by the east wind, that sprouted after them.
And the thin ears swallowed up the seven fat and full ears. Then Pharaoh awoke, and it was a dream.

verse.text: And in the morning his [xref]a[/xref]spirit was troubled, so he sent and called for all the [xref]b[/xref]magicians of Egypt and all its wise men; and Pharaoh told them his dream, but there was no one who could interpret them to Pharaoh.

chapter.verse: Then the chief cupbearer spoke to Pharaoh, saying, I do remember my sins today.

verse.text: Pharaoh was [xref]a[/xref]angry with his servants, and he put me in custody at the house of the [xref]b[/xref]captain of the guard, [i]both[/i] me and the chief baker.
And we [i]both[/i] had a [xref]a[/xref]dream in one night, I and he; each of us had a dream with its own interpretation.

And a young Hebrew man was there with us, a servant of the captain of the guard. And we told him our dreams, and he [xref]a[/xref]interpreted [i]them[/i] for us; to each one he interpreted according to his dream.
And as he interpreted to us, so it happened; [note]1[/note]Pharaoh [xref]a[/xref]restored me to my office, and he hanged the [note]2[/note]baker.
verse.note: Lit., he.
Lit., him.

verse.text: Then Pharaoh sent and called for Joseph, and they brought him hastily [xref]a[/xref]out of the [note]1[/note]dungeon; and he had shaved himself and changed his garments, and he came to Pharaoh.
verse.note: Or, pit. In his being released from the dungeon, Joseph typifies Christ as the One resurrected from the prison of death ([link]Acts 2:24[/link]).

verse.text: And Pharaoh said to Joseph, I have had a dream, but there is no one who can [xref]a[/xref]interpret it; and I have heard it said of you that when you hear a dream you can interpret it.
And Joseph answered Pharaoh, saying, It is not of [xref]a[/xref]me; [xref]b[/xref]God [note]1[/note]will give Pharaoh a favorable answer.
verse.note: Lit., will answer Pharaoh with peace.

verse.text: And Pharaoh spoke to Joseph, In my dream, [xref]a[/xref]there I was, standing on the bank of the River.

chapter.verse: And there came up out of the River seven cows, fat-fleshed and fine-looking; and they grazed in the reed grass.
Then there came up after them seven other cows, poor and very ugly-looking and thin-fleshed; I had never seen such in all the land of Egypt for ugliness.
And the thin and ugly[i]-looking[/i] cows ate up the first seven fat cows.
And when they had swallowed them, no one would have known that they had swallowed them, for they were still as ugly-looking as at the beginning. Then I awoke.
And I saw [i]this[/i] in my dream: There were seven ears of grain, coming up on one stalk, full and good.
Then there were seven ears, withered, thin, [i]and[/i] scorched by the east wind, that sprouted after them.

verse.text: And the thin ears swallowed up the seven good ears. And I told [i]it[/i] to the [xref]a[/xref]magicians, but there was no one who could explain [i]it[/i] to me.
Then Joseph said to Pharaoh, Pharaoh's dream is one [i]dream;[/i] [xref]a[/xref]what God is about to do He has told Pharaoh.

chapter.verse: The seven good cows are seven years, and the seven good ears are seven years; the dream is one.
And the seven thin and ugly-looking cows that came up after them are seven years, and [i]so are[/i] the seven empty ears scorched by the east wind; they will be seven years of famine.

verse.text: This matter is just as I have spoken to Pharaoh; [xref]a[/xref]what God is about to do He has shown to Pharaoh.
Seven years of great [xref]a[/xref]abundance are now about to come throughout all the land of Egypt.
Then seven years of [xref]a[/xref]famine will arise after them, and all the abundance in the land of Egypt will be forgotten, and the famine will consume the land.

chapter.verse: And the abundance will be unknown in the land because of that famine which follows, for it will be very severe.
And as for the repeating of the dream to Pharaoh twice, [i]it means[/i] that the matter is determined by God, and God will quickly bring it about.
Now therefore let Pharaoh look out for a discerning and wise man, and set him over the land of Egypt.
Let Pharaoh take action to appoint overseers over the land and take a fifth [i]of the produce[/i] of the land of Egypt in the seven years of abundance.

verse.text: And let them [xref]a[/xref]gather all the food of these coming good years and lay up grain under Pharaoh's authority for food in the cities, and let them keep [i]it.[/i]

chapter.verse: And let the food become a reserve for the land against the seven years of famine that will be in the land of Egypt, so that the land does not perish in the famine.
And the word seemed good to Pharaoh and to all his servants.

verse.text: And Pharaoh said to his servants, Can we find such a man like this, in whom the [xref]a[/xref]Spirit of God is?

chapter.verse: And Pharaoh said to Joseph, Since God let you know all this, there is no one as discerning and wise as you.

verse.text: You shall be [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]over my household, and according to your word all my people shall be ruled; only in the throne will I be greater than you.
verse.note: On the day Joseph was released from the dungeon, he was enthroned to be the actual ruler over the whole land of Egypt. In like manner, after Christ was resurrected from death, He was enthroned with all authority in heaven and on earth ([link]Matt. 28:18[/link]; [link]Acts 2:36[/link]).

verse.text: Then Pharaoh said to Joseph, See, I have set you [xref]a[/xref]over all the land of Egypt.

And Pharaoh took off his [note]1[/note]signet ring from his hand and put it upon Joseph's hand, and clothed him in [note]1[/note]garments of fine linen, and put a [note]1[/note]gold chain around his neck.
verse.note: In his receiving glory and gifts in his enthronement, Joseph typifies Christ, who received glory ([link]Heb. 2:9[/link]) and gifts ([link]Psa. 68:18[/link]; [link]Acts 2:33[/link]) in His ascension. The ring, the garments, and the gold chain portray the gifts that Christ received in His ascension to the heavens, which gifts He has passed on to the church. The signet ring signifies the Holy Spirit as a seal within and upon Christ's believers ([link]Acts 2:33[/link]; [link]Eph. 1:13[/link]; [link]4:30[/link]; cf. [link]Luke 15:22[/link]). The garments signify Christ as our objective righteousness for our justification before God ([link]1 Cor. 1:30[/link]; cf. [link]Psa. 45:9[/link], [link]13[/link]; [link]Luke 15:22[/link]) and as our subjective righteousness lived out of us that we may be qualified to participate in the marriage of the Lamb ([link]Psa. 45:14[/link] and note 1; [link]Rev. 19:7-9[/link] and note [link]8[sup]2[/sup][/link]). The golden chain signifies the beauty of the Holy Spirit given for obedience expressed in submission (cf. [link]Acts 5:32[/link]). A chained neck signifies a will that has been conquered and subdued to obey God's commandment (cf. [link]S.S. 1:10[/link]; [link]Prov. 1:8-9[/link]). According to the sequence of spiritual experience, we first receive the sealing Spirit for salvation; then we receive the garment of righteousness and begin to live Christ ([link]Gal. 2:20[/link]; [link]Phil. 1:20-21a[/link]). In order for us to live Christ, our neck must be chained, our will must be subdued, by the Holy Spirit.

chapter.verse: And he made him ride in the chariot of his second[i]-in-command,[/i] and they cried out before him, Bow the knee! And he set him over all the land of Egypt.
And Pharaoh said to Joseph, I am Pharaoh, yet without your consent no man will lift up his hand or his foot in all the land of Egypt.

verse.text: And Pharaoh called Joseph's name [note]1[/note]Zaphenath-paneah, and he gave him [note]2[/note]Asenath, the daughter of Potiphera priest of On, as his wife. And Joseph went out over the land of Egypt.
verse.note: Meaning [i]savior of the world, sustainer of life,[/i] or [i]revealer of secrets.[/i] First, Joseph was the revealer of secrets ([link]40:9-19[/link]; [link]41:17-32[/link]); then, because he sustained the life of the people ([link]vv. 47-57[/link]; [link]47:12-24[/link]), he became the savior of the world ([link]47:25[/link]). In this also he typifies Christ ([link]Matt. 13:1-52[/link]; [link]John 6:50-51[/link]; [link]Acts 5:31[/link]).

In taking an Egyptian, a Gentile, as his wife, Joseph typifies Christ, who is taking the church from among the Gentiles as His wife during the time that He is being rejected by Israel (cf. note [link]1[sup]4[/sup] in Matt. 1[/link]).

chapter.verse: Now Joseph was thirty years old when he stood before Pharaoh, the king of Egypt. And Joseph went out from the presence of Pharaoh and passed through all the land of Egypt.
And in the seven years of abundance the earth produced copiously.
And he gathered up all the food of the seven years which came upon the land of Egypt and put the food in the cities; he placed the food from the surrounding fields within each city.
And Joseph stored grain in great abundance like the sand of the sea until he stopped measuring [i]it;[/i] for it was beyond measure.
And before the year of famine came, two sons were born to Joseph, whom Asenath, the daughter of Potiphera priest of On, bore to him.

verse.text: And Joseph called the name of the firstborn [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Manasseh, for, [i]he said,[/i] God has made me forget all my trouble and all my father's house.
verse.note: Meaning [i]making to forget.[/i]

verse.text: And he called the name of the second [note]1[/note]Ephraim, for, [i]he said,[/i] God has made me [xref]a[/xref]fruitful in the land of my affliction.
verse.note: Meaning [i]fruitful,[/i] or [i]twice fruitful.[/i]

chapter.verse: And the seven years of plenty that came upon the land of Egypt came to an end.

verse.text: And the seven years of famine began to come, as Joseph had said. And there was [xref]a[/xref]famine in all lands, but in all the land of Egypt there was bread.
So when [xref]a[/xref]all the land of Egypt became hungry, the people cried out to Pharaoh for bread. And Pharaoh said to all the Egyptians, Go to Joseph; whatever he says to you, you shall do.

And when the famine was over [note]1[/note]all the face of the earth, Joseph opened [note]2[/note]all the storehouses of grain and [xref]a[/xref]sold grain to the Egyptians; and the famine became severe in the land of Egypt.
verse.note: Food maintains man's existence and also brings man satisfaction. The whole earth being under famine signifies that all the nations are struggling to maintain their existence and are dissatisfied. Food could be found only where Joseph was ([link]42:5-6[/link]), indicating in type that the real life supply and satisfaction can be found only in the church, where Christ is.
Following some ancient versions; the Hebrew text reads, all which was in them.

verse.text: And all the earth came to Joseph in Egypt to [xref]a[/xref]buy grain, because the [xref]b[/xref]famine was severe in all the earth.

chapter.verse: Now when Jacob saw that there was grain in Egypt, Jacob said to his sons, Why do you keep looking at one another?

verse.text: And he said, I have now heard that there is grain in Egypt; [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]go down there, and buy grain for us from there, that we may live and not [xref]b[/xref]die.
verse.note: God used the famine and Jacob's sending of his sons to Egypt to deal with Jacob for his maturity in life. During his long wait for the return of his sons, Jacob was emptied of all his preoccupations ([link]v. 36[/link]; [link]43:13-14[/link]) that God might fill Jacob with the element of the divine life. See note [link]26[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 45[/link].

verse.text: So Joseph's ten [note]1[/note]brothers went down to buy grain from Egypt.
verse.note: The account of the relationship between Joseph and his brothers in [link]chs. 42-45[/link] is a detailed portrait of the relationship between Christ and the nation of Israel: (1) Just as Joseph's brothers were forced to turn to him for food ([link]vv. 1-5[/link]; [link]43:1-15[/link]), the children of Israel will be forced to turn to Christ to preserve their existence ([link]Zech. 12:10[/link]; [link]Rom. 11:26[/link]). (2) Just as Joseph's brothers were ignorant of him ([link]vv. 8[/link], [link]28[/link]; [link]43:32-34[/link]; [link]44:14-34[/link]), so the people of Israel are ignorant of who Christ is today. (3) Just as Joseph tested and disciplined his brothers after they were forced to turn to him ([link]vv. 15-24[/link]; [link]44:1-13[/link]), so Christ will test and discipline Israel when they are in the process of turning to Him ([link]Zech. 13:8-9[/link]). (4) While Joseph was disciplining his brothers, he loved them and cared for them in a secret way ([link]v. 25[/link]; [link]43:16[/link], [link]25-34[/link]); similarly, at the end time Christ will secretly show His love toward Israel and provide for their needs (cf. [link]Rev. 7:2-8[/link]). (5) Just as Joseph eventually acknowledged his ignorant brothers ([link]45:1-4[/link], [link]14-16[/link]), Christ will acknowledge the ignorant nation of Israel ([link]Rom. 11:26[/link]). (6) Just as Joseph's brothers eventually recognized him ([link]45:15[/link]), the Israelites will eventually recognize Christ ([link]Zech. 12:10[/link]). (7) Just as Joseph revealed himself in his exaltation and glory to his brothers ([link]45:1[/link], [link]8[/link], [link]13[/link]), Christ will reveal Himself in His exaltation and glory to the remnant of Israel ([link]Micah 5:3-4[/link]; [link]Matt. 24:30[/link]). (8) Joseph's brothers participated in the enjoyment of his reign, and Joseph took special care of them as God's testimony on earth ([link]45:16-24[/link]; [link]47:11-12[/link]; [link]50:21[/link]); likewise, in the millennium Israel will participate in the enjoyment of Christ's reign, and Christ will care in a special way for Israel as God's testimony among the nations ([link]Isa. 2:2-3[/link]; [link]61:6[/link]; [link]Zech. 8:23[/link]; [link]14:16-19[/link]).

verse.text: But Jacob did not send Joseph's brother [xref]a[/xref]Benjamin with his brothers, for he said, Perhaps [xref]b[/xref]harm may befall him.
And the sons of Israel came to buy grain among [i]the others[/i] who came, for the [xref]a[/xref]famine was in the land of Canaan.

Now Joseph was the governor [xref]a[/xref]over the land; it was he who sold grain to all the people of the land. And Joseph's brothers came and [xref]b[/xref]bowed down to him with [i]their[/i] faces to the ground.

And Joseph saw his brothers and recognized them, but he disguised himself to them and spoke [xref]a[/xref]harshly with them. And he said to them, Where have you come from? And they said, From the land of Canaan, to buy grain for food.

chapter.verse: And Joseph recognized his brothers, but they did not recognize him.

verse.text: And Joseph remembered the [xref]a[/xref]dreams that he had dreamed about them, and he [note]1[/note]said to them, You are [xref]b[/xref]spies; you have come to see the nakedness of the land.
verse.note: The record of Joseph's life is a revelation of the rulership of the Spirit, for the rulership of the Spirit is the reigning aspect of a mature saint. Although he was full of human feelings and sentiments toward his brothers ([link]v. 24[/link]; [link]43:30-31[/link]; [link]45:1-2[/link]), he kept himself with all his feelings under the rulership of the Spirit. He dealt with his brothers soberly, wisely, and with discernment, disciplining them according to their need in order to perfect them and build them up that they might be a collective people living together as God's testimony on earth (cf. [link]45:24[/link]). Joseph denied himself and placed himself absolutely under God's sovereign leading, conducting himself wholly for the interest of God and His people. Joseph's living under God's restriction, a portrait of the human living of Christ ([link]John 5:19[/link], [link]30b[/link]; [link]7:16[/link], [link]18[/link]; [link]14:10[/link]), manifested the maturity and perfection of the divine life and brought in God's kingdom.

chapter.verse: And they said to him, No, my lord; rather your servants have come to buy grain for food.
We are all sons of one man. We are honest men; your servants have never been spies.
And he said to them, No; but you have come to see the nakedness of the land.

verse.text: And they said, We, your servants, are twelve brothers, the sons of one man in the land of Canaan; and at this moment the youngest is with our father today, and one is [xref]a[/xref]no more.

chapter.verse: But Joseph said to them, It is just as I spoke to you, saying, You are spies.

verse.text: By this you shall be tested: As Pharaoh lives, you shall not go away from this place unless your [xref]a[/xref]youngest brother comes here.

chapter.verse: Send one of you to get your brother while you remain bound, that your words may be tested whether there is truth in you. And if not, as Pharaoh lives, surely you are spies.

verse.text: And he put them all together in [note]1[/note]custody three days.
verse.note: This was done to touch their conscience and cause them to realize their guilt in hating Joseph and selling him ([link]vv. 21-22[/link]).

chapter.verse: And Joseph said to them on the third day, Do this and live, [i]for[/i] I fear God.

verse.text: If you are [xref]a[/xref]honest men, let one of your brothers remain bound in your place of custody; and [i]the rest of[/i] you go, carry grain for the famine of your households.

chapter.verse: And bring your youngest brother to me, that your words may be verified; and you will not die. And they did so.

verse.text: And they said one to another, We are indeed [xref]a[/xref]guilty concerning our brother, because we saw the distress of his soul when he pleaded with us, yet we would not listen; therefore this distress has come to us.
And Reuben answered them, saying, Did I not speak to you, saying, Do not [xref]a[/xref]sin against the child? But you would not listen. So now also his [xref]b[/xref]blood is required.

chapter.verse: And they did not know that Joseph understood, for there was an interpreter between them.

verse.text: And he turned away from them and [xref]a[/xref]wept. Then he returned to them and spoke to them. And he took [note]1[/note]Simeon from among them and bound him before their eyes.
verse.note: It might have been Simeon who took the lead in plotting to murder Joseph (cf. [link]49:5-7[/link]).

verse.text: Then Joseph gave orders to [xref]a[/xref]fill their bags with grain and to restore every man's silver pieces to his sack and to give them provisions for the way. And thus was it done for them.

chapter.verse: And they loaded their grain upon their donkeys and departed from there.

verse.text: And one [i]of them[/i] opened his sack to give his donkey fodder at the lodging place, and he saw his silver; there it was in the mouth of his [xref]a[/xref]sack.

chapter.verse: And he said to his brothers, My silver has been returned; and here it is in my sack! And their heart stopped, and they [i]turned[/i] trembling to one another, saying, What is this that God has done to us?
And they came to Jacob their father in the land of Canaan and told him all that had happened to them, saying,

verse.text: The man, the lord of the land, spoke [xref]a[/xref]harshly to us and took us for spies on the land.
But we said to him, We are honest men; we have never been [xref]a[/xref]spies.
We are twelve brothers, sons of our father; the one is [xref]a[/xref]no more, and the youngest is with our father today in the land of Canaan.

And the man, the lord of the land, said to us, By this will I know that you are [xref]a[/xref]honest men: Leave one of your brothers with me, and take [i]grain[/i] for the famine of your households, and go.
And bring your [xref]a[/xref]youngest brother to me that I may know that you are not spies but honest men. I will give you your brother, and you may [xref]b[/xref]trade in the land.
And when they emptied their sacks, there was each man's bundle of silver pieces, in his [xref]a[/xref]sack. And when they and their father saw their bundles of silver, they were afraid.
And Jacob their father said to them, You have [xref]a[/xref]bereaved me of my children: Joseph is no more, and Simeon is no more, and you would take Benjamin; all these things are against me.

chapter.verse: And Reuben spoke to his father, saying, You may put to death my two sons if I do not bring him to you. Put him in my hand, and I will return him to you.

verse.text: But he said, My son shall not go down with you, for his brother is dead, and he alone is left. And if [xref]a[/xref]harm should befall him on the way in which you go, then you will bring down my gray hairs in [xref]b[/xref]sorrow to Sheol.
Now the [xref]a[/xref]famine was severe in the land.
And when they had completely consumed the grain which they had brought out of Egypt, their father said to them, [xref]a[/xref]Go back; buy us a little food.
But Judah spoke to him, saying, The man solemnly warned us, saying, You shall not see my face unless your [xref]a[/xref]brother is with you.

chapter.verse: If you are willing to send our brother with us, we will go down and buy you grain for food;
But if you are not willing to send [i]him,[/i] we will not go down; for the man said to us, You shall not see my face unless your brother is with you.
And Israel said, Why did you treat me so badly as to tell the man that you had another brother?

And they said, The man asked very carefully about us and about our relatives, saying, Is your father still alive? Do you have [i]another[/i] brother? So we told him about these things. Could we possibly know that he would say, Bring your brother down?

verse.text: And Judah said to Israel his father, Send the boy with me, and we will rise up and go, that we may live and not [xref]a[/xref]die, we and you and our little ones.
I myself will be surety for him; of my hand you may require him. If I do not [xref]a[/xref]bring him to you and set him before you, then I shall bear the blame of sinning before you forever.

chapter.verse: For if we had not delayed, by now we could have returned twice.

And their father Israel said to them, If it [i]must be[/i] so, then do this: Take some of the choice fruits of the land in your bags, and carry a present down to the man — a little balm and a little honey, aromatic gum and myrrh, pistachio nuts and almonds.

verse.text: And take double the silver in your hand, and carry back in your hand the silver that was returned in the mouth of your [xref]a[/xref]sacks; perhaps it was a mistake.

chapter.verse: Take your brother also, and rise up; return to the man.

verse.text: And may the [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]All-sufficient God grant you [note]2[/note]mercy before the man, that he may release to you your other brother and Benjamin. And as for me, if I am to be [xref]b[/xref]bereaved of my children, I shall be bereaved.
verse.note: Heb. [i]El Shaddai.[/i] See note [link]1[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 17[/link].

Or, compassion. While he was being dealt with in the last stage for his maturity, Jacob did not struggle but absolutely submitted to God's sovereignty in his circumstances. He no longer trusted in his own skill and ability; rather, he trusted in the mercy of his all-sufficient God. This shows that he had been fully transformed for maturity.

chapter.verse: So the men took this present, and they took double the silver in their hand and Benjamin; and they rose up and went down to Egypt and stood before Joseph.

verse.text: And when Joseph saw Benjamin with them, he said to him who was over his house, Bring the men into the house, and slaughter an [note]1[/note]animal, and prepare [i]it;[/i] for the men will eat with me at noon.
verse.note: Lit., a slaughter.

chapter.verse: And the man did as Joseph said, and the man brought the men into Joseph's house.
