And the men were afraid because they were brought to Joseph's house; and they said, [i]It is[/i] because of the silver that was returned in our sacks the first time, that we are being brought in, that he may come out against us and fall upon us and take us as slaves with our donkeys.
And they came near to the man who was over Joseph's house and spoke to him at the door of the house,

verse.text: And said, Please, my lord, we indeed came down the first time to [xref]a[/xref]buy grain for food;
And when we came to the lodging place, we opened our sacks, and there was each man's silver, in the mouth of his [xref]a[/xref]sack, our silver in full weight. So we have brought it back in our hand.

chapter.verse: And we have also brought down extra silver in our hand to buy grain for food. We do not know who put our silver in our sacks.
And he said, Be at peace; do not fear. Your God and the God of your father has given you treasure in your sacks; your silver came to me. Then he brought Simeon out to them.

verse.text: And the man brought the men into Joseph's house and gave [i]them[/i] water, and they washed their [xref]a[/xref]feet; and he gave their donkeys fodder.
And they prepared the [xref]a[/xref]present for Joseph's coming at noon, for they had heard that they would eat a meal there.
And when Joseph came into the house, they brought him the present which was in their hand into the house and [xref]a[/xref]bowed down to the ground to him.
And he asked them about their welfare and said, Is your [xref]a[/xref]father well, the old man of whom you spoke? Is he still alive?

chapter.verse: And they said, Your servant our father is well; he is still alive. And they bowed and paid [i]him[/i] homage.

verse.text: And he lifted up his eyes and saw his brother [xref]a[/xref]Benjamin, his mother's son, and said, Is this your youngest brother, of whom you spoke to me? And he said, God be gracious to you, my son.
And Joseph hurried — for his [xref]a[/xref]inward parts burned for his brother — and sought [i]a place[/i] to [xref]b[/xref]weep. So he entered into his chamber and wept there.

chapter.verse: Then he washed his face and came out, and he controlled himself and said, Serve the meal.

verse.text: And they served him by himself, and them by themselves, and the Egyptians who ate with him by themselves, because the Egyptians could not eat a meal with the Hebrews, for that is an [xref]a[/xref]abomination to the Egyptians.

chapter.verse: And they sat before him, the firstborn according to his birthright and the youngest according to his youth, and the men looked at one another in astonishment.

verse.text: And he had portions brought to them from before him; however Benjamin's portion was [xref]a[/xref]five times as much as any of theirs. And they drank and were merry with him.
And he commanded him who was over his house, saying, [xref]a[/xref]Fill the men's sacks with food, as much as they can carry, and put each man's silver in the mouth of his sack.

chapter.verse: And put my cup, the silver cup, in the mouth of the sack of the youngest with his silver for the grain. And he did [i]so,[/i] according to the word that Joseph had spoken.
As soon as the morning was light, the men were sent away, they and their donkeys.

verse.text: When they had [i]just[/i] gone out of the city [i]and[/i] were not yet far off, Joseph said to [xref]a[/xref]him who was over his house, Rise up, follow after the men; and when you overtake them, say to them, Why have you repaid evil for good?

chapter.verse: Is not this that from which my lord drinks, and which he indeed uses for divining? You have done wrong in so doing.
And he overtook them and spoke these words to them.
And they said to him, Why does my lord speak such words as these? Far be it from your servants to do such a thing.

verse.text: See [i]how[/i] we brought back to you from the land of Canaan the silver which we found in the mouth of our [xref]a[/xref]sacks. How then could we steal silver or gold out of your lord's house?
With [xref]a[/xref]whomever of your servants it is found, let him die; and we ourselves will become my lord's slaves.

chapter.verse: And he said, Now also let it be according to your words: He with whom it is found will be my slave, and [i]the rest of[/i] you will be blameless.
Then each man hurried and lowered his sack to the ground, and each man opened his sack.
And he searched, beginning with the oldest and ending with the youngest; and the cup was found in Benjamin's sack.
Then they tore their garments, and each man loaded his donkey, and they returned to the city.

verse.text: And [xref]a[/xref]Judah and his brothers came to Joseph's house, and he was still there; and they [xref]b[/xref]fell to the ground before him.

chapter.verse: And Joseph said to them, What deed is this that you have done? Do you not know that such a man as I can indeed divine?

verse.text: And Judah said, What can we say to my lord? What can we speak? And how can we justify ourselves? God has found out the [xref]a[/xref]iniquity of your servants. Here we are, my lord's slaves, both we and the one in whose hand the cup has been found.
But he said, Far be it from me to do this. The man in whose hand the cup has been [xref]a[/xref]found, he will be my slave; but as for [i]the rest of[/i] you, go up in peace to your father.

chapter.verse: Then Judah came near to him and said, Please, my lord, let your servant speak a word in my lord's ears, and let not your anger burn against your servant; for you are even as Pharaoh.
My lord asked his servants, saying, Do you have a father or a brother?

verse.text: And we said to my lord, We have an old father and a young child of his [xref]a[/xref]old age; and his brother is dead, and he alone is left of his mother, and his father loves him.
And you said to your servants, [xref]a[/xref]Bring him down to me, that I may set my eyes on him.
And we said to my lord, The boy cannot leave his father; for if he should leave his father, [i]his father[/i] would [xref]a[/xref]die.
And you said to your servants, Unless your [xref]a[/xref]youngest brother comes down with you, you shall see my face no more.

chapter.verse: And when we went up to your servant my father, we told him my lord's words.

verse.text: And our father said, Return, [xref]a[/xref]buy us a little food.

chapter.verse: But we said, We cannot go down. If our youngest brother is with us, we will go down; for we cannot see the man's face unless our youngest brother is with us.

verse.text: And your servant my father said to us, You know that my wife bore me two [xref]a[/xref]sons;
And the one went away from me, and I said, Surely he has been [xref]a[/xref]torn to pieces; and I have not seen him to this day.
And if you take this one also from me and harm befalls him, you will bring down my gray hairs in misery to [xref]a[/xref]Sheol.

chapter.verse: Now therefore when I come to your servant my father, and the boy is not with us, then, his life being bound up in the boy's life,
When he sees that the boy is not [i]with us,[/i] he will die; and your servants will bring down the gray hairs of your servant our father in sorrow to Sheol.

verse.text: For your servant became [xref]a[/xref]surety for the lad to my father, saying, If I do not bring him to you, then I shall bear the blame of sinning before my father forever.

chapter.verse: Now therefore, please let your servant remain as a slave to my lord instead of the boy, and let the boy go up with his brothers.
For how shall I go up to my father if the boy is not with me? I fear to see the evil that would come on my father.

verse.text: Then [note]1[/note]Joseph could not [xref]a[/xref]control himself before all those who attended him; and he cried out, Have everyone go out from me. So there was no one standing with him when Joseph made himself [xref]b[/xref]known to his brothers.
verse.note: When Joseph's brothers sold him, they hated him and did not care for their father or their younger brother. The attitude and spirit with which Judah spoke to Joseph about his father and brother ([link]44:18-34[/link]) convinced Joseph that Judah had been subdued and broken. This was the right time for Joseph to reveal himself to his brothers.

chapter.verse: And he wept so loudly that the Egyptians heard [i]it,[/i] and the household of Pharaoh heard [i]it.[/i]
And Joseph said to his brothers, I am Joseph! Is my father still alive? But his brothers could not answer him, so troubled were they at his presence.

verse.text: And Joseph said to his brothers, Please come closer to me. And they came closer. And he said, I am your brother Joseph, whom you [xref]a[/xref]sold into Egypt.
And now do not be [note]1[/note]grieved or angry with yourselves because you sold me here, for God [xref]a[/xref]sent me before you to [xref]b[/xref]preserve life.
verse.note: Joseph did not need to forgive his brothers, because he did not blame them (cf. note [link]28[sup]1[/sup][/link]). He received as from God all that his brothers had done to him, and he comforted those who had offended him ([link]vv. 5-8[/link]; [link]50:15-21[/link]). What grace, and what an excellent spirit, he had!

chapter.verse: For the famine has been in the midst of the land these two years, and there are still five years in which there will be neither plowing nor harvest.

verse.text: And God sent me before you to preserve for you a [note]1[/note]remnant in the earth and to keep you alive by a great deliverance.
verse.note: God's intention was that the descendants of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob would build Him a tabernacle ([link]Exo. 25-30[/link], [link]35-40[/link]) so that He might establish His kingdom on earth. God sent Joseph to Egypt to preserve life so that a remnant of the chosen and called race might remain for the fulfillment of His purpose.

verse.text: So now it was not you who sent me here, but God; and He has made me a father to Pharaoh and lord of all his house and ruler [xref]a[/xref]over all the land of Egypt.
Hurry and go up to my father, and say to him, Thus says your son Joseph, God has made me lord of all Egypt; [xref]a[/xref]come down to me; do not delay.

chapter.verse: And you shall dwell in the land of Goshen and be near to me, you and your children and your children's children and your flocks and your herds and all that you have.

verse.text: And there I will [xref]a[/xref]sustain you — for there are still five years of famine [i]to come[/i] — so that you and your household and all that you have do not become impoverished.

chapter.verse: And now your eyes see, and the eyes of my brother Benjamin see, that it is my own mouth that speaks to you.
And you must tell my father of all my glory in Egypt and of all that you have seen, and you must hurry and bring my father down here.

verse.text: And he [xref]a[/xref]fell upon his brother Benjamin's neck and wept, and Benjamin [xref]b[/xref]wept upon his neck.

chapter.verse: And he kissed all his brothers and wept upon them, and after that his brothers talked with him.

verse.text: And when the report was heard in [xref]a[/xref]Pharaoh's house, saying, Joseph's brothers have come, it was pleasing to Pharaoh and to his servants.

chapter.verse: And Pharaoh said to Joseph, Say to your brothers, Do this: Load your beasts, and depart; go to the land of Canaan;

verse.text: And take your father and your households, and come to me. And I will give you the best of the land of Egypt, and you will eat the [xref]a[/xref]fat of the land.
And you are commanded, Do this: Take [xref]a[/xref]wagons out of the land of Egypt for your little ones and for your wives; and bring your father, and come.

chapter.verse: And do not be concerned for your possessions, for the best of all the land of Egypt is yours.
And the sons of Israel did so, and Joseph gave them wagons according to the command of Pharaoh and gave them provisions for the way.

verse.text: To each of them he gave changes of garments; but to Benjamin he gave three hundred [i]pieces[/i] of silver and [xref]a[/xref]five changes of garments.

chapter.verse: And he sent to his father the following: ten donkeys loaded with the best of Egypt, and ten female donkeys loaded with grain, and bread and provision for his father on the way.
So he sent his brothers away; and as they departed, he said to them, Do not quarrel on the way.
So they went up out of Egypt and came to the land of Canaan to Jacob their father.

verse.text: And they told him, saying, Joseph is still alive, and he is ruler [xref]a[/xref]over all the land of Egypt. And his heart grew [note]1[/note]numb, for he did not believe them.
verse.note: When Jacob received the good news regarding Joseph, his heart grew numb, but his spirit revived ([link]v. 27[/link]), indicating that his soul and spirit had been divided ([link]Heb. 4:12[/link]). This was a manifestation of Jacob's maturity in life.

verse.text: And they told him all the words of Joseph, which he had said to them; and when he saw the [xref]a[/xref]wagons which Joseph had sent to carry him, the [xref]b[/xref]spirit of Jacob their father revived.
And Israel said, [note]1[/note]It is enough. Joseph my son is still alive. I will go and see him before I die.
verse.note: Upon hearing that Joseph was alive, Jacob did not blame anyone regarding the loss of Joseph. This is a sign that he not only had been transformed but also was mature, completely filled with the fullness of the divine life.

verse.text: So Israel set out with all that he had and came to Beer-sheba and [note]1[/note]offered sacrifices to the God of his father Isaac.
verse.note: As one who was mature in life, Jacob had fellowship with God by offering sacrifices to Him. Jacob's way of offering signifies the worship of God with the worship that He seeks by offering Christ to God for His satisfaction (cf. [link]John 4:24[/link]).

verse.text: And God spoke to Israel in the [xref]a[/xref]visions of the night and said, Jacob, Jacob. And he said, Here I am.
And He said, I am [note]1[/note]God, the God of your [xref]a[/xref]father; do not be afraid to go down to Egypt, for I will make of you a [xref]b[/xref]great nation there.
verse.note: Heb. [i]El.[/i]

verse.text: I Myself will [xref]a[/xref]go down with you to Egypt, and I Myself will also surely bring you up again; and Joseph's hand will close your eyes.
And Jacob rose up from Beer-sheba, and the sons of Israel carried Jacob their father and their little ones and their wives in the [xref]a[/xref]wagons which Pharaoh had sent to carry him.
And they took their livestock and their possessions, which they had acquired in the land of Canaan, and [xref]a[/xref]Jacob and all his offspring with him came to Egypt.

chapter.verse: His sons and his grandsons with him, his daughters and his granddaughters, and all his offspring he brought with him to Egypt.

verse.text: And these are the [xref]a[/xref]names of the children of Israel, who came to Egypt, Jacob and his sons: Jacob's firstborn, Reuben.
And the sons of [xref]a[/xref]Reuben: Hanoch and Pallu and Hezron and Carmi.
And the sons of [xref]a[/xref]Simeon: Jemuel and Jamin and Ohad and Jachin and Zohar and Shaul the son of a Canaanite woman.
And the sons of [xref]a[/xref]Levi: Gershon, Kohath, and Merari.
And the sons of [xref]a[/xref]Judah: Er and Onan and Shelah and Perez and Zerah; but Er and Onan died in the land of Canaan. And the sons of Perez were Hezron and Hamul.
And the sons of [xref]a[/xref]Issachar: Tola and Puvah and Iob and Shimron.
And the sons of [xref]a[/xref]Zebulun: Sered and Elon and Jahleel.
These are the sons of Leah, whom she bore to Jacob in Paddan-aram, along with his daughter [xref]a[/xref]Dinah. His sons and his daughters were thirty-three [note]1[/note]persons in all.
verse.note: Lit., souls. So also throughout the chapter.

verse.text: And the sons of [xref]a[/xref]Gad: Ziphion and Haggi, Shuni and Ezbon, Eri and Arodi and Areli.
And the sons of [xref]a[/xref]Asher: Imnah and Ishvah and Ishvi and Beriah, and Serah their sister; and the sons of Beriah: Heber and Malchiel.

chapter.verse: These are the sons of Zilpah, whom Laban gave to his daughter Leah; and she bore these to Jacob, sixteen persons.
The sons of Rachel, Jacob's wife: Joseph and Benjamin.

verse.text: And to [xref]a[/xref]Joseph in the land of Egypt were born Manasseh and Ephraim, whom Asenath the daughter of Potiphera priest of On bore to him.
And the sons of [xref]a[/xref]Benjamin: Bela and Becher and Ashbel, Gera and Naaman, Ehi and Rosh, Muppim and Huppim and Ard.

chapter.verse: These are the sons of Rachel, who were born to Jacob, fourteen persons in all.

verse.text: And the sons of [xref]a[/xref]Dan: Hushim.
And the sons of [xref]a[/xref]Naphtali: Jahzeel and Guni and Jezer and Shillem.

chapter.verse: These are the sons of Bilhah, whom Laban gave to Rachel his daughter, and she bore these to Jacob, seven persons in all.
All the persons who came with Jacob into Egypt, who came out of his loins, besides the wives of Jacob's sons, were sixty-six persons in all.

verse.text: And the sons of Joseph, who were born to him in Egypt, were two persons. All the persons of the house of Jacob, who came to Egypt, were [xref]a[/xref]seventy.

chapter.verse: And he sent Judah before him to Joseph to show the way before him to Goshen, and they came to the land of Goshen.

verse.text: And Joseph made his chariot ready and went up to Goshen to meet Israel his father. And when he appeared before him, he fell on his [xref]a[/xref]neck and wept on his neck a good while.
And Israel said to Joseph, Let me die now since I have [xref]a[/xref]seen your face [i]and know[/i] that you are still alive.

And Joseph said to his brothers and to his father's household, I will go up and [xref]a[/xref]tell Pharaoh, and will say to him, My brothers and my father's household, who were in the land of Canaan, have come to me.
And the men are [xref]a[/xref]shepherds, for they have been keepers of livestock; and they have brought their flocks and their herds and all that they have.

chapter.verse: And when Pharaoh calls you and says, What is your occupation?

verse.text: You shall say, Your servants have been keepers of livestock from our youth even until now, both we and our fathers; that you may dwell in the land of Goshen, for every shepherd is an [xref]a[/xref]abomination to the Egyptians.

Then Joseph went in and [xref]a[/xref]told Pharaoh and said, My father and my brothers and their flocks and their herds and all that they have, have come out of the land of Canaan; and now they are in the land of Goshen.

chapter.verse: And he took five men from among his brothers and presented them to Pharaoh.

verse.text: And Pharaoh said to his brothers, [xref]a[/xref]What is your occupation? And they said to Pharaoh, Your servants are [xref]b[/xref]shepherds, both we and our fathers.

And they said to Pharaoh, We have come to [xref]a[/xref]sojourn in the land because there is no pasture for your servants' flocks, for the famine is severe in the land of Canaan. Now therefore, please let your servants dwell in the land of Goshen.

chapter.verse: And Pharaoh spoke to Joseph, saying, Your father and your brothers have come to you.

verse.text: The land of Egypt is before you; settle your father and your brothers in the [xref]a[/xref]best of the land; let them dwell in the land of Goshen. And if you know any capable men among them, make them overseers over my livestock.
And Joseph brought in Jacob his father and set him before Pharaoh, and Jacob [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]blessed Pharaoh.
verse.note: The strongest manifestation of Jacob's maturity in life is the fact that Jacob blessed everyone, including Pharaoh ([link]vv. 7[/link], [link]10[/link]), Jacob's two grandsons ([link]ch. 48[/link]), and his own twelve sons ([link]49:1-28[/link]). Jacob's supplanting hands became blessing hands ([link]48:14-16[/link]). Maturity in life is a matter of being filled with God as life, and blessing is the overflow of life, the overflow of God through the maturity in life. To bless others is to bring them into the presence of God and to bring God into them as grace, love, and fellowship that they may enjoy the Triune God — the Father, the Son, and the Spirit ([link]14:18-19[/link]; [link]Num. 6:23-27[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 13:14[/link]). That Jacob blessed Pharaoh indicates that he was greater than Pharaoh ([link]Heb. 7:7[/link]).

verse.text: And Pharaoh said to Jacob, How many are the [note]1[/note]years of your life?
verse.note: Lit., the days of the years. So also in [link]v. 9[/link].

verse.text: And Jacob said to Pharaoh, The years of my [xref]a[/xref]sojourning are one hundred thirty years; [xref]b[/xref]few and evil have been the [xref]c[/xref]years of my life, and they have not attained to the years of the lives of my fathers during the days of their sojourning.

chapter.verse: And Jacob blessed Pharaoh and went forth from Pharaoh's presence.
And Joseph settled his father and his brothers and gave them a possession in the land of Egypt, in the best of the land, in the land of Rameses, as Pharaoh had commanded.

verse.text: And Joseph [xref]a[/xref]sustained his father and his brothers and all his father's household with food according to [i]the number of[/i] their little ones.

chapter.verse: And there was no food in all the land, for the famine was so very severe that the land of Egypt and the land of Canaan languished because of the famine.

verse.text: And Joseph [note]1[/note]collected all the money that was to be found in the land of Egypt and in the land of Canaan for the grain which they [xref]a[/xref]bought, and Joseph brought the money into Pharaoh's house.
verse.note: Lit., gleaned. Because Joseph suffered and denied himself, he gained the riches of the life supply. In Egypt all the food was in the hand of Joseph. In order to receive food from Joseph, the people had to pay four kinds of prices: their money, their livestock, their land, and themselves ([link]vv. 14-23[/link]). Money represents convenience, livestock signifies the means of living, and land represents resources. If we would receive the life supply from the Lord, we must give Him our convenience, our means of livelihood, and our resources. The more we give Him, the more life supply we will receive from Him. Ultimately, in order to receive the best portion from the Lord, including food for satisfaction and seed for reproduction ([link]v. 23[/link]), we must hand ourselves, every part of our being, over to Him.[br][br]Eventually, there was only one landlord in Egypt, and all the people became enjoyers on the same level. This is a prefigure of the millennium, in which the earth and all its fullness will belong to Christ ([link]Psa. 2:8[/link]; [link]24:1[/link]; [link]Dan. 7:13-14[/link]) and all the nations on the earth will enjoy Christ's riches.

chapter.verse: And when the money from the land of Egypt and from the land of Canaan had been spent, all the Egyptians came to Joseph saying, Give us food, for why should we die in your presence? For [i]our[/i] money is gone.
And Joseph said, Bring your livestock, and I will give you [i]food[/i] in exchange for your livestock, if [i]your[/i] money is gone.

verse.text: And they brought their livestock to Joseph, and Joseph gave them food in exchange for the horses and for the flocks of sheep and for the herds of cattle and for the donkeys; and he [note]1[/note]fed them with food in exchange for all their livestock that year.
verse.note: Lit., guided (as a shepherd).

chapter.verse: And when that year had ended, they came to him the second year and said to him, We cannot hide from my lord that our money has been spent, and the herds of cattle are my lord's. There is nothing left in the sight of my lord except our bodies and our lands.

Why should we die before your eyes, both we and our land? Buy us and our land in exchange for food, and we and our land will become servants to Pharaoh. And give us seed that we may live and not die, and that the land may not be desolate.
So Joseph bought all the land of Egypt for Pharaoh; for every Egyptian sold his field, because the famine was severe upon them; and the land became Pharaoh's.
And as for the people, he removed them to the cities from one end of the border of Egypt even to the other end.
Only the land of the priests he did not buy, for the priests had an assigned portion from Pharaoh, and they lived off their portion which Pharaoh gave them; therefore they did not sell their land.
Then Joseph said to the people, Now that I have this day bought you and your land for Pharaoh, here is seed for you that you may sow the land.

verse.text: And when harvest comes, you shall give a [xref]a[/xref]fifth to Pharaoh, and four-fifths shall be your own as seed of the field and as food for you and for those of your households and as food for your little ones.

chapter.verse: And they said, You have saved our lives. May we find favor in the sight of my lord and be Pharaoh's servants.

verse.text: And Joseph made it a statute concerning the land of Egypt [i]that stands[/i] to this day, that Pharaoh should have the fifth; [xref]a[/xref]only the land of the priests alone did not become Pharaoh's.
And Israel dwelt in the land of Egypt, in the land of [xref]a[/xref]Goshen; and they acquired possessions in it and were fruitful and multiplied exceedingly.
And Jacob lived in the land of Egypt seventeen years. Thus the days of Jacob, the [xref]a[/xref]years of his life, were one hundred forty-seven years.

And the time for Israel to die drew near. And he called his son Joseph and said to him, If now I have found favor in your sight, please put your hand under my [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]thigh and deal with me in kindness and truth. Please do not bury me in Egypt;
verse.note: To put the hand under the thigh means to swear. In [link]32:25[/link] God touched Jacob's thigh (see note 2 there). After that experience, Jacob could still walk, albeit with a limp ([link]32:31[/link]). However, as he was departing this life, Jacob could no longer do anything for himself; he could only lie on his bed. His natural strength having been fully terminated, he could trust only in God's grace, represented here by Joseph, a type of Christ. It was not by Jacob's strength but by the hand of Joseph that Jacob was finally brought to the good land for his actual inheritance ([link]50:5-13[/link]). Likewise, it is not by our strength but by the grace of Christ that we inherit God's promise (cf. [link]2 Cor. 12:9[/link]).

verse.text: But when I [note]1[/note]lie down with my [xref]a[/xref]fathers, you shall carry me out of Egypt, and bury me in their burial place. And he said, I will do as you have said.
verse.note: Jacob viewed his death as lying down to sleep, indicating that he believed in resurrection ([link]1 Thes. 4:13-16[/link]). He charged Joseph not to bury him in Egypt ([link]v. 29[/link]) but in the good land, in the cave of Machpelah, where his fathers had been buried ([link]49:29-32[/link]), indicating that he died in faith, believing that on the day of resurrection he would rise up to inherit the good land according to God's promise ([link]28:13[/link]; [link]35:12[/link]).

verse.text: And he said, Swear to me; and he swore to him. Then Israel [xref]a[/xref]bowed himself [note]1[/note]at the head of his [xref]b[/xref]bed.
verse.note: The Septuagint translates this phrase [i]on the top of his staff[/i] (cf. [link]Heb. 11:21[/link]). See note [link]21[sup]1[/sup] in Heb. 11[/link].

chapter.verse: Now after these things Joseph was told, Your father is sick. So he took with him his two sons, Manasseh and Ephraim.
And someone told Jacob and said, Your son Joseph is coming to you. So Israel strengthened himself and sat up on his bed.

verse.text: And Jacob said to Joseph, The [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]All-sufficient God appeared to me at [xref]b[/xref]Luz in the land of Canaan and blessed me.
verse.note: Heb. [i]El Shaddai.[/i] See note [link]1[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 17[/link].

verse.text: And He said to me, Behold, I am going to make you [xref]a[/xref]fruitful and multiply you, and I will make of you a company of peoples and will [xref]b[/xref]give this land to your seed after you for an everlasting possession.
And now your two sons, who were born to you in the land of Egypt before I came to you in Egypt, are [note]1[/note]mine; [xref]a[/xref]Ephraim and Manasseh will be mine, as Reuben and Simeon are.
verse.note: Jacob made the two sons of Joseph, who was born of Rachel, his first two sons to replace Reuben and Simeon, who were born of Leah. In blessing Ephraim and Manasseh, Jacob gave Joseph a double portion of the land ([link]Josh. 16-17[/link]). Thus, the birthright among Jacob's sons was shifted from Reuben to Joseph through Jacob's desire to remember Rachel ([link]v. 7[/link]). God honored what Jacob did and made it a fact by the allotting of the land at the time the children of Israel entered the good land. See note [link]2[sup]3[/sup] in Matt. 1[/link].[br][br]In Genesis there are four cases of the shifting of the birthright. The shifting of the birthright from Esau to Jacob ([link]25:22-26[/link], [link]29-34[/link]) reveals that receiving the birthright does not depend on our natural birth but on God's predestination ([link]Rom. 9:10-13[/link]). The shifting of the birthright from Zarah to Pharez ([link]38:27-30[/link]) illustrates the fact that the granting of the birthright does not depend on man's doing but on God's choosing. The shifting of the birthright from Reuben to Joseph ([link]49:3-4[/link]; [link]1 Chron. 5:1-2[/link]) reveals that, although we may be predestinated to have the birthright, we can lose it by indulging in fornication. The shifting of the birthright from Manasseh to Ephraim ([link]vv. 12-20[/link]) shows that the Lord's blessing does not depend on man's natural maneuvering but on God's desire and selection. The last case of the shifting of the birthright in the Scriptures is the shifting of the birthright from Israel to the church (see note [link]31[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 21[/link]).

chapter.verse: And your offspring whom you beget after them will be yours; they will be called by the name of their brothers in their inheritance.

verse.text: And as for me, when I came from Paddan, Rachel [xref]a[/xref]died [note]1[/note]to my sorrow in the land of Canaan on the way, while there was still some distance to go to Ephrath; and I buried her there on the way to Ephrath (that is, Bethlehem).
verse.note: Or, by me.

chapter.verse: And when Israel saw Joseph's sons, he said, Who are these?

verse.text: And Joseph said to his father, They are my sons, whom God has [xref]a[/xref]given to me here. And he said, Bring them to me, please, that I may [xref]b[/xref]bless them.
Now the eyes of Israel were [xref]a[/xref]dim with age, and he could not see. So [note]1[/note]Joseph brought them near to him, and he kissed them and embraced them.
verse.note: Lit., he.

chapter.verse: And Israel said to Joseph, I never expected to see your face, and now God has let me see your seed also.
And Joseph brought them out from between his knees and bowed himself with his face to the ground.
And Joseph took them both, Ephraim in his right hand toward Israel's left hand and Manasseh in his left hand toward Israel's right hand, and brought them near to him.

verse.text: But [xref]a[/xref]Israel stretched out his right hand and laid [i]it[/i] upon Ephraim's head — although he was the younger — and his left hand upon Manasseh's head, [note]1[/note]guiding his hands with insight, even though Manasseh was the firstborn.
verse.note: Or, crossing his hands. Jacob's father, Isaac, blessed blindly ([link]27:1[/link], [link]23[/link], [link]27[/link]), but Jacob's blessing of his two grandsons was full of insight. Although his physical eyes were dim ([link]v. 10[/link]), because Jacob was mature and was one with God in life, he was clear in his spirit that God's will was to establish Ephraim above Manasseh ([link]vv. 17-20[/link]).

verse.text: And he blessed Joseph and said, / The [note]1[/note]God before whom my fathers Abraham and Isaac walked, / The God who has [xref]a[/xref]shepherded me [note]2[/note]all my life to this day,
verse.note: Jacob's threefold mentioning of God in [link]vv. 15-16[/link] is a reference to the Triune God. The God before whom Abraham and Isaac walked is the Father; the God who shepherded Jacob his whole life is the Spirit; and the Angel who redeemed him from all evil is the Son. This is the Triune God in Jacob's experience. See note [link]14[sup]1[/sup] in 2 Cor. 13[/link].
Lit., from since I was, to this day.

verse.text: The [xref]a[/xref]Angel who has [xref]b[/xref]redeemed me from all evil, bless the boys; / And may my name be named on them, and the name of my fathers Abraham and Isaac; / And may they be a teeming [xref]c[/xref]multitude in the midst of the earth.

And when Joseph saw that his father laid his [xref]a[/xref]right hand upon the head of Ephraim, it displeased him; and he took hold of his father's hand to remove it from Ephraim's head onto Manasseh's head.

chapter.verse: And Joseph said to his father, Not so, my father, for this is the firstborn. Put your right hand upon his head.

verse.text: But his father refused and said, I know, my son, I know. He also will become a people, and he also will be great. However, his younger brother will be greater than he, and his seed will become a [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]multitude of nations.
verse.note: Or, fullness; plethora.

chapter.verse: And he blessed them that day, saying,[br/]By you Israel will pronounce blessings, saying, / God make you like Ephraim and like Manasseh.[br/]Thus he set Ephraim before Manasseh.

verse.text: And Israel said to Joseph, Now I am about to die, but God will be [xref]a[/xref]with you and will bring you again to the land of your fathers.
Moreover I have [xref]a[/xref]given to you one [note]1[/note]portion more than your brothers, which I took out of the hand of the Amorite with my sword and with my bow.
verse.note: Or, mountain slope.

verse.text: And Jacob called to his sons and said, Gather yourselves together that I may [note]1[/note]tell you what will happen to you in the [xref]a[/xref]last days.
verse.note: Jacob's prophesying with blessing ([link]v. 28[/link]) concerning his twelve sons is a further manifestation of his maturity in the divine life. As a God-constituted person, Jacob was saturated with God; thus, his speaking was God's speaking and his word was God's word (cf. [link]1 Cor. 7:25[/link], [link]40[/link] and notes).[br][br]Jacob's twelve sons eventually became the twelve tribes of the house of Israel, a type of the church as God's house, composed of all the believers ([link]1 Tim. 3:15[/link]; [link]Heb. 3:5-6[/link]). Thus, whatever was spoken prophetically by Jacob concerning his sons was a type, a picture, of the church and should be applied to the church and to the spiritual experience of the believers, as well as to the sons of Israel (cf. [link]1 Cor. 10:6[/link]).

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Assemble yourselves, and listen, O sons of Jacob; / Yes, listen to Israel your father.
[xref]a[/xref]Reuben, you are my firstborn, / My might and the [xref]b[/xref]firstfruits of my vigor, / Preeminent in dignity and preeminent in power.
Ebullient as water, you will [note]1[/note]not have the preeminence, / Because you went up to your father's [xref]a[/xref]bed; / Then you defiled [i]it[/i] — he went up to my couch.
verse.note: Although Reuben had the preeminence of the birthright, because of his defilement he lost the birthright (cf. [link]Eph. 5:5[/link]; see note [link]2[sup]3[/sup] in Matt. 1[/link]) and became in danger of dying or of being greatly decreased ([link]Deut. 33:6[/link]). This should be a solemn warning to us.

verse.text: [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Simeon and Levi are brothers; / Weapons of violence are their swords.
verse.note: Because of their cruelty ([link]34:25-30[/link]) Simeon and Levi received no blessing from Jacob. Rather, Jacob exercised judgment over them to scatter them among the children of Israel ([link]v. 7[/link]) so that they would not be able to behave cruelly according to their disposition ([link]Josh. 19:1[/link], [link]9[/link]; [link]21:1-3[/link], [link]41[/link]). Later, Levi used his disposition in a renewed, transformed way to slay the worshippers of the golden calf ([link]Exo. 32:26-28[/link]). Because of his absoluteness, desperation, and faithfulness toward God, Levi received the blessing of the priesthood with God's Urim and Thummim ([link]Deut. 33:8-9[/link]).

verse.text: Come not into their council, O my soul; / Be not united with their assembly, O my [xref]a[/xref]glory; / For in their anger they slew men, / And in their self-will they hamstrung oxen.
[note]1[/note]Cursed be their anger, for it is fierce; / And their wrath, for it is cruel: / I will [xref]a[/xref]divide them in Jacob, / And scatter them in Israel.
verse.note: Cf. note [link]8[sup]1[/sup] in Num. 35[/link].

verse.text: [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Judah, your brothers will praise you; / Your hand will be on the neck of your enemies; / Your father's [xref]b[/xref]sons will bow down before you.
verse.note: [link]Verses 8-12[/link] contain three wonderful seeds of the three main truths in the New Testament regarding Christ, which are the contents of the gospel: the seed of Christ's victory ([link]vv. 8-9[/link]), the seed of Christ's kingdom ([link]v. 10[/link]), and the seed of the rest in the enjoyment of the riches of Christ's life ([link]vv. 11-12[/link]). These three truths are a summary of the New Testament.

verse.text: Judah is a [xref]a[/xref]young [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]lion; / From the prey, my son, you have gone [note]2[/note]up. / He [note]2[/note]couches, he stretches out like a lion, / And like a [note]3[/note]lioness; [note]4[/note]who will rouse him up?
verse.note: Judah, likened poetically to a young lion here, is a type of Christ as the ultimate Overcomer, the fighting, victorious Lion ([link]Rev. 5:5[/link] and note 1).

The young lion in his freshness and strength is for fighting, for seizing the prey. When a lion goes after some prey, he descends from his dwelling place on the mountain, and after he takes the prey, he brings it up the mountain with him to devour it. After enjoying the prey, the lion couches, i.e., lies down, to rest in satisfaction. This is a picture of the victory of Christ over His enemies in His crucifixion ([link]Col. 2:15[/link]; [link]Heb. 2:14[/link]) and of His satisfaction and rest in His ascension as the issue of His victory ([link]Eph. 4:8[/link] and notes).
A lioness, a female lion, is for producing baby lions. Christ is not only the fighting lion and the resting lion but also the producing lioness, who brought forth many overcomers as His "lion cubs."

That no one dares to rouse Judah up signifies that Christ's terrifying power in His resurrection and ascension has subdued everything ([link]Matt. 28:18[/link]; [link]Phil. 2:9[/link]; [link]Eph. 1:21-22[/link]).

verse.text: The [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]scepter will not depart from Judah, / Nor the ruler's staff from [note]2[/note]between his feet, / Until [note]3[/note]Shiloh [xref]b[/xref]comes, / And to Him shall be the obedience of the [note]4[/note]peoples.
verse.note: Christ's victory brings in the kingdom. The scepter, a symbol of the kingdom ([link]Psa. 45:6[/link]), denotes the kingly authority of Christ. That the scepter will never depart from Judah means that the kingship will never depart from Christ ([link]2 Sam. 7:12-13[/link]; [link]Dan. 2:44-45[/link]; [link]7:13-14[/link]; [link]Rev. 11:15[/link]; [link]22:1[/link], [link]3[/link]).

[i]Between his feet[/i] is a poetic term denoting seed or posterity. This means that kings will always be produced from Judah's descendants ([link]1 Chron. 5:2[/link]). Christ, the King in God's kingdom, is a descendant of Judah ([link]Heb. 7:14[/link]).
Meaning [i]peace bringer;[/i] referring to Christ in His second coming as the Prince of Peace, who will bring peace to the whole earth ([link]Isa. 9:6-7[/link]; [link]2:4[/link]).
Equivalent to the nations, who will submit to Christ and obey Him at His second coming ([link]Isa. 2:1-3[/link]; [link]11:10[/link]).

verse.text: Binding his [note]1[/note]foal to the vine, / And his donkey's colt to the choice vine, / He washes his [note]2[/note]garment in wine, / And his robe in the blood of grapes.
verse.note: A foal or a donkey is an animal used for transportation (cf. [link]Matt. 21:5[/link]). To tie a donkey indicates that the journey is over and the destination has been reached. The vine in this verse typifies the living Christ, who is full of life ([link]John 15:1[/link], [link]5[/link]). To tie our donkey to the vine signifies to cease from our labor and our striving in our natural life and to rest in Christ, the living One who is the source of life (cf. [link]Matt. 11:28-30[/link]). Because Christ has won the victory and has gained the kingdom, He has become the rich vine to us for our enjoyment, rest, and satisfaction.

Garments signify our behavior in our daily living, and wine signifies life ([link]John 2:3[/link]). Hence, to wash our garments in wine and our robe in the blood of grapes signifies to soak our behavior, our daily walk, in the enjoyment of the riches of Christ's life ([link]Matt. 9:17[/link] and note 1).

verse.text: [note]1[/note]Dark are his eyes with wine, / And white are his teeth with milk.
verse.note: Or, Red. The eyes being red with wine and the teeth being white with milk signifies transformation from death to life by the enjoyment of the rich life of Christ. The teeth function to receive food into the mouth and to help the utterance in speaking. Spiritually, the whiteness of the teeth here indicates the sound, healthy function to take in God's Word as food and to utter His word so that others may be nourished.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Zebulun will dwell at the shore of the sea, / And he will be a shore for [note]1[/note]ships, / And his flank will be toward [note]2[/note][xref]b[/xref]Sidon.
verse.note: The prophecy concerning Judah portrays the contents of the gospel (see note [link]8[sup]1[/sup][/link]). Jacob's prophecy concerning Zebulun is a picture of the preaching of the gospel. Zebulun was part of Galilee, the place where the Lord Jesus began His ministry of the preaching of the gospel of the kingdom ([link]Matt. 4:12-23[/link]; [link]28:7[/link], [link]10[/link], [link]16-20[/link]). It was a shore for ships, a seaport. In ancient times the ships sailed from the seaport with their cargoes by the power of the wind. This portrays the sending out of the glad tidings of the gospel by the Galilean preachers under the power of the Holy Spirit as the heavenly wind ([link]Acts 1:8[/link]; [link]2:2-41[/link]). See note [link]27[sup]3[/sup] in Psa. 68[/link].
The mentioning of Sidon, a Gentile seaport, indicates that the gospel would reach the Gentile world and spread to the uttermost part of the earth ([link]Acts 1:8[/link]; [link]13:46-47[/link]).

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Issachar is a strong donkey, / [note]1[/note]Couching between the [xref]b[/xref]sheepfolds.
verse.note: The strong donkey signifies the natural man; to couch is to rest in satisfaction; and the sheepfolds signify the denominations and various religions based on the law (cf. [link]John 10:1-9[/link], [link]16[/link] and notes). The poetry in this verse portrays the genuine church life as the issue of the preaching of the gospel, in which our natural man rests in satisfaction between (outside) the religious sheepfolds.[br][br]In Moses' blessing in [link]Deut. 33:18b[/link], Issachar was to rejoice for his tents. There the tents signify the local churches as the expressions of the unique Body of Christ ([link]Eph. 4:4a[/link]), in which the believers rejoice in the enjoyment of Christ's riches ([link]Phil. 4:4[/link]; [link]1 Thes. 5:16[/link]).

verse.text: And he saw a resting place that was good / And the [note]1[/note]land that was pleasant, / And he bowed his shoulder to bear, / And became a [note]2[/note]task-worker to [i]bring[/i] [note]3[/note]tribute.
verse.note: The land typifies Christ as the green pasture ([link]John 10:9[/link] and note 2) enjoyed by the believers in the church life.

A task-worker does work assigned by his master. This signifies the members of the Body of Christ, whose service in the Body is assigned by the Head ([link]1 Cor. 12:4-6[/link], [link]18[/link], [link]28[/link]; [link]Eph. 2:10[/link]; [link]4:11-12[/link]). Such service eventually becomes a tribute offered to the Master for His satisfaction (cf. [link]Rom. 15:16[/link]).

The second group of Jacob's sons portray the gospel, signified by Judah and fulfilled in the four Gospels; the preaching of the gospel, signified by Zebulun and fulfilled in Acts; and the church life, signified by Issachar and fulfilled in the remaining books of the New Testament. The consummation of Jacob's prophecy concerning Judah, Zebulun, and Issachar is seen in [link]Deut. 33:19[/link], which says that the peoples, the nations, will be called to the mountain, signifying the kingdom of God ([link]Dan. 2:35[/link]), where they will offer sacrifices of righteousness and enjoy the abundance of the seas (the church composed mainly of Gentile believers — see note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 13[/link]) and the hidden treasures of the sand (the kingdom hidden in the earth — [link]Matt. 13:44[/link]). This shows that the gospel, the preaching of the gospel, and the church life as the issue of the gospel result in the enjoyment of the church life and the kingdom life (cf. [link]Rom. 14:17[/link] and note 1).

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Dan will judge his people, / As one of the [note]1[/note]tribes of Israel.
verse.note: The Hebrew word also means scepters. This prophecy with blessing indicates that Jacob was concerned that Dan would be cut off because of his apostasy ([link]v. 17[/link]; [link]Deut. 13:5-18[/link]). Jacob's word here means that Dan not only would remain as a tribe but also would be a scepter, an authority. In [link]1 Chron. 2-9[/link] and in [link]Rev. 7[/link] Dan is omitted in the record of God's holy people (cf. [link]Rev. 3:5[/link]), but he will still be a tribe in the millennium because of his father's blessing ([link]Ezek. 48:1[/link]). See note [link]6[sup]1[/sup], par. 2, in Rev. 7[/link].

verse.text: Dan will be a [note]1[/note]serpent in the way, / A viper on the path, / That bites the horse's heels, / So that his rider falls backward.
verse.note: In [link]Deut. 33:22[/link] Dan is likened to a young lion leaping from Bashan. As a young lion, Dan fought in order to gain more land ([link]Josh. 19:47[/link]; [link]Judg. 18:27-29[/link]), the land signifying Christ (see note [link]7[sup]1[/sup] in Deut. 8[/link]). After his success in his victory Dan became a serpent, a viper, acting individualistically and independently in his pride to set up an idol and a divisive center of worship and to ordain a hired priest in the city of Dan during the time that the house of God was in Shiloh ([link]Judg. 18:30-31[/link]; cf. [link]Deut. 12:5[/link] and note). As a serpent Dan bit the horse's heels so that its rider fell backward, signifying that the apostasy brought in by Dan became a great stumbling block to the nation of Israel. Throughout the history of the church many spiritual people have followed Dan's example, thereby frustrating God's people from going on in His ordained way. A further fulfillment of Jacob's prophecy concerning Dan is seen in [link]1 Kings 12:26-31[/link] (see notes there).

verse.text: I have [xref]a[/xref]waited for Your [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]salvation, O Jehovah.
verse.note: Jacob anticipated a salvation from the stumbling block that eventually resulted from the apostasy of the tribe of Dan.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Gad, raiders will raid him, / But he will raid at [note]1[/note]their heel.
verse.note: Gad's victory in this verse, corresponding to his victory in [link]Deut. 33:20[/link], signifies the recovery of the victory of Christ lost by Dan because of his apostasy. According to [link]Deut. 33:20-21[/link], Gad was enlarged because of his victory; he provided the first part of the good land (the land east of the Jordan) for himself, but before enjoying his portion, he went with his brothers and fought with them to gain their portion of the land west of the Jordan ([link]Num. 32:1-32[/link]), thus executing Jehovah's righteousness and His judgments in Israel. Dan's failure was because he was individualistic and cared only for himself, whereas Gad's success was because he was corporate and took care of the need of his brothers. In New Testament terms, to follow Gad's example we need to have the corporate sense of the Body and care for the members of the Body for the accomplishing of God's will, which is to have the Body life ([link]Rom. 12:1-21[/link]).

verse.text: [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]Asher's food will be [note]2[/note]rich, / And he will yield royal dainties.
verse.note: Following some ancient versions; the Hebrew text reads, From Asher.

Lit., fat. Both Jacob's prophecy in this verse and Moses' blessing in [link]Deut. 33:24-25[/link] show the sufficiency of Asher, coming after the recovery with Gad ([link]v. 19[/link]). Asher was blessed with rich food, with the rich provision of life. His dipping his foot in oil ([link]Deut. 33:24[/link]) signifies the enjoyment of the bountiful supply of the Spirit for the daily walk ([link]Phil. 1:19[/link]; [link]Gal. 3:5[/link]). The issue of such a rich provision is the enjoyment of absolute rest with peace, strength, security, and sufficiency.

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Naphtali is a [note]1[/note]hind let loose; / He gives beautiful words.
verse.note: The hind typifies the resurrected Christ (see title of [link]Psa. 22[/link] and note). The beautiful words are uttered by Christ and by those who experience Christ in His resurrection ([link]Luke 4:22[/link]; [link]John 7:46[/link]; [link]Matt. 28:16[/link], [link]18-20[/link]; [link]Acts 2:32-36[/link]). According to [link]Deut. 33:23[/link], Naphtali is satisfied with favor (the Old Testament equivalent of New Testament grace) and is full of the blessing of Jehovah (referring to the spiritual blessings in the heavenlies — [link]Eph. 1:3[/link]). Furthermore, Naphtali will possess the sea (the Gentile world — see note [link]1[sup]1[/sup] in Matt. 13[/link]) and the south (the land of Israel), signifying that those who experience the resurrected Christ will possess the whole earth through their proclaiming of Christ ([link]Matt. 28:19[/link]; [link]Acts 1:8[/link]; [link]Rom. 15:19[/link]). See note [link]27[sup]4[/sup] in Psa. 68[/link].

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Joseph is a fruitful [note]1[/note]bough, / A fruitful bough by a fountain; / [i]His[/i] branches run over the wall.
verse.note: Joseph as a fruitful bough typifies Christ as the branch ([link]Isa. 11:1[/link]) for the branching out of God through His believers as His branches ([link]John 15:1[/link], [link]5[/link]). In this verse the fountain signifies God, the source of fruitfulness ([link]Psa. 36:9[/link]; [link]Jer. 2:13[/link]), and the branches' running over the wall signifies that Christ's believers as His branches spread Christ over every restriction, magnifying Him in all circumstances ([link]Phil. 1:20[/link]; [link]4:22[/link]; [link]Philem. 10[/link]).

chapter.verse: The archers bitterly attacked him, / And shot [i]at him[/i] and harassed him;

verse.text: But his bow remained firm, / And the arms of his hands were [note]1[/note]agile, / By the hands of the [xref]a[/xref]Mighty One of Jacob — / From there is the [xref]b[/xref]Shepherd, the [xref]c[/xref]stone of Israel —
verse.note: Or, strong. [link]Verses 23-24[/link] refer to Joseph's suffering at the hands of his brothers ([link]37:18-31[/link]). Joseph overcame in his sufferings (cf. [link]Rom. 8:36-37[/link]) because he was strengthened by God, the Mighty One of Jacob and the All-sufficient One, in whom he trusted (cf. [link]2 Tim. 2:1[/link]; [link]Phil. 4:13[/link]).

verse.text: From the [xref]a[/xref]God of your father, who will help you, / And from the [note]1[/note][xref]b[/xref]All-sufficient One, who will [note]2[/note]bless you / With [xref]c[/xref]blessings of heaven above, / Blessings of the deep that lies beneath, / Blessings of the breasts and of the womb.
verse.note: Heb. [i]Shaddai.[/i] See note [link]1[sup]2[/sup] in ch. 17[/link].

The blessings bestowed on Joseph, as seen in [link]vv. 25-26[/link] and [link]Deut. 33:13-16[/link], encompass all time, from ancient times to eternity ([link]v. 26[/link]; [link]Deut. 33:15[/link]), and all space, from heaven to earth, including the deep under the earth ([link]v. 25b[/link]; [link]Deut. 33:13-14[/link], [link]16a[/link]). Time plus space equals the universe. As the one universally blessed by his father, Joseph typifies Christ, the appointed Heir of all things ([link]Heb. 1:2[/link]; [link]Col. 1:16[/link]), and His believers, Christ's partners who participate in His inheritance ([link]1 Cor. 3:21-22[/link]; [link]Rom. 8:17[/link]; [link]Heb. 1:9[/link]; [link]3:14[/link]; [link]1:14[/link] and note). The universal blessing on Joseph will consummate in the new heaven and new earth, in which everything will be a blessing to Christ and His believers ([link]Rev. 21:1[/link], [link]4-5[/link]; [link]22:3[/link], [link]5[/link]).

verse.text: The blessings of your father surpass / The blessings of my ancestors / To the utmost bound of the [xref]a[/xref]everlasting hills. / They will be on the head of Joseph, / And on the crown of the [xref]b[/xref]head of the one who was [note]1[/note]separate from his brothers.
verse.note: Heb. [i]nazir;[/i] translated Nazarite in [link]Judg. 13:5[/link], [link]7[/link]; [link]16:17[/link]. Here Joseph typifies Christ as the Nazarite, the One who was separated from the common people to live wholly for God (see note [link]2[sup]2[/sup] in Num. 6[/link]). The universal blessing is bestowed on the crown of the head of such a Nazarite (cf. [link]Deut. 33:16b[/link]).

verse.text: [xref]a[/xref]Benjamin is a [note]1[/note]ravenous wolf, / In the morning devouring the prey / And in the evening dividing the [note]2[/note]spoil.
verse.note: Lit., tearing. As a tearing wolf, Benjamin is a type of Christ, who destroys the enemy by tearing him to pieces ([link]Eph. 4:8[/link]; [link]2 Cor. 10:5[/link]).

Moses' blessing in [link]Deut. 33:12[/link] says that Benjamin will dwell securely beside Jehovah and that Jehovah will dwell between Benjamin's shoulders. Jerusalem with God's temple, God's dwelling place, was located in the territory of Benjamin ([link]Judg. 1:21[/link]). Thus, the blessing of Jacob's twelve sons ends with God's dwelling place, which ultimately consummates in the New Jerusalem as the mutual dwelling of God and His redeemed for eternity ([link]Rev. 21-22[/link]). This is the greatest blessing to God's people.[br][br][link]Genesis 49:1-28[/link] is an abstract of the entire Bible and a summary of the history of God's people, as seen in the twelve sons of Jacob, the nation of Israel, and the church. It is also a portrait of the personal history of every believer. Jacob's first four sons — Reuben, Simeon, Levi, and Judah — were sinners, indicating that the history of God's people begins with sinners. However, two of these sinners, Levi and Judah, were transformed to become priests and kings. Out of the kingship with Judah a kingly salvation was produced, which was preached as the gospel in the Gentile world by Zebulun and which issued in the church life with Issachar. But the apostasy came in through Dan, followed by the recovery with Gad, which issued in the sufficiency of the riches of Christ with Asher and in the resurrection with Naphtali. Finally, the history of God's people concludes with Joseph and Benjamin, who typify Christ as the One who is altogether victorious and perfect, without defect. According to Jacob's prophecy and Moses' word, Joseph brought in God's boundless, universal blessing ([link]vv. 22-26[/link]; [link]Deut. 33:13-16[/link]), and Benjamin, God's eternal dwelling place ([link]Deut. 33:12[/link]). Thus, the conclusion of [link]Gen. 49[/link] corresponds with the conclusion of the entire Bible — the universal blessing in the new heaven and the new earth, in which is God's eternal dwelling, the New Jerusalem, as the issue and goal of God's universal blessing (cf. [link]Eph. 1:3[/link]; [link]2:22[/link]).

chapter.verse: All these are the twelve tribes of Israel, and this is what their father spoke to them when he blessed them; he blessed them, each one according to his blessing.

verse.text: And he charged them and said to them, I am being gathered to my people. [note]1[/note]Bury me with [xref]a[/xref]my fathers in the cave that is in the field of Ephron the Hittite,
verse.note: See note [link]30[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 47[/link].

verse.text: In the cave that is in the field of [xref]a[/xref]Machpelah, which is before Mamre in the land of Canaan, which Abraham bought along with the field from Ephron the Hittite for the possession of a burial place —
There they [xref]a[/xref]buried Abraham and Sarah his wife, there they [xref]b[/xref]buried Isaac and Rebekah his wife, and there I buried Leah —

chapter.verse: The field and the cave that is in it, purchased from the children of Heth.

verse.text: And when Jacob had finished charging his sons, he gathered up his feet into the bed and [xref]a[/xref]expired, and he was gathered to his people.
Then [xref]a[/xref]Joseph fell upon his father's face and wept over him and kissed him.

chapter.verse: And Joseph commanded his servants the physicians to embalm his father. So the physicians embalmed Israel.

verse.text: And forty days were spent for this, for this is the time to be spent for embalming. And the Egyptians [xref]a[/xref]wept for him seventy days.

chapter.verse: And when the days of weeping for him had passed, Joseph spoke to the house of Pharaoh, saying, If I have found favor in your eyes, please speak in the hearing of Pharaoh, saying,

verse.text: My father made me swear, saying, Now I am about to die; in my [xref]a[/xref]grave which I dug for myself in the land of Canaan, there shall you bury me. Now therefore please let me go up and bury my father; then I will return.

chapter.verse: And Pharaoh said, Go up, and bury your father, as he made you swear.
And Joseph went up to bury his father; and all the servants of Pharaoh went up with him, the elders of his house and all the elders of the land of Egypt,
And all the house of Joseph and his brothers and his father's household; they left only their little ones and their flocks and their herds in the land of Goshen.
And chariots also went up with him, as well as horsemen; and it was a very great company.

verse.text: And they came to the threshing floor of Atad, which is beyond the Jordan, and they lamented there with a very great and grievous lamentation; and he observed seven days of [xref]a[/xref]mourning for his father.

And when the inhabitants of the land, the Canaanites, saw the mourning at the threshing floor of Atad, they said, This is a grievous mourning for the Egyptians. Therefore the name of it was called [note]1[/note]Abel-mizraim, which is beyond the Jordan.
verse.note: Meaning [i]mourning of the Egyptians.[/i]

chapter.verse: And thus his sons did to him as he commanded them;

verse.text: For his sons carried him into the land of Canaan and buried him in the cave of the field of [xref]a[/xref]Machpelah before Mamre, which Abraham had [xref]b[/xref]bought with the field for a possession of a burial place from Ephron the Hittite.

chapter.verse: And after he had buried his father, Joseph returned into Egypt, he and his brothers and all who went up with him to bury his father.
And when Joseph's brothers saw that their father was dead, they said, What if Joseph bears a grudge against us and pays us back in full for all the evil which we did to him?
And they sent a message to Joseph, saying, Your father charged before he died, saying,

verse.text: Thus shall you say to Joseph, Please forgive the transgression of your brothers and their sin, for they did you wrong. So now please forgive the transgression of the servants of the [xref]a[/xref]God of your father. And Joseph wept when they spoke to him.
And his brothers also went and [xref]a[/xref]fell down before him and said, We are here as your servants.
And Joseph said to them, [note]1[/note]Do not be afraid, for [xref]a[/xref]am I in the place of God?
verse.note: See note [link]5[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 45[/link].

verse.text: Even though you intended evil against me, God intended it for good, to do as it is this day, to [xref]a[/xref]preserve alive a numerous people.
Now therefore do not be afraid; I will [xref]a[/xref]sustain you and your little ones. And he comforted them and spoke [note]1[/note]kindly to them.
verse.note: Lit., to their heart.

chapter.verse: And Joseph dwelt in Egypt, he and his father's household; and Joseph lived one hundred ten years.

verse.text: And Joseph saw Ephraim's [xref]a[/xref]children of the third generation; the children of [xref]b[/xref]Machir the son of Manasseh were also born on Joseph's knees.

And [xref]a[/xref]Joseph said to his brothers, I am about to die, but God will surely visit you and bring you up out of this land to the [xref]b[/xref]land which He swore to Abraham, to Isaac, and to Jacob.
And Joseph made the children of Israel swear, saying, God will surely visit you, and you shall [note]1[/note]bring my [xref]a[/xref]bones up from here.
verse.note: Cf. [link]Exo. 13:19[/link]. Like Jacob, Joseph died in faith, expecting that he would be resurrected to inherit the good land and participate in all the enjoyment therein. See note [link book="Gen."]30[sup]1[/sup] in ch. 47[/link].

verse.text: And Joseph [note]1[/note][xref]a[/xref]died, being one hundred ten years old; and they [xref]b[/xref]embalmed him, and he was put in a coffin in Egypt.
verse.note: In the beginning of this book God created man in His image that man might express Him and gave man His dominion that man might represent Him ([link]1:26[/link]). After the experiences of so many called ones, this book concludes with a life that, in Jacob on the one hand, expressed God in His image and, in Joseph on the other hand, represented God with His dominion (see note [link]1[sup]1[/sup], par. 2, in ch. 37[/link]). How excellent and wonderful this is! However, what is portrayed in Genesis is still a shadow in the age of typology. At Joseph's time the reality had not come. Hence, in the conclusion of this book Joseph died expecting the age of fulfillment, in which he would share in the reality.
